name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the statement by the President of the Commission on the state of the Union (2018/2736(RSP)).

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. Mr President, Madam President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, sometimes history moves with discretion and steps and takes leave quickly. This is the case when it comes to the action of a Commission, which has only a five-year mandate to make a permanent change. But in such a short period of time, you can't change things for good. The current Commission, like its predecessors, is an episode, a brief moment in the long history of the European Union. The time for the final review of the Commission that I chair has not yet come, so I will not give you a review today of what we have been able to do over the past four years. On the contrary, I am telling you that work continues for the coming months, to make the European Union imperfect, a more perfect European Union every day. There are still things to do, and that is what I would like to talk to you about this morning. No complacency, no bulging torso, modesty and hard work, this is the attitude that the Commission will make its own, this is our agenda for the coming months. Sometimes history, history in the true sense of the word, invites itself into the life of nations without notice, and is slow to leave it. This was the case at the time of the Great War, which in 1914 took the continent by surprise, so was sunny, calm, peaceful, optimistic the year 1913. In 1913, Europeans expected to live in peace for a long time, yet a fratricidal war swept across Europe the following year. I am referring to this period, not that I believe that we are on the threshold of another catastrophe in Europe. The European Union is a guarantor of peace. Let us be happy to live on a continent of peace, a continent that knows peace thanks to the European Union. (Applause) So let us respect the European Union better, let us not sully its image, defend our way of being and our way of life, say yes to patriotism which is not directed against others, say no to the overrated nationalism that rejects and hates others, that destroys, that seeks culprits instead of looking for solutions that allow us to live better together. (Applause) The founding pact of the European Union, 'never again war', remains a burning demand, a burning obligation of vigilance that is required in and around us. Ladies and gentlemen, what is the state of the European Union today, in 2018? Ten years after Lehman Brothers, Europe has largely turned the page on the economic and financial crisis, which came to us from elsewhere and which hit us in a very often brutal way. The European Union has experienced uninterrupted growth over the past 21 quarters. Employment is picking up steam, with nearly 12 million jobs created since 2014. Twelve million jobs is more than the population of Belgium. Never before have so many people - 239 million men and women - been to work in Europe. Youth unemployment stands at 14.8%: this figure remains too high but is at its lowest level since 2000. Investment is back in Europe, thanks in part to our European Fund for Strategic Investments, which some, increasingly rare, continue to call the Juncker Plan, a plan that has generated 335 billion euros in public and private investment, and we are on our way to 400 billion. And then there's Greece. After years, it must be said, painful, after unprecedented serious social problems, Greece has managed to carry out its programme and get back on its feet. I welcome, once again, the Herculean efforts of the Greek people, efforts which other Europeans continue to underestimate. (Applause) I have always defended - and you know - Greece, its dignity, its role in Europe, and in particular its continued existence in the euro area. I'm still proud of it. Europe has also reaffirmed its status as a trading power. Our global trading power is nothing more than proof of the need to share our sovereignty. The European Union now has trade agreements with 70 countries. Together, we account for 40% of global GDP. These agreements, I am talking about trade agreements, very often, and often wrongly, disputed, help us to export high European standards of food safety, workers' rights, environmental issues and consumer rights to other parts of the world. When, last July, during a long and dangerous period of international tension, I visited Beijing, Tokyo and Washington the same week, I was able to speak, as President of the Commission, on behalf of the largest single market in the world, on behalf of a Union that accounts for one-fifth of economy, on behalf of a Union ready to defend its values and defend its interests. I represented Europe as an open continent, but not as a continent offered. With the European unity that I have been able to set out in principle and in detail, I have been able to make the voice of the European Union heard in order to achieve concrete results for our citizens and for our businesses. United, we Europeans have, as a Union, become an unavoidable force. In Washington, I spoke on behalf of Europe. Some describe the agreement, the arrangement I was able to get after my negotiations with President Trump, as a surprise. However, there was no surprise because every time Europe speaks with one voice, there is no surprise. If she wants and if she speaks with one voice, she can impose herself on others. Europe, where necessary, must act as one man. We proved this when we have consistently defended the Paris climate agreement, because we Europeans want to leave a cleaner planet for the next generations. I share our Energy Commissioner's analysis of the 2030 CO2 reduction targets. They are scientifically accurate and politically necessary. This summer's droughts were a stark reminder, not just to farmers, of the importance of our efforts to ensure the safeguarding and future of future generations. (Applause) Of course, we may not want to see the climate challenge and look elsewhere. We, the Commission, and you, Parliament, must look to the future. Ladies and gentlemen, the world, which keeps turning, has become more volatile than ever. The external challenges facing our continent are multiplying day by day. We cannot, therefore, relax, even for a second, our efforts to build a more united and stronger Europe. Europe can export its stability, as we have done with the successive enlargements of our Union. Enlargements which, for me, are and remain successes, because we have managed to reconcile European geography and history. But more work needs to be done. (Applause) We must irrevocably define our attitude towards the countries of the Western Balkans with regard to their accession. Otherwise, others will shape our immediate neighbourhood. (Applause) Let's look around. What is happening, at this time, in Syria, in Idlib, must be a cause of deep and immediate concern for all of us. We cannot remain silent in the face of the impending humanitarian disaster which, in fact, is an announced disaster. The Syrian conflict illustrates how the international order, which Europeans have benefited from since the Second World War, is increasingly being called into question. For the rest, in today's world, Europe can no longer be assured that the commitments that were made yesterday will still be kept tomorrow. Yesterday's alliances may no longer be the alliances of tomorrow. I said, today's world needs a strong and united Europe, a Europe that works for peace, trade agreements and stable monetary relations, even if others elsewhere are too inclined to choose trade wars or even money. In fact, I do not like this unilateralism disrespectful of the expectations and hopes of others. I will always remain a convinced multilateralist. (Applause) If Europe were to become more aware of its political power, the economic and sometimes military power of its nations, we could abandon the exclusive role of global payer, something that we want to stay in any case. We need to become more of a global player. Yes, we are global payers, but we have to be global players, too. That is why, despite strong resistance at the time, I relaunched the European Defence Union in 2014. That is why, in the coming months, the Commission will continue to work to ensure that the European Defence Fund and structured permanent defence cooperation become fully operational. (Applause) This is an important point for me in this place: we will not militarise the European Union. What we want is to become more responsible and independent, because only a strong and united Europe can protect our citizens from internal and external threats, from terrorism to climate change. Only a strong and united Europe can preserve jobs in an open and interconnected world. Only a strong and united Europe can master the challenges of global digitisation. We Europeans, because we are the largest single market in the world, can establish standards for big data for artificial intelligence, for automation, while defending our values, the rights and individuality of our citizens. We can do that if we are united. A strong and united Europe allows its Member States to win the stars. It is thanks to our Galileo programme that Europe remains in the race for space. No Member State, none, could have put into orbit 26 satellites that already benefit 400 million users worldwide. No Member State would have succeeded alone. Galileo, yes, is a success. A european success first, if not exclusively. Without Europe, no Galileo. Let's be proud of it. (Applause) Mr President, geopolitics tells us that the time for European sovereignty has finally come. It is time for Europe to take its destiny into its own hands. The time for Europe to develop what I have called its Weltpolitikf-higkeit. This ability to play our part in gaining influence in the course of world affairs. Europe must become more of a sovereign player in international relations. European sovereignty comes from the national sovereignty of our Member States. It does not replace what is unique to nations. Sharing our sovereignty where it is necessary makes each of our states and nations stronger. This conviction that we are greater is the essence of what it means to be part of the European Union. European sovereignty will never be directed against others. Europe must remain a continent of openness and tolerance, and it will remain so. Europe will never be a fortress turning its back on the world, especially the world that is suffering. Europe will never be an island, Europe must and will remain multilateral because the planet belongs to all and not just a few. (Applause) This is also the focus of the elections to the European Parliament, which will take place in May 2019. We will use the 250 days between us and the European elections to prove to our citizens that when we act together, the European Union can achieve results and that it respects the commitments we made at the beginning of this mandate. Between now and the European elections, we must demonstrate that Europe can overcome the differences between North and South, East and West. The European Union, Europe, is too small to divide one day in two, the next day in four. We must demonstrate that together, East, West, South and North, we can sow the seeds of a more sovereign Europe. Herr President, meine sehr geehrten Damen und Herren! Wenn wir im Mai 2019 zur Wahl schreiten, wird es die Bàrger Europas nicht interessieren, was die Kommission vorgeschlagen hat. Aber es wird sie in hohem Mae interessieren, dass die Internetgiganten dort Steuern zahlen, wo sie ihre Gewinne erwirtschaften.  (Beifall) Die Wàhler wollen - viele von Ihnen auch, nicht alle, wie ich wei, dass der diesbez-gliche Vorschlag der Kommission rasch zum Gesetz wird. Die, die das wollen, haben absolut recht. (Beifall) Wenn die Europeer 2019 wàhlen, wird sie weniger der gute Wille der Kommission begeistern, gegen Einwegplastik vorzugehen, um unsere Meere zu schotzen. Wenn wir die Europeer von uns selbst und von der Richtigkeit unseres Tuns erzeugen wollen, dann brauchen wir ein europeisches Gesetz, das das Plastikverbot zementiert. (Beifall) Wir alle erklàren, meistens in Sonntagsreden, dass wir in groen Fragen ehrgeiziger und in kleinen Fragen bescheidener sein sollten. Doch die Europeer werden im Mai 2019 nicht applaudieren, wenn wir weiterhin zweimal im Jahr aufgrund europeischer Regulierungen die Zeit umstellen messen. Die Zeitumstellung abgeschafft! (Beifall) Die Mitgliedstaaten - dies ist ein Gebot der Subsidiaritet - sollten selbst entscheiden, ob ihre Bàrger in der Sommer- oder in der Winterzeit leben sollen. Ich erwarte, dass Parlament und Rat dies ebenso sehen und dafar sorgen werden, dass regionale, binnenmarktkonforme Lsungen gefunden werden. Die Zeit drungt!  'berhaupt rufe ich uns alle dazu auf, in den kommenden Monaten eng zusammenzuarbeiten, damit wir das, was wir 2014 versprochen hatten, rechtzeitig vor der Europawahl einl-sen kunnen. Als wir angetreten sind, haben wir alle gemeinsam versprochen, einen innovativen digitalen Binnenmarkt, eine vertiefte Wirtschafts- und Wàhrungsunion, eine Bankenunion, eine Kapitalmarktunion, einen fairen Binnenmarkt, eine Energieunion mit einer zukunftsorientieren Klimapolitik, eine umfassende Migrations Und wir haben uns - jedenfalls die meisten von uns - vorgenommen, die soziale Dimension Europas nicht weiter stiefm-tterlich zu behandeln, sondern in Richtung Zukunft aufzustellen. Die Kommission hat alle Vorschlàge und Initiativen, die wir 2014 angek-ndigt haben, auf den Tisch gelegt. Die Hulfte davon wurde schon von Rat und Parlament verabschiedet. Zwanzig Prozent sind auf einem guten Weg, und drei-ig Prozent stecken in teilweise schwierigen Beratungen.  Meine Damen und Herren, ich akzeptiere nicht, dass die Kommission fer alle Versumnisse, die es selbstverst-ndlich gab, allein haftbar gemacht wird. Unsere Vorschlege sind bekannt, vor allem in Sachen Flichtlinge und Migration. Sie sollten angenommen und umgesetzt werden. Ich werde auch in Zukunft nicht zulassen, aber ich wei, es wird so kommen, dass die Kommission zum alleinigen Sàndenbock gemacht wird. Sündenböcke sitzen in allen Institutionen, die wenigsten davon in der Kommission und im Parlament. (Beifall) Fuhrung auf breitester Front bleibt angesagt. Dies trifft auch in puncto Vollendung unserer Sicherheitsunion zu. Die Europeer erwarten zu Recht, dass die European Union sie besch-tzt und schotzt. Deshalb schl-gt die Kommission heute neue Regeln vor, um terroristische Propaganda binnen einer Stunde aus dem Internet zu entfernen. Eine Stunde ist nemlich das entscheidende Zeitfenster, wàhrend dessen 'ffnung greter Schaden entstehen kann.  Zudem schlagen wir vor, die Aufgaben der neu geschaffenen Europ-ischen Staatsanwaltschaft auf die Bek-mpfung terroristischer Taten auszuweiten.  Wir messen Terroristen unionsweit und grenz-berschreitend verfolgen kunnen. Terroristen kennen keine Grenzen. Wir sollten uns nicht durch Nichtzusammenarbeit zu ihren Komplizen machen. Aus diesem Grund schlagen wir heute auch neue Maenahmen vor, um effektiv und grenz-berschreitend gegen Geldw-sche vorgehen zu kunnen. Genauso entschlossen messen wir vorgehen, um freie und make Wahlen in Europa sicherzustellen. Deshalb schl-gt die Kommission neue Regeln vor, um unsere demokratischen Prozesse gegen Manipulation durch Drittstaaten und auch - ja, das gibt es - gegen massiv geb-ndelte Privatinteressen abzusichern. (Beifall) Fuhrung und Kompromisswillen sind naturlich ganz besonders in Migrationsfragen dringend geboten. Wir haben yesterday mehr Fortschritte gemacht, als oft behauptet wird. Funf von sieben Kommissionsvorschlungen zur Neugestaltung unseres gemeinsamen europeischen Asylsystems wurden angenommen. Unsere Anstrengungen haben Erfolg gezeigt. Es gibt 97% weniger Flàchtlinge im 'stlichen Mittelmeerraum und um 80% weniger Flàchtlinge entlang der zentralen Mittelmeerroute. EU-Einsetze trugen seit 2015 zur Rettung von mehr als 690,000 Menschen auf hoher See bei. Allerdings haben die Mitgliedstaaten noch nicht das richtige Verh-ltnis zwischen Verantwortung eines jeden Landes fàr sein eigenes Hoheitsgebiet und der netigen Solidaritet untereinander gefunden. Diese Solidaritet messen die Mitgliedstaaten aber an den Tag legen, wenn sie den Schengen-Raum ohne Binnengrenzen erhalten wollen. (Beifall) Ich bin und bleibe gegen Binnengrenzen. Sie messen sleeps, wo es sie inzwischen wieder gibt, abgeschafft werden. Blieben sie erhalten, wre dies ein nicht akzeptabler R-ckschritt europeischen Seins und Werdens. (Beifall) Die Kommission und mehrere Ratspresidentschaften haben zahlreiche Vorschlàge zur Migration vorgelegt. Ich fordere die 'sterreichische Ratspresidentschaft auf - und sie wird es auch tun ', jetzt entscheidende Schritte einzuleiten, um zukunftsf-hige Lsungen fer eine ausgewogene Migrationsreform zu erarbeiten. Wir konnen nicht bei der Ankunft jedes neuen Schiffes weiter 'ber Ad-hoc-L'sungen fer die Menschen an Bord streiten. (Beifall) Ad-hoc-Lungen reichen nicht aus. Wir brauchen vielmehr mehr Gegenwarts- und Zukunftssolidaritit. Solidarity muss von Dauer sein, und sie muss auch organisiert werden. Wir brauchen auch mehr Solidaritet, weil wir mehr Effizienz brauchen. Dies trifft auch zu, wenn es darum geht, einen verst-rkten europeischen Katastrophenschutz in die Wege zu leiten. Wenn es in einem Land brennt, dann brennt es 'berall in Europa. Zu den eindrucksvollen Bildern des Sommers geh-ren nicht nur die Brende, sondern auch der Applaus, den vom Feuer bedrohte Schweden den solidarisch helfenden polnischen Feuerwehrleuten gespendet haben. Europe at its best! (Beifall) Zur-ck zur Migration. Wir legen heute einen Vorschlag zur St-rkung of the European Grenz- und Kostenschutzes vor. Au-engrenzen messen effizienter gesch-tzt werden. Deshalb schlagen wir vor, die Zahl europeischer Grenzschutzbeamter, die aus dem europeischen Haushalt finanziert werden, bis zum Jahr 2020 auf 10,000 Grenzsch-tzer zu erh-hen. Wir legen zudem einen Vorschlag zum Ausbau der Asylagentur der European Union vor. Mitgliedstaaten brauchen st-rkere europeische Unterst-tzung bei der Bearbeitung von Asylantr-gen - eine Bearbeitung, die im Einklang mit der Genfer Konvention zu stehen hat. Und wir legen einen Vorschlag vor, um die R-c-ckf-hrung irregul-r eingereister Migranten zu beschleunigen. Ich wiederhole hier im Parlament meinen Wunsch, der einer Aufforderung gleichkommt, legale Einwanderungswege in die European Union zu 'ffnen. (Beifall) Wir Brauchen qualifierzierte Migranten. Auch hierzu liegen die Kommissionsvorschlàge seit Langem auf dem Tisch - bitte umsetzen!  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to talk to you about the future, and therefore about our cousin continent of Africa. By 2050, Africa will have 2.5 billion people. One in four people will be African. We must invest more in our relations with this great and noble continent and its individual nations. And we must stop looking at this African-European relationship from the perspective of a development aid provider alone. Such an approach would be insufficient and, in fact, humiliating for Africa. (Applause) Africa does not need charity. It needs a balanced partnership, a real partnership. And we Europeans need this partnership, as well. In preparing this speech, I spoke with my African friends, including President Kagame, President of the African Union. We agreed that in the future, our respective commitments must be reciprocal. We want to build a new partnership with Africa. (Applause) The Commission is today proposing a new alliance between Africa and Europe, an alliance for investment and sustainable jobs. This alliance, as we envision it, would create up to 10 million jobs in Africa over the next five years. We want to create a framework to attract more private investment to Africa. In fact, we are not starting from scratch: our external investment fund, launched here two years ago, will mobilise more than 44 billion euros of investment in the public and private sectors in Africa. The planned projects and the projects undertaken will mobilize 24 billion euros. We will focus our investments in areas where investments make a real difference. By 2020, the European Union will have supported 35,000 African students and researchers through our re-muscled Erasmus programme. By 2027, this figure is expected to increase to 105,000. Trade between Europe and Africa is not unimportant. 36% of Africa's trade is already with the European Union. But trade between us is not enough. I am convinced that we should move the many trade agreements between African countries and the European Union towards a continent-to-continent free trade agreement, an economic partnership between equal partners. Another issue where I see a strong need for the Union for leadership is Brexit. I will not enter into the details of the negotiations, which are being masterfully handled by my friend Michel Barnier. He works on the basis of a unanimous position confirmed time and again by the 27 Member States. However, allow me to recall three principles which should guide our work on Brexit in the months to come. First of all, we respect, of course, the British decision to leave our Union, yes, but we regret it deeply that you are. But we also ask the British Government to understand that someone who leaves the Union cannot be in the same privileged position as a Member State. If you leave the Union, you are of course no longer part of our single market, and certainly not only in parts of it. (Applause) Secondly, the Commission, this Parliament and all other Member States will always show loyalty and solidarity with Ireland when it comes to the Irish border. This is why we want to find a creative solution that prevents a hard border in Northern Ireland.  (Applause) And we will defend all the elements of the Good Friday Agreement. It is Brexit that is making the border more visible in Northern Ireland. It is not the European Union. Thirdly, after 29 March 2019, the United Kingdom will never be an ordinary third country for us. The United Kingdom will always be a very close neighbour and partner, in political, economic and security terms.  In the past months, when we needed unity in the Union, Britain was at our side, driven by the same values and principles as all other Europeans. This is why I welcome Prime Minister May's proposal to develop an ambitious new partnership for the future, after Brexit. We agree with the statement made at Chequers that the starting point for such a partnership should be a free trade area between the United Kingdom and the European Union.  On the basis of these principles, the Commission's negotiators, mainly my good friend Michel Barnier, stand ready to work day and night to reach a deal. We owe it to our citizens and our businesses to ensure the United Kingdom's withdrawal is orderly and that there is stability afterwards. It will not be the Commission that will stand in the way of this. Ladies and gentlemen, between now and the European elections and the summit on 9 May of the year Romania, much work remains to be done. In Sibiu, we will have to convince our fellow citizens that, on the essentials, we share the same conception of the purpose of our Union. People do not like uncertainty or diffuse purposes. They like clear indications. They hate the near-to-the-near and half-measures. So let us not offer half measures to European citizens. All this is the European agenda on the road to Sibiu. Between now and Sibiu, we must ratify the partnership agreement between the European Union and Japan, for economic but also geopolitical reasons. Between now and the Sibiu summit, we have a duty to negotiate an agreement in principle on the European Union budget after 2020. If we want to give young Europeans the chance to make the most of the opportunities offered by the Erasmus programme, which deserves more funding, we will have to decide on this envelope, this envelope as well as other envelopes. If we want to give more opportunities to our researchers, to our start-ups to avoid a lack of resources leading to a drastic reduction in the number of research positions, we will have to make a decision on the budget before the European elections. If we want, without militarising ourselves, to increase defence spending by 20, we must decide before the European elections. If we want to spend 23% more investment on Africa, we will have to decide quickly. I am always told - heads of state, ministers, European and national parliamentarians - that we cannot decide before the elections. As if the elections were a crisis of democracy. No! It is normal in a democracy to have elections, and it is normal, urgent, to decide before the elections to show the way to those who are supposed to elect us. (Applause) By next year, we will also have to further develop the international role of the euro. After only 20 years of existence, and despite the declining voices that have accompanied us on this journey, the euro already has a rich track record behind it. The euro has become the world's second largest currency after the dollar. Sixty countries link their own currency to the euro in one way or another. But we must do more to enable our single currency to play its full role on the international stage.  Recent events have highlighted the need to deepen our economic and monetary union and to build deep, liquid capital markets. Many of the Commission's proposals in this area are just waiting to be adopted. We must and we can go further. It is aberrant that Europe pays 80% of its energy import bill, which amounts to 300 billion euros per year, in U.S. dollars, while only 2% of our energy imports come from the United States. It is absurd, ridiculous, that European airlines buy European planes in dollars and not in euros. We have to change all that. (Applause) That is why the Commission will present initiatives before the end of the year to strengthen the international role of the euro. The euro must become the active instrument of the new European sovereignty. And for that, the first thing to do is to put our house in order, strengthening and deepening the economic and monetary union, as we have begun to do. Without a thorough economic and monetary union, we will lack credible arguments to strengthen the international role of the euro. We must complete the economic and monetary union so that Europe and the euro can become stronger. And still on the way to Sibiu (Hermannstadt), I would like us to make tangible progress in strengthening our foreign policy. We need to strengthen our ability to speak with one voice on foreign policy. It is not normal for Europe to silence itself when, at the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva, we cannot speak out to condemn human rights violations in China because a Member State has opposed it. I am quoting this example, but I could cite others. (Applause) That is why, today, the Commission is once again proposing to you to vote by qualified majority in specific areas of our external relations. I repeat the message. (Applause) I repeat the message I explained, detailed, last year. We will make proposals so that we can proceed, in certain areas, not in all areas, on qualified majority foreign policy. The Treaty, as it is, allows the European Council to take a decision in this direction. I believe that the time has come to bring to life the bridge clause of the Lisbon Treaty, which paves the way for qualified majority decision-making, which is the 'forgotten beauty' of the Treaty. (Applause) I think, moreover, since we are there, that for certain matters of taxation, we should also be able to decide by qualified majority. (Applause) A word, Mr President, to say that I am becoming more and more concerned about the way we discuss our disagreements. Controversial exchanges between governments, sometimes between institutions, are increasing. But it is not polemical and often hurtful comments that allow the European construction to move forward. What worries me is not just an unfortunate tone when the political forces are talking to each other. This is also true of the way some people deal, because they want to put an end to all debate, the media and journalists. Europe must remain a place where freedom of the press is not called into question. Too many journalists are intimidated, attacked and murdered. (Applause) There is no democracy without a free press. (Applause) Thank you for applauding, so that I can drink. (Laughter) In general, ladies and gentlemen, we must rediscover the virtues of compromise. Seeking compromise is not a weakness, does not imply the sacrifice of our convictions and does not prevent the free debate that respects the point of view of each other. The Commission opposes all violations of the rule of law. We remain concerned about the evolution of debates in some of our Member States. Section 7 must apply where the rule of law is in danger. (Applause) In this regard, First Vice-President Timmermans is doing a remarkable, but very often, too often, solitary job in defending the rule of law. It has my strong personal support and that of the whole Commission. (Applause) And then there is one point on which we must not and cannot deviate: the judgments of the European Court of Justice must be respected and executed. (Applause) The European Union is a community of law. Respect for the rule of law and respect for court decisions are not an option, but an obligation. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, and for many of you, dear friends, by introducing, not my last speech, but my last speech on the State of the European Union, I have told you about the history, the small story, which covers the mandate of this Commission and the great history, which is that of Europe. We are all responsible for Europe as it is, and we will all be responsible, both of us, for the Europe that will be. History is thus made: Parliaments and Commissions pass, Europe remains. In order for the European Union to become what it must be, we must have several elements in mind. I would like Europe to leave the stands of the world stage. Europe must not be a spectator, a commentator of international events. She must be a constructive actor, a shaper, an architect of the world of tomorrow. There is a strong demand from Europe around the world. To meet this pressing demand, Europe will have to speak with one voice on the international stage. In the concert of nations, the voice of Europe must be intelligible, understandable, distinguishable in order to be listened to and heard. Federica Mogherini has advanced the diplomatic coherence of the European Union in a way that has never been done before. But let us never fall back on the inconsistency of competing and parallel national diplomacy. European diplomacy must be one, and our multilateral solidarity must be complete. (Applause) I would like us to make greater efforts to bring eastern and western Europe closer together; let us put an end to this sad spectacle of the intra-European division. Our continent and those who ended the Cold War deserve better. I would like the European Union to take more care of its social dimension. Those who ignore the justified expectations of workers and small businesses pose a great risk to the cohesion of our societies. Let us turn the intentions of the Gothenburg Summit into a rule of law. (Applause) I would like next year's elections to be a great moment for European democracy. I hope that the experience of the Spitzenkandidaten (head of the list) - this small step forward in European democracy - will be renewed. For me, this experience will be all the more credible the day when we have real lists Transnational. I think it will have to be done in 2024. (Applause) Above all, I would like us to say no to unhealthy nationalism, and say yes to enlightened patriotism. Let us keep in mind that the patriotism of the 21st century is two-dimensional, one national, the other European, the two not excluded. I like, said the French philosopher Blaise Pascal, the things that go together. To stand on both legs, nations and the European Union must walk together. Whoever loves Europe must love the nations that make it up. He who loves his homeland must love and love Europe. Patriotism is a virtue, narrow-minded nationalism is a damning lie and a pernicious poison. (Applause) In a nutshell, let's stay true to who we are. Let us plant today the trees in the shade from which our great-grandchildren, wherever they come from, from the north, south, west or east, can grow and breathe in peace. A few years ago, I told you here that Europe was the big deal of my life. Yes, I love Europe and I will continue to do so. Thank you for listening. (The Assembly, standing, applauds the speaker)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Mr President, dear Jean-Claude, in your speech you have given a lot of ideas, you have tried to give a perspective. The following debate will serve to strengthen certain positions. I believe that Parliament will be able, at the end of this parliamentary term, to make its contribution to speeding up the adoption of rules that are still under discussion. Parliament, as you said, cannot and does not want to be a scapegoat, the scapegoats may be from other quarters. Parliament wants to be at the heart of democracy more and more, which is why I would ask you to start thinking, for example, about the need to give Parliament the power of legislative initiative. We are the only Parliament in the world that has no power of legislative initiative.  (Applause) You rightly pointed out – it was met with applause – your reference to the need for majority voting. When we talk about immigration, the Commission's and Parliament's proposal on the Dublin reform can be approved by a majority, but there is always resistance on the part of the Council. If that reform had been approved, there would not have been the Diciotti case in Italy. So you can and should, in my opinion, accelerate. Parliament, having applauded by an overwhelming majority the proposal to proceed by majority vote, means that it supports this action. All the proposals on immigration and Africa are also of great interest and go in the direction called for by Parliament. We have asked for a fund for Africa. Europe has woken up very late on the immigration issue. If you had heard the cry from some countries and from some Members a few years earlier, perhaps we would not be at this point. Of course, Africa needs investment, important investments. I agree that it is not necessary – and Parliament has always said this in a very clear way – to only give gifts. We need a policy of growth, sharing and economic diplomacy. But we need to take a quick decision and Parliament will not fail to make its contribution. As on Brexit, Mr President, Parliament wants to be a leading player. The final vote will be that of Parliament and our representatives are first and foremost working, as they have written in our resolutions, to protect the rights of three and a half million European citizens living in the United Kingdom. We should also do more on work and on economic and monetary union, because unemployment, especially youth unemployment, must be the main social issue that we must tackle. Therefore, Mr President, the European Parliament has been working hard over the last few months trying to give concrete answers to the citizens. My aim as President is to ensure that this institution is ever closer to our European citizens.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Europe is much more robust than it was four years ago. You overcame tough times. I think everybody can underline this, but without you, Jean—Claude, without your leadership, it would have been impossible to manage the last few years. With your cool head, your determination and your sincere heart for Europe, you defended the unity of this continent. I want to thank you for this and I also want to thank you for the details of your love affair, which you shared with us in your final remarks. Thank you, Jean-Claude Juncker. (Applause)  But there is still a lot to do and that is the main message of today’s State of the Union speech. We are still in a working session. We have to deliver and, from today’s announcements from Jean-Claude Juncker and the Commission, we can sum up that all the proposals that the Commission promised at the beginning of their mandate are now on Parliament’s and the Commission’s table. I would also add that these were not only the Commission’s proposals in the beginning, but were the promises of the PPE candidate, Jean—Claude Juncker, in his election campaign, to give a clear link between what you promised in the campaign last year and what you delivered under your leadership in the Commission. Also, on the implementing front, we have to be aware that we delivered a lot: you already mentioned some of the figures which are on the table on the economy, a stable growth rate, all the eurozone countries below 3%, we have created millions of new jobs – our companies did so, Mario Draghi has now given a clear signal that he will stop the low interest rate policy by the end of this year. So, having this in mind, it is a big success story. We have Brexit. I can remember, Jean—Claude, when we in your office after we got the messages from London about the outcome of the referendum and we were disappointed. We were looking for answers and we were a little scared about whether others could or would follow. Today, Europe is united and ready for a deal, but London cannot give us a clear answer, so the EU is united and London is in trouble. Finally, on migration, we reduced the numbers of arrivals, especially through the Mediterranean route, by more than 80% by 2015. When you sum up all these things, some would probably say that listing success stories is a boring exercise and probably journalists are not very interested. I would say that this is not the case, but I would say that it is a precondition for the most important thing a politician can have, and that is trust from the people. We did it together: all the political families worked on this. I want to pick up only one aspect because there is still a discussion going on about how we rescued the euro and yes, my party, the PPE party, is proud of what we did. It is about the policy of Enda Kenny, of Passos Coelho, of Mariano Rajoy, of Samaras, and of Anastasiades in Cyprus. They took the necessary steps and we rescued Europe and the euro with the policy that we invented and we established. (Applause) We created growth and a good future perspective for the people and I do not remember – let me say this in party political terms –Hollande, Renzi, Dijsselbloem or even Moscovici presenting any kind of alternative proposal about how we should answer the challenge which was on the table. Even Mr Bullmann, in the German Government, with your contribution and your party, I didn’t see any alternative proposal presenting other strategies to overcome the crisis. Stable budgets and an ambitious reform programme are necessary for a good economic future. That is what the PPE believes in.  (Applause) But now let’s look to the future. A people’s Europe is, first of all, a Europe of security. That’s why we welcome the proposal to provide 10 000 Frontex officers to really contribute to a strong border control. Security also still means the fight against organised crime and criminals. Their data exchange is key for Europe and I also want to underline that the Schengen area brings more and not less security. That’s why we ask the Council to take further steps to include Bulgaria and Croatia inside the Schengen area. They have waited for such a long time. It’s now time to act. I ask the Romanian Government to stop the risks regarding the fight against corruption in Romania because they are harming the decision—making process towards Bulgaria and Croatia in the same way. All three countries must have the right to join the Schengen area immediately. I want to underline this again. A second point for a people’s Europe is a Europe of democracy. That’s why I thank you for the initiatives to make our European elections safe. Neither Russia, nor China, nor any external power will decide. No trolls, fake news or Cambridge Analytica will decide. The people will decide. Europeans will decide the future of this continent. A third point: a people’s Europe is a Europe of fairness. I wonder what a truck driver is thinking when he listens to the radio and they talk about self-driving trucks. I think he is asking himself, ‘what will happen to me?’ In such a world – we are facing a revolution in the labour market – we have to create a new fair deal for Europe. That means – and I think in this House we all share these general ideas – fair taxation, contributions by the digital business sector to the future of this fair approach, and a new social model. Today’s Europe cannot be united – and cannot be called united – as living conditions in the European Union are still not equal. That’s why I think we have to do more on common living conditions and living standards in the European Union.  Finally, a people’s Europe is a Europe which is strong at global level. You showed in the Oval Office that we are strong – economically, a giant – and we also have to become a giant politically. That’s why a change from the unanimous vote mechanism to the majority vote system is fully supported by the EPP. Let’s stand up, let’s make this century a European one again. The crisis times are over. Now it’s time for a more united Europe, for a more democratic Europe and for a more ambitious Europe. (Applause)

name: Udo Bullmann
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the President of the Commission started his term of office by promising that he would be a politician, a political leader of the College of Commissioners, and even those who tend, as I do, to criticise him on a daily basis – of course, only if it’s really necessary – have to admit he is a political leader of the Commission. Chapeau, Mr Juncker! You are not the porte-parole of the national capitals, and you are a credit to the decency of this political role in Europe. By fulfilling it as you do you make a huge difference vis-à-vis the predecessor from your own political family, and I appreciate that. But that is not the issue at stake today. The issue is not whether you are a dedicated European or whether the College of Commissioners consists of dedicated Europeans. We are convinced of that, otherwise we would not have voted for you. The question at stake is whether our institution and our policies are yet up to the task on which we have to deliver nowadays. Yes, we are in an era of huge crisis. Mr Weber, I do not think we have yet overcome the crisis: think of migration, which you mentioned; think of climate change; think of the deepening divides between north and south and between east and west. No. We are in a transformational period and, as Pope Francis said at the beginning of your term of office, ‘This is not an era of change, this is a change of era.’ The real question, which we discuss in our political Group, is ‘Why can’t we be more radical?’ Why can’t we go for a clearer policy change to live up to the change of era. You mentioned migration, Mr Juncker, and we wholeheartedly support what you were saying. Given that, as Manfred Weber reminded us, you were the PPE candidate for your post at the last election, why is it that, when you talk about migration you have the applause only of the left side of this House, while the rest are silent? I wonder why that is. I cannot understand it, because migration is what he says is the task of today. Yes, we have to open legal ways for migration. What we witnessed again in the summer in the Mediterranean is a scandal. It is disgusting to see people drowning – although the official mission of the European Union no longer includes safe harbours because of the right-wing Italian Government. And this is the mission of the Commission President who was the PPE candidate last time for that office. I urge the Council to take note of that when preparing for the summit on 19 September: to discuss his proposals and to take urgent action. This is what we expect from the Council.  (Applause) We will be able to act in a broader picture only if we reach out to the societies of the east. Yes, they need a new compact. They have an interest beyond Bratislava, Mr Juncker. They have a clear interest in safe energy. They have an interest in cohesion, long-lasting cohesion, and in the re—industrialisation of their countries – and they deserve that. The workers in the eastern countries deserve a decent future, and we need to establish a new compact. I am deeply convinced that it will then be easier to resolve the migration question too. Let us talk about the south. It is not bearable that 40—50% of the young people in the south are without any prospects. We need a new master plan for the south. And why not? This could be done by the Commission in the remaining months of its term of office. Why not propose a new master plan, building on the investment plan of Jean—Claude Juncker, extending that to the south and restoring hope and a vision of the future to the southern countries? Why not make them again the marketplaces of new ideas, the bridge builders to the cultures in our neighbourhood? That would be a very important task, and we would encourage the Commission to undertake it. But it is not only the societies in the east and the south that are falling apart. Look at the north. Look at Brexit. Of course, we fully back the position of the Commission and we stand united on that. But look at Brexit, look at the Swedish elections, and you see that ordinary working-class people, who have invested their hope in Europe, would like to see us delivering, at the top of our agenda, one specific proposal. Why does the Commission not come forward with the proposal that each and every child in the European Union have a child guarantee: that each child deserves free healthcare, deserves proper education, deserves decent housing? That could be a proposal in the forthcoming months to unite the European Union around a new future for the next generation. And that is what we propose. You are right, Mr Juncker, that we need to defend our institution. We need to fight against enemies who would like to undermine our democracy – Cambridge Analytica, for example, and all the enemies from the outside, as well as enemies from inside. And yes, we need to strengthen the Community method in the last months of your term of office. Good luck.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it was a very interesting speech. I expect there will be more of a ‘summing-up speech’ and I was just wondering what the proportion will be between pluses and minuses. On the plus side, I would put the Juncker plan which you mentioned en passant, which I think has been a success, but there is also a minus sign and the first thing that comes to mind is immigration and the demographic crisis. Of course you did not cause it directly: it was Chancellor Merkel who opened the European borders, but you could have prevented her or at least tried to prevent her. I don’t know with what effect, but at least you could have. We can subscribe to the idea of strengthening European borders, but I think it is a somewhat belated proposal. We could have talked about it some time ago. Instead, we spent a couple of years imposing a solution that was absurd from the very beginning: mandatory relocation. A lot of energy was spent on it, a lot of bad blood was shed, and the typical share of bullying and invectives were thrown around, but the real question that you should ask yourself and we should ask ourselves is: ‘is the European Union in a better shape now than it was when you took office?’ And I think the answer is clear: no. With all due respect, President Juncker, and all the successes that you had, no. There has never been a time in the history of European integration where Europe was more disunited than it is now. You talked about unity; no, unity is no longer there. It doesn’t mean World War I or World War II. Until recently, integration was a one-way street; now it’s a two-way street. The number of people who are deeply dissatisfied with the European project is increasing. That’s why our colleagues– my colleagues, too – are somewhat nervous about the elections – because they do not know what will happen. They are afraid of a possible political earthquake and you cannot say that the European Commission has no share in it and no responsibility – there is at least political responsibility. I mean, come on, there is some relation between cause and effect. It’s not the fact that there are so many people who have been antagonised, made angry, irritated, marginalised, bullied and rejected. The number is so high that you cannot neglect it and you cannot decline any responsibility for that. ‘You’ not as a person, but ‘you’ as a chief of the important European institution. We have to roll back this process somehow. When you mentioned that you wanted to have qualified majority votes in more areas of policy, public life in Europe, you are in for more trouble because that will petrify this system, in which some actors are equal and some are more equal than others and in which the decision-making process is extremely obscure. Nobody knows who makes the decisions, and the division between north and south, east and west are still there. If you want to have more trouble, go along this path. This will be an extremely interesting situation after the election. To what extent will you be responsive to the signals? You are charming man, President Juncker, and I love listening to you, but when you were talking today, I thought, ‘my God, we are living in two different worlds’. I wonder which one is the true one.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I first want to react to Mr Legutko. What he is saying is terrifying. He is saying here that we were never so disunited as today. Has he forgotten what Europe was between the two world wars? Has he forgotten what Europe was in the Cold War? Has he never heard about the Berlin Wall and the Iron Curtain? (Applause) Europe is united now. Mr Legutko is not offering another vision. He says he is in another world from Mr Juncker: very well, for me that’s no problem. But please, Mr Legutko, don’t say things that are completely crazy in a continent that has seen 20 million dead and victims because of nationalism and populism like that which you defend today. That is the point. (Applause) I have to tell you, Mr Juncker, I did not want to start on this note but I find it so terrifying that somebody should give us lessons here about unity in Europe and then try, with his Government, to go against the rule of law and against a number of other things – against European values. Sorry, I wanted to start with the State of the Union of Jean-Claude Juncker, and especially a part that none of the speakers so far has mentioned, namely the part about Africa. I think you are right, Jean-Claude, you have made a clear proposal: they don’t need charity. What they need is a true partnership, between Africa and the EU. And I think it is possible to create what I would call the biggest economic and trade area in the world, because if Europe does that with Africa, it will become – it is already – the biggest trade area. It will also, in my opinion, be a true alternative for Africa, for African citizens, to the takeover by the Chinese, which is happening every day, every week, in every investment today in Africa. I think that Parliament must support you in pursuing this goal. My question is a little different to the questions from other political group leaders. It is this: last year you gave us your legacy, and you repeated that this year, and so the question is whether we can translate that legacy into reality in the coming years? It is an existential year of elections with a number of threats, let’s be honest, with the rise of nationalism and populism everywhere in Europe. We have a number of authoritarian leaders. (Interjection from the floor: ‘Hurray’) Yes, thank you for supporting me! We have leaders like Mr Kaczyński and like Mr Orbán, who is, in fact, hijacking our European parties. I think they’re doing a little of what Trump is doing in the US Republican Party. (Heckling) Let’s be honest, your voice is only an affirmation of this. The inconvenient truth is that the alt-right in Europe is trying to undermine this European Union and is actually trying to take over European politics from within: to do the opposite of the agenda that Jean-Claude Juncker presented to us today. It is for that reason – and I think all of us, certainly including Manfred Weber, are aware of this – that in the vote we are going to have in a few moments it is so important that all pro-Europeans are united against this alt-right authoritarian tendency apparent in a number of our countries. Leading the European Union is not only a matter of mathematical strength: it’s also a question of moral authority. And it is moral authority which is at stake at the moment in the European Union.  In the same spirit, Mr Juncker, I want to ask the Commission about a specific issue: something that you mentioned very briefly, but which I want to go into in more detail. I want to ask the Commission to introduce in the coming months a package of specific proposals and measures to protect our elections against the foreign meddling that we have already seen in other continents and in other places in Europe. These would include, for example, measures identifying foreign agents who are active on European social media platforms, as well as the extremist politicians with whom they are colluding. In the USA, as you all know, Special Counsel Robert Mueller has been appointed to investigate Russian interference in elections, and they have already issued dozens of indictments. I think we need to catch up as quickly as possible by establishing our own special prosecutor to investigate and to stop all disinformation in Europe too – and certainly before it is too late in the light of the European elections to be held next year. My special request to you, Mr Juncker, is to ask if the Commission could take an initiative on this and bring it to the table of the Council and the table of the European Parliament.  Finally, my last point: I want to support you in one thing. The most important point you made was about the end of unanimity and the use of what is called, using a French term, the passerelle clause. That was your most important proposal, and my proposal, Jean-Claude, is that you be ambitious. Include all fields, all possible articles of the Treaty, in your proposal on the passerelle clause, because I am pretty sure that, at the other side of the table, in the Council there will be a number of them who will not be in agreement with you. It is obvious that the best thing to do in politics is to ask for the maximum possible. Start with 100%. Say ‘I want the end of unanimity inside the European Union’ because that is the main problem at the moment in deciding on a number of things: for example, as you mentioned Mr Juncker, the migration package. With the Council not capable of deciding, even when it is with a qualified majority, my proposal is to be ambitious: include the whole package, all fields of foreign policy and, as far as I am concerned, all fields of taxation too. Include everything in it and we will see what the end game will be if we support you. You said – and this will be my conclusion – that this would be the ‘last-chance Commission’. Do you remember that, four years ago? And I have been asking myself what can come after the ‘last-chance Commission’ in the coming years. I think that what will come is something different. The Commission that we need in the future, colleagues, will be more than that: it will be a type of new, renewed European government. And it will have one task, which is to realise further the legacy of Jean-Claude Juncker, as well as the other visions that have been set out in recent months, for example by the French President in his Sorbonne speech. That will be the task of this new Commission. And that – furthering your legacy – is also the task that we, as our political group and movement, will offer to the electorate as a real European alternative to the nationalists and the populists inside and outside this House. (Applause)

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, you yourself and many colleagues have looked at the challenges that we have globally, and I totally agree with them. We have a lot of challenges. We have problems – to say the least – in our transatlantic partnership, we have China rising up – there are so many challenges out there. But I would argue that more threatening than anything that the world can throw at us are actually the enemies from the inside, and that they are the obvious ones: the nationalists that bring hatred, division; the racists that spread fear and hate. But there are also some less obvious: the decision-makers who actually don’t take decisions and want to keep the status quo, who just want to keep their own privileges and who are just closing their eyes at what is at stake. And then there are powers in governments – of which, unfortunately, we have more and more – who use the European Union as a scapegoat for all their own failures and that are cutting away democracy and civil liberties bit by bit and piece by piece. But a Europe united, a Europe that knows what it stands for, can face all external problems and can be a front-runner and a shining example in the world. We can be strong if we don’t make ourselves weak. And Europe has promised its citizens to bring peace, prosperity and democracy, and those promises are still very relevant – but we need to renew them and we need to bring them to fulfilment. On peace, we have major achievements to show, but we cannot rest on laurels and Norwegian medals: there are new global challenges ahead that threaten our future and our security, and the biggest one of them is climate change. We have seen this summer that climate change is happening: it’s happening now and it’s happening everywhere, from disastrous harvests to forest fires. There is no way anyone could possibly deny that. And the good news about climate change is that we know what to do; and the bad news about climate change is that we don’t do it. But with Trump leading the US into space rather than forwards, we cannot wait as Europeans for someone else to protect our planet. No, we have to do it ourselves, and there is no time to lose. And there the Commission has been way too timid in the past five years, I have to say. It is now that we need a very quick change to renewables and phasing-out of the climate-killer: coal. And if climate protection truly is a priority, then it should also be a priority in the multiannual budget. It should also be a priority in the agricultural reform. Agriculture is both a victim as well as a culprit in climate change, but farmers can also be part of the solution. And here is where the Commission should have been more ambitious with the agricultural reform. The European Union has also always promised prosperity, but we are far away from the triple-A rating that we should have, I agree, on social policies. And the austerity imposed on Member States in the past without regard to consequences and also without regard to whether this would actually help anything: that has seriously undermined the European promise of increasing living standards. But increasing the quality of life is not just some minor thing that you can forget about. It’s an essence of policy-making, and we need to renew this promise and build a social Europe, and one not just of nice declarations like we’ve seen from Gothenburg. We need not just nice intentions – that’s all very nice, but we need a social Europe with real facts and real figures. We need common minimum social standards in Europe. All citizens must get full access to social protection, to housing and to medical care. A framework directive on adequate minimum income schemes can create such a safety net as well, and here it would be very interesting to see a proposal by the Commission, so that we can ensure that safety net for everyone and not just for a lucky few. And Europe has promised democracy, rule of law and civil liberties to all its citizens, and that was a very strong call for all the countries that wanted to join, for all the people living under dictatorships who were being deprived of freedoms – like the country where I myself was born. Our continent has a long and bloody history of oppressions, of tanks rolling against protesters, of people suffering in prison camps, and it’s only thanks to those courageous people who were marching for freedom, who were marching for democracy and who did not give up, that today in the European Union we have that democracy, we have those civil liberties and we have freedom. But those very big successes are under threat. We need to fight for them again every single day, because inside Europe today, judges are being dismissed, corruption is being legalised, newspapers are closed, universities harassed and civil society treated as criminals. And this is not a detail; this is a threat to all of us. And again, today as well, courageous people are standing up, marching for human rights – their own rights and the rights of their neighbours – and they are marching for freedom, be it in Sicily or Romania, be it in Chiemnitz or be it in Pirin. And they defend democracy, they defend humanity and they defend Europe, and we see as well that, if we stand up together, then we really have power and we are really strong together. And I think more now than ever, it is now the task and responsibility of all of us to take a stance and to take up all of our responsibilities. We have responsibilities: you, as President of the Commission, we all, as Members of the European Parliament – and all Europeans from north to south, from east to west. Because if Europe loses on democracy, then it will lose itself. And this is about more than one country or another country: this is about the achievements on this continent that so many people have even died for. This is about our true self, the true self of Europe, and it is time to take a stance.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Juncker, today, in a very intensive speech, you have expressed your political positions, with which you have taken over as President of the Commission and have led to this up to this point. I would like to pay tribute to you for that. I believe that this makes it easier for us to talk about what needs to be different from the point of view of the various political groups in the European Union.  I would like to start with the evaluation as the first thing I want to do. Are we really at the stage where we can say that we have weathered the crises, we have come to the point where we can look forward to all the dangers, to all the challenges, to be prepared, to ensure that people have a corresponding sense of social security, of solidarity, of a community here in the European Union? And here I say to you clearly: no!  Yesterday, when the Greek Prime Minister was here, a sentence from him was very revealing when he said, 'We are out of the memorandum', and then added – and he said this several times: 'We survived'. If, however, the phrase 'we have survived' is the conclusion of a policy which has been largely supported by the institutions and also by the Commission, of a way of crisis management which has ultimately been carried out on the backs of the poorest of the poor and ultimately led to it, that inequalities have been deepened, and that we do not have the certainty that we can look to the future, but that we all feel that with the coming election we really have something ahead of us, where we have to say today that we have to avert it, because we want a Europe of solidarity, of community, of peace, then there are a whole series of starting points where we have to look at today's policy and say. : That's not how it will work.  We have to say that, even ten years after the start of the financial crisis, the level of prosperity from the pre-crisis periods has not yet been restored in many countries. And where growth is back, it doesn't matter to many people. The rights of women workers have been severely reduced in many Member States. We must send a signal that we are strengthening these rights and also the protection of women workers and, above all, those who are not in a working process at all, that we are bringing them back, that we accept them, that this is part of it for us, to the European Union, and that we do not want the promised Triple-A for Social Triple-A to ultimately become a triple-A for a future military strength of the European Union.  That cannot be the case that we are taking the money from the EU budget for the fund that you mentioned earlier. And I say to you: the title you needed to show strength, to show common ground, to demonstrate strength to the outside world and, ultimately, to protect the citizens, reminds me too much of the slogan of the Austrian Presidency, of which I do not believe at all, of this slogan, because it says ' Europe that protects'. And you make this very clear: this is not about social union, it is not about that at all. There is virtually no specific objective in the terms of reference for this Presidency. It is a question of protecting the external borders, of repelling the refugees, and of continuing this process, these humanitarian disasters that we experienced in the summer, in practice.  I am very grateful to you for saying where the stumbling block is and who is blocking here. And I believe that we as a Parliament should make it very clear that we finally need Dublin, that we will not accept it, that the Council is constantly blocking us here and that it simply thinks that it can do what it wants and simply remains silent in inaction.  And what we expect from the Commission is my urgent request: say it out loud. It does not help the people and many consciously looking actors, including those who are looking at development, activists in Europe at all, if they do not know where the causes lie and who they have to turn to, with whom they can fight together, if it is not clear who is responsible for what, what responsibility the individual institutions bear.  We must make that clear. Otherwise, we will hardly win over voters who are prepared to overcome this lethargy – namely, to fight for Europe. We have to compete together. That must become our mission. And here we differ – and I say this quite clearly – also massively as leftists from all right-wing attempts, destroy Europe. I would like to emphasise this once again.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I say to Mr Juncker, what a picture you paint. A European Union of peace, of prosperity, of contentedness and, as you said, you’re trying to make it a little more perfect every day. Well, it’s a very good advertising slogan, but I tell you what surprised me.  Since your last State of the Union speech there’s been a seismic political event in Europe, perhaps one even on a par with Brexit. Italy, a founding member of the Union, the third-biggest economy in the euro area, now has a coalition government between the 5—Stars and the Lega that is polling over 60% of the vote and is posing a direct challenge, both in terms of the management of the euro area and indeed, how the migration crisis is handled. You made no acknowledgment of that at all. No acknowledgment of the populist revolt that is sweeping through virtually every single Member State. Instead you’re to carry on regardless.  And I noted your continued use of the phrase ‘sovereign Europe’. What you’re talking about is a deeper centralisation of power: a centralisation of power in terms of Europe’s foreign policy; a centralisation of power, as you first laid out last year, in terms of building a European army; more power at the centre for taxation. All of this, of course, meaning less to be done at the nation-state level. And now another 10 000 European border guards paving the way for a federal border police in Europe. Well, I’ll tell you something – if you’ve got problems with the Italians now, you ain’t seen nothing yet when you put that proposal to them.  But it’s all about centralisation – power, power, power. But here’s the funny thing – you appealed to our sense of European patriotism. So why is it that patriotism at the nation-state level is considered to be insular, bad, nasty, xenophobic, probably racist into the bargain? And yet, patriotism at a European level is a good and a virtuous thing. I’m afraid this idea of European patriotism, this idea of putting that flag above their own nation-state flag is for the birds. People do not have a profound sense of European identity. They have a sense of national identity and in a way that is the great dividing line between your vision of Europe and that increasingly that is being said by the electors. We wish to live in nation states. Now on Brexit, Mr Juncker. On the Irish border already there are huge differences between the north and the south. Differences of politics, of tax, of currency and of law and we manage. And if we can get to a free trade deal, well, of course, there’ll be no difficulties whatsoever. I thought you had some very positive things to say. You said our vote to leave was a vote to leave the single market and its associated parts. I agree with you. Quite why Ms May at Chequers wants to opt back into much of it, I don’t know.  But you said twice that we need to come to a free trade deal. It’s what European exporters want, and it is, absolutely, and it’s what we want. Surely now the time is right. The ground is prepared for a Canada—plus—style trade deal between you and between us. We leave political union but we carry on doing business on a tariff—free basis. We want it. Increasingly, I think that you want it. Let’s get Brexit sorted and, Mr Verhofstadt, you’ll be happy, you’ll see the back of us.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Mr Juncker, four years after the installation of your Commission, and only a few months before the European elections, the time is obviously on the balance sheet, and it is clear that your Commission is finally a summary of all the excesses of the European Union and of all that people cannot bear today. The action of your Commission is opaque, undemocratic and punitive. Opaque, when you decide, it is the prince's decision to appoint Mr Selmayr as Secretary General of the Commission. His majesty Jean-Claude Juncker is breaking all the rules in force. Undemocratic, when your Commissioner Mr Oettinger declares, in a statement of incredible arrogance, I quote, 'that the financial markets will teach Italians to vote well'. And also undemocratic when, as recently as now, you say that the European Union's budget will be locked down until 2027, without waiting for the citizens of our peoples to vote in the elections in May 2019. Punitive also, with regard to Poland or Hungary, and we had a fine example of a Stalinist trial, just yesterday, simply because these countries have the courage to define what our values of civilization are and because they refuse the mandatory quotas of migrants that you wanted to impose on them. Punitive also against the British, to whom you want to charge the price of freedom, by refusing any trade agreement while countries that are not in the European Union, such as Norway or Iceland, are granted access to the single market. As you multiply free trade treaties with the whole world, would you deny that to the British? And then, of course, the action of your Commission has been marked by the acceleration of the abolition of all economic protections. You are knowingly organising unfair competition, within the European Union with seconded work, outside the European Union with free trade treaties whose consequences are seriously anti-ecological and which harm our industries and our agriculture. This is true of CETA (AECG, Global Economic and Commercial Agreement), it is true of future treaties with the countries of Mercosur or Oceania. And as recently as this summer, you went to Tokyo, without the advice of the European Parliament or the national parliaments, to sign a pre-free trade agreement with Japan. Finally, of course, your Commission has been characterised by a crazy migration policy, and Mr Legutko pointed out earlier - with great moderation - which has not stopped him from suffering the wrath of Mr Verhofstadt, who spends his time criticising and attacking populists or extremists, but who is in this Chamber with great steadfastness. , the face of hatred, of aggression, of the rejection of any idea that would be different from his own, and he has demonstrated it just now. Mr Avramopoulos, your Commissioner, had talked about immigration, in setting the framework for your Commission, the reception of migrants, I quote, is an economic and social imperative for our ageing continent and you yourself said earlier that you wanted to increase legal immigration routes even further.  This is, without doubt, undoubtedly your greatest political fault: to have allowed to encourage and organize this mass immigration, which weakens our continent and makes our peoples suffer.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to start by thanking President Juncker for his speech and saying that I appreciate this pragmatic tone, this principle, that it is better to be effective on small issues and careful on big issues. Unlike the Socialists, who are demanding direct funding for new jobs from the EU level, I appreciate this pragmatism. But I have run out of a clear rate here to build a competitive market, without blockades, to remove protectionism, which is based not only on populism, but much broader, on support for small and medium-sized enterprises – that would be a very pragmatic approach.  Unlike Mr Farage, who spoke here three minutes ago, I am in favour of Europe being more responsible for defence policy than before. I look at this process very positively. Europe should share responsibility for this area with the United States. But practical solidarity is needed, it is necessary to be accompanied by the feeling that Europeans, that the European Union will defend the security of Eastern Europe as much as southern Europe, and that it will not tolerate initiatives contrary to European security and European solidarity, such as Nord Stream 2. We need pragmatism and practical solidarity.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr President of the Commission, in your speech you mentioned the role of journalists as guarantors of the rule of law. Once again, I would like to remind you in this House, given that the allegedly murdered allegedly murdered in Slovakia, Daphne Caruana Galizia, and Jan Kuciak, who was murdered in Slovakia, have not yet been discovered. Until we know who the sponsors are, we will continue to insist and denounce what happened.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will limit myself to a few very brief remarks in response to concrete questions that have been put to me. I will start with Mr Bullmann, who has drawn our attention to the need to further develop children's rights and social rights in general. I would like to point out here that the Commission has exactly proposed, in the context of the so-called 'Gothenburg' process, such an action. This is Chapter 3, point number 11. I would also like to remind Mrs Keller that I pleaded, today as yesterday, that the Gothenburg Declaration should not remain a poem, but that we should turn intentions into deeds, including legislative acts. I would like to say to my friend Verhofstadt, to whom we should address with a minimum of politeness, that the Commission has today adopted a text on the protection of European voters, European candidates and political parties in the forthcoming European elections. So it's all on track. I will tell Mr. Farage that you have to listen before you speak. I have not put on the same level national patriotism and European patriotism. I said "one does not exclude the other," and I will continue to be patriotic, but an enlightened patriot. My little grand-ducal patriotism is not directed against anyone. (Applause) I love my country but I don't hate others, and if you say we live in two different worlds - it's not Mr. Farage who said it, but a previous speaker - yes, I don't want to live in this world of rejection, in this world of hate, I don't want to live in this world, I prefer mine , which is also yours. (Applause)

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, on behalf of the Council, let me – first of all – thank President Juncker for his address and for his analyses regarding the challenges but also the opportunities facing our Union at this crucial juncture as we approach the end of the parliamentary term. I won’t be able to go into all the detailed elements of President Juncker’s speech but his considerations deserve careful examination. Obviously, he touched upon issues that are at the centre of our attention. But let me turn to something else at the outset. I would like to stress that I fully second what President Juncker stated at the beginning of his speech. Our union is a union of peace. It is a union of prosperity and we should show respect towards this union, deal with it carefully and protect our common values. Now let me turn to some of the issues touched upon, for instance, the idea of further strengthening Frontex. It is an important element of a functioning EU policy on migration. It was already discussed at the European Council in June and it will be a main topic for the discussions at the informal Heads of State or Government summit in Salzburg. Yes, the strengthening of Frontex is, in our view, a precondition to establishing a resilient and well—grounded European asylum system. We hope as far as possible to find common ground and to bring things forward.  The European Council in June also reconfirmed the need to bring our cooperation with Africa to a new level. A visible expression of this aim will be a high-level forum, which we are currently planning to hold in Vienna at the beginning of December. As far as the proposal on summertime is concerned, we are planning to put that on the Council’s agenda very soon. Given the specific political context, before the end of the current parliamentary term, there is indeed a need to concentrate on the delivery of pending proposals and on the effective implementation of legislation. Be assured that the Austrian Presidency’s energy and determination is fully focused on this. In recent months, there have been developments which may on the surface seem contradictory. There is much talk about Euroscepticism and concerns in this respect ahead of next year’s European Parliament elections. Yet, at the same time, we have seen positive signs on renewed trust and higher levels of support for the Union.
