For our part, as the Presidency, we are confident that there is enough unity and determination in Europe to tackle these challenges ahead and to transfer them into opportunities. Our motto is ‘a Europe that protects’ and this is what we are trying to contribute. I think this motto could also apply to a series of elements of President Juncker’s speech today. Europe has emerged stronger in many ways from the crisis we have faced in recent years, but now we need to act swiftly and determinedly on the economy, migration, security and digital Europe, especially cybercrime. The increasing number of cyberattacks and the crucial questions on cybersecurity must be discussed diligently. We will strive to use the effects of digitalisation at its best on the one hand but, on the other hand, we have to deal carefully with the possible negative effects. The goal must be a secure, stable single digital market and the highest trust from the consumers of this service in Europe. Addressing you in this Chamber in July, Chancellor Kurz presented to you the priorities of our Presidency, namely, security and the fight against illegal migration, securing prosperity and competitiveness through digitalisation and stability in the European neighbourhood. I will not go through these principles and priorities again. They focus on achieving tangible results through demonstrating to European citizens the EU’s indispensable added value for its citizens and Member States. This is particularly important in this period as we near the end of the parliamentary term. As President Juncker mentioned, we have a lot of work to do in the coming months with regard to legislation, but there are also the informal meetings of the Heads of State or Government in Salzburg next week and the European Council meetings in October and December in which crucial decisions will have to be made. Beyond our Presidency are the European elections and the informal meeting in Sibiu in May 2019, when the implementation of the leaders’ agenda will be reviewed and a strategic agenda for the period 2019—2024 will be prepared. Finally, speaking of delivering on priority policies, I would also note that today’s debate on the State of the Union is a key moment in a new annual cycle of programming. The General Affairs Council, at its meeting on 18 September, will have an exchange of views on the basis of the Commission’s letter of intent, which was issued only yesterday. We also look forward to continuing the fruitful dialogue among the three institutions on priorities, particularly on the implementation of the joint declaration on the EU’s legislative priorities for 2018 and 2019. Results can be delivered in a focused and targeted way through our joint programming. Let me reaffirm the Council’s commitment to this process and assure you that the Presidency will continue to be a determined partner.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. President Juncker has put it aptly: the European Union is now in a much, much better position politically, economically and socially than many people perceive it to be. But still, many people see great challenges, many people have concerns or are dissatisfied. My impression is that often these concerns and dissatisfaction come from the fact that people have an expectation of the European Union that we cannot fulfil, that we have expectations, where the Member States do not give us the tools to meet these expectations, and the European institutions do not have the necessary competence. When President Juncker suggests that we eliminate the issue of tax breaks, tax breaks for companies such as Apple or Amazon, which are granted on the backs of craftsmen and small and medium-sized enterprises, if we want to shape a stronger common foreign policy, or if we want to tackle the issue of migration and the protection of external borders better together at European level, then we have the very situation where the Member States have not given us the competence to do so far in many of these things and that we are not regulating things here. Can. That is why I have strong support for the European Commission. Dear Representative of the Council! I hope that these proposals by President Juncker will be taken up in the Council, that you will discuss in the Council that the European Union will finally be able to meet the demands and wishes of the citizens, so that satisfaction with the European Union increases and we can successfully develop this overall project in the interests of the citizens.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the President of the European Commission has just presented to us an agenda for the future and an agenda presented by a true European politician.  It is indeed true that the time for European sovereignty has come, and it has come at the forefront of the response to climate change, the digital revolution, trade, the need to manage migration in another way.  But why doesn't this agenda go ahead? This agenda does not advance because we have forces from the past arguing that it is better to protect citizens only behind national borders. This is a complete illusion because it is not possible today to be able to protect citizens on the basis of national policies, solutions are needed at European level. But the real reason why this agenda is not moving forward is that we have conservative status quo forces that resist that these European-scale solutions are truly implemented. For these forces of the status quo, migration has only an organised European border, but progressive forces have to overcome this blockade because it is not enough. We need a real partnership with Africa, we need to have a European asylum system and we need to live up to it when we receive refugees here and we have to give them protection. The forces of the status quo think it is positive that we have had a pick-up in employment in Europe and investment, but progressive forces want more because we need much more investment to drive the energy transition and drive the digital revolution in the right direction. Here we have a huge blockade which has to do with the reform of the euro zone. Mr Weber is pleased with where we are, but it is not possible because this euro area continues to produce divergences until it has a working budgetary capacity. And then the conservative forces think it's enough to have jobs. That's not good enough. The quality of jobs must have a real social pillar that guarantees a contract of employment and social protection for all citizens of Europe, in any region in which they are located.  Therefore, this blockade can only be overcome when progressive forces are able to overcome the forces of the status quo that have been underway with the real European solutions.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Juncker has enlightened us about the need to defend European values against chauvinist nationalism and I could not agree more, but I would like to make a suggestion to him. Please, go to Catalonia and visit our nine political prisoners, amongst them two former MEPs. Please go and have a chat with them about their core values and the founding principles of the European Union, and having spoken with them, ask yourself, ‘what are these democratic, peaceful, European people doing in jail?’ Ask yourself if having politicians and civil society leaders in jail for nearly a year without trial, on the basis of fake accusations, just for having organised a referendum, just for having implemented a democratic mandate, if all of this is in line with European values. Yesterday, over a million people were in Barcelona again, claiming our democratic rights, standing up for European values and against repression. People are convinced, despite feeling let down by European institutions, that Europe needs to be part of the solution.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Mr Juncker, I do not want to be unfair to you, many welcome your action. The rich thank you, because your Last Chance Commission will have been a chance for tax evaders; it will have been an opportunity for the lobbies, for Bayer—Monsanto, which will continue to poison people for years to come; it will have been an opportunity for the vultures who have taken over Greece and, throughout the European Union, for all those who now hold a hand in the commons. I believe that President Macron can also thank you for your encouragement to implement structural reforms: opening up to rail competition, pension reform now and dismantling workers' rights. Mr President Juncker, Vice-President Timmermans, I regret to tell you that if the rich say thank you, the Peoples of Europe, on the other hand, do not say thank you.

name: Jörg Meuthen (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are talking today about the state of the Union. Mr Juncker has presented his view of this to us. He has taken a historical approach to this, but it does not do much justice to the current situation. His analysis is wrong in the elementary points. Firstly, he considers the financial crisis to be over. That is a fatal mistake, Mr Juncker. Nothing has been solved, everything is just covered. The pot continues to simmer, and the day will come when the lid will lift and all the omissions and misjudgments will fly around our ears. Secondly, peace, which is so important to us, is no longer threatened from the outside as it was in the 20th century, but from within, above all through a completely misguided migration policy, which the Commission and this House are working with. Thirdly, his policy of ever closer union is no longer going on. Today, it is more a question of who will leave next, rather than who will join the Union next. The menetekel of Brexit has obviously not yet been properly understood here. The time of this Commission and this policy has come to an end. This was also very noticeable in the bloodless speech, Mr Juncker. If the EU is to be strong, it must remember its few real core tasks and respect the sovereignty of its nations. This is exactly the opposite, as was shown yesterday in the dealings with Prime Minister Orban – unfortunately still. That will soon change.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I always find this very amusing, as the first row praises each other. You can see that you are still not used to opposition. But, ladies and gentlemen, do not be afraid! I can tell you one thing: we all love Europe. I am not arguing about that here. But what have we heard today? We have not heard much from Jean-Claude Juncker. He has mentioned the word solidarity six times in total. But solidarity cannot be a one-way street. However, we saw this here in this House yesterday, when there was a debate with Hungary. A left-wing minority here in this House has drawn the largest group through the Chamber here in the House at the nose ring. And what has become of the White Paper? Presented in March 2017, we haven't heard of it. I cannot go down a path where I do not yet know in which direction he is to move. It is particularly remarkable, because Juncker knows that this migration crisis is changing Europe in a sustainable way, and we are only in the first phase. That is why he is, after all, quite late in his proposals. This years of hesitation have not improved the crisis at all.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Madam President, today Mr Juncker wanted to establish his legacy, but sadly, that legacy will be the loss of a Member State and more importantly the loss of confidence in the European Union, as demonstrated by recent elections in Sweden, Italy and Germany, as well the migration crisis that continues to cost lives. On Brexit, Mr Juncker reaffirms his view that there should be no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. I agree. But he also reaffirms support for the Belfast Agreement. However, the EU backstop proposal ignores one of the core principles of that agreement: the principle of consent. Let me make it clear once again in this House: there can be no borders – and certainly not those imposed by the European Union – within the internal market of the United Kingdom, or interference in its constitutional framework. Great Britain is Northern Ireland’s largest market place, where we sell more than in the Republic of Ireland, the rest of Europe and the rest of the world put together. Equally, 70% of everything that comes into Northern Ireland for consumers and the manufacturing process comes from Great Britain. Customs are regulatory barriers which put jobs and families at risk.

name: President. –
text: If I give everyone that leeway I will be in trouble and you will be annoyed with me because votes will run late. So please be strict on your time.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab What is the state of the Union, we will find out in the European elections of 2019. People, voters at the ballot box, either by participating in elections or by refusing to participate and by political indication, will tell us about this. Because the European Union is not primarily an institution, but a sense of meaning to be together, the expectation of tangible benefits and the perception of the Union as an opportunity, not a source of problems. It seems to me that we can do a lot more over the remaining nine months to ensure that the verdict of the European sovereign 2019 is a vote of confidence, not a censure, to coincide with the optimistic diagnosis of President Juncker, whom, on behalf of the Polish delegation, I sincerely thank for serving a united Europe. We know what not to do – not to make intrusive regulations that teach people how to live, that renew divisions between East-West or South-North. For many, a multiannual budget is important – not for everyone, because some prefer a small European budget – but for many it is important as a confirmation of the European Union's capacity and predictability of funding. But trust or distrust is settled in the sphere of security in the broader sense, and that is the most important agenda of the next nine months.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as you know, you never get a second chance to make a first impression, and in that sense, you will never get a second chance to be the Commission of the last chance. And that’s what you promised us when you started this legislature, and that ship has sailed, I have to say. We know now that the successor of Mr Juncker will be the next Commission President of the last chance. And this time it might get really serious. Yesterday, we saw the face of the anti-democrats, and we all know that sort of extremism in Europe is based on raising inequalities and the fact that our citizens fear for the future for themselves and their children. This Commission promised us a triple A on social issues. What we have is a lot of paper and nice words but not the concrete measures to fight inequalities. And you said you would tackle migration and make sure that we have good answers to that, and now everything is based on the fact that we need to defend our borders. And last but not least, you said we would be top for climate change. We did some things in the right direction but we lack the real ambition to have a sustainable future.

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Mr Juncker, because certainly where you are, you are listening to us, you have rightly mentioned the dramatic consequences of climate change. But on July 26, when you meet Donald Trump, you are committing the European Union to import more GMO soybeans "shot" at Roundup and more shale gas. You are committing, on behalf of more than 500 million European citizens, without a mandate. Without a warrant. You have not heard, Mr Juncker, the ardent desire of these Europeans to free themselves from glyphosate and their ardent desire to fight against climate change. At the same time, your Commission has abandoned, abolished the anti-dumping duties on Chinese photovoltaic panels, delivering our industry, this 21st century industry, to Chinese industrial voracity. Your trade policy, the globalization that you defend with CETA (AECG, Global Economic and Trade Agreement), Mercosur and so many others, it is the globalization of junk food, that of pesticides, that of animal suffering, it is deforestation, it is fossil fuels and it is climate chaos. So our responsibility, and listen to The citizens of Europe, is to depend on the sun and the wind, not Putin and Trump.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, the Europeans have also remembered from yesterday's debate on Greece that there is no democracy and popular sovereignty in the European Union. We remembered that the economic crisis was paid for by the people and the countries of the south; This is the European Union, this is the state of the European Union, that is the character of the European Union. From Mr Juncker's speech we understood that the future of the European Union will now be to intensify the policy of austerity and reforms, i.e. those that further take away social and labour rights, bring security to work, privatisation everywhere, poverty and youth unemployment, that is to say, create the greenhouse of the far right and fascism. But ladies and gentlemen, the peoples will seek solutions outside the neoliberal treaties of the European Union, outside the plans of the euro, by demanding a future of cooperation between sovereign, equal states in the European Union with democracy, solidarity and peace.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, the game over is over. The opportunity to tell the citizens the fairy tale of your Europe is over. The 'once upon a time Europe' that will make families richer and safer has in fact turned out to be a scam, it has turned out to be a failed project, a poisonous project for citizens, for businesses, for families, who have been affected by this European project, making them more insecure and poorer. Mr Juncker, you said this morning: 'the peoples of Europe need certainty'. You do not know what the peoples of Europe need, unfortunately. The only certainty that the peoples of Europe have is that they hate your certainty. Mr Juncker, in all the projects it would be a good use from time to time to self-evaluate, to evaluate yourself in the eyes of the citizens of Europe, who are looking at you with these eyes today, and you yourself should resign in your self-assessment. The time has come to make fun of the Italians, and the Italians give her back that fairy tale that she tried to tell with this cadeau that is "Junckerocchio", that is, those lies that have been told.

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President, many have wished today to take stock of your mandate, but the work does not stop tomorrow morning, especially as the global context is increasingly difficult. The obvious alliances due to history are no longer necessarily synonymous with friendship or even solidarity. You yourself are putting the pieces of our trade relationship with the United States back together. But the easy question, which is asked here by many parliamentarians, is: "What is Europe doing?" What is the Commission doing? What are you doing, Mr Juncker? I prefer to ask you the question in a different way: "What are the Member States doing?" A year ago, during the State of the Union address, you brought a new word, that of reciprocity, into the dictionary of the European Institutions. Previously taboo, it has been legitimized by what you say, in the context of this Europe that acts and protects. What do states do with this concept, which is expected by many businesses and citizens? What do Member States do when they are asked to agree on immigration, and the question arises: what do you do to get them to agree when they no longer talk? Because some states determine their migration policy according to the arrivals of the boats. This is not the serious answer that our fellow citizens expect. What they are waiting for, however, is to finally be told the truth. States are sometimes unable to find a solution when they are given all the means to find them. The failure of Europe is first and foremost the failure of dialogue between states, because as you said earlier, European sovereignty exists because of the sovereignty of states, it does not replace nations.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Juncker, Europe, even if it is important, deserves better than a change of time. Tax evasion, CETA, Selmayr, glyphosate, this is what will remain of your conservative and liberal presidency. It is a Europe that sees the progress of populists of all kinds, powerless in front of the rest of the world, that you leave us. We were entitled to expect an ambitious European Commission, that of the last chance, you said, committed, protective, implementing the 17 sustainable development goals of the United Nations, based on the triptych: economy, social, environmental. We have had a Commission that has sacrificed our farmers and our territories on the altar of free trade, flouted the issue of equality between women and men and endangered the health of millions of European citizens by not applying the precautionary principle, whether on glyphosate, endocrine disruptors or GMOs. And it is not the multi-year financial framework, without vision and without ambition, that you propose, that will change your balance sheet. We need to hope.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Juncker, I thank you for the equivalence between European patriotism and intelligent patriotism; that is why I ask you to include euroorder reform in your programme as well. The list of crimes included in the Euroorder has not changed in fifteen years, but the world has changed a lot in fifteen years. For example, we are not protected by the Euroorder against cyber-terrorism, not even against the terrorist propaganda on the internet, which you mentioned, or the manipulation of election results, which you have also mentioned. Personal data are not protected by the Euroorder and no country is protected against coup attempts. My country, Spain, has suffered an attempted coup a year ago, but the Spanish Supreme Court does not have at its disposal, to try them, all those responsible because a regional court of another State of the Union has denied it that possibility. Spain is not the only case where the Euroorder does not work. What message are we passing on to the Spaniards? That Europe does not protect the Spanish Constitution? Without mutual trust, we cannot live without borders. Without a working Euroorder, we cannot live in Schengen. If we want Schengen to exist, we have to make the Euroorder exist as well. It makes no sense for Schengen to serve to get some countries to close borders to refugees and for other countries to open borders to criminals. It's not time to judge ourselves anymore, it's no longer time to look at each other, it's no longer time to accuse or attack us. If we want a truly united European Union, it must also be a European union of justice.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – In the European Union, borders are clearly only open to capital. Because people are closing.  Xenophobic outbursts are no longer just fee-a-man babbling, but they are becoming part of an argumentation strategy. It is closing the room for criticism of xenophobic discourse and increasing pressure to adopt such rhetoric as a common practice.  Populist leaders are spreading fear of an imaginary mass of people, and the refugee crisis is being exploited as a means of masking the crisis of the European institutions.  The fundamental failure is the disorder of the common asylum policy, which should rest on solidarity. Before the elections, the European Union faces a choice: whether it will resort to radical xenophobia or radical social change.  If it wants to survive, those of us who believe in its acquisitions must strive to preserve European values. The opposite path leads to closure in national states.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, first of all I would like to pay tribute to President Juncker as a true European and indeed an example for all of us in his European soul. And having said that in your last Union speech, I would like to put a question here which I was very disappointed, with the vision that has been presented here and which has to do with the next financial framework and the MFF.  The Commission has put forward a proposal that increases divergence, a bad proposal for the cohesion countries. How is estonia to fall by 24% and Finland to rise by 5%?  How is it explainable that Croatia will fall by 6 % and Italy to increase by 6%? The argument that some states have grown is a false argument. So they grow up, promote good policies, promote prosperity and are punished by European funds, even though they are far below, but far below rising states. This is not equity, this is not a path for the next seven years, this is not a discourse for the future and therefore we need to review the MFF deeply and I am also concerned because the Portuguese Government is conformist - as was seen here with Maria João Rodrigues - which criticises the jobs created because they are low, is what happens in Portugal , there is jobs created, but low, that is the socialist policy and that is the policy that we want to condemn.  And, by the way, one last question about the Solidarity Fund that was applied to Portugal for the fires. It must be said that the Portuguese has used more than half of the Fund for bureaucratic structures and not to re-place the situation on the ground. This is very regrettable and the Commission should criticise this. The money was for victims and for the regions, it was not for the state apparatus Portuguese. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D)
text: according to the "blue card" procedure. – Mr Rangel, it really is remarkable, it cannot resist the temptation to turn a European debate into a national debate. But on what I say, I think you have absolutely no authority to say what you said, because you represent here a Government that has buried employment in Portugal in terms of quantity and quality. The Socialist government Portuguese is doing exactly the opposite. So I think you should take your words back, I'm sorry.

name: President. –
text: Just before you start, Mr Rangel: it is usually a question on the debate, and this was more a point, but you have 30 seconds to respond.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. " I just wanted to say this: I talked about the multiannual financial framework. I know that for Mrs Rodrigues it does not interest you, because the Portuguese Government has negotiated badly, but I spoke of Italy, I spoke of Croatia, I spoke of Finland and I spoke of Estonia, I did not speak of Portugal.  And now about the job I will tell you this: who sank it was the Government of Socrates that left Portugal in bankruptcy. And you're responsible for that, too. And we." Employment began to grow with the Government Portuguese. Fortunately Mário Centeno, in the video he made for Greece, has already shown that he recognizes that the Government of Passos Coelho has done a great service to the country. That's what Mario Centeno came to recognize. Too bad he has a word in Brussels and has another in Lisbon. But I am here to talk about Brussels and I trust Mario Centeno of Brussels more than Mario Centeno in Lisbon.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as co-rapporteur of the Special Committee on Financial Crimes, Tax Evasion and Tax Avoidance, I was pleased to hear you talk about the need for combating money laundering. What we see in Europe is a crisis, and we need a real, comprehensive reform of anti-money laundering systems, regulations and authorities. It’s not only a money-laundering crisis, it’s a tax evasion and tax avoidance crisis too. It’s corruption, it’s terrorist finance. It’s already too rich and too powerful, swindling the tax coffers of our countries, and this must be stopped now. For some of Europe’s largest banks, the free movement of capital has become freedom from responsibility. It is because these banks are so-called ‘too big to fail’. Let me tell the Commission: these banks have already failed. They have failed their responsibility to society, and we need to hold them accountable. In the Danske Bank case alone, transactions worth more than the entire state budget of Denmark are now under suspicion of money laundering. So, President Juncker and Commission, we need not only to talk tough on holding banks accountable, we need to be tough on the banks.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, jobs and growth, this was the key slogan of the Commission a few years ago and I wonder if all of us still remember that. The world has changed and sometimes it has changed for the better actually. Despite, too, the unfortunate decision of the people of the United Kingdom, the position of the European Union in the world has strengthened significantly and now the European Union represents the hopes and visions of hundreds of millions of people all around the world.  But the successes of the past belong in the past; what counts is the future and the way that we will tackle the challenges and the problems of today will decide the future of our Union, of our continent, and the list of these problems is demanding – migration, security, economic problems, foreign policy, tax issues and environment are among those on the list – but we shouldn’t forget, and this is what Mr Juncker has said, that unity, cooperation and solidarity is what we are decided on to succeed and we shouldn’t forget it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, please remind our President Juncker that we very much appreciated his plaidoyer for a sovereign Europe, but also for a Europe in which the euro is fully functioned, to perform all its functions, and above all the strength with which it has proposed the application of the bridging clause. We would have liked an answer from the Council. However, I would also like to mention the economic crisis that has bent our continent in recent years, which has lengthened the gap between rich and poor, and that is why our first priority should be to work for a more equal Europe. We need to rebuild the sense of community. We must combat the sense of loneliness in which many Europeans live. We need to think about a measure for European children, one against unemployment, one against wage differences between men and women.  In short, the European social pillar must be at the heart of european policies of the future. Only in this way could we counter people like Orbán and the many of his epigoni that we have heard.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for What a difference! Let us compare yesterday's speech on the rule of law, democracy and fundamental values with Jean-Claude Juncker's speech: one ignores the idea of Europe and divides. The other makes the idea of Europe a programme, a response to the challenges – European and global – of our time, and it unites. Thank you, Jean-Claude Juncker!  But we also see in comparison what blockages, attitudes, ignorance we still have to overcome in order to be able to fully implement Juncker's legacy. Let us start with the votes today!  European democracy is more than the sum of national democracies and a rejection of authoritarian democracy. The EU must establish European sovereignty and become the continent's effective, efficient, credible spokesman in the world.  I therefore support the analysis, every objective, every proposal without compromise. Let us eliminate unanimity in the legislative process! Let us parliamentise all decisions! Let us speed up the procedure so that we can take a concrete step forward on every matter before the election. The political will to unite can make a big difference. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr Karas, you appreciated Mr Juncker's speech. I appreciated him, too. Among other things, Mr Juncker said that we wanted a Union of peace and prosperity. I am interested in your opinion, because you have not expressed your point of view now. What do you think: can we have peace and prosperity without cohesion? Do you agree that it is being cut from the Cohesion Fund? At least that is the Commission's proposal in the next year to cut back on cohesion funds. How will we have prosperity and how will we have understanding in the internal market?

name: Othmar Karas (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report, You cannot answer all the questions in a minute. But the fact is that the rule of law, that respect for values and the fulfilment of the objectives can also bring us more peace, freedom, prosperity and security. The budget negotiations will be tough because the demands on the EU require more money, require more solidarity than the current budget proposal represents. And there is a great discrepancy between the Commission, the Council and Parliament. Everyone must leap forward over their shadow sobs in order for the Juncker programme to be implemented.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I address President Juncker. Once again, you have made a good speech – groundbreaking, pro-European and full of good intentions – as you have done so many times. Unfortunately, however, there is often a large gap between the promise and what is then implemented. In 2015, you promised a functioning European border management system here. Three years later, we have to say that we have not made any progress, and the redistribution of refugees has also been difficult to get under way – not only because individual Member States have blocked, but also because many things have been approached only half-heartedly and hesitantly at Commission level. Recently, we have been getting information that the international community's refugee programmes are chronically underfunded, that schools need to be closed. You have made interesting proposals today, which we are happy to discuss. But I would remind you that it is also a question of doing the homework and ensuring sufficient funding for capacity in our neighbourhood. Otherwise, the same thing will happen as in 2015.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: Mr President, I will speak Dutch because I know that the President of the European Commission understands that and because I actually want to tell him something personal today. I have been here for four years in this debate on the state of the Union, saying what I did not like and what I was criticising. I would like to thank the Commission and the President of the Commission today, because I see someone who, from the bottom of his heart – in Dutch we say 'from his toes' – always advocates for a common European solution, even if he does not have the zeitgeist.  Take the subject of migration: the whole of Europe is crying out for better protection of our external borders. The European Commission is proposing 10 000 border guards and, for example, a better, faster and more effective deportation and return policy. And you can already hear the reactions on the flanks. What's that going to cost? Who's going to pay for that? Does that not remove the powers of the Member States? And who will end up being blamed if nothing happens? Europe and the European Commission first! The debate on the state of the Union is above all a call for a sense of responsibility and leadership. I hope that they will be shown, and I thank the European Commission for at least setting a good example.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am grateful for the area of self-criticism that Mr Juncker has used in his speech, recognising the problems that the European project is going through. In this time it has lacked courage and courage, it has lacked leadership to catch the helm of the European Union and not allow drift. But despite some populists and the far right, Europe is still more alive than ever and more necessary also to meet challenges. A strong Europe that assumes common positions and solidarity to meet the challenge of immigration and restore dignity to our project. A Europe capable of translating economic growth into social justice and sharing, ensuring strong welfare states. A Europe capable of tacking the fight against climate change. A Europe with a woman's face, which ends gender-based violence and is able to move towards more egalitarian societies. In short, a Europe that gives us back the pride of belonging to a space of encounter of coexistence and respect. A strong Europe makes us all and all more united.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Juncker’s speech lasted 53 minutes and 14 seconds; it was well received, and rightly so. In it, you referred, Mr Juncker, to the Juncker Plan, which was so successful in helping us get over the economic recovery that they no longer call it the Juncker Plan, and as the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy rapporteur for its successor InvestEU, I hope that can be equally successful. I think you also deserve great credit for negotiating with the wayward Donald Trump, helping to avoid a trade war, and that was much appreciated by businesses across Europe, especially in my own country, which relies so much on trade with the US. In mentioning my own country, Ireland, I thank you again for expressing total solidarity with Ireland, and especially the need to avoid a hard border.  I would appeal to you though to accompany that with a financial commitment to help businesses, farmers and SMEs, which are inevitably going to be affected one way or the other as a consequence of Brexit. You quoted the French philosopher, saying he liked things to go together. If that solidarity went together with financial commitment, I would be very pleased, especially before the elections, because we all see that it is easier and easier to win elections by bashing Brussels. This would help to prevent that.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Madam President, we truly believe and support the European Union and believe that this European Union has both a future and a prospect. We fully agree with the President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker, that we need a strong European Union. However, in order for a strong European Union to exist, it must defend, defend and safeguard the sovereign rights of its Member States and, at the same time, defend principles and values. In a strong European Union we cannot discount and the European Union cannot continue to discount acceding countries, such as Turkey which does not respect and recognise sovereign rights of Member States. If we are really in a Union of Law, as the President quite rightly said, it must defend the sovereign rights of Member States that are currently threatened by Turkey by taking measures towards Turkey. European citizens expect the President of the European Commission to raise his voice and call on Turkey or respect the sovereign rights of Cyprus and Greece or to suffer, in real life, as is the case with other countries. Closing...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mr President, the alarms are set. The European landscape is not encouraging when the far right grows, hand in hand with a xenophobic, nationalist and populist discourse that goes against the fundamental values of the European Union. And I'm worried about the lack of a speech to counter it. I am more concerned when words are not accompanied by facts, or when we move forward at a turtle's pace. We defend cohesion, but we have little resources or we cut the CAP and cohesion policy. We are advocating to lead the fight against climate change, but emissions have increased this year, and the resources we are going to provide are cosmic. Mr President, if we want to engage with European citizenship, we must make words correspond to the facts, that equality is progressing and that the social pillar should also advance.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, we believe in the Europe of nations and homelands, in the Europe of peoples and not of banks, in a Europe that respects national identity and relies on subsidiarity. In this context, the member states' right of veto is a guarantee for the protection of national interests. At the euro area level, the Stability Pact, which allows Germany to have huge trade surpluses, should be abolished. The European Central Bank must become the ultimate lender of the Member States and, at the same time, there must be a decentralised System of Central Banks in order to regain the monetary sovereignty of the national states, which will be able to exercise their sovereignty on the basis of their share capital of the ECB. For Greece, I believe that there must be a special relationship, special arrangements, both permanent and transitional, so that Greece can breathe special arrangements in the field of energy, state aid, shipbuilding, tourism, transport, agriculture and livestock farming.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I am very pleased that you are offering European solutions to the challenges we face. Your proposals today were ambitious, but sometimes we can be even more ambitious and even more concrete. I would like to give you some recommendations. As far as the qualified majority is concerned, I think we need to go wider than just foreign policy. As far as security and defence policy is concerned, I would like to reiterate our plea here for a genuine European intelligence service in the fight against terror. As far as asylum and migration are concerned, I would like to hear from you that you are stepping up the fight against people smugglers and that you are protecting unaccompanied child asylum seekers and ensuring that they no longer disappear in Europe. As far as your personal battle point is concerned, the abolition of summer and winter time, I follow you there. Let us abolish this changeover, let us listen to the voice of the citizen and opt for daylight saving time, and let us do so quickly. Finally, we support you! Carry out the achievements, continue to fight for peace and make Sure That Europe acts faster to silence the populists.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, 11.50am: Strasbourg time, 10.45am: in Portugal, Ireland or the Canary Islands. This should also be time in Galicia. Mr Juncker's proposed change of time today is an opportunity for countries that have a time zone that is not adapted to the Greenwich meridian. This time was proposed by Francoism to adapt the time to Nazi Germany. It's time to change. In Galicia, the gap between the official time and the solar hour is two and a half hours. This gap has consequences for health and quality of life and also in my work. I sent the letter to Commissioner Juncker to explain this situation and to help streamline schedules in Europe.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, President Juncker, who belongs to the European People's Party, has spoken as a European democrat about the future. Yesterday, Mr Orbán, who also belongs to the European People's Party, told us about a Europe that is returning to the past. We choose the first one. I thank President Juncker for what he has said positively about my country, Greece. I hope everyone in Athens will hear it - and the opposition parties that are engaged in a miserable disaster. I believe that we need to do everything possible to build the broadest possible alliance of pro-European progressive forces, to avoid the risks of regression expressed by far-right, anti-European, anti-democratic populism.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, I have listened carefully to your speech again this year, and the first comment that came to mind is a quote from The Leopard: 'everything must change if everything is to remain as it is'. Yes, because even today the mistakes are repeated: his gaze and his efforts go decisively to the instruments and not to the policies that govern them. Deploying 10 000 European border agents as a solution to the tragic migration crisis, without first reviewing and overcoming the current Dublin Regulation, without a compulsory preventive and permanent redistribution of asylum seekers, but also of the management of economic migrants, will transform this deployment into a mere instrument for the forced execution of anachronistic, inadequate and, above all, deeply unfair rules. Can't Dublin be changed to 27? Take note of that. Instead, support the idea of enhanced cooperation, and the Commission rewards states with enormous financial and material support that they will show solidarity in deeds and not just in words. If only he had the same courage he has with daylight saving time... Time runs fast and cannot be recovered. You decide how you want to be reminded: whether like the Commission of courage or the Commission by regret.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, in his speech Mr Juncker tried to make good on what is really happening in Europe today. He spoke, for example, of a united Europe. We believe and fight for the Europe of the peoples and nations who will cooperate with each other. But how can this Union exist when it seeks to reduce national sovereignty? When, instead of compromise and transaction, a state is persecuted because it wants to defend the interests of its people? How can there be a united Europe when the principle of unanimity is abolished and a multi-speed Europe is created? Is immigration policy a success when some states close their borders and Greece has been transformed into a vast concentration camp for unhappy illegal immigrants? Is there success in social policy when there is unemployment and impoverishment of peoples? Finally, is there a prospect in Europe when it wants to become a global gendarme to supposedly go after terrorists everywhere?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, President of the Commission, I am very glad that you have finally been able to compare the priorities for the Commission's work as we, the citizens of Central and Eastern Europe, see security as a real priority. I also agree with your emphasis on cooperation with Africa, which is crucial. With the strengthening of Frontex: I have seen for myself the need for these coastguard and border guard protection components to be strengthened, those 10,000 workers can help. I also appreciate you highlighting the need to protect human rights in China, it was the first time I have heard this from you. I wish that the new President of the European Commission would not celebrate Marx and trust Putin less. The Commission you led, Mr President, has done a great deal of work and I want to thank you for that. But it should also be recalled that this Commission has certain rests that will need to be rectified.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, President Juncker has expressed love for the history of Europe. I share it, but I would have liked there to be greater resonance of the Ninth Symphony in his speech and less of Beethoven's Pathetic Sonata, because new legislation cannot be proposed when the law in force has not been enforced, nor to ensure that the legislation already put in place finally sees the light of day. Because the collapse, in the area of freedom, justice and security, of mutual trust is what explains the failure of the Euroorder. But President Juncker has also hurt the absence of legal avenues to cope with migration flows. And there are many of us in this Parliament who have been working to open legal avenues, humanitarian visas. In the Visa Code, in the parliamentary report and in our resolutions we have been stressing the need for these legal avenues without the Commission's support or commitment to the Council's resistance.  That is why, before the 'Commission of the Last Opportunity', the 2019 elections are an existential test so that neither nationalism nor europhobia cannot win out of the incompensence of those of us who must avoid it. The Commission's responsibility is invaluable.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, as much as Mr Juncker is trying to smooth the situation in the Union, the situation is constantly getting worse and the economic, political and institutional crisis is deepening every day. The deepening and institutionalisation of the same neoliberal policies have led people to unemployment and poverty, tore apart the social state, deregulated labour relations and made climate change more pronounced. As a result, we now have a continuous widening of economic, social and regional disparities. It is these neoliberal policies that are lubricating the ground for the rise of the far right and it is a fact that unfortunately leads the forces of the Right to adopt racist and xenophobic rhetoric and politics. The situation will become even more dangerous as militarisation and investment in wars are promoted, which is also the main cause of the refugee flow, a Fortress Europe with permanent military structures and new fences at internal and external borders. In order to have hope, we must reverse these policies and work for a Europe of peoples, social justice, solidarity and peace.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support It is regretting that, unlike the clock change, the Western Balkans region was no longer a priority in President Juncker's speech this year. Once again, it ignores the need for consistent messages and politics about the area. Unfortunately, the attitude of some Member States and party associations is also inconsistent with regard to the Belgrade-Pristina dialogue. For years, the EU has been demanding solutions from the parties to speed up integration processes. In return, the attitudes of some EU Member States only reinforce the status quo.  Member States should help the parties, not fear for their own political convenience, and scare themselves and others with recent events. The proposals of the parties concerned should not be rejected without listening carefully to their arguments. In recent days, we have witnessed the fact that, due to the lack of unified support, the parties have once again thresed on the road to a deal. The Balkans cannot be held hostage by some hesitant EU Member States, as it could threaten the security of the whole region and of Europe as a whole.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: – President Juncker, Commissioner Timmermans, I agree with what you have said: we need a united Europe, a monetary unity, patriotism. What I have done in the European Parliament should be done by every MEP. The European Parliament, these days, has vibrated Romanian folk songs and dances. We need a Europe of solidarity. I agree that we must defend Europe's external borders, but how can we defend them if Romania, which is on Europe's external border, is not a Schengen member? You, mePs, and you, Mr President, must help Romania, because it has fulfilled all the conditions to become a Schengen member. On the other hand, Romania will take over the presidency of the Council of the European Union next year. For this, Romania must be a Schengen member and for this it must be respected by each country. A country's problem, Mr President, is, in fact, a problem for the whole of Europe.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I agree with the President of the Commission that the European Union must strengthen its own global role. We have influence internationally in trade policy, through international agreements, development cooperation and investment. Europe can make a significant contribution to global development if we are united. At the moment, the unity of the European Union is eroded by the worrying divestile of some Member States from the fundamental values of the European Union. The violation of these fundamental values, namely democracy, human rights and the rule of law, affects not only the Member State concerned and its citizens, but affects all member states, it affects relations between Member States, our confidence and the nature of the European Union as a whole. That is why this needs to be seriously addressed. The European Parliament held a debate on this yesterday. It is important that we have effective instruments to address this worrying development of the rule of law, which unfortunately is currently going on in some EU Member States. The European Union can only act when everyone respects common values, commitments that have been made.

name: Răzvan Popa (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I appreciate Mr Juncker's speech, balanced and responsible. The need for solidarity is now felt more than ever in this time of challenge. But it left me with a bitter taste the attitude of Mr Weber, who, through his speech, only weakened the European project and thickened the ranks of eurosceptics. A divisive speech. It is the exact opposite of what we all want, and exactly what President Juncker also pointed out. Mr Weber, Romania deserves to enter the Schengen area, because Romania has fulfilled all its obligations to Europe, and Romanian citizens have equal rights with other European citizens. The way in which you and other colleagues attacked Romania only weaken the confidence of Romanian citizens in the European project. Unfortunately, Mr Weber, you have turned the popular Europeans into European populists.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to thank President Juncker for the kind words and praise he had to say about the sacrifices of the Greeks to stay in the euro. But the real recognition of the labors of all citizens takes place when Europe takes steps to improve everyday life. In the 250 days we have until the European elections, we need to vote on the 2020-2027 budget because the delay will leave cohesion programmes and competitive programmes, such as Erasmus and Horizon Europe, without funding. We need to move on to the single asylum system. With the 10 000 additional border guards, of course, that we are announcing today, we are strengthening the guarding of European borders. But we need updated and integrated procedures on migration. Finally, we need to make use of the European Union's flagship policies, such as defence and tackling climate change. We need immediate results that can directly affect citizens.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I too want to appreciate the presentation made by President Juncker. It's one we need: unity, prosperity. As colleagues have said, we also need a transposition into practice. But I cannot fail to add that, unfortunately, at the stage that has been taken so far, we have not been able to achieve that cohesion. I want to thank Mr Bullmann, who has made it very clear that we need to take into account the countries of the East. Our problem is to have this social cohesion, growth, prosperity, so that we can also have peace in the European Union and equity. And that is why I hope, Commissioner, that you – who know my country well – will take into account what my colleagues have said, namely: Romania should enter the Schengen area and Romania will be well treated, because, in the end, we have the same entry card in this very nice club, the European Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this debate has resulted in an exercise in cynicism, propaganda and mystification. The logic of the commitment to defend the end of the unanimity rule was praised, thus further reinforcing the decision-making power of the main powers.  The European sovereignty of which they speak is the sovereignty of these powers, the power to set and dispose and to impose their interests and the interests of their economic and financial groups. Military spending associated with the Defence Fund has increased more than twenty-fold, but Mr. Juncker has been undoing the case to say that there is no militarisation here.  Young people who the European Union pushes for unemployment, underemployment or precariousness in life and work, serve doses of enhanced propaganda. It is a case to say, they are given the honour of mannequin to wind up their absence and thus a process of exhausted integration without solutions to the problems it creates itself, a process whose defeat is a condition for building another Europe, a Europe of workers and peoples, a Europe of peace and cooperation.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, Mr Juncker's speech and slogan on 'European Union world leader' aims to shield the interests of European monopolies against other powerful capitalist centres, such as the United States, China, Russia, in the context of competition for control of markets, energy sources, with special weight in Africa. The need to expand the interests of the European Union also leads to further militarization, whatever Mr Juncker says, and to the promotion of multilateral transnational cooperation, in fact, through special majorities. That's not all! A characteristic feature of the European Union and its governments are anti-labour surveillance mechanisms, long-term anti-labour measures for hard-working, recycled workers, the entrapment of migrants and the infiltration of Euro-EU funds into their home countries for even greater profits. This line is a strategically liberal social democrat of "new and old cutting". Nationalist forces are on the same bank. The European Union has neither been nor will it ever become a People's Europe. The peoples with their struggle to claim their own power and fight for release!

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Madam President, may I congratulate President Juncker on his final State of the Union speech and whilst many people will be congratulating you, Mr Juncker, on that and your vision for the future, I just thought it might be pertinent to remind you of what actually happened in Europe during your tenure.  On the economy, we have seen the collapse of many European countries. Youth unemployment in Greece sits at 43.2%, in Spain 38.8%, in Croatia 23.6%. In Greece the children of today’s grandchildren will still be paying off the 100 billion in debt that has been left upon them. Poverty, misery and sadness covers Europe like a dark mist of perpetual pain, whilst in the Mediterranean 45 000 bodies will have been buried there. You will have seen millions swarm into Europe illegally and you have seen the deaths of 400 in the terrorist attacks.  Whilst you and your fellow unelected colleagues raise a glass or two to the State of the Union, the rest of Europe will be asking, what is the Union’s state?

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, Mr Juncker, I found your State of the Union speech to be something particularly positive, namely that we can at least be sure that it will be your last. An ambitious and comprehensive programme, I read from your admirers everywhere, but in fact it is just a shopping list of what remains of the old Europe, the old European Union.  What we urgently need is a new European Union, because the current one has a flawed design, a flawed ground plan and a wrong blueprint. If progress in your view means that more powers should go to the EU, then you are wrong. More and more European citizens want a new European Union, in which the Member States and the peoples do not disappear, but are restored. In your ivory tower you have so beautifully divided the world into cosmopolitan, open-minded, itinerant, good people on the one hand and populist, narrow-minded, xenophobic, nationalist, bad people on the other. You, fanatical, extremist supporters of diversity, I therefore call on: accept the diversity of opinions and visions, put up your shopping list and make way for the new time!

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Madam President, Mr Juncker, Mr Timmermans, your mandate will soon come to an end, and it is fortunate for Europeans who will no longer have to undergo this two-headed Juncker-Selmayr presidency. Without a profound transformation of the ultraliberalism of the European Union, your Commission will continue to do great damage. Everywhere, your federalist European Union is in denial of reality and institutional lies. You say you want to strengthen the European border guards, but when France was France, the customs officer effectively controlled and secured our national borders. You also want the European Union to take control of the foreign policy of the Member States. However, foreign affairs are the last regal power and bastion of nations. You are gargling with European solidarity, but for the last 15 years, because of EU rules, your country has committed the worst acts of tax piracy against its partners. In the LuxLeaks scandal, your guilt is proven. Stop European disunity. I am against a Frexit, but also against your utopia of the United States of Europe. Europeans no longer want to suffer the planned Africanisation of Europe, Islamist terrorism, globalism and the plundering of their taxes by multinationals and GAFAM (Google, Amazon, Facebook, Apple, Microsoft). We need a European alliance of independent nations, which really protects peoples. We'll do it!

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Juncker, in his first response to our interventions as group chairmen, pointed out earlier that there are appropriate references in the Gothenburg process – and indeed in the Pillar of Social Rights – particularly when it comes to introducing appropriate conditions and guarantees for children in all the Member States of the European Union. I would like to point out that the Treaty certainly offers the possibility of also regulating the issue of minimum income throughout the EU, and that we should absolutely do so. There are initiatives in all Member States – particularly from the homeless, from poverty initiatives that are European-linked – to finally put this on the agenda, and we would be very pleased with a Commission initiative to introduce EU-wide minimum incomes and would think it would be important if this were to happen now.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, you can be a European patriot and a Finnish patriot. You can be a European patriot and a Hungarian patriot, but you can’t be a European patriot and a nationalist. That does not go together. Jean-Claude Juncker has spoken very nicely about his love affair with Europe. We all know that love affairs are difficult; that goes for European love affairs, that goes for Finnish love affairs and that goes for Hungarian love affairs, but love affairs need possibilities and an ability to make decisions. If we can’t make the decisions about our love affairs, we are going to lose out and therefore, I am all for love affairs but I am all for decisions and I thank Jean—Claude for his nice words about his love affair with Europe.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, at its heart, today’s State of the Union was actually an appraisal of the Commission, of us in this Parliament and of the whole European Union. Too often, when we are wrapped in our bubble of commentators’ blogs, news cycles and work programmes, we forget that it is the people, the taxpayers and the voters, that we serve and not the other way round. But we hear many in this Chamber tell voters that their concerns are unfounded, or that the way they have chosen to vote is nationalistic or populist. But by attempting to shut out parties that do not share their vision and do not believe in the project, they also shut up many voters and push them further away.  I know that Mr Juncker has worked very hard to regain the confidence of voters. But many people in many EU Member States feel that the EU has lost its way, that it has failed to deliver on issues such as jobs. It has failed to deliver on their concerns over migration; it has failed to deliver on them feeling safer in their home countries, and on the things that they care about. So when politicians here talk about winning back their confidence, it rings hollow to those that are still willing to listen, as they feel that they have heard it all before.  I remember only too well in 2014 as President Juncker addressed this Chamber full of freshly elected MEPs, he declared it to be a moment to be a new start for Europe and said that we should play as a team with common policies. Yet voters have seen attempts to push divisive migration policies that sadly, rather than helping people, have reduced sympathy in some quarters for refugees and those fleeing war and persecution, rather than going around the table and asking each country what they can do, rather than telling them what to do.  He spoke of greater transparency but the public read in the papers of the appointment of a Commission Secretary—General that was clouded in secrecy. He said that Europe cannot spend money that it does not have but they see a multiannual budget demanding more money at a time when one of the largest net contributors is leaving. He talked about considering giving the euro area its own budget capacity and powers but, as the people of Germany will tell you, there is no such thing as European money.  My Group agreed with Mr Juncker when he said: ‘we don’t need a European solution to everything’ and this is still the case. So European Conservatives and Reformists ask that this Commission President and future Commission Presidents listen to the people who have lost confidence in the EU.  I know at times that our Group can be the greatest critics, but real friends tell each other the hard truths and we work together where we agree. So the ECR calls on the Commission to start delivering the kind of European Union that people want and deserve. Not an EU which increasingly replaces national governments, not a European Union that is dismantled and destroyed, but a reformed European Union that Mr Juncker promised to deliver here in this Chamber five years ago. With vital elections next year, this is the eleventh hour for the EU. It is time to move on from the 1950s model of a federalised EU, an outdated vision of yesterday and it is time to deliver an EU shaped by the wishes of its peoples, those who want a better tomorrow.

name: Udo Bullmann
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This debate has shown that we need to increase citizens' confidence in the European Union. That is why I am addressing the Commission, the Commissioners.  I believe that this discussion must have consequences. Yes, we said that we need basic security for every child in the European Union. The President of the Commission has replied and said that he will take care to get an initiative started. I expect that. Yes, we have said that the workers on digital platforms must not become the new proletariat. We need to secure their status, their rights. We await your proposal.  In our view, it is absolutely unacceptable that in most countries of the European Union women earn less than men on average for the same work. When will the European Commission's proposal come? And yes, Mrs Zimmer is quite right: we need a framework directive to ensure a European minimum wage. This is urgently needed to balance the imbalances in the internal market gap.  When we say that we want the transformation to more sustainability, to a new economic model, then we must be able to read that in the semester of the European Union. The figures must tell the truth about environmental consumption, about social costs, about the effects of employment. Reform the European Semester and give the chance that we will finally make progress in economic and monetary union. That is what we need to make the euro zone capable of acting.  We have called on the Commission to take action against cybercrime. I like to hear this when President Juncker says that he wants to take initiatives. I appeal to the Austrian Presidency. They now have a special summit in September: they oblige all Member States to take the necessary steps to ensure that the next European elections are secure and cannot be manipulated by third parties. That is the order of the day.  We have also said that you, the Austrian Presidency of the Council, are responsible for taking effective steps at this special summit to ensure rescue at sea – which is a scandal that is what is happening there. I hope for their initiative!

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. Finally, I too would like to thank you for the constructive discussion we have had. We feel that we in the European Parliament are still in a working mode where we want to provide answers to the challenges. And it is precisely as the European Parliament that we can be proud of what we have presented and moved. One point is extremely important to us: we must be able to provide answers on the migration question in 2018. Otherwise, the citizens will ask us the question: why has nothing happened here? Why couldn't you get the issue off the road? That is why it is our top priority. Of the debates on the future, which are part of the State of the Union address, I would like to highlight two points that are important to us. The one thing is the security, the sense of security of the people. The second is fairness in Europe. A new approach to fairness in a digital world is key. Last but not least, Madam President, we had a debate in the first round of speeches as to whether or not we have already overcome the crises, whether or not we have already resolved them, whether we still have a great deal to do or not. I believe that we can only convince the people of Europe if we go out with optimism, if we tell them that we are capable of carrying out tasks, of solving tasks. And that is why I am proud of the successes we have.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed.  We will have a short recess and votes will begin at 12.30. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – No one calls into question the problems that the European project is going through. It's lacked courage and courage. It has lacked leadership to catch the helm hard and not allow this ship to drift. But the European Union is still alive and the European project is now more necessary than ever to meet the challenges of globalisation. A strong European Union, which assumes common and supportive positions to meet the challenge of immigration and refugees and thus restore dignity to our project. A European Union capable of translating economic growth into social justice and sharing to end poverty and ensure the welfare state. A leading European Union in the fight against climate change and the modernization of our production systems. A European Union with a woman's face, ending gender-based violence and moving towards a more egalitarian society. In short, a European Union that gives us back the pride of belonging to a space of encounter, respect and coexistence. Let us not give up on trying, because together we are better, because together we are stronger, because united we will have a future.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. – Jean-Claude Juncker, in the context of a very significant global intervention, stressed the need to continue on the path of concluding trade agreements with other regions of the world. That statement deserves my full agreement. What is already deeply concerned about me is the fact that we do not move resolutely towards the implementation of the political and trade agreement that we have been negotiating with Mercosur for too many years. I do not think there will be another set of countries with greater cultural, political, economic and social proximity to the EU. For a long time the responsibility for the delays observed in the negotiation process fell on latin american countries. However, at the moment, I believe that the greatest responsibilities are some European states and in some way the European Commission itself. The European Commissioner for Agriculture has acted more as an Irish citizen and less as a European Commissioner. The President of the Commission should have already realised this and acted in line. Unfortunately, it has not yet done so, although it maintains the expectation that it will still be able to do so. This Trade Treaty is of the greatest interest to both regions and there is no valid reason why it should not be completed in a short period of time.

name: Monika Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – Unlike last year, the President of the European Commission, Juncker, had only a general speech full of non-specific phrases. Probably in the context of the forthcoming Brexit, he sought to emphasise the need for unity of the Union. At the same time, it is precisely the faster settlement of the pay gap between the old and the new Member States of the European Union that could increase confidence in the integration project in many countries. In fact, a significantly different wage for equal work in individual countries does not contribute to the stability of the EU. It is legitimate that citizens of several Member States, including Slovakia, expect the Commission, in cooperation with the leaders of the nation states, to develop legislation that will promote wage growth in the eastern part of the Union. The Report of the President of the Commission also did not sufficiently address the issues of further strengthening economic cooperation and growth or developing countries' cooperation in the field of European security. Above all, it is in our interest to build a stronger and more consolidated Union that is better able to adapt to people's needs and take their demands into account consistently.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. In just over eight months' time, millions of European citizens will be going to the polls to pass judgment on Europe. It will be a referendum, and if even a state such as Sweden has seen the rise of sovereignists in the recent elections, it means that, over and above Europe's responsibilities, the wind of fear and uncertainty could affect the outcome of the next election. Europe is short of breath because its policies are not far-sighted. In this parliamentary term, progress has only been made in environmental matters and perhaps in military cooperation, but if, in times of crisis, priority is given to free trade relations with third countries rather than to the construction of effective welfare, it means deliberately deciding to create a europe of several speeds. And it has not been understood that no one should fall behind because either we walk side by side or the European dream does not exist because pockets of marginalisation are created in which it is nowhere near imaginable. I do not know whether the European results will reflect the results of the national elections, but the wind cannot be stopped with our bare hands: we need concrete proposals for work, the economy and immigration.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – President Juncker's State of the Union address presented an extensive letter of intent, which I generally agree with. I am sorry, however, that it will come just six months before the end of this parliamentary term. It is a good thing to strengthen the Coast guard and border guard and revive proposals for integrated border management. But I warn of the need to do so consistently with the necessary changes in the asylum and return system. I agree with the priorities for the end of the Brexit negotiations, but I believe that safeguarding the rights of European citizens in the UK should be the first compromise. I follow the ambition to strengthen the internationalisation of the euro, but I believe that we need to deepen the reforms of the single currency in order to achieve economic and monetary union, promote more growth and jobs and reduce public debt. I share the ambition to speed up the Union's foreign policy through changes in the decision-making process, notably in the majority system. I hope that the implementation of permanent structured cooperation will be fulfilled. I welcome the priority given to Africa in the future of the Union's external action.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. The current crises are increasingly becoming a test for the EU: the shocks of the financial and debt crisis have not yet been overcome, the refugee issue poses enormous difficulties for the EU, Brexit is causing consternation, populism is challenging the EU construct. Europe is currently facing a wide range of challenges that put cohesion to the test. What are the long-term paths to the crisis? And what about the future of the EU as a whole? The President of the Commission has replied: we need more European sovereignty. I can only agree with that: the EU's population is 7% of the world's population. And global competition has one interest in common: a weak Europe. We have something to do with that. We need a clear understanding of our own role as Europeans in global developments, but also in relations within the EU.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "I'm not a pessimist, but the image depicted in State of the Union is far from reality. President Juncker spoke of solidarity, while ignoring the nord stream-2 project, which perfidiously breaks that solidarity. He gently talked about Syria, completely ignoring the issues of responsibility for the genocide carried out there, the silence about Russian aggression against Ukraine, the occupation of Georgia and Moldova, the attacks in Salisbury and the increased espionage activities, or Russian propaganda against Western societies and institutions. Instead, he proposed qualified majority voting in some areas of external policy. How can we talk about a common perception of threats when, even in such clearly expressive times, the real threats from the East in the most important speech are ignored by silence? I am also against the proposal to vote on tax matters by qualified majority.
