name: Czesław Hoc (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Speaking today in the debate on the State of the European Union, I would like to recall this important motto which was to guide this community: 'United in diversity'. In today's debate in Strasbourg, EC President J.C Juncker also stressed 'Europe must speak with one voice'! Meanwhile, the European reality is quite different! From everywhere - double standards! "European" Matrix! The Eurocrats are therefore calling for the centralisation of Europe, the creation of a super-state, and not a Europe of homelands and a Europe of nation states. When forced to relocate refugees has not worked, it now wants to be financially penalisation for not accepting refugees, despite ensuring the sovereignty of individual EU countries. There are proposals to vote by qualified majority on foreign policy issues, which will only increase the division of Europe. When, on the one hand, the importance of diversification of energy sources is emphasised, the much-needed European solidarity is buried 'at the bottom of the Baltic Sea' by agreeing to the Nord-Stream I and II northern gas pipelines. Unfortunately, these examples could still be multiplied, so I will just conclude with the question: Quo Vadis, Europo?

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Europe is in worse shape today than it was at the beginning of the millennium. The economic crisis may have been left behind by the Union, and the migration crisis has eased, but in the meantime, a crack has created that is now splitting Europe into a chasm. The gap between the poor and the rich has increased, the consequences of which can be felt in national and European politics: populism has risen, and several countries, like my own country, have begun to replace their democratic values with small daily political benefits. Unfortunately, orban's pattern is sticky, against which neither the Barroso nor the Juncker Commission has acted decisively. Today, Viktor Orban's policies have become an example to follow in many countries: he has grown before our eyes into a European movement: Poland, Slovenia, Italy are on the path paved by Viktor Orban. As the political fight in Europe becomes increasingly bitter, the essential questions remain unanswered: the Commission has not acted decisively to help social groups that are dotted, it has not done enough for freedom of the press, it has not moved towards transparency and to combat corruption. Nor has a common solution been found to the refugee situation. This process may not be reversible, but the only way that can be successful is for the Union to take small steps towards a more transparent, cleaner, freer and more united Europe, taking into account European values and focusing on the rights of European citizens.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Modernising education plays a key role in the debate on the state and future of the Union. Education must take its rightful place on the political agenda at EU and national level. Although education is a competence of the Member States, we are all responsible for the future of Europeans, and this future will depend on their knowledge, competences and skills.  Furthermore, the achievement of the Union's economic and social objectives, as well as its competitiveness and sustainable development, are closely linked to high-quality education. We should take as a key objective ensuring equal access to quality education for all. It is then essential to harness the potential of new information and communication technologies and innovation to modernise the teaching and learning process. In turn, personalisation of education and improvement of teacher status should be the main objectives of education policy.  Finally, Mr President, I will refer to budgetary issues. I call on the Member States to fulfil their commitments to invest in education, research and development. I also believe that these measures should be deducted when calculating the national deficit in order to encourage more investment in the most important sector for the future of Europeans, namely education.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. Mr. President, I'm going to have to Juncker spoke of a strong Europe that acts as a guarantor of peace, which is considered a major achievement. However, what is at stake in today's treaties is a strong European Union that acts as a true guarantor of the rule of law and the well-being of European citizens throughout its territory and ensures that the judgments of the European Courts are implemented in practice. To do this, the EU must be prepared to use its lobbying tools impartially. For example, (a) sanctions were imposed against Russia for the invasion of Crimea, but the breakdown of the rule of law within Turkey and the continued illegal occupation of Territory of Cyprus are being neglected, and an upgrade of Turkey-EU trade relations is also proposed. (b) The European Banking Union remains without a pan-European deposit guarantee providing the same protection to European citizens. (c) Finally, the opinion of European citizens must become more important in order to have a future.

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE)
text: Writing. – In my opinion, the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, said there was a bit of a lack of energy and an assessment of his mistakes, while a bit too much was optimistic. The phrase 'The Europe that protects' has become Mr Juncker's motto and should be our common objective. I therefore welcome Mr Juncker's proposal to continue strengthening the European External Borders and Coast Guard Agency by providing an additional 10 000 border guards by 2020. However, the question of whether and how this promise can be implemented in such a short time is unanswered, because the previous mandate of the Agency has not yet been fully implemented and this proposal would require serious investment and support from EU Member States. The rapid return of illegal migrants, which has hitherto been a stumbling block in the Member States, is also essential to strengthen security. These are proposals that would have been liked more quickly, as they would have saved many painful insights into the process of solving migration and integration problems.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. – I want to say that Juncker's speech disappointed me a bit today. If I could sublimate my impressions, then I would compare it to last year's, when everything was bursting with optimism. Contrary to last year's speech, this one was quite lukewarm and did not use it to properly round out in a kind of political will what was happening during his tenure. If we were to draw the line under Juncker's mandate, we can see two things clearly. He found the European Union reeling from the economic, financial and social crisis. He can say that after his mandate, the EU has been fully economically recovered. For more than 20 quarters, europe's economy has been growing, 12.5 million jobs have been created since 2012, youth unemployment is at a record low. But it should be said that it leaves the Union in a political crisis. I expected Juncker to be more reassessed in the roots of the political crisis, but he did not do so. They will have to leave the debate on the future of the EU to those to come.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. – There were a few things I would like to appreciate in the State of the Union speech by the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker. These include, for example, highlighting the need to maintain a healthier planet for future generations, the need for deeper relationship building with the countries of the Western Balkans, protection in the manipulation of citizens on the Internet, integration in the defence field, cooperation with Africa, and long-term solutions to the migration issue. What I can agree with, however, is the fact that even the next President of the Commission, towards the end of his career, was unable to put forward a proposal to increase the transparency of his office. Specifically, change the process of comitology, which lacks democratic legitimacy. But we would probably expect too much from a president whose office is linked to the controversial professional growth of his right hand. I am very disappointed that it is Mr Juncker, who defends the need to combat climate change every year, who has not been able to live up to his commitment for the entire length of his presidency, to ensure sufficient funding in this area. If President Juncker wants to talk about protecting the next generation, I think it is crucial that the Commission ensures that substances whose safety we do not have enough information about are not maintained on the European market, that the precautionary principle is not violated and that the emergency authorisation of pesticides is not overused. I believe that if the Commission wants to guarantee the protection of Europeans, it should start by protecting their health.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. It is time to take time to make use of the remaining months to deliver on the promises made to Europeans! We must take advantage of the coming months, and all the EU institutions must take the turbo off. Citizens expect more than a discussion from the EU about how the clocks should tick. There are still 250 days left to finalise urgent legislation. The digital tax must now be a breakthrough. Big Internet companies, such as Facebook, Google & Co., must finally pay their taxes! The ball is in the Member States' way. I fully support the proposal to abolish unanimity in the Council on tax matters. We see that nothing else will go in the direction of tax justice, even under the Austrian Presidency. It prefers to make policy for the corporations. Unfortunately, today's speech on social Europe was forgotten. Europe will be, or will not be, social. The Children's Guarantee aims to give every child in Europe access to free healthcare, education and care, decent housing and adequate nutrition. This is a clear mandate for the European Union to act. Juncker loves Europe. But we Social Democrats are fighting for a Europe to fall in love with!

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Commission must be big on the big things, and act only where it can achieve better results than Member States acting alone”. So said President Juncker at the beginning of his Commission’s term in 2014. While agreeing with this approach, I believe that as of today, it has not happened. If there were attempts in that direction, they were insufficient to correct the weaknesses of the Union. On big things like addressing the migration crisis, social cohesion, economic and social imbalances, the Union was not decisive in the last 5 years. Most targets set in the Europe-2020-Strategy remain only on paper. We were told that “more Europe” is the solution. This has increased citizens’ expectations. One year before the European elections, citizens still find themselves distant from what happens in Brussels. In a world where globalisation is valued, perhaps, only for economic purposes, citizens are not finding their request for better representation in the European institutions, but in national political fora. Which is why populism in many EU countries has progressed so much. It will not be countered by establishing new layers of institutions or policies. What we should work for is a genuine, shared political consolidation of a few key priorities.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – In his speech, the President of the European Commission stressed the importance of European unity for peacekeeping and further economic growth. However, unity also means responsibility and mutual solidarity. It is detrimental to be disturbed on one side by populists and by some damaging proposals from the European Commission itself.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – According to the statement of the President of the European Commission, the European Council, which will take place in Sibiu in May 2019, must provide a clear vision of the future of the European Union. In this context, Mr Juncker made a key point: until this European Council in Sibiu, Member States should reach a consensus on the size of the Union budget for the period 2021-2027. He rejects the ideas of some heads of state who say that only after the elections to the European Parliament (in May 2019) can this consensus be reached. President Juncker is right, because no European regulation on European policies (whether it is cohesion policy or agricultural policy, etc.) can be negotiated without consensus on the size of the European Union's multiannual budget.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – Four years ago, I myself was one of those Members who voted in favour of the Juncker Commission programme because of its policy programme, which strengthens the unity, international weight and competitiveness of the EU and promises greater social security and social justice for its citizens. However, it is at these points that I am experiencing the greatest shortcomings that threaten the unity of the EU, exploited by the nationalist populists of some Member States (unfortunately led by the current leadership of my own country).  Therefore, in the remainder of the Mandate of the Commission and of the EP, in addition to the reform of the common migration policy, I would expect initiative and results from the European Commission mainly on two issues: - In order to promote the important principles and objectives adopted in the Gothenburg Declaration, the Commission must now use proactive, targeted plans to force Member States to act in order to achieve the concrete European value and achievement that is most tangible to European citizens, Social Europe.  - The escalating security challenges in the UNION environment and the changed Euro-Atlantic relationship call for a strong and autonomous European security identity and capabilities, which presupposes the swift and effective preparatory and organising work of the Commission and the USSR. The remaining few months will also require more concrete results and renewals to rebuild eu unity, including counteracting destructive efforts to challenge the chances of a united Europe, which would limit the EP's election campaign to the fear-monstred limits of anti-migration-terrorism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – In this debate, the logic of compromise was praised in order to defend the end of the unanimity rule, thereby further strengthening the decision-making power of the great powers. The "European sovereignty" they speak of is the sovereignty of these powers, the power to stand and dispose of, and to impose their interests and the interests of their economic and financial groups. Military spending associated with the Defence Fund increases more than 20-fold, but Mr. Juncker has the disdain to say that there is no militarisation here. Young people - who european union policies push for unemployment, underemployment and precariousness at work and in life - serve propaganda in enhanced doses. "They give them the honor of mannequin, to wind up their absence." Thus, a process of exhausted integration goes on, without solutions to the problems it creates. A process whose defeat is a condition for the construction of another Europe, of workers and peoples, of peace and cooperation.

name: Kristina Winberg (ECR)
text: in writing. – A word of advice is needed for those who advocate an ever-expanding EU in terms of both territory and competencies. The EU that most citizens had the chance to vote for is not that which has emerged over the past 15 years: therefore, this expansion must cease. Furthermore, the EU has an obligation to ensure the integrity of its external border in order for Member States to be able to uphold law and order, which is a prerequisite for the contract between citizens and the EU itself. Should that contract be broken – and it has been broken – then trust in the Union will decrease. The cultural absorption level has already been exceeded in all the Member States that had unchecked mass migration during recent decades. Mass migration to the EU must cease, and support must be provided so that the vast majority of migrants who have arrived are supported to return in a dignified manner, integrate effectively in their home countries and be enabled to become vehicles of democratic change. If European notions, values and ideals are not to be changed irrevocably, or indeed lost, in the near future a migration moratorium is needed.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The last year of the current European Commission's term of office cannot be a transitional or end-of-cycle year. It has to be a year of action and strong motivation to strengthen and support all those who strive for a More United, More Ambitious and Closer European Union to citizens, and to weaken all those who promote undemocratic populism to weaken the European project. This action implies the creation of conditions for the adoption of a Multiannual Financial Framework that promotes competitiveness, convergence and cohesion. It also involves bold actions to address the global challenges facing the European Union such as trade war, security and defence, and protection against new technological risks. It finally implies the ability to respond to the wishes of European citizens by defining a solidarity and transparent migration management policy, fostering the skills needed to generate more and better jobs in emerging society and ending economic and monetary union to prevent new financial crises such as the one that followed the subprime crisis in the United States of America.

name: Presidente. –
text: At the opening of the sitting on Monday 10 September, decisions were announced by several committees to open interinstitutional negotiations under Rule 69c(1). I would like to inform you that I have received requests from the EFDD and ENF Groups to put to the vote the decision of the LibE Committee to open interinstitutional negotiations on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council adopting the list of third countries whose nationals must be in possession of a visa when crossing the external borders and the list of countries exempt from this obligation (Kosovo). The rapporteur is Mr Beazley. Tanja Fajon. With regard to the other decisions to open interinstitutional negotiations, I have not received requests for a vote in this House from a number of Members or from one or more political groups at least equal to the average threshold. ***

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to take 30 seconds to discuss with you a value that should not be foreign to you, I mean here the duty to interfere. What is it about? In any democracy, when a citizen, let alone an elected official, finds that the right is violated, he has a duty to intervene and react. That is what I and six other colleagues did when you and your services commandeered the interpreters, thus violating all international rights to strike. Still, you've decided, you've stubbornly punished us. But our individual case is not very serious; what is serious is that you have trampled on the democracy, the law and the values of solidarity that Mr Juncker was talking about earlier. What is serious and lamentable is that through your sanction you disgrace this Institution.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Martin, I imposed the penalty because I enforced the Rules of Procedure. I would remind you that you, together with other Members, arbitrarily interrupted Parliament's work for over forty minutes. So I imposed a penalty equal to the third of the maximum that can be imposed. It is, of course, your right to have recourse to the Bureau and the Bureau, which will decide what is to be done. With regard to the fact that I dishonour Parliament, as an honest person, I have never trampled on democracy and the last choice I made was to give up the EUR 3 600 pension I was entitled to as European Commissioner, I believe I have honoured the European Parliament and democracy in this way. I hope you will do the same when you leave this Parliament.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Yesterday, during the debate on the state of democracy and the rule of law in Hungary, something scandalous happened: Mr Flanagan called Prime Minister Orban 'rubbish'. Once again, the Lord, the 'chief censor' who wanted to close his mouth to Mr Korwin-Mikke, did not react to this or even apologise on behalf of this House to Prime Minister Orban. I believe that this exposes your hypocrisy in this matter. Please clarify whether Mr Flanagan will be punished.

name: Karol Karski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would just like to inform the President that Yesterday I made a written request to the President to punish Mr Flanagan for calling Prime Minister Orbán rubbish and Mr Ujhelyi for naming Prime Minister Orbán Goebbels.

name: Presidente. –
text: Once we have examined the transcript, we will see if there are grounds for intervening or not.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Axel Voss
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Today, for a second time, we have the opportunity to decide on the application of copyright in the digital world. I would be grateful if the European Parliament could also take the side of our creatives today. A further rejection would be a major blow to the European creative industries. After the summer break I made you new offers. It may not be all for everyone, but we will not continue without a head. The problems are well known and we can develop them further. The proposal for talks for all parties is on the table. Please, please, you would only have to give us your approval today so that we can continue.

name: Axel Voss
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Thank you very much for this Community effort that we have received today! This was a good sign for our creative industries in Europe. However, in accordance with the second subparagraph of Article 59(4), I would like to request that our report be referred back to committee in order to be able to start interinstitutional negotiations.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, thank you for letting me speak. This is an enormous strike against freedom of speech on the internet and I ... (Vociferous objections) (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Presidente. –
text: We shall now proceed to the vote. We must not open the debate on the result. (The matter was referred back to the committee responsible for initiating interinstitutional negotiations.)

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we would just ask here to strike the first word and to insert ‘Commends’ UNRWA.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we had a great opportunity today to protect the rights of authors, creators, artists, journalists, scientists, but unfortunately that is not the case. Not only did the vote we have just reduced their rights - in the case of journalists who were protected in the amendments, they were not protected, but the companies that own the bonds.  In the case of breeders, their protection has been reduced and has become the hands of industry, but even more serious than that - which is already quite serious - we have a situation where we were already with a previous proposal with the introduction of censorship mechanisms and filters and these mechanisms and these censorship filters have worsened by today's vote.  I believe that we have opened a Pandora's box, an attack on democracy and that these filters and censorship mechanisms will turn against those themselves who have defended this directive. It is an attack on democracy, as I said, and will be used in many other dimensions, unfortunately, as in the commission's forthcoming communication on combating radicalism in Europe. It is not a fight against radicalism, it is a reduction of democracy. I'm sad that this house approves censorship.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I believe that the rapporteur of the People's Party himself on this directive made this clear when he said that the adoption of this Directive for the cultural industry was a big step. We have been tried to sell what it was to protect creators, but not: it was to protect the industry, to protect it precisely against the right to information and against a free internet. At Podemos we know that creators' rights are not sufficiently protected, which is why we support the right of creators to fair remuneration. But that doesn't have to go against internet freedom. We consider freedom of expression and information to be a fundamental value of any democratic state. That is why we understand that platforms cannot become arbiters of freedom of expression, as this Directive rightly says has been adopted today. We will only have a critical society with a free and uncensored internet, where knowledge can be shared and the rights of creators and creators respected. Today we have taken a step back in internet freedom.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against the proposal despite a number of amendments, because I believe that the proposals for a directive m.in restrict the freedom to publish content online. In addition, its provisions can be used under the gui backing of copyright for so-called preventive censorship.  The provisions of Article 3, 4, 12 and 13 are particularly controversial. The provisions of the Directive can seriously reduce competitiveness and innovation, inhibit the market for new technologies, including the development of Artificial Intelligence, and increase teaching costs. The creation of an extensive licensing system and mechanisms for content filtering and control, on the other hand, can lead to filtering, that is, censorship of uncomfortable content.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this vote is deleterious to free speech and deleterious to innovation. It is clear that, interpreted in the way we have now seen, it will deter internet platforms from running any material whose copyright they don’t recognise. This will mean effectively the end of memes: no more ‘Johny Johny Yes Papa’, no more downfall spoofs, no more ‘distracted boyfriends’. I can’t help noticing that, since the Brexit vote, a number of large tech companies have been relocating their European headquarters to London: Google, Apple, Snapchat, Ali Baba. Is it possible that they think there will be a friendlier and looser regulatory climate there than with this kind of restrictive nonsense on the continent? If you want to picture today’s vote in the form of one of the memes before they are banned, then think of it as the distracted boyfriend: the woman in the foreground labelled ‘post-Brexit Britain’, the ogling man labelled ‘tech companies’ and the angry girlfriend labelled ‘EU institutions’.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, today there were 703 MEPs in the Chamber and 438 voted to support this copyright directive. I voted against, I was one of 226, and although I understand the concerns of libraries, creators and authors because there were lots of contacts that came in, I simply could not afford to support a directive which violates the fundamental principles of freedom of speech and individual liberty, particularly via the Articles 11 and 13. It is an awful situation when a number of fellow United Kingdom MEPs voted to support a directive which will penalise a thriving industry base and sector in the United Kingdom – Brexit immaterial in this situation – and they ought to be ashamed.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Mr President! In one area, this report has been quite unique. yes, actually, a positive flash of light in this house. That is because it has engaged European citizens to an unprecedented extent, who have been concerned about what we are doing here today. Time and again, this house is voting through massive reforms that restrict democracy, which make it more difficult to be European, without anyone waking up at all, neither the press, domestic bureaucrats or the electorate. But here the voters, the citizens, have, after all, been engaged. I think we have all received a great deal of inquiries, which has shown the interest that has been in the matter. Now the fine words of the rapporteur, and put forward by the shadow rapporteurs, must be put to the test. Is this really going to be a restriction on freedom of expression that some fear, which I fear and many fear? That's your job to prove that it's not happening. Thank you for the word.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the European Union’s copyrights rules need to be modernised and adapted to the digital age in the most efficient way, we know that, so that Europe can further lead in the digital economy around the globe. We need to make sure that the rules protect the creators and remuneration of artists and encourage users to buy artistic content, but we should not establish obstacles such as filtering the free Internet, freedom of speech and development of smaller platforms. Therefore, I voted against the Commission’s proposal as I do not believe that it has achieved sufficient balance on those issues. My colleagues and I supported the amendments to the text – we said no to filtering and sought to establish dispute settlement, to ensure freedom of panorama and to protect press publications in respect of digital uses, as well as users of protected content for entertainment such as internet memes – which we believe would have balanced it. It is unfortunate that a compromise has not been reached.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted against the mandate for the copyright directive and I appreciate that some colleagues here worked hard on this file, but the final document is not more satisfactory than the one we voted down in July. Parliament had only two working weeks to discuss and approve the proposal and I really feel that they have the responsibility in front of our citizens to achieve a good and fair agreement here in Parliament before the file goes to the negotiation table with the Council and the Commission. Debates in this Parliament are the last opportunity for our voters to see in a transparent way what will happen to their digital rights in future and I believe that what we have achieved now is not democratic enough. As a journalist, but also as a citizen of the EU, I put freedom of expression among the top values. By no means can we suppress through the filters the creativity and the freedom of Europeans.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report because it is urgent to regulate this sector in a balanced and fair manner. It seems that we are opening a gap between what is right and what is wrong. But this directive is not at all that. It is about recognizing the challenges of the digital single market that need appropriate legislative adaptation and it is about responsible policy.  The Internet has opened up possibilities in the extent, depth and speed with which we share information, but with this we have been trampling copyright. Digital media can reliablely reproduce audiovisual creations and achieve their infinite dissemination without the due retribution of artists.  The copy/paste culture allows full-time plutonium stems from texts and images without copyright references to make commercials, that is, someone has been, with impunity, profiting from the work of others and that is what has to end.  We may not yet have solved the problem of the sustainability of music and the press in the digital age, but surely this directive will contribute to a large extent to correcting this injustice.  I would like to stress that this directive is not about people's right to information, culture and is also not a coartration of freedom of expression. This Directive is about justice which requires farmers to be properly remunerated and that workers in culture and information are duly recognised.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report because many lobbying interests of major search engines remain in me and some of my colleagues. These search engines are trying to monopolise this market, restrict internet access, restrict freedom of speech, filter opinions, filter information and ultimately jeopardise the work of independent internet media.  There remain many doubts that lobbying interests interfere with a good solution. Prevent the rights of authors from being protected, publishers' rights protected, the rights of users of information protected. This report is a vivid example of the frustration and ineedement of bureaucracy in Brussels. She turned a good decision into a huge lobbying scandal in theory. That's the reason I don't support the report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as was the case during the July plenary session, I have once again received hundreds of e-mails highlighting a total misinformation and exploitation of the issue of copyright in the digital market, particularly with regard to Article 13 on the liability of network operators. The result achieved represents the right balance between copyright and internet freedom, protecting SMEs but at the same time recognising that large online platforms cannot continue to profit from materials that others own.  The Internet is a relatively new and constantly evolving tool which, although desired, since it operates in a virtual and therefore by definition boundless world, can never be limited. But it was necessary to identify certain principles in order to establish fixed points, so as not to harm the rights of others. I am glad that, over and above exploitation, common sense has prevailed in defence of the creative industry and the quality of its productions.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I therefore regret that the proposals to improve both Article 11 and 13, these most controversial articles, have not been adopted and, unfortunately, the right balance has not been struck between justice and the need to protect authors and, on the other hand, over the so-called freedom of the Internet as we know it today.  The Internet, i.say, is as communication technology as a social state of connection, as an amplifier of social relationships.  And then, if this proposal is adopted in such a text, it will no longer be what we know. And I think that in this way, of course, by the allowed use of filters or these control mechanisms, it can also roughly intervene in this recognition of the use of these platforms, which also poses a hidden risk of so-called filtering (interruption due to microphone off). I'm sorry. I would just like to summarise the words of the United Nations Rapporteur on Freedom of Expression, who pointed out that the proposed directive can establish a regime for active control and prior censorship of user content, which is inconsistent with international law and the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.  And therefore, this text must be absolutely corrected and supplemented and, of course, allowing these control filters to be used can also establish a system of the so-called big brother, and then we can also turn the Internet into a filternet.  And I therefore regret that, by not accepting amendments to the amendments and the compromises that have been rejected, we have not been able to achieve this balance so desired, on the one hand, the necessary protection of copyright and, on the other hand, the free use of the Internet.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted against rapporteur Voss's proposal for the new Copyright Directive because I still do not think it provides the balance between respect for consumer rights and fair pay for rightholders.  I think it is a pity that the debate has been artificially shifted and simplified to whether we are in for or against the fact that artists are paid a decent wage for their work. I don't think there is anyone who can say openly that they don't want to support European artists.  The problem comes from the fact that, as representatives in the European Parliament who must protect the interests of their fellow citizens, we have a duty to ensure that their rights and freedoms are protected on the internet. There is no way to support legislation that, by claiming to protect authors, will impose censorship on consumers and limit their freedom on the web.  Filtering user content is not only contrary to fundamental rights and freedoms that we otherwise zealously defend, but also risks manipulation and political propaganda. We all remember the case of Cambridge Analytica and Facebook and how, through an algorithm, data from the platform was misused to manipulate public opinion, which scandalized everyone. Clearly, the memory of those who support reforms in this form is too short.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this directive. I supported the launch of the trilogue on the grounds that I believe that the EU needs to have a clear legal basis for the digital field, to have a common right. Copyright has been regulated at European level for a very long time, it is so good. In my opinion, the current situation is not fair, because it is mainly the biggest giants that make money from it, and the others are only in the so-called "red line". I think it's good to set a fair balance in these relationships.  I also blamed the directive for not being very specific, but it is also a directive, it is not a regulation. Now it will be important to find agreement within the trilogue, and of course the legal basis will have to be put into transposed laws in individual states. So I don't think we're going down the path of revolution, we're going down the path of evolution. It is important that Europe has a common legal basis in the field of copyright.

name: Francis Zammit Dimech (PPE).
text: – Sur President, huwa pja大ir tiegħi li vvutajt favur ir-rapport li kellna minn Voss għaliex nemmen li l-vot li kellna llum huwa vot mill-aktar importanti favur l-artisti u favur il-midja. Meta jiena ridt nagħmelkonsultazzjoni dwar dan is-suġġett fil-ġranet li għaddew ma' artisti, ma' nies li huma fil-qasam tal-pubblikazzjoni, awturi, pubblikaturi, ġurnalisti ġewwa pajjiżi, ġewwa Malta, dawn kellmuni dwar kif huma ttrattati ħażin mill-platforms, kif dawn ma jir大evux remunerazzjoni ġusta għax-xogħol li mbagħad jitqiegħed online mill-ġntiga l-kbar tal U allura dak li għamilna llum għandu jkun il-bidu biex nagħmlu l-ġustizzja ma' dawn in-nies kollha għaliex huwa l-mod kif anki jkollna kontenut aktar. Issemmiet ħafna hawnhekk, Sur President, il-libertà tal-espressjoni. Għalija huwa rilevanti li għandek tmintax-il aġenzija Ewropea tal-aħbarijiet, li f'din il-pubblikazzjoni copyright qalu "Europe's independent press needs Article 11". Għaliex illum għandek xogħol ġurnalistiku li jispi大大a jintuża u ma jingħata ebda ħlas lil min ikun anke ssogra ħajtu biex dak jipproduħih. Mela għamilna pass favur u mhux kontra l-libertà tal-espressjoni u nirringrazzja lil hawk min tani feedback importanti fuq dan is-suġġetti.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, it has been years since I’ve had so many emails from concerned members of the public about a proposal as I did for the Copyright Directive. And this isn’t just the usual people sending bulk emails either: it is people, often a younger demographic, who are concerned about the impact this directive will have on the internet, and on their lives in a digital world which is already so far away from the world that I grew up in. When you have such concerns, you need to be careful. First, do no harm: so today I voted according to two principles. One, I supported amendments that try to provide some balance and protection for individual users of platforms: protections for SMEs, protection of hyperlinks and protection against big business overriding consumers. Two, I voted against the whole directive on the final vote because I simply cannot support the text of Article 11 or Article 13. I am sorry that we lost the final vote, but I did my best to stave off the worst excesses.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, you will surely know the famous verses of a song by Battisti and Mogol that read 'how can a rock stem the sea', contained in the album 'My free singing'. So, having had the honour, like many Italian colleagues, of being asked by Mogol as President of the SIAE about my vote on the Voss resolution, I would like to explain that, precisely in the light of these verses, I have chosen to vote against it. Because this text is actually a very strong attack on freedom of information, it is an attack on the idea of the Internet as a tool for sharing and knowledge. In particular, Articles 11 and 13 are extremely dangerous, because they ask for a licence even in advance of publication and insert an automatic filtering mechanism. The fight against multinationals is being done by introducing a different tax regime. On the other hand, this text not only does not mention and mention the whole sphere of Creative Commons, but it does not contain any real elements of protection for creative work. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Stanisław Żółtek (ENF).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted against this disgusting directive, or at least voted in favour of the removal of Article 13 and 11. Unfortunately, Parliament has decided otherwise. I do not know whether the Members who voted in favour of this directive voted out of cowardice, whether they were bribed or out of stupidity, but I commit to one thing: I will do everything to ensure that the names of those Members who voted 'in favour' are disseminated – so that internet users can give back to them in the next elections.  I wanted to draw attention to one thing: how disgusting such a double morality is. On the same day, today, we are voting against Hungary, arguing that there is some kind of media censorship, and at the same time some of these people are voting in favour of censorship for all European citizens – a hundred times greater one that was not. I understand that, on average, people have not understood this directive. She was specially written in such a language that they did not understand her. But Members had a duty to understand it, and therefore, as I say, I do not know why they voted, but I will try to make people know who voted.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the copyright directive. Today was one of the most difficult and complex votes for me, at least. I don’t believe we have the perfect outcome, in fact I’m not even sure there is a perfect solution, but I believe we have established a balance between the rights of creators and a free internet, and we have sent a strong political message that property rights must be enforced on the internet as well as everywhere else. Creators, artists, journalists must get fair remuneration for their works that are copyrighted, otherwise we are all complicit in stealing their work.  Somebody asked a question of a group of us: who here works for nothing? There was silence and that silence was more powerful than any words. We cannot expect our creators to work for nothing and at the same time allow gigantic platforms like Facebook and Google, who respectively made profits of 16 and 12 billion in 2017 to profit from abusing the copyright works of our creators.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, a colour-coded coalition of supporters of the directive and the lobbyists behind it have won. Lobbyists are happy, but I hope you have bought a ticket for a long holiday from the European Parliament. You have triggered a Eurosceptic avalanche that will sweep you away – I hope – at the next election, because you have sided with lobbyists against your own citizens. And these citizens will settle you out of it, and I will try to help them. All these lobbying breakfasts and dinners from last week will have you – I hope – hiccups at the next election. Furthermore, I believe that President Tajani should resign.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Mr President! There are many good reasons for controlling the money that is being channelled into the European Union, both in a physical sense and electronically, and one of the areas which unfortunately is not covered by this report, but which is of increasing concern to me, is the way in which certain countries in the Middle East finance mosque activities. We have seen how a ministry in Turkey, Diyanet, is simply funding mosques on a growing scale around the EU and using them as a kind of bridgehead for a particular Islamist propaganda. At least in Denmark, we have seen how direct instructions have been given by the Turkish Government to the mosques in Denmark, and also how embassies cooperate by monitoring Turks in Denmark and so on, and that is completely unacceptable. That is why I am annoyed that something so topical is not included in this report.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the control of cash entering and leaving the European Union must be mandatory, real, urgent and, above all, systematic, and the amount of cash allowed on entry into and exit from the Union should be reduced below EUR 10 000, especially in situations where there are suspicions of criminal action. Otherwise, we cannot effectively combat terrorist financing, money laundering or organised crime, and customs cooperation must be real and rapid, in order to prevent criminals from defrauding cash control at the Union's borders.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Mr President! There is something paradoxical about the fact that, as the rules are today, you cannot go down to the post office and pick up a package, a birthday present, or whatever it may be that you have sent without having to have ID and everything else in order to be able to identify. At the same time, thousands of euros can be sent to all the organisations and people in third countries, no matter what their intention is – and how they want to spend – that money. There is, of course, something paradoxical about this, on the one hand, the way we suspiciously make perfectly legal and regular citizens who will just receive a birthday present from a nephew or other family member, and, on the other hand, that it is so easy to finance and send money to organisations for which we have no idea at all whether they are peaceful or not peaceful. Whether they are with us or against us. This is a small step in the right direction, but unfortunately not at all a step that we want, namely by the mellegovernal model, rather than the federal model.  It's too bad we don't do the right thing when the opportunity is there.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, every year we lose between 1.5 and 2.8 trillion dollars, or between 2% and 5% of the world's gross domestic product, precisely through money laundering. It's a black hole where people's money flows and often their lives. The new European directive on combating money laundering by criminal means seeks to correct some of these shortcomings. Removes the link between the main offence, money laundering, and the predicated offence, the one that produces dirty money that must be laundered by criminals. So there is no need for a previous conviction or to know the perpetrator of the criminal activity that generated the dirty money. The directive also introduces exceptions to the principle of double criminality for all serious crimes, makes it possible to prosecute and convict money laundering, even if the criminal activity that generated the goods was committed in another country and so on. So we will have common crimes for all Member States for money laundering.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, today we voted against authoritarian drift driven by the Hungarian Government and attacks on the rule of law, migrants, women and minorities. The Government of Orbán is one of the most racist and Islamophobic in the European Union and seriously violates human rights and international law.  It should be remembered that Mr Orbán is a member of the European People's Party and has not infreeredly set Mariano Rajoy's government as an example in Europe. But we not only regret that the Spanish People's Party has abstained, decided not to vote or even voted for Orbán, but we often regret a hypocritical debate, because many of the proposals on migration—those authoritarian proposals it makes with Salvini—are often supported by the majority of this House, a House that disapproves of Orbán but then practices its policies , buys the agenda on the right and especially on the far right of Europe. It is essential to stop Orbán but, above all, to put a stop to his policies.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against today's resolution on Hungary, and I would like to say that not only are the provisions of this document controversial, but also the statements that have been made in this House and which should never have happened. This resolution, I believe, will not have the desired effect. On the contrary, it will encourage European citizens to vote against those who voted for it.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear fellow members who are pro-migration, I would like to thank you for your support. Well, the thing is, you failed this Sargentini report. You didn't win. They did not receive two-thirds because they wanted to meet their friend George Soros at all prices. They just started cheating, didn't they? They say abstention is like not voting. Well, at least we don't think of each other as idiots, my fellow Members. We all know that abstention means otherwise and it means that if I choose not to come in and vote. Let me give you two fellow Hungarian Members as examples. Zoltán Balczó correctly said that there are elements of the report that he agrees with, some of which he does not, which is why he has taken a rational, considered decision to abstant. Our fellow Green MEMBER Tamás Meszerics received an instruct from his party at home that he did not agree with, so he told the press that he would not come in to vote. It's a different story. Please stop cheating. Well, it's practically a crime, it's disgusting, it's disgusting. Acknowledge that you have lost. God save and lead Hungary!

name: Christelle Lechevalier (ENF).
text: Mr President, some Members here present themselves as self-proclaimed defenders of European values, arbitrarily distinguishing who respects them from who flouts them, and condemning all those who do not walk in their direction to come out of unanimity. The Europe of nations is reborn, the European Union breaks out. Democracy, pluralism, tolerance and freedom are intangible pillars of our institution. Many pointed out yesterday, before clarifying that this should not apply to Mr Orbon, of course. Pluralism is good when everyone thinks like you. Democracy is good when everyone votes for you. Well, no, no, It was recalled that the sanction should be directed against the government, not the Hungarian people, but it is the Hungarian people that you are going to strangle, and this with pressure that you will not release until they vote according to your diktat. If viktor Orban does not represent Hungarians for you, then you question the very essence of democracy. So Emmanuel Macron does not represent the French, so Angela Merkel does not represent the Germans, and none of the European Commissioners appointed by these governments represents Europeans in this regard. Let's not vote anymore. Name! By triggering Article 7, you are sending the worst of the signals to the Hungarian people, to whom you offer one more reason to hate a European Union whose values you claim to defend.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I voted in favour of the adoption of the Sargentini report because I consider it to give an accurate and balanced picture of the dismantling of European standards and the rule of law in the wake of the activities of the Orban government. The hungarian opposition, me and my own party, the Hungarian Socialist Party, regularly talk about the conditions and violations contained in this report, but by abusing the parliamentary majority of the ruling party, relying on a distorted electoral system and its media and media monopolies, it is increasingly unscrupulous in restricting freedoms, social rights, blocking European funds in its corruption web and inciting against minorities, foreigners and the European Union. I therefore supported the report and the possible launch of the procedure under Article 7 of the Treaty as a special way of helping Hungarian citizens to assert their democratic rights as a manifestation of European solidarity. I will make sure that the Hungarian electorate appreciates it in the same way. In defence of my country, I thank the 448 brave Members for voting yes.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, I have been in this institution for 30 years, and I must say that I am always amazed by what it proposes, and in particular by the extraordinary hypocrisy and good conscience that this debate has revealed. Indeed, what are hungarians accused of? To violate academic freedoms, for example, because they claim to impose their national standards, including on a foreign university. But when I, the dean of the honorary faculty, a respected academic, I was suspended for five years for comments that the supreme court of my country declared perfectly lawful and legitimate, the majority of this Parliament referred me to the judicial institutions of my country, instead of defending me, and was condemned for it by the Court of Luxembourg. They are accused of undermining freedom of expression. But there are 1,150 prisoners of expression in Germany, under the pretext of denialism, they are prisoners of conscience, including a 90-year-old lady. And that leaves you totally indifferent? There is a criticism of "hostile and intimidating campaign rhetoric." But what do we mean here? Patriots are called populists, family advocates are called homophobes, anti-immigration people are called xenophobes. It's not hostile, it's not intimidating?

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This debate and all these attacks on Hungary are, of course, attacks on the unity of the European Union, on our countries' ability to cooperate, on our community of destiny to which we are called. At the same time, however, this debate has exposed the disastrous state of democracy in this Parliament and in the European Union in general. This is a very serious warning signal, showing what we are really capable of. The introduction of some kind of parliamentary arithmetic, a way of counting votes to invalidate some of the votes properly cast in order to obtain the intended and correct result of the vote, is a practice known only from totalitarian states, because that is how authoritarian states used their power. To call black white and white to be black, or to claim that there were no votes that have died is unknown outside totalitarian states, unknown where the rule of law operates. High Chamber! If these practices continue, we will destroy the remnants of the authority of the institution that we should represent.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I fully supported the report on Article 7 asking Members to assess if there is a risk of a serious breach of European values in Hungary. I voted for Europe and for PPE values, on the side of the Hungarian people.  Raising concerns, based on facts, about the Hungarian Government’s policies is not punishing the people. I am proud to be a Swede, an Italian and a European. There is no contradiction. As a friend of Hungary, I appeal to Prime Minister Orbán to move from denial to dialogue and to reconsider policies violating Article 2 of the EU Treaty, in particular restrictions on academic freedom and on civil society, and breaches of European asylum law. I believe in building bridges, but we urgently need to see concrete changes and results in Hungary. I am proud the PPE stood united for European values, showing that we are a credible political family. I will continue to stand up for the rule of law against populism and extremism in Europe.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, today is a sad and shameful day for the European Parliament. Today is the first time this parliament has been divided and this Union has been divided. A group of people who think they have the right to decide instead of the Hungarian people, instead of the Romanian people, today decided to punish a sovereign government for the decisions it has taken.  The Hungarian government is elected by the Hungarian people and they have every right to decide how to run their country. Not to mention these are the right solutions: curbing illegal immigration, zero migration, fighting Islamism are legitimate causes. We all see what happens on the streets of Germany every day, on the streets of France every day.  I categorically do not accept a handful of anonymous bureaucrats or people with strange views, understandings and feelings about themselves having the left Marxist idea that they are more than others and can make decisions for them. This is not the European Union, this is the Soviet Union. In 1989, I was nine years old and little I remember from the Soviet Union, but what I read makes it clear. The Soviet Union made such decisions. We want the European Union of free fatherness, the sovereigns fathered, not the Soviet Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in his speech on the situation in Hungary, Mr Orbán spoke of falsehoods, lies and witch-hunts. He said that Europe commits abuse if it excludes a country that does not accept the rules of the community of which it is a member. What can I say? I understand the meaning of your speech, capricious and at times delirious, and I understand it because, alas, in Italy too we are getting used to this inconsistent style. I believe that Hungary is a great country, of fundamental importance to the European Union, but there is an involutional process in that country which is practically dismantling the rule of law and liberal democracy. After the bissures in the media, the walls, the barbed wire and the detention camps for refugees and migrants, this Parliament finally had the courage to initiate the procedure provided for in Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union. This is a necessary measure to give Europe a political direction, which must not lose its trait as a Community of Member States united by the values of civilization and democracy that are indispensable.

name: Rupert Matthews (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the great French statesman Charles de Talleyrand said of the returning Bourbon aristocrats in 1815, ‘they’ve learned nothing and they have forgotten nothing’. Sadly, much the same could be said about this Chamber. Two years ago Britain voted to leave the European Union, and while there were many reasons for that, one was that the British people had got fed up with the way the European institutions kept interfering in our national life. We do not want to be told what to do by this Parliament and the Commission. But you just can’t help yourselves. You’re at it again. With this motion you are using the power of the European Parliament improperly to interfere in the daily life of the Hungarians and how the Hungarian Government rules their country. To invoke Article 7 in this way is the act of a self-serving bully. Like those aristocrats, you have learned nothing and you have forgotten nothing.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The report on which the debate on Hungary is based contains a number of politically based assessments of the situation, which is not surprising in fact from a political body. However, this is not an excuse for the many untruths and factual errors that are found in the text. Not only Sargentini, but all 448 Members are qualified by the completion of a report of this standard. As far as the procedure is concerned, it would be much more fortunate to examine the fundamental values, human rights and the rights of minorities in all Member States on the basis of the same criteria and the same standards, because this kind of pillory can only be considered as a political attack. Why not examine the rights of minorities in France or Romania, the imbalances in the electoral system in the United Kingdom, the freedom of religion in Greece, freedom of expression in Spain, or the independence of the judiciary from politics and intelligence services in Romania? Without uniform standards and equal treatment, this procedure is for political purposes only.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the decision to invoke Article 7 against a nation is one of the most solemn that this Parliament could take. It should be greeted accordingly, not with standing ovations. We were being asked, as MEPs, to sit in judgment on an entire nation and its laws. In such situations, irrespective of anything else, the bar must be set very high indeed, and the inclusion of questions such as health and safety, or gender studies courses at university, implies the wrong approach.  There are indeed aspects of Hungary’s policies on the media and independent judiciary which should well be criticised. But fundamentally, there is the question of whether the European Union should override national sovereignty. Those who support the Treaties may well believe it should but the tone of debate is wrong.  Finally, Hungary seems to have been singled out for political reasons. Similar cases could have been made against other nations and yet they are not. Mr President, I opposed invoking Article 7 because this is not the right way to do it, because it has become politicised and because of the precedent it would set.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I say to you who voted in favour of this resolution: you are hypocrites, you do not understand what democracy is. Democracy is only good for you when you win, when europhile forces win – the ones you favor. When you lose an election somewhere, you immediately cry that democracy is under threat. You do not understand what freedom of speech is, because when a left-wing MEMBER rebukes his tweets, you applaud him, but when you had to patiently listen to the opinions you disagree with, which Janusz Korwin-Mikke gave, you wanted to punish him with fines, and to this day you are clampering President Tajani, who says that he would do the same again.  For you, democracy is just the baton you want to put on those who disagree with you. Yesterday, President Timmermans said, in a moment of sincerity, that for him the Charter of Fundamental Rights is more important than democracy, that is, democracy was good to adopt the Charter of Fundamental Rights, but if he wanted to repeal it, democracy no longer counts for him. So you treat it all instrumentally. Furthermore, I believe that President Tajani should resign.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted with conviction in favour of this report for the reasons mentioned several times by my colleagues. Orbán has been an example of an attack on migrants' rights and even abuse of migrants, against asylum seekers, has restricted freedom of the press and freedom of education, has constantly attacked gender studies, has constantly attacked women's freedom and is accused of corruption. In short, there are so many reasons to vote in favour of this report. I would therefore like to take advantage of this time which I have left to ask here a concern, that concerning the Italian right. Forza Italia, with its vote today, has tried to sink the Sargentini report to the end. Interior Minister Salvini shook hands with Orbán, who should actually be his fiercest opponent, as Orbán opposes any policy of European relocation. Today, the European Parliament has given a good signal against racism in Europe. I am concerned that Italy cannot do the same.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we here are on the side of the citizens. We call on the Member States to act to protect their citizens as well. They must protect civil rights and the rule of law, and the rule of law inextricably includes freedom of the press, an independent court and democracy. These rights also belong to Hungarian citizens, now and also to future Hungarian citizens. Viktor Orbán, these you must also take into account after the election victory, although the elections did not become completely clean papers. Even an election winner cannot go out of his way to break the rule of law and Europe's values have been created for the implementation of Article 2. The European Parliament was now acting on this legal basis and wanted the Article 7 procedure to be launched.

name: Christelle Lechevalier (ENF).
text: Mr President, it is good for international security that a debate is open on the subject of killer robots. Indeed, autonomous lethal weapons systems raise legitimate moral questions, because of the extent of the damage they can cause and the non-discrimination between their potential targets. Moreover, these killer robots that have become ultra-developed could in the future escape human control. The idea of a convention on autonomous weapons systems might be an appropriate response, if it imposed a moratorium or a total ban on the signatory states, but that convention would have to include China, the United States, Iran, Israel and Russia, which are already not participating in the Osaka Convention on anti-personnel mines, otherwise it would be of no use at all. Whatever the ethical problems involved, there is no question that the lack of lucidity and military development of the European states will make them ever more dependent on the great powers. Although the initial intentions are laudable, it is by no means within the competence of the European Union to sign a convention on such a subject. Even if we can share findings in a Community way, Member States remain in control of the right position to be taken on this subject and, from our point of view, we doubt the relevance of a convention governing the use of autonomous weapons.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, artificial intelligence is improving at an incredible pace. We have seen a revolution in how machines learn, some of it reported by the media and sensationalised in the usual way, and the big change in the last couple of years has been the speed at which machines learn. For a computer, for example, to beat the best humans at chess is one thing, but for a new engine to go from learning the rules to beating the best computer in the world in the space of hours, that says that artificial intelligence has improved and is changing. We have computer systems now learning languages to communicate with each other, creating their own languages, in ways that humans don’t even understand. But real-life military situations are not games of complete information like chess, they are games of incomplete information, based on a fog of war, more like Stratega. If we cannot understand how machines are making decisions then there are serious future questions, especially when it comes to matters of life and death. So although I disagree with aspects of this report, the debate certainly matters, not just in the UK, not just in Europe, but throughout the whole world and through the United Nations.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report which reaffirms our shared values of freedom and democracy. Democracy is the topic that US Senator Paul Strauss recently visited our Parliament to discuss in relation to the District of Columbia. Quite frankly, when I first heard that 700 000 US citizens in Washington do not have the right to elect Senators and Congressmen or women who actually get to vote on laws, I was baffled. That is more people than live in Malta or Luxembourg disenfranchised, and whilst the reasons are to be found in history, the situation is a real problem today with local decisions such as funding for family planning for those in financial need being blocked.  We in this Parliament call out human rights violations across the world. I see no reason not to do so in this case too. The citizens of the District of Columbia are denied the basic rights that others living in liberal democracies take for granted. It is time that this 200—year injustice was ended.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I doubt many people in the European Parliament  have heard of – or indeed visited – the wonderful north Nottinghamshire villages of Babworth and Scrooby, but they are incredibly significant in the history of US and European relations because they are where, almost 400 years ago, some of the pioneering Pilgrim Fathers set out from on their historic voyage to the United States, via Holland. I want to commend the important work by those at Bassetlaw District Council, in my constituency, who are bringing that story to life as we approach the 400th anniversary of the voyage of the Mayflower. Their work is incredibly important in bringing that rich history to life today; a story of discovery, migration, freedom and democracy, values which we reflect on today in voting through this report.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report on European Union-Us relations is generally not very confrontational, but some of its provisions are unacceptable. For example, paragraph 5, in which we express concern about the United States' approach to solving global regional problems and conflicts following the election of Donald Trump, certainly does not move towards real cooperation. The provisions of paragraph 39, in which we criticise the recent appointment of Gina Haspel as director of the Central Intelligence Agency and express concern about her poor human rights record, are also unacceptable. I believe that there are also provisions in place, such as paragraph 38, which points to a comprehensive approach by the European Union and the US to combat terrorism. We are talking about joint efforts, and this is pure hypocrisy, because so far the Union has done almost nothing on counter-terrorism, and almost all the burden of the fight against terrorism has been on the United States. Until now, the Union has rather bothered – i would remind you, for example, of the establishment of a special committee on the protection of human rights and freedoms. In view of the above, I voted against this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I supported this thorough report, agreeing that we should make a low-key and constructive criticism of the EU's largest and closest global strategic partner, even at a hopefully short, transitional historical period when Trump's presidency threatens the mutual trust on which transatlantic cooperation is based. I think it is important that Europe, faced with the effects of an unpredictable US foreign and economic policy, should simultaneously seek new avenues for the eu and its Member States' own security and international competitiveness, while preserving the decades-old values of the Transatlantic Alliance that underlie the peace and prosperity of our continent. This report can be an appropriate starting point for the European Parliament and the Union as a whole to be prepared with concrete forward-looking proposals for a time when we will once again face a predictable and responsible government partner on the US side. This, of course, also requires us to strengthen the unity of the Union in shaping the EU-US relationship and to keep in mind the unsolicited European admirers and servers of Trump's political rampage, such as Viktor Orban.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the EU-US transatlantic relationship remains the crucial pillar for global stability, and for upholding fundamental rights in the world. Threats in the EU neighbourhood that we are currently faced with can be effectively deterred only through deep and coherent partnerships within a NATO framework. I therefore believe we should continue showing our full political and financial commitment to this partnership. However, I also share the concerns expressed in the report that President Trump’s administration has led to some set-backs in very important fields of cooperation, such as trade, climate change or the United Nations. Having said this, despite developing and deepening the partnership further wherever possible, the European Union should also be prepared to build its strategic powers and, if necessary, lead by example when it comes to such issues as human rights or global warming.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we can like Donald Trump or not, but one thing is sure, we have to deal with the United States. The US has been supporting the European project since the beginning. Our ties are irreversible and the shadow of the future is long for us both. What we must do in this House is decide our approach to the US notwithstanding who is in power there. We need to be serious about it and not reduce the current disequilibrium in our relations to the individual figure of Trump only. As a member of the SND Group, I am convinced that our dialogue with the US must be equal and fair – I repeat, equal and fair. The EU needs to stop merchandising its values for the sake of a deal with the US. Why did we not adopt any urgency resolution on the human rights violation perpetrated by the US. Why do we not speak about the US violating the sovereignty of other states. It is easy to be strong with weak ones and weak with the strong ones.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, once again, Mr Brok's report is totally lacking in purpose, because the problem is not at all to interfere in the internal politics of the United States, as it does and as do the amendments that have been tabled and voted on. The United States has no more to interfere with our affairs than we have to interfere in the internal affairs of the United States. The real problem is whether we have not insensitively gone from being allied to being vassals. And we must demand reciprocity and focus only on international issues. We must therefore seize the opportunity of the Trump presidency to free ourselves from NATO, whose existence is no longer justified since the Soviet Union disappeared and is no longer a threat against us. We must speak out against the incredible plunders that the American administration or the judiciary has carried out against our banks, against our interests, and we must speak out against the unbearable claim of the United States to impose the universality of its sanctions at the expense of our companies. Everything else is none of our business.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report because we need a new settlement with the USA, not just because of Trump’s politics and the way he is attacking the EU and our steel and aluminium industries but also because we don’t have the global rules and governance we need to tackle the challenges we all face, from sustainable development to security, without the USA at the table. So we need to do more than just talk to them. We need to negotiate with the USA: for the climate and to re-regulate globalisation, bringing the USA back into the multilateral game. Bilateral horse trading won’t work, and nor will a new, narrow EU-US deal on tariffs and quotas. MEPs dismissed attempts to conclude a Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) ‘lite’ in 2016 and I am pleased that today’s report has reiterated this firm position, but it’s worth noting, as we’re about to leave the European Parliament, how the atmosphere in our EU-US relations has changed in my time in politics. Much needs to be done to improve it.

name: Rupert Matthews (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I’m absolutely delighted to be able to support stronger links between the democratic nations on this side of the Atlantic and the United States of America on the other side. But that cause will not be served if the European Union insists on putting all of the blame for the recent chilling in relations on the United States of America. How many times have I sat in this very building and listened to my fellow MEPs talking about American culture: how vulgar it is, how common it is, how awful it is, how much better things would be if everything was run by les énarques and the other elite here in the European Union? Is it any surprise that President Trump and the peoples of the United States of America resent the snobbery and contempt that daily fall upon their ears from people within this Chamber? We need to improve relations with the United States of America, but let us start by taking a lead ourselves.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Until recently, transatlantic relations were the foundation of everything that is most important in cooperation in the world, namely the values of our civilization, cooperation and economic growth, and therefore also of social development, and finally of international security.  But it seems that the world we've known so far is slowly moving into history. This is due to the current us presidential administration. It is enough to cite examples such as unleashing a trade war, attacking the unity of the European Union, undermining the functioning of NATO, the UN, and, finally, the WTO, and, of course, the dismantling of international trade agreements and services or investment. Nevertheless, I believe that it is in the interest of both the European Union and the United States and the whole democratic world to return to the path of global cooperation and cooperation. There is, in my opinion, no alternative to this solution.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I voted in favour of this report because I consider it to provide a comprehensive and overall realistic picture of the state of European Union-China relations, and although somewhat cautious in some places for me, it also contains the most important criticisms of the Chinese leadership from the point of view of European democracies. I do not dispute that the People's Republic of China is one of the European Union's most important strategic partners, a key player in the world economy, our second largest trading partner, and therefore there is no alternative to the importance of dialogue and the pursuit of cooperation.
