At the same time, I think it is important for the European Union, in the spirit of this report, to take even stronger and more critical action, if necessary in the form of protests, against the practice of the Chinese government, which it is pursuing against its own population, or we can also talk about human rights violations on the Tibetan issue.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the recent EU-China summit has witnessed the fact that both parties are stepping up their cooperation in many fields, including security, defence, anti-terrorism and climate change. Certainly, China is seeking greater influence in Europe due to its growing investments in strategic infrastructure. However, we must be rather cautious and think how to counter-balance this influence in order to preserve our democracy and not to be indebted to Chinese banks. I wish to highlight that the European Union also should continue to speak up for press freedom, human rights and other fundamental liberties in this country. I agree with this report’s conclusions and the relationship with China, if pursued with cautious diplomacy, can be a great opportunity not only for the European Union and China, but for global stability too, although it is crucial that we remain very loyal to our values, and to democracy and human rights.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution on EU—China relations. It states that EU—China cooperation should be more people oriented. I fully agree with this but, in order to benefit the people, our cooperation should be dominated by human rights issues and social standards. Instead, our cooperation is dominated by commercial interests. China is probably bigger and stronger than ever before, but please remember that it was this big and strong China that put the Nobel Prize laureate for peace, Liu Xiobo, in Laogai, a detention camp supposed to re-educate and reform through labour. The fact is that it is a prison where people are forced to work. Liu Xiobo found the courage to write a manifesto for democracy in China and at that moment, penal labour became his destiny. Do you know what, colleagues? The penitentiary labour camp was expressly proud to have among its prisoners a Nobel Prize winner – and who knows how many products from such camps we use every day.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, China is concentrating some of its investments in the poorest economies in Central and Eastern Europe and in the Balkans. Why is that? Because there are corrupt politicians and oligarchs there. Sixteen countries, including eleven Member States of the Union, are the Trojan horse through which China is trying to control Europe. 50 billion euros are being put on the line by China in these countries for financing in infrastructure, hi-tech and consumer goods. But China, we know, doesn't just come with money, it also comes with corruption, it comes with dictatorial practices, it comes with human rights violations, it comes with the ban, for example, on the Internet, especially in countries where power is corrupt and, precisely, dictatorial. That's where he can make his way. That is why strict and effective control is needed throughout the Union, because otherwise we risk destroying our China and fair market competition, and our democracy.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is unclear whether we are on the last page of a chapter of world history or the first page of the next chapter. The rise of China has, and is, shifting the economic and political tectonic plates. Trump’s response to Chinese overcapacity in steel and aluminium amounts to collective punishment, but our opposition to Trump’s tariffs must not mean that we let China off the hook.  China’s economic strategy poses long-term challenges for jobs and incomes in Europe and it is time that we fully recognised it. Investment flows and trade flows between China and Europe are seriously unbalanced. China has a plan and it is not benevolent. We need a plan of our own to uphold social standards, to re-regulate globalisation and invigorate our economy. The time of laissez-faire economics must end if we want this to be the first page of fairer EU-China relations in the future.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the EU is a community of values which, inter alia, places human rights at the centre of its relations with all third countries and strategic partners. Still, it has little results to show for years of human rights dialogue with China. In China today, peaceful dissent is banned, freedom of religion and free speech are curtailed, and human rights defenders are being detained, prosecuted and imprisoned. Tibetan identity and culture is relentlessly under attack and Tibetans themselves are subject to arbitrary detention, forced disappearance, torture and ill treatment. Xinjiang region is a frightening and dystopian experiment in which China’s decades-old repressive methods are reinforced by cutting-edge technology to create a true police state. Today, nearly every family in the Uighur diaspora has a relative or loved one who has been sent to re-education camps created to erode their religious, cultural and ethnic identities. What does Europe do when hundreds of persecuted Tibetans self-immolate themselves to show their people’s desperation to the world? It celebrates the EU-China Tourism Year.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As chairman of the Intergroup on Tibet in the European Parliament, I am very grateful to Mr Belder for a balanced Report on China, especially the chapters on the right of Tibetans to freedom of expression and religion. It is clear that Chinese authorities have greatly tightened surveillance measures and controls on individuals and social groups. On the pretext of creating security and stability, massive action is being taken against Tibetan culture and identity. Arbitrary arrests and ill-treatment have decreased rather than decreased. We must not look the other way when lawyers and politically engaged citizens are locked away. Access to the Tibet Autonomous Region for foreigners, journalists and diplomats must be facilitated. We Europeans are calling for respect for human rights and the rule of law, including in relation to a trading partner as strong as China.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes voting time. (The sitting was suspended at 2.36 p.m.)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on a topical issue (Rule 153 of the Rules of Procedure): The future of pensions: combating privatisation and strengthening public universal social security systems (2018/2843(RSP)). I would point out to Members that there is no spontaneous procedure for speaking in this debate and that no blue cards are being adopted.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: Author. – Madam President, the words of Laurence Fink, CEO of BlackRock, when in 2017 the new year of the German stock exchange opened, make it clear what is coming. It said "workers tend to be too dependent on state pensions." Two years earlier, the same company recommended that the European Union set up a cross-border pension fund on its territory.  June 2016: the date on which Commissioner Dombrowskis announced the Commission's proposal to set up a European personal pension plan. We understand the complaints of three months ago of the high promiscuity among senior officials of the European Commission, including Dombrowski, with the multinational. Even before any decision on this proposal already BlackRock tracks the path in European pension funds managing a pilot project created by Commissioner Coins and delivered to the American multinational. If masks have ever had them, they have fallen, leaving the interests to which the European Commission serves to the public. But this is not a debate on BlackRock, nor about commissioners, it is a debate on the future of pensions and the political choices that the European Union seeks to impose to the detriment of peoples and workers.  The completion of a new pan-European pension product responds to an old demand by large investment funds to appropriate workers' contributions to public social security, integrating the World Bank's model of promoting growth called the "second pillar". This is a despicable assault proposed by the European Union on workers' pensions for appropriation of their income, aimed at the liquidation of public and universal social security with the support of the right and social democracy.  It is not surprising that the Commission's proposal is that, through country-specific recommendations in the context of the European Semester, they insist on theorising the unsustainability of public pension systems and the inevitable replacement of redistributive themes by capitalisation systems. The implementation of such recommendations of the European Union, together with the right-wing and austerity policies followed in recent decades by those who have governed countries such as Portugal, have led to an accelerated process of weakening public social security, with obvious and harmful consequences: the attack on the right to social protection, the introduction of measures that erode the financing base of the systems , harming especially the older people, unemployed workers and beneficiaries of non-contributory social benefits. A reality aggravated by low-wage policies and high job insecurity, destruction of national productive capacity, increased unemployment, inevitable reductions in contributions made and consequent increase in poverty and social exclusion. In addition, the retirement age has been increased on a proposal from the European Commission. They instigate the generational confrontation with a single goal: to privatise pension systems and usurp workers' incomes, serving them with a hand to vultures of pension funds, making a shallow plank of the brutal social consequences of the bankruptcy of these funds. The needs of workers and peoples opposed to the interests of large economic and financial groups require a clear response: the defence of public, universal and solidarity social security as an irreplaceable instrument for promoting social justice in the distribution of income, which must be consolidated by strengthening public systems with contributory funding based on principles of solidarity between generations and a redistributive logic , a path incompatible with your integration project that cannot be disconnected from the fight against unemployment and precariousness, the creation of jobs with rights and the effective appreciation of wages, the fight against contributory evasion and the rejection of the misuse of revenuestemming the income of the contributory regime for purposes unrelated to its purposes.  Public and universal social security must serve the interests, well-being and happiness of workers and peoples. Their defence and strengthening are fundamental to building a more just and supportive society in another Europe based on progress and social convergence.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I see that Mrs Edtstadler, who should speak on behalf of the Council, is still prevented, because she is still in the making of signatures under legislative texts. That is why, for once, I would like to give the European Commission the lead.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. A stable, trustworthy guarantee of old age is a central task in a social society. That is why we also welcome the debate – knowing full well that pension insurance law is primarily national law and that our powers are limited.  We recognise that in many Member States the demographic structure is difficult. We are pleased that the life expectancy of our European citizens continues to increase. From generation to generation, life expectancy increases by three years on average in Europe: that is, my year will be on average six years older than the grandpa has become, and my son will be three years older than my year on average with his vintage. That is why we must be concerned about the age structure, which means that there are fewer and fewer employees in a pensioner.  The task remains, first and foremost, a task for the Member States. With our proposal, we in the European Commission want to make a supplementary voluntary offer, not a substitute. We believe that the state pension and the statutory pension must remain the main pillar of pension provision in the future. And we believe that private security by the citizen and economically reputable offers can also play a useful complementary role. Supplementary pension schemes and the added value that should also be organised at European level are the background to the Commission's proposal, which my colleague Mr Dombrovskis has drawn up in the lead.  Please take it away from him: we do not want the American industrial companies that have just been mentioned to benefit from it. We want there to be a second pillar in which Europe can add value and which fully meets our legal requirements of insurance law and the market economy.  We want to make an offer that the Member States and the citizens can accept, but do not have to accept. If a Member State wants to continue to place pension provision fully on the state statutory pillar, it is its own decision, its right, its responsibility. However, if the second pillar is to be added in addition, our proposal, if you follow it, is an offer – no more and no less.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I am sorry for the delay: there was a slight delay in signing legal acts together with President Tajani. Let me turn to our topic. Sustainability of the pension system is crucial and has to be seen in the overall context of sustainable public finances. We need a modern and efficient social safety net that targets public resources to where they are needed most, catering in particular for vulnerable groups in society. But beyond the sustainability, we should also not forget about adequacy. Sustaining adequate pensions in ageing societies is key to the economic coordination efforts and ensuring inclusive growth in the EU, as pensions are both the main source of income for older Europeans and an important component of public expenditure. An increased awareness about old-age poverty led to a 1.9 million decrease in the number of old people at risk of poverty or social exclusion since 2008 in the EU, despite growing life expectancy. Despite these improvements, there is no room for complacency, as was rightly highlighted by the 2018 Pension Adequacy Report endorsed by the Council in June this year. The European Pillar of Social Rights, Principle 15, highlights precisely this issue. It affirms the right of workers and the self-employed in retirement to a pension which commensurate with their contributions and ensuring an adequate income. Furthermore, it highlights that women and men shall have equal opportunities to acquire pension rights. To this end, Member States are working hard to ensure that the gender income and pay gap is closing. It is well known that the gender pay gap is amplified in old age. More than 20% of old women aged 65 and over are at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU. The Council has not lost sight of this issue. Most recently in March, Ministers have debated the implications of the gender pay gap on our societies and discussed ways forward on how to tackle it. The Adequacy Report’s key messages focus in this regard on the following: reducing the inequality requires equal opportunity policies targeted at women and men of working age, inter alia through promoting the work-life balance and equal distributions of caring responsibilities and addressing labour market participation and career opportunities, work intensity and career breaks. Last but not least, this debate closely ties in with discussions on the future of work. An increasing number of people do not work in regular full-time employment any more. We must make sure that our social security systems, including pensions, are not the last ones to adapt to this reality. This would have grave consequences on our societies in a few decades from now. The proposed recommendations on access to social protection for workers and the self-employed is currently being discussed. The intention is to take steps to extend pension coverage to more people in non-standard or self-employment, and adapting accrual conditions to diverse work patterns. This can help more people build up adequate pension rights. In conclusion, ensuring the long-term sustainability of public finances is particularly important, given the ageing population and the debt levels in the EU. It is also of utmost importance that we do not leave our fellow citizens who have contributed to the betterment of our societies, who were instrumental in the growth of our economies, and who have shaped the Europe that we live in today.

name: Heinz K. Becker
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, Secretary of State for the Council, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work on the work she has said. Today's debate on the future of pensions concerns all European citizens. However, this issue lies in national competence, and that is a good thing. I share this position in the division of competences. The future of pensions, as it is designed, should be based on three pillars. The first pillar of statutory pensions should continue to be a priority, as in Austria, the stable pension scheme is largely provided by statutory pensions. Reforms are, of course, imperative here. Intergenerational justice means that demographic development must not be carried out on the backs of young people. And if we already spend an average of 20 years in retirement today, then it is clear that we have to work longer. The second pillar – we have mostly regulated it through company pensions – must become as attractive as possible. We need to strengthen them in order to maintain living standards in old age. And the third pillar, private pension provision, will soon be able to get something particularly attractive for young people with the PEPP proposed by the Commission, the Pan-European pension product, which, for the first time in this form, also offers a capital guarantee in the standard version of pension savings, which, irrespective of the development of the capital markets, will include a guarantee for the payment of the amounts paid in. I believe that this is an attractive way forward. I therefore believe that all the myths that are being put into the room must be relegated to the realm of lies. The future of young people and our social systems is at stake and well prepared.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the S&D Group welcomes clearly the debate on the pension system in plenary. This is indeed a very important part of the welfare system and this is now the right time for us to design a welfare system for the 21st century.  Yes, we know that our pension systems are confronted with difficult challenges because of ageing and because the poverty we still have among pensioners is not being reduced. Something needs to be addressed because we cannot have poverty involved in the pension system. This is even more acute if we have in mind the future of younger generations because, for the sake of fairness, we need to make sure that young generations have the same chances to count on an adequate pension when they need it. How could we address this? First of all, let me make the point that the best way to have a sustainable pension system is to have a very high employment rate and good quality jobs. Then, let me also underline, in the middle of the discussion about the outcomes of migration, that migration, if it is properly managed, can make a positive contribution to the sustainability of the pension system. Last but not least, we need to consider new ways to finance the system, notably by corporate taxation and by the so-called digital tax, because a new source of tax is there.  Let me make the point that the European social model involves a pension system based basically in a public pillar and the pensions system should be available for everyone. This is a key ingredient, even in the digital economy. So this is our main point for the architecture.

name: Ulrike Trebesius
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Many young people in my country do not believe that they will receive an adequate pension later on. Many people in Germany are – not unjustifiably – very concerned about old-age poverty.  The German Institute for Economic Research (DIW) has just published that more than sixty percent of Germans have to adjust to the fact that they will be missing around seven hundred euros a month in order to maintain their standard of living in old age. Private pension provision is therefore recommended, as is the one in this House, which is not without a certain irony, because private pension provision is being severely damaged by the policies of the European Central Bank. Persistently low interest rates devalue savings assets and deprive people of the opportunity to provide appropriately privately for their pension.  In addition, in my country, the parties have been competing for the highest pensions for years. As a result, around 100 billion from the federal budget are already being paid into pensions. Of course, many other areas such as education, infrastructure, defence, family support and much more suffer from this. Nevertheless, every second pension in Germany is less than 800 euros. The ratio of contributors and contributors is getting worse and worse and will not improve in the future.  Already today, social transfers to immigrants per capita in Germany are higher than those to domestic welfare recipients. Unfortunately, Germany is increasing the number of low-skilled or unqualified immigrants further, thereby depriving it of financial leeway. Citizens whose life insurance policies, as well as their savings, are devalued, are increasingly relying on state pensions, even low pensions or social assistance, at least in Germany.  In the euro area, we need the policy of banks and insurers to be unbundled, not an increase in interdependence and dependence. We want free citizens and not the highest possible quota of citizens who depend on state services. Politics must deal with the consideration of reality. And in my country, and also in the EU, I do not trust the politicians to do so.

name: Sophia in ’t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I have to say that I’m a little bit confused having heard all the speakers, including Ms Trebesius who is now leaving, because apparently the fact that we don’t all have a proper pension later on is to be blamed on either evil neo-capitalists, the European Union, the European Central Bank or immigrants. Ms Trebesius is not sticking around to explain that to me, because I actually think that we rely a great deal on immigration for our economy and for the future of our health-care and pension systems. Never mind. I’m not really sure why we’re having this debate today on ‘fighting privatisation and strengthening public universal social security systems’. I mean it sounds as if a fierce attack were being mounted on our pension systems by private actors. I have not noticed that. I may not have read the newspapers properly but, as far as I can see, in those cases where there is an attack on pension systems, it’s twofold. One type of attack is by trade unions and left-wing parties who are refusing reform of the public systems, at the expense of the younger generation. They’re protecting the rights of the elderly. The average age of the board members of pension funds is, I believe, 56! I think there should be more 18-year-olds on the boards, deciding about their own future. Okay. The second type of attack is actually by governments because the attack that I’ve seen in certain countries, mainly in central and eastern Europe, has involved the government nationalising pension funds. This is basically doing what is being advocating here. They nationalised the pension funds in what I would call highway robbery, because people’s savings then went into the public coffers and were used for other purposes. In my dictionary that’s theft. In the Pan-European Personal Pension Product (PEPP) report – because of course that’s at the root of all this – we explicitly emphasised the need for strong first and second pillars. Nobody has denied the need for a strong public system, but there is also a third pillar – and I’m coming to a conclusion, Madam President! There is a third pillar which may allow people to achieve a proper pension in countries where the state systems do not supply that. That is what we want to achieve. I hope those people will not be denied their rights. (Applause)

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it is very important that we have this debate and, of course, that we move forward with demographic challenges when we talk about the pension system. But the big problem with the public pension system is not an ageing population: it is the precarious work and it is the attacks on workers' rights, which have made contributions fall very significantly and at the moment, indeed, some public pension systems are in difficulty. And of course it is a generational issue, but it is a generational issue because the precariousness of young people today puts today's and the future's pensions at risk in many of our Member States. That's the fundamental problem. What can the Commission do? What you don't have to do at first is send specific recommendations to countries like Spain, criticizing small and very few pension hikes when there have been successive reforms in 2011 and 2013 to further cut them. Therefore, to strengthen Pillar I and to tackle above all precariousness in the labour market in order to have good contributions to Social Security: that is what the European Union must do to have worthy pensions now and in the future.

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her According to Eurostat, the statistics office of the European Union, just over twenty percent of the European population is now at risk of old-age poverty or even affected. But instead of addressing the real problems in the pension system, the Commission and the majority of the House, as we have heard today, are clinging to the misconception that the capital market could somehow pay for pension provision. It's like entrusting a gambler with his laborious savings because he said he's sure to take it to the nearest bank, but he forgot to mention that his casino is on the way to that bank, and he always comes in to play.  Indeed, research by the investigative journalism network Investigate Europe shows how the Commission's financial lobby has worked at European level because it promises to be mad at pensions. The result was this Pan-European Personal Pension Product, or PEPP for short, which does not even meet the minimum requirements for a serious pension product. There is no guarantee that consumers will get what they have paid in, and at the same time the market is being opened up to hedge funds and asset managers – true to the motto: happy gamble with pensions. This policy exposes people to the whims of the capital market and, consequently, forces them to collect bottles in old age.  Stop this wrong policy! Work with us on a Europe of social protection! Join us in arguing for the introduction of a European minimum wage, a European unemployment insurance scheme and the strengthening of a pension system based on the principle of solidarity.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I would like to point out once again that, as I announced at the beginning of the sitting, there is no spontaneous procedure in this debate and that no blue cards are adopted. I'm sorry, woman in 't Veld. I would have liked to have done it, but unfortunately that is not possible.

name: Tim Aker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the pension system in the UK is showing increasing inequalities that should alarm us all. There always used to be a trade—off between working in the public and the private sector. The private sector was the wealth creator. There was high risk, but it also provided high rewards. Life in the public sector was low risk, by which I mean job security, but also provided rewards that were far lower than those expected in the private sector. It is, after all, the private sector that generates the taxes, the price we pay for a civilised society, and high-grade public services run by first-class public sector workers who knew that, barring economic catastrophe, they had a job for life. Now we have a complete reversal of the situation. Public sector pensions are protected, incredibly generous and yet horrifyingly unfunded. The money has got to come from somewhere, and no government has been honest enough to say where or even speculate if these promises will be met. Private sector pensions in Britain were the gold standard. That was until Gordon Brown raided them in the early Blair years and abolished the tax relief that pension funds earned on dividends from stock market investment. That was the end of final salary and many successful private pensions in Britain. Those now relying on the state pension can look on and see one of the worst in the developed world and one that they will have to work longer to see. In 2011, the coalition government introduced plans that were never in any manifesto voted on to increase the retirement age of women. This has brought about the Women Against State Pension Inequality campaign, a cause I completely support. To rush ahead proposals – life—changing plans – without adequate consultation and without giving people a chance to plan their lives was a heartless act, especially in times of economic strife. Policy—makers need to take an incredibly thoughtful look at the parlous state of British pensions. It is not good enough that we lose sight of the welfare of those who bequeathed to us a better standard of living only to give them less in return.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the financing of pensions is above all speculation, of course, of a good family man, but a speculation nonetheless. We put as little as possible on the table to touch as much as possible, as long as possible.  Therefore, no system is satisfactory: neither public funding, always closely linked to unemployment or work, depending on the time, many of which have been mismanaged, often bordering on scandals, when one looks at the general level of pensions in Europe; nor the private system, since the 2008 crisis showed the seriousness of the dysfunctions of predatory pension funds. So the new world that is opening up, with digitization, robotics and also economic migration flows, requires us to be very attentive and above all very rigorous. Unfortunately, the complementary European system proposed to us by the Commission will not be able to benefit the most vulnerable, who would need it most. It may even become monopolistic. So yes, of course, to several pillars of retirement - the public, the private sector and personalized savings - but always under the strict control and guarantee of the states, because it is not possible to make our pensioners the poor of today and tomorrow.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, the SYRIZA-ANEL government maintains in Greece the anti-labour legislation on new pension cuts from the beginning of 2019 and is making good on workers with the haggling it makes with the troika, when it has agreed to cuts in pension expenditure of up to 7.8 billion over the next three years. The Prime Minister's recent macabre allusion to pensioners reflects the European Union's reactionary strategy to reduce the time from retirement to death already implemented by increases in the retirement age by all capital governments, regardless of hue, or even staying in work and after retirement, even severely ill. The strategy of the European Union, SYRIZA and The New Republic for active ageing, for work in the deep old age, is common, with the Pinochet-type three-pillar system, which provides for pensions and benefits for the poor, pushing pensioners into the clutches of private insurance companies. Workers, pensioners and young people to organize their fight to recover the huge losses and abolish all anti-insurance, anti-labour laws and planning!

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I agreed with Ms in ’t Velt when she said that the title of this debate is somewhat ideological. What is needed in a proper pension debate in this Parliament is less ideology and more practicality. We have a falling birth rate, we have huge demographic changes, we have life expectancy, thankfully, growing, but we have less money being saved for the purposes of pensions, and we have huge varieties between Member States in terms of pension coverage. Take the Netherlands: about 90% coverage in terms of private pensions and in my own country, Ireland, for the private sector, the figure is about 40%, and massive varieties.  The only way we are going to get to a better place is with solid policies. The truth of the matter is that for the public sector, as regards their pensions, the best way to protect pillar one pensions into the future is for governments to run surpluses to put money aside so that their pensioners into the future have guarantees with regard to the basic old age pension for people as they get older. We need the private sector as part of this debate. I heard some ideological views from the left that we don’t, but we do. We have a totally underdeveloped personal pension area when it comes to private pensions in Europe. The market is currently worth about EUR 700 billion. That could double in the next 10 years if we get it right, and that’s about ensuring some certainty for savers, proper tax treatment when it comes to encouraging people to put money aside and also auto-enrolment, as they have in the Netherlands and other places, which encourages people to put money aside from a very early age. We should encourage people to save, and that is a personal responsibility, but it also makes sure that the mix of public policy is right. We have this vast difference from Member States east, west, north and south; we have a vast difference when it comes to occupational pensions. Anything we do should not undermine or diminish the existing savings in Member States that have good pension coverage systems in place. We need to tread carefully in this area to make sure that we give protection to savers and protect people who are putting part of their income on a weekly or monthly basis aside.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Madam President, I agree with this current debate: the privatisation of pension schemes is not a solution. The issue of pension levels is a major issue that is being addressed in most of our economies. We know the imbalances that exist, we know the fragility of our retirees, regardless of the systems in place. We know how the imbalance between men and women argues against women, argues against those who benefit from atypical employment schemes, against those who are not today salaried. We are in favour of strengthening the first and second pillars of pensions. We are against the development of PEPP as a single financial product. For us, this European pension product must be first and foremost a retirement project. That is why we and my group have contributed to the need for a minimum of 35% in the basic plan, and that, in the event of a capital outfing, it cannot exceed 30% of the accumulated amount in the basic plan. That is also why we have argued that the costs and charges on these basic schemes should not exceed 1% of the accumulated annual capital, which we have obtained, with the rapporteur's agreement, and I thank her for that. It is also for this reason that we have refused to allow the use of this product to be a means of developing a kind of tax dumping that would have allowed some to use this product as a financial investment tool and then to benefit from a tax regime of their free choice in the countries most favourable to capital accumulators. Nevertheless, there are still holes in the proposal and in the mandate of the European Parliament. The question, for example, of the definition of capital: is it nominal capital, is it capital after deducting costs? That is why my group abstained on this text in the committee vote. That is why we are asking our negotiating team, in the discussion to be engaged with the Council, to be vigilant on this point. This product can be useful for pension portability at a time when many people are on the move, have difficulty effectively transferring their pension and can benefit from such a plan. We want it to be a retirement product that guarantees new access to people who may be exposed to significant mobility.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Speaking in this debate, I would like to remind you that social security systems modelled on the Bismarck system created in the second half of the 19th century in Germany are the basis of modern welfare states. However, due to the increasing average life expectancy of insured persons and demographic problems in many countries, these systems increasingly require support from the budgets of individual Member States. However, the steady increase in wages in the economy and, consequently, the increase in the payment of insurance premiums, as well as the increase in the number of employees employed under the employment contract from which contributions are paid, mean that budget subsidies to the pension system do not have to increase at all. A good example in this case is my country, Poland, where such subsidies have not been increasing for two years.  However, the most important element of future pension systems is the demographic policy supporting fertility, as in the long term this is a key factor that will ensure the efficiency of pension systems in individual Member States. Three years ago, Poland also decided to support family policy by implementing the Family 500+ programme, for which it allocates around 1.5% of its GDP per year, which I would like to stress very strongly. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. It would be good for the European Social Fund to be able to support such family-funded schemes in individual Member States in the next financial perspective for the period 2021-2027, as they form the basis for the efficiency of public pension systems in all Member States.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the policy in the area we are talking about today is mainly created by younger people, so it is not superfluous to warn someone like me, who has already been in retirement and has returned to the living, that youth is fleeting, that more and more of us are older, and that those who today still avoid weighty debates and decisions that concern the older generation will also be soon alone in the years when they will be caught up in low pensions, weak health and other ailment of mature years.  It is already clear today that we will no longer be able to give up on the demographic trends we know, which are willing to be active even later years.  During this term of office, we dealt with the problems of the elderly more often than in the previous years. We are looking for a Place of the European Parliament in discourse on how to ensure a safe and dignified age, a decent level of pensions. This, of course, is different from country to country. However, there should be in the frameworks that ensure that nowhere in Europe do pensioners and older people, people with special needs and health problems are pushed to the brink of society, to the brink or beyond the brink of poverty.  We see that Member States are facing these problems in different ways, experimenting with systems, and it is too common practice for pension systems to adapt to more current budgetary needs. We are not looking for a universal and ubiquitous model, but it would be worth considering good solutions and replicateing them.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, you are creating social alarm. Redistributing wealth and ensuring a decent pension is contributing not to be socially excluded at the end of professional life.  Don't be fooled, it's not a demographic problem, it's not a problem of increasing the number of retirees. The only thing that endangers public pensions is a problem of focusing on the financial interest and economic policy in favour of austerity.  There is a scam in the system because, first of all, the Commission contributes to raising social alarm. He then implements austere policies for governments, many in his ranks, to carry out labour reforms and pension reforms. This social alarm brings many people to the streets, as was the case of the coordinator of the defence of the public pension system in the Spanish State of Galicia, my country, which is engaged in this matter. Finally, I would like to talk about another problem: the average European effort to maintain the pension system is higher, for example, than in the Spanish average, where they are the lowest in Europe. In particular, in Galicia much more and, in particular, in non-contributory pensions, especially.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I very much ask that those who say that the future of insurance is private pensions should not forget the past. What happened ten years ago? Do you remember how the crisis started? Such days were in September 2008. That's when the Lehman Brothers investment bank collapsed, dragging the savings of policyholders who thought private pensions could guarantee insurance for their old age. Do you really believe that the future of pensions can be guaranteed by the markets after the great crisis and the collapse of the third pillar? We also see this in Greece, when private Pinochet pensions are proposed by the New Democracy represented by the European People's Party. But also here in the European Parliament? Why are you ladies and gentlemen of the European People's Party and of the Liberals in such a hurry that the report should go straight to a tripartite debate and not even be debated in the European Parliament? Why are Brack Rock and the other big investment banks in a hurry to sell private pensions again? Are we, colleagues, going to allow this?

name: Steeve Briois (ENF).
text: Madam President, in order to discuss the future of pensions, we must ask ourselves the right questions. Is the European Union not responsible for the privatisation of our social security systems through the austerity measures it imposes on the Member States? In France, for example, is the future pension reform, on which the government is currently working, not stem from the recommendations of the European Commission dated 23 May? In any case, Mr Macron, on the other hand, zealously implements these recommendations. As a result, pensioners are suffering the consequences today, including the end of the indexation of pensions to inflation, which for them constitutes a significant loss of purchasing power.  While reducing our public deficit is essential to reduce our dependence on financial markets, this should not be done at the expense of pensioners. However, the current generalization of the funded pension system will plunge into poverty many retirees who have not been able to save enough in their lifetime. To ensure the sustainability of our pay-as-you-go pension systems, we are systematically locked into this infernal triptych: lower pensions, higher contributions and lower legal retirement age. We have witnessed the unbearable fate of pensioners in Greece, because of the austerity imposed by the European Union. This black scenario, we will fight with determination so that it will never be applied in France.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, the future of pensions in the present circumstances is not just ominous. It's nonexistent. Pensions are converted into benefits and pensioners are relegated to beggars. What universality are we talking about when pensions in Greece are cut with only information from television and with radio silence from the government? When those incompetent governments refuse to admit their mistakes? When in an instant they become familiar and divest decades of work? When the answer to the real needs of citizens is the wooden invocation of fiscal policy? When the Prime Minister of Greece, who only yesterday in this Chamber was applauded for his economic choices, immorally wishes the 70-year-olds not to long on the altar of supposed economic success? The principles of a legal and sustainable system are simple but basic: compulsory insurance, minimum guaranteed decent pension, proportionality and stability of contributions, remunerative benefits, support for continuity of contributions in redistribution terms, long-term structured savings and the creation of reserves.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: Mr President, pensions and Europe. It is often a sensitive subject, especially in my own country and that is not so strange. The European Union actually has few powers in this area. The Member States themselves are responsible for the establishment of their social system and their pension system, and above all they must remain so. There's no other way. The differences in pension provisions between Member States in the EU are life-size. It is impossible and undesirable to turn it into a kind of European unity sausage. Pension system deserve customization. And that customization can be delivered especially at national level.  However, that does not mean that we do not have a common challenge. Ageing, for example, is taking place in all European countries. At the turn of the century we counted about four workers per pensioner. In a few decades we have fallen back to two workers who will have to pay the costs for one pensioner. So we are facing a huge challenge when it comes to the affordability of the first pillar in particular. That challenge is there in all countries. We must therefore ensure from the EU that our regulations do not make it more difficult for those countries that already have successful second-pillar pensions, but that we encourage other countries to set up such systems as well.  When we voted on IBPV legislation here, we commissioned the Commission to set up a high-level working group to examine how to boost occupational pension provision. I would very much appreciate it if Commissioner Oettinger could give a little update on this.  At the same time, I find it regrettable – like others – that the left is actually trying to create a kind of false contradiction between the first pillar and the other pillars with this debate. A fair look at the future shows that if we want a good retirement system for all European citizens, we need a healthy mix of the three pillars. The sooner the left sees that, the better, for all European citizens, both now and in the future.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, to say that the first pillar of pension is necessary is not enough.  The first pillar of the pension must first be strong, i.e. with a replacement rate that does not plunge pensioners into poverty. It must be non-discriminatory, i.e. it must compensate for situations where there are pension gaps, such as for women. It needs to be modernized, of course, but not only in relation to the ageing of the population, but also in relation to new forms of contracts. Today, we see employment reforms, at zero contribution rates, which are only gifts to businesses, but which are deadly for the pension system. And so to say that pensions are not within European competence is wrong because the European Semester system today requires countries to make savings in their social security. And social security is the pension system. Today, social security is approached, not on the basis of the well-being of individuals, but on the savings that we will be able to make. It is a short-term management of social security. So transferring the collective solidarity solution of pay-as-you-go pensions to an individual system of capitalisation is not the solution. PEPP (a pan-European individual retirement savings product) may be a financial savings product, which we probably need to improve. But the PEPP is simply a plus for those who already have, but it is nothing at all for those who do not today, and therefore our concern must go to those who today are not covered by a fair pension system that allows them to live in dignity.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which This debate comes far too late. It is astonishing that we are only now addressing the crisis in state pension systems, where this crisis has actually been looming for decades. I am here at the ripe age of 56, and I was a member of the baby boomers in Germany. We know that in Germany and in many other European countries, the birth rate has been steadily declining since the 1960s. And while we still had a birth surplus in the 1960s and the population grew, it has been shrinking for decades. This shrinking population is causing the levy system to go into deep crisis. Because, of course, the rate of return of the levy procedure depends crucially on the size of the population growth rate. We have been in a situation for a long time now where the rate of population growth is negative. In other words, it is not possible to build up a sustainable guarantee of pension provision solely on the basis of the levy procedure.  The alternative is, of course, a capitalisation procedure, and this capitalisation procedure is now being maddened by colleagues on the left and those on the far right. They say this is a vicious form of privatization. No, that's not it! This is simply another offer to citizens to better secure themselves at a time when the levy system has reached the limits of its capacity. It must be seen that it is not only demographic developments that jeopardise the pay-as-you-go procedure. We must not only see that the increase in life expectancy continues to strain the pay-as-you-go system, at least if we do not also increase the retirement age at the same time. Another problem is that the pay-as-you-go procedure, in its foundation as an element of the intergenerational contract, was actually an insurance against unwanted childlessness. And today the problem is that there is far more than the problem of unwanted childlessness. There is the big problem of wanting childlessness – people who simply don't want to raise children or want to be humble with a child. These people have great earning potential. They pay into the pay-as-you-go system and draw the corresponding income from the pensions of the pay-as-you-go system. But they do not fulfil the second part – or, if you like, the first part – of the intergenerational contract, that they also give birth to and raise children themselves, and then pay those children into the pension insurance system later. Because of these difficulties in the pay-as-you-go procedure, we need to supplement the pay-as-you-go procedure, and this can be a capitalisation procedure. It is now completely wrong for colleagues on the left and colleagues on the far right to see it as a vicious privatisation. Because, of course, it is the case that private companies can offer this. But it is just as well possible for the state to offer a capitalisation procedure. There is really no objection to the fact that the State also saves an asset fund and that, for example, non-insurance benefits, which are currently subject to the pay-as-you-go procedure, are fed from such an asset fund or from the income of the asset fund. Many states already have what is called a sovereign wealth fund, but few actually use it to address the pressing problem of retirement provision. We could do that. We could use this asset fund to invest in much-needed tasks, for example in the area of infrastructure investment. We could encourage business investment with high rates of return and use the returns to better hedge old age. These are all possibilities which the levy procedure does not have at its disposal. And if there is such a state-driven capitalization procedure, then the state also has an interest in high interest rates. The problem that has been raised is that we now have a low interest rate phase and that the capitalisation procedure is no longer worthwhile and that the Riester pension has halved in present value, for example, would be solved if the state finally ensured that we were earning decent interest on our savings.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, a privileged instrument for realising the ethical-political imperative of solidarity is the existence of a pension system that guarantees conditions of dignity in old age. This pension system must be supported, first of all, by the beneficiary himself through the discounts made throughout his contributory life, but it must also be borne by the contributions and taxes of those who are now at full in their contributory capacity. This effort should not be seen as a generosity of today's generations, but rather as the payment of a debt of gratitude to our elderly. They paid with their taxes and contributions to schools where we study for free as children, adolescents and young people, as well as the health services we all benefit from. So the least we can do today is also an effort to guarantee them economic conditions so that they can have an end of life with dignity. On the other hand, a public pension system is not in itself better than a private system. It all depends on the effectiveness of the control mechanisms that can be exercised over who manages the available money. It all depends, finally, on the ability to prevent corruption or abuses of power. Unfortunately, there are states, even within the European Union, which are not a good example of managing pension systems.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Our pension system is sick. Although contributions to pension insurance are very high, there is a lot of old-age poverty. This poverty in old age will increase considerably in the coming years. Private provision of provision is of little help, especially for these people, and also for the EU in part. Because we do not have enough money to invest it in any way that it is not eaten up by inflation. Investing in funds also brings great uncertainty. The bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers should be a lesson to us.  In my opinion, the only sensible solution is that all income is used for a public pension fund, including income from shares and corporate profits, for example – as is already the case in Switzerland today. This relieves the middle class. There should be minimum and maximum pensions. Only in this way can our pension system become safe and efficient again.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, pensions are not a gift: they are the result of years of contributions, they are workers' wages. When you talk about pensions, you propose to extend years of work and private plans, such as the pan-European pension product, which we totally reject. If public pension systems are at risk, it is because of their reform policy and the limits of public spending on pensions arising from their unfair spending rule. It should be remembered that pensions are employment-related, good wages, stable and rights-related. That is why we must end the precariousness, the temporality, the zero-hour contracts that young people suffer. And we must also end the gender pay gap. We must, of course, reverse the labour and pension reforms that you have encouraged. So if you radically change your policies and your neoliberal agenda, you will see how they find positive solutions for the social majority and, above all, you will see how workers thank you and the far right continues to grow.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Madam President, as European citizens grow older and live longer, national government pension schemes are under strain. They suffer from the basic problem that pensions payable today are taken from taxes paid today. Policy-makers have taken decisions that the funding gap must come from raising the pension age and increasing mass immigration to supply labour from below. These policies are short-sighted, as the immigrants of today will be the pensioners of tomorrow, and to pay for them would require much more immigration.  Governments that solve the pensions crisis will be those that enact smarter policies on the three pillars of government, state and corporate and private pensions. Public schemes must become investment-based schemes, not tax-matched schemes, and contributions must start much earlier.  Legislation should guarantee pension portability of corporate pension schemes to help those who move jobs regularly. The tax system must be used to incentivise the growth of private self-managed pension schemes, and the governments must use tax incentives to improve technological advances in administration and fund management. Such practical improvements are the basis of improving pensions for the many, not the few.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: Mr President, a debate on the future of pensions cannot be held without naming the concerns of the next generation. I don't think I'm the first to stress this this afternoon: will there still be a pension for us, for my generation? Ageing is a fact. Figures show that the population will continue to increase. But the active population will continue to decline at the same time. That's less of a working way to support more people. This means increasing costs for public pensions, which will become increasingly difficult to finance. As former President of the European Council, Herman Van Rompuy, said: 'With an evolution from four to two active people for one pensioner within fifty years, it is no longer a question of left or right, but purely arithmetic.'  I believe that the real solution to control pension costs is contained in three things: Firstly, we need to get public budgets in the euro area in order, so that there is room to absorb the growth in pension costs.  Secondly, the degree of activity must be increased. The more people are in work, the more contributions there are to pensions.  Thirdly, re-measures are needed to reform the pension system itself and to keep people in work longer.  Finally, part of the solution is also for people to invest more in a supplementary pension themselves. We have known for longer than today that public money will not be available in the long term. Incentives must therefore be put in place to make both the second and third pillars accessible to all.  All too often it is the bottom of society that does not set aside money for later. The fact that the parties that are supposedly standing up for these people are on the brakes for ideological reasons is wrong, even unjust. The private market can indeed offer solutions. But then we must all dare to sit at the table and create a framework for this. For example, after retirement, people have the security of a guaranteed supplementary income, on top of the pension, for the rest of their life. Let us therefore work together on a global vision to tackle this problem. Let's show for once that as politicians we can also think about long-term

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: Mr President, the care of old age applies to every generation, to the old and the young generations. That has to come first. Financial products are often sought. That's very human. We'd rather make money work than work ourselves. Again, that's very human, but not always wise. For three reasons: First, the return on money is currently low. Interest rates are lower than ever. This means that money will not work for us and there is still talk in this Parliament of a pan-European pension product. Again, people will have to save, while the money does not yield much. Interest rates are low. The return is low. What we do need is for people to stay fit, enjoy going to work and being able to handle that work, even at a later stage of their career. But for that we have to invest and not save. The second reason is that money is looking for financial returns, when it should be about social returns. Not only profit but also people and planet. That's exactly what sustainable finance is about, which is a broader look so that pension funds and insurers don't just put money into fossil energy companies, companies that violate human rights, or companies that evade taxes. There is also a social return. Thirdly, return cannot be without risk. It is therefore a matter of achieving a fair distribution of those risks. For this we are not looking at individualising the pension scheme, but we are ensuring a collective insurance of risks, so that care for everyone for the old age is good and people do not have to fear for that old age.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, while we are discussing the serious issue of pensions, millions of pensioners in Greece are living in agony whether or not pensions will be cut from 1 January 2019. Because these are the troika's orders, these are the agreements Mr. Tsipras signed with the lenders. There must be an answer to this in Greece, where pensioners have literally been impoverished, where a quarter of pensioners live on less than EUR 500 gross, i.e. 1 157 000 pensioners. Also, 611 000 pensioners get 372 euros gross per month. You realize that under these conditions and under these conditions no one can live. And, of course, widow's pensions are also falling apart. 80 000 people have a problem because they are bleeding. But there's an answer. We had proposed a recapitalisation of the insurance system; The troika with its policies drove unemployment to 29%, so the entire insurance system was dismantled. I suggested yesterday to Mr Tsipras that he should keep the 24 billion euros left over from the third loan package and recapitalise the insurance funds with 12 billion euros. To ensure the sustainability of the insurance system! There is no need to cut pensions! This was imposed by the IMF. The evidence shows that there should be no reduction in pensions both because of the procedures but also because of the very social sensitivity that needs to be done. So there is a solution: recapitalisation of the insurance system! We recommended it. The troika is deaf and the Tsipras government is deaf!

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to express my commitment to public systems, universal and worthy of social security, which are expressions of intergenerational solidarity. That is why its viability is threatened, in the first place, by the demographic decline of the Union. This is such a serious and notorious problem that right now it needs a smarter and more open policy of immigration and people integration, which must be, for all purposes, new Europeans. Job precariousness is the second major threat to social security. With unworthy temporary contracts and remuneration, even if the number of people occupied is 19 levels, contributions will not be enough. Reviewing the retirement age may be necessary, but it is much more dignified by the conditions of employment. Finally, it is urgent that social security systems be consistent with the mobility of workers that must operate in the Union. This requires taking seriously the establishment of minimum standards of coverage and efficient procedures for the relationship between the systems of the different Member States.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, pension systems only have a future when they really protect workers and their toil. The Union's political choice to downgrade public pension schemes and to promote private schemes, which will bear the shoulders of the workers themselves, is intended solely to satisfy the interests of insurance and financial capital. The restructuring of pension systems does not result from an ageing population. It stems from the philosophy and persistence of the dominant circles of the Union in the unbridled free market and neoliberalism. This includes temporary flexible forms of work, lack of insurance and poorly paid contracts, which are a means of violently reducing so-called labour costs. What is needed are policies that will first of all ensure decent work that requires social security. There are many relevant conventions signed by the Union and the Member States of the International Labour Organisation on decent work. This can sustain sustainable and strengthen public pension systems.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is an example of the disastrous impact of state regulations. Unfortunately, from what I see, you completely do not understand what disaster they bring to us and to ourselves to maintain this system. You don't understand cause-and-effect relationships, you don't understand what it came from. This is because since the system of state pensions was introduced in the 19th century, people have ceased to see a link between having children and maintaining them in old age. And as long as you maintain the illusion through state guaranteed pensions that these two facts are not dependent on each other, people will be less and less, there will be more and more people who need to work and those who are no longer working and less and less working.  This has worsened with the invention of the birth control pill, and there is widespread approval in this House for both contraception and state pension systems. So you are sawing the branch on which they sit, and this leads to an inevitable catastrophe regardless of the various shifts in budgets, etc. People need to start seeing the connection between the fact that they don't have children, the fact that they won't have a livelihood in old age.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the aim of pension systems must be to ensure adequate income levels to our elders, ensuring the overall economic sustainability of the system. It is clear that employment is the best guarantee to achieve this. However, demographic changes force us to propose reforms to achieve this, reforms that should not focus on a widespread increase in taxes, as it would have a medium and long-term negative impact on economic growth and job creation and therefore adversely affect social security systems.  We must move gradually towards a mixed system which, on the one hand, ensures that current pensioners and those who are about to do so receive what they have contributed in their working lives and, on the other hand, do not jeopardize the future rights of our young people. That is, to combine a distribution pillar with a capitalization pillar, linking what has been received with what has been contributed and which can be supplemented by private pension plans. This complementarity does not mean ending the public, since its function is essential, above all, to meet the basic needs of those who have been less quoted or who have not been able to quote for different reasons.  Similarly, it is important to underline the work of public systems in support of widowhood, orphanhood or disability, as well as their support for the elderly who need it most to ensure minimum income that avoids situations of risk of poverty or social exclusion. It means adapting to today's reality, looking to the future and being as fair as possible to our citizens.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, a part of European citizenship looks at your retirement age with fear and anxiety. They wonder if they will be entitled to a benefit, whether this benefit is going to be excessive and whether they will be able to survive with it, or whether they will be strong enough to work every year they give access to pensions—by the way, more and more. And to respond to this anxiety and this fear the only answer may be the security, guarantees and protection of our public pension system: a well-endowed system, with guarantees, that ensures that benefits are increasing at the same level as the cost of living and that it assures all our pensioners a decent life. And to reject outright any mechanism for privatisation of our pension systems, which have proved unfair and ineffective. But not just this. What needs to be done is also to ensure a robust state, quality jobs and combat inequality; also the gender gap. Because these three issues (employment, state capacity and inequality) impact the sustainability and fairness of our pension system.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, from the Pension White Paper to the pan-European private pension product, all the Commission's measures have been aimed at dismantling the public pension system. Don't say that pensions are not sustainable, more than that, it is that pensions are essential to sustain life.  Today in Spain, precisely where there have been two reforms to dismantle pensions — one in 2011, from the Socialist Party, and one in 2013 from the People's Party —unfortunately 300,000 families live off the pensions of grandparents and grandmothers, because while they have implemented cuts, the welfare state has been dismantled, and working conditions, wages have been devalued and jobs destroyed , it was the pensioners who have borne the burden of the crisis on their backs.  There are solutions: raise wages, fight the pay gap, promote stable employment, improve funding sources, eliminate price caps to higher wages. It's a matter of will and objectives. Who are we with? With financial institutions that want to make pensions a business or are we with the families who need and deserve them?

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab All experts and a majority of Members of the European Parliament agree that a stable and safe pension system must be diversified. We cannot create a good pension system unless it is based on at least two pillars: a strong public pillar and a strong private pillar. The public pillar should guarantee a minimum pension, while the private pillar should enable citizens to increase the benefits they will receive in the future. Of course, especially in the case of the public pillar, the State should secure guarantees and ensure adequate security of contributions, invest them responsibly, safely and sustainably. Today, Eu citizens need certainty that the contributions paid will actually be paid to them in the form of safe pensions. We must not forget to educate young people about the importance of saving and securing their future for the duration of retirement. When planning the retirement age, we should respond to the lengthening lives of european union citizens. In this case, of course, the specificities of certain professions must be taken into account. Finally, I would like to draw your attention to mobile workers. By promoting the mobility of workers, we must ensure that they are able to continue social security and that the rights acquired in different Member States can be transferred. This has a huge link to the current debate on the coordination of social security systems. The fragmentation of social security must not be allowed. Let us remember that maintaining 24 months, during which the employee remains in the country of origin security system, ensures safety.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: Madam President! The European Union must be a union of strong welfare states, a bulwark for each country and a pure opportunity to provide its citizens with a fine-meshed social safety net, including a fair pension system, with respect for the national and historical differences that exist between our countries. The Social Democrats stood up to the Danish welfare society – it is built up through generations of toil, it suits us. But Europe's welfare states are under pressure, from international tax fraud, draining the state coffers of much-needed billions to welfare, from bourgeois politicians who claim to be privatising, outsourcing and saving for better welfare. That is not the way to do this, and that is why Europe must be the defence of the welfare states and its citizens for a proper pension system, proper welfare, proper health, proper education, it must guarantee the freedom of our welfare states and the sustainability of our welfare states.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, in this Europe, Brussels decides and the states execute. In France, pension reform, supposedly wanted by Macron but in fact on the injunction of Brussels, is no exception to the rule. The European Semester says "gradually unify the rules of different pension schemes," and Macron applies. The European Commission says "save five billion by lining up pension schemes": Macron applies and commits France to a point pension reform that will see pensions fall and the big winners will be the markets, banks and insurance. This beautiful Europe that protects... in reality, this Europe protects the rich, and it is always the same story: we take the people to redistribute to the rich.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I would like to recall what I said at the beginning of the sitting, that there is no spontaneous procedure for speaking in this debate and that no blue cards are adopted. I'm very sorry about that, but I keep getting signs. I have to repeat here what I have said twice before that it is not possible today.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is good that, even at European Union level, we are also talking more and more recently about pensions and the pension system. It is certainly an area that affects all Europeans and all Europeans. But regardless, I advocate the thesis that the pension system and its regulation remain subject to subsidiarity in individual countries.  Ensuring access to social protection for all is certainly one of the values and objectives that we have in the European Union, of which we are proud, which is why I also support the public system and the first pillar of pension insurance as one that offers basic security.  However, with the demographic picture deteriorating, it is also necessary to think of other options. However, I would point out that these other options do not mean the exclusion and diminishing importance of the first pillar, but rather complement and complementacity. Of course, I am therefore pleased and I also support our talks on the so-called pan-European pension product, which will also offer such additional insurance options for old age. With the increasing mobility of our workforce or employees, it is of course essential to ensure such a single product at European level.  And there is another important point that I would like to touch on: pension systems must also follow the evolution of time. What was sustainable 50 years ago, when we had a completely different relationship between employees and pensioners, is not sustainable today. Therefore, countries must ensure that their systems are modern and keep pace with the development of time and allow decent pensions for all their pensioners.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Secretary of State, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. A strong first pillar is not a utopia. A strong allocation system is possible. It is not for nothing that we see this when we look at where pensioners have better got over the financial market crisis. These are precisely those countries that trust a levy system – quite simply because it is more stable.  What does this mean for the boys? For young people, this means pushing for a strong levy system, because that is the best guarantee for the future: a strong levy system and an active, inclusive labour market strategy, a high level of employment – employment is particularly important here. The ultimate goal of pensions is precisely to ensure living standards in old age. You should be able to live well from the pension. And I can only say so much about my country, Austria, which trusts in the levy system, that it succeeds better here than other European countries. So the levy system is a system for the future.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, having a decent pension cannot depend on each person's individual savings capacity. Having a decent pension has to be guaranteed by public institutions. That is why I ask the Commission, Parliament and also the Council to withdraw the pan-European product of individual pensions, and instead put the three institutions to work on a new regulation guaranteeing worthy pensions and public pension systems and measures to ensure that moving from working life to retirement does not mean entering poverty; public budgets to guarantee public pensions; ending the gender gap in pensions, as well as people working in agriculture and at sea and self-employed people in general; to put an end , as I say — to the inequality of maintaining pensions through pan-European private pension products.

name: Geoffroy Didier (PPE).
text: Madam President, when asked about his future retirement, a young European worker does not wonder how much it will amount to, he wonders above all if he will have one. And this fear of youth is not an irrational fear, it is a legitimate sense of concern because today's observation, as we all know, is alarming. According to the European Commission, more than 17 million elderly people are now at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU. And in France - I do not choose the example of this country by chance - the most optimistic forecasts do not envisage a return to financial balance before 2036. So this courage, this lack of courage precisely, is the observation of today: our rulers lacked courage. And contrary to what Emmanuel Macron, who calls the French, I quote, "Gaulois resistant to change", I see precisely the value of being European in order to be able to draw inspiration from the good practices of other countries. With regard to, for example, the retirement age, in France we have opted for a departure at 62, whereas in Germany, Spain or Poland it is planned for 67 years and swedes are planning to raise it to 69. Yes, in France as elsewhere, given the increase in our life expectancy, which is happy news, I say, we can and we must work longer. And what is certain is that it is time, all over Europe, that retirement becomes the right reward for a working life, and not just a variable of budgetary adjustment of leaders clearly lacking courage.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
