text: Madam President, we are discussing the strengthening of public social insurance systems which must take account of their sustainability and must be based and adapted to contributions and demographic changes and, unfortunately, we are hearing arguments about how to structure them and how we will rely, in fact, on private insurance. Commissioner, the issue before us is not just technocratic. It is about social groups, it is about people and it is therefore also political and that does need boldness. The role of the social partners is therefore crucial, otherwise, if they rely on the private sector alone, the privileged will continue to be privileged and the poorest will become poorer. An example from Cyprus: in 2013, along with deposits, thousands of people who had money in insurance funds were "tired". That is why their protection is also a European mechanism;

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider the private pillar and supplementary pension insurance to be complementary to those decided by the Member States. In many countries this is a tradition and there are countries where this private insurance system works very well. We also have optional private insurance in the Czech Republic. But the question of the future of pensions should not be reduced to what is better, whether state or private pension systems. However, in view of the ageing population and other challenges, pension reforms need to be addressed in this context as well, and we need to reflect on how the system responds to the balance of family, private and working life that we are dealing with here in the European Parliament in many proposals.  In 2011, my own KDU-ČSL party came up with a proposal that working parents pay lower social contributions depending on the number of children. As a result, people would not be punished for having children to look after and not being able to contribute to a private pension pillar. The benefits for the sustainability of pension systems are also clear. By returning to work earlier, parents could contribute to the state budget earlier and would undoubtedly feel the company's support for their children. I consider this measure to be as important as other social systemic benefits. Unlike the widespread increase in parental contributions, this has not only an individual but also a social impact.

name: Michael Detjen (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think that every European, every worker in Europe, must know that they will receive a pension that will also guarantee their standard of living in retirement – in a stable state model that is independent of the fluctuations in the capital market. The financial products announced by the insurance industry as a stable pillar have proved to be not particularly viable in retrospect. The pension must be linked to the development of productivity in the economy and not to the number of children's heads. The level of pensions must be based on the actual course of people's employment. It is not acceptable to be in employment for forty years and then fall into social assistance somewhere in Europe. Respect for life's benefit means being able to continue your lifestyle with your pension when you are no longer in work.

name: La Présidente. –
text: Hello my dear colleagues, I will pass the floor to my colleague Liberadzki, not without having, once again, wished him a very happy birthday.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the subject itself, namely the strengthening of the public social security system. There were phrases here that this title is ideological. Well, no – the title is not ideological, the title is simply social. And this is not about a welfare state that has different connotations. This is a responsible state and this is, in my opinion, crucial. We want a dignified life. Part of the last stage of a decent life is a decent pension, i.e. guaranteed and, secondly, an amount that will allow you to survive.  Citizens save for retirement in different ways, it is true – forced, but there have been phrases that the public part is invalid. I come from a country where today's Khadec liberals introduced a private insurance system in the late 1990s. A dozen years later, they were back in the state budget. The basis should therefore be a public, decent pension system. I would like to say to the Commissioner: Commissioner, I am in favour of the European Pillar of Social Rights announced by the Commission. Reach for it. Let's do something that's saved there.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the questions of sustainability and adequacy that face basic pension systems need first to be faced and solved on a national basis before they can realistically be dealt with on a European basis.  In my view such solutions cannot be grounded only on increasing the work span in citizensʼ lives and on a rise in contributions, nor should they be reduced to a further privatisation of parts of the pension system. The latter should be regarded as an integral part of the public commitment within the state budget, with the highest priority being given to the most vulnerable.  Indeed, this is part of the wider European heritage on the social front, shared by the right and the left, from Bismarck to Willy Brandt. It should not be abandoned. Balance in state budgets should fully include, on the expenditure side, the underwriting of shortfalls between outgoings and income over basic pension payments and revenues. This would necessarily entail a radical revision of national budgetary strategies by way of spending priorities, implying a greater emphasis on investment and on modernisation of social welfare delivery, plus a re-engineering of taxation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, we really all agree that people who have worked their whole lives must receive a dignified pension in old age. And ideally, a sufficient pension would be paid from a public fund and even more would accrue people into occupational funds or additional insidation. But what is the reality? Pensioners in Lithuania, Germany, Italy or Greece receive very different pensions. Here, for example, in my country, Lithuania, a frequent pensioner has to survive out of ten euros per day. It's life in poverty. That is why we here, both in the Institutions of the European Union and in the Member States, need to invest more, first of all, in quality jobs, in decent wages, in serious quality employment, because, first of all, how much a person works, how much he accumulates in his or her working life and how much he receives wages, he very often receives such a pension. And I would also like to point out that in the European Union the pension gap between men and women is still huge, even 40%. It means we still have a lot of work to do in this area.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This debate was very important today, and I hope that it does not stop at this one time. There is hardly a social area that moves people more. Many people in Europe are afraid of getting older because they do not know whether they will end their lives in poverty. Nowhere are there more myths, misinformation, half-truths, and that is why we need an objective debate. The Commission could provide a framework for this. We should also discuss politically how social risks are most effectively safeguarded. This is not always done through privatisation, on the contrary. Here, too, the European level could provide a good basis for comparing best practices. Above all, however, political action is also needed. The area of services of general interest should be subject to specific rules, as provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon. This requires a new approach, and it must not be the case that public services are at a disadvantage compared to the private sector.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. In many Member States of the European Union, the risk of poverty in old age is a serious social problem. We know that the number of citizens who are marginalised in old age is increasing. It is impermissible for older people to be placed in unbearable conditions as a result of increasing social inequalities, so I consider it in the common European interest to find solutions that reduce and mitigate this threat. One such possible solution is to regulate the functioning of private pension funds supplementing the state pension in Europe. However, this is not an accessible solution for everyone, which is why we must also think of citizens who, for some reason, are not entitled to a state pension or receive only a small number of pensions. For them, a comprehensive European model of social care must be created. I think that if the European Parliament takes the idea of a social Europe seriously, it must first and foremost think of these people.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. All the speakers unanimously stressed the objective that the citizens of Europe deserve human dignity, a sufficiently good, stable standard of living and also personal independence in old age. We are in agreement on the objective.  Secondly, the Commission believes that, along with the historically developed pension schemes, along the not in all Member States the same age structure, along the different labour and social law, the competence for pension provision should continue to lie first and foremost with the Member States. They are primarily responsible.  On the commission, I share the view of many speakers that pay-as-you-go statutory pensions must remain the most important, the central pillar, which will then be supplemented to varying degrees in the Member States from national budgets – and thus to be financed by taxation. We believe that occupational pensions along different cultures in the Member States is also a second sensible, albeit narrower pillar. And we believe that even grown private pension schemes, often motivated by tax incentives, have a complementary – not replaceable – meaning as a third pillar.  However, the market for private pension products in Europe is not sufficiently exhausted. And only in a few Member States does private pension provision have a significant importance, with up to fifteen per cent of total pension provision. And here we want to make an offer – not a duty.  We want to strengthen the national legislator by offering accordingly, by building a European internal market with serious products. The extent to which these products are then used is a matter for national policy, but also for our citizens in all the Member States. It shouldn't be an obligation, it should be an offer.  In this sense, we have noted your critical and constructive contributions and will take them into account in the further procedure, but believe that the Commission's proposal can be a good basis for complementary support for the primary national and private pension provision in the Member States.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank you for this very interesting discussion. It showed that even young people will be concerned in the near future by the pension systems. So it is very important to think about these pension systems. However, the Council does not take decisions on specific features of national pension systems. It is up to each Member State to take decisions on their own pension systems. The Member States retain full responsibility for the organisation of such systems, as was also mentioned by the Commissioner. In the context of the European Semester in June this year, the Council welcomed the fact that in most countries, recent pension reforms have had a positive impact on sustainability by containing public expenditure dynamics. However, on the basis of the economic and budgetary projections for the Member States over the period 2016-2070, presented in the 2018 Ageing Report, the Council also noted that the scale of reforms in several countries was still insufficient to curb the increase in public pension expenditures. The Council therefore underlined that further steps still need to be taken by Member States. The Council’s priorities do not refer to the need for private schemes. Policy decisions in this area are made by national governments based on whatever action they deem appropriate to tackle their own individual challenges. I think there is also a lot to do for the Member States and I hope that every Member State will do that. We can only do so much.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – It is our task to ensure that European citizens can look to the future with the peace of mind of knowing that the pension system that awaits them will be sound, well endowed and guarantee them decent pensions. Pension funds in the global economy, in a 0% interest rate scenario, have a difficult task to secure future pensions, as their investments are going to have fewer and fewer benefits. Who and how the rules of the game are set in the global economy will have an essential impact on the future of pensions. Privatization is not the answer to the sustainability of the pension system. Private pension funds are risky financial products that are based on speculation. A robust, well-organized and run public social security system is much safer and more economically efficient. Privatization of pension systems not only does not help protect pensioners from the insolvency of the system, but also increases the deficit of States by referring funds from the public to private pension funds.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – The regulation, maintenance and operation of social protection systems, such as pension systems, are the responsibility of the Member States in accordance with the applicable rules. Member States' pension systems are diverse and diverse and have a long history of development. Therefore, changes to member states' pension systems have internal limitations and risks. Previous EU debates on pensions (Green Paper, White Paper on Pensions) have shown that, due to historical circumstances, established institutional systems, other characteristics (different levels of earnings, traditions, financial infrastructure) systems are quite different, and that their changes can only be made slowly, under the right conditions, in close interaction with various factors. It is not possible to develop optimal solutions for pension systems that are equally useful for all countries. There's no decorated model that can be copied. This was also convinced by the EP debates on pensions in the wake of the White Paper. At the same time, a number of questions relating to the future of pensions, such as demographic trends and ageing challenges, put on the agenda questions for which jointly formulated answers and methods can be useful. This is true despite the fact that demographic issues and ageing are present at different stages in each Member State. Discourse on finding common solutions and learning from good practices can be useful for all participants. These initiatives are worth supporting, but they can only function properly in local circumstances and conditions.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for the Council to present its position on the draft general budget for the 2019 fiscal year (2018/2737 (RSP)). So we are going to start this debate, but I want to inform you that there will be no on-demand interventions or blue cards on this one.

name: Hartwig Löger
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner and ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is a great honour and pleasure for me to present the Council's position on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2019 here today, as an MEP, but above all in the even greater interest of the citizens who are here today and can also watch live.  I am pleased that, during the Austrian Presidency too, it has been possible to draw up a balanced commission proposal and to be able to adopt it unanimously with all the Member States. We have drawn up a proposal which provides for a total budget approach to the commitments of EUR 164 billion for 2019. And this proposal has succeeded in achieving an increase of 2.09% compared to 2018.  I am pleased that Parliament's report, which was adopted by a large majority in this House on 5 July, also confirmed that we have been able to achieve a great deal of agreement on the priorities we are setting for the European Union for 2019 and beyond. And so, in the Council's proposal – together with this Report by Parliament – we see a good basis for being able to discuss and adopt these common priorities in a common budget in 2019. The clear priorities we see together relate to the issue of youth in Europe, our common future, which is also manifested in the strengthening and promotion of young people at European level, growth and employment – also as a basis for social peace in Europe – and the issue of security and migration.  We all know that, at the same time, we are facing major challenges, especially in 2019. We do not yet know what the negotiations on the UK's exit will be. We are currently having major discussions with America in connection with trade relations, which are also under discussion at global level. We also see from this summer that in many regions of Europe natural disasters, exemplified by a major drought, are likely to put an additional strain on us in the future in budgetary reasons. The migration crisis has taken on a level that has improved significantly compared to recent years. Nevertheless, just referring to Today's speech by President Jean-Claude Juncker, it is important to point out that we need to act here, particularly with regard to migration, which is on the move on the continent of Africa and where we are called upon to take measures to improve this situation.  For all of us, and you in particular, 2019 is also an election year for the European Parliament. This makes it all the more important to demonstrate here and to show that we are able to work together – the European Parliament, the Commission and the European Council – to lay a common basis on what we are responsible for in terms of expenditure towards taxpayers at European level.  Allow me to mention a few important basic data on the Council's position: the starting point of the Commission's proposal has laid a basis for an increase of around three% compared to 2018. I make no secret of the fact that this was a very difficult starting point for the discussion in the Council's discussions with all the Member States, because in most Member States the budget estimates are well below this increase approach, and I dare say that it is my own responsibility: we have planned an increase of less than one% for Austria's budget for 2018 and 2019. Therefore, our position and our proposal, with sensible, balanced planning, but with an increase of more than two% as I announced at the start, is the common one. can also cover important projects well. The Council's proposed position for the 2019 budget, unlike the Commission's proposal, is a difference of around EUR 1.5 billion. This is significantly lower than the difference in the previous year's proposal. It is important that we all recognise that it will be necessary to use this approach to increase, in particular, to continue high-performing programmes and to support priorities in the right form, as outlined in the introduction. In order to put the priorities into practice with measures, I would like to give some examples to which we have paid particular attention: we have earmarked an increase of ten percent for the Erasmus programme in this proposal, an increase of six percent for the agenda of the Horizon 2020 research agenda, and an increase of six per cent for the Erasmus programme. the expansion of our infrastructure network in this area in Europe, an increase of 25 percent and, in parallel, an increase of 30 percent for the transport networks, an increase of 55 percent in the area of migration capital, of which an additional 10 percent for foreign policy, with a conscious focus on our priority issue of the Western Balkans and in the approximation in the sense of the common partnership for the future an increase of plus 40 percent.  We were particularly critical of the Commission's proposal, in that we provided for a significant reduction of EUR 66 million in our proposal in terms of administrative expenditure. We see here the need to seek a ceiling of two per cent in order to ensure that, above all, the efficiency and effectiveness of administration in all the institutions, bodies and agencies of the European Union are seen as a clear objective and a clear signal for this issue of optimisation and efficiency.  In addition, we have added three statements to this proposal and to this Council position: firstly, it is the well-known and familiar approach of the declaration on sufficient resources for payments in the field of agriculture and cohesion.  In addition, we have added two new declarations, which refer to an audit of administrative expenditure, which, as mentioned above, constitutes a particular and important point in the proposal. We want to analyse the high stock of so-called earmarked revenue in this area. And in this statement, we ask Commissioner Oettinger, also with regard to our negotiations, to give a more detailed analysis in the presentation.  In the third declaration, we would like to draw attention to an agreement dating back to 2017, which is to keep and make the agreed increases by 2020 budget neutral and to the fact that this has not yet been achieved in this form, which is why an additional spectrum is needed in the context of the 2019 budget and budget.  Allow me, Madam President, honourable Members and Commissioners and guests, to conclude by saying that, starting with this debate in the coming weeks and months, I believe that we have the opportunity to underline the common ground – a great opportunity, which is that we have the opportunity for all sides – both Parliament, the Commission, but above all from our side – with our proposal. to jointly negotiate and adopt a sensible, sustainable and also correct budget for 2019. And I can promise you and promise that, as the Austrian Presidency, we will make every effort within the Council to conduct these joint negotiations constructively and do everything possible in this area to achieve a good result.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Minister Löger, rapporteur Viotti and Mr Rübig, Mr Arthuis, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur and gentlemen for the work he has done on this report. We – both the Council and Parliament and the Commission – have shared common objectives with the budget: on the one hand, growth and employment, strengthening European competitiveness and, secondly, security and the abandonment of migration policy. In the area of migration and security, we are grateful that the Council proposal does not provide for any reductions in the Commission's approach to the AMIF asylum, migration and integration fund, as well as to Frontex or EASO and Europol, that is to say, central agencies. In other programmes, such as COSME or Erasmus+, the Council's approaches and proposals are also encouraging and forward-looking for us. We are counting on us to meet the time frame in the coming weeks. It is the last budget proposal to be debated and decided by this Parliament, the second last one drawn up by the Commission, and it is the first to see the british friends leave for more than nine months. We are grateful that, in the negotiations, the UK has so far continued its willingness to exercise all the rights and obligations of the budgetary framework by the end of 2020, thus remaining a stable partner in 2019. In other words, a normal budget. We want to talk to Parliament and the Council about the approaches, and I admit that what the Council is proposing is not really cuts, but corrections from an increased commission proposal. We are concerned about a few programmes as far as the Council's approach is concerned. I believe that the European Union should not save on research. We have, incidentally, supported by the European Council, for years and days, a 3% target in relation to our European gross national product, but we are only 2%. Austria is one of the few Member States that has reached 3 or even more than 3%. This makes it all the more important that we do everything we can to strengthen horizons and thus allow existing programmes and joint ventures to continue, and also to launch new ones – artificial intelligence and more. We are concerned about the Council's approach to the issue of the Connecting Europe Facility. I mention two outstanding projects: the Brenner Base Tunnel between Austria and Italy and Rail Baltica – a project between Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland. For both, we should avoid delays in tendering and awarding, and thus implementation. This has to do with the actual appropriations. The same applies to Copernicus, where we can only provide emergency services, border surveillance services and other important services if the Commission's proposal is complied with. We are therefore aware that there will be differences between Parliament and the Council on the issue of financing the Turkey-EU agreement in the second tranche. We should be prepared to compromise on the issue of a billion or two billion or a division between Europe's budget and the Member States' injections of between one and two billion. We, as the Commission, will take a critical look at administrative expenditure. This is not just about the Commission, it is about all the institutions. We have frozen the appropriations for expenditure in kind. In terms of human resources expenditure, we are guided by what should be the corresponding percentage adjustment in 2019 as a formula from many Member States and their salary growth in the public sector. And since we do not have a pension fund, but of course there has been a significant increase in the Number of Member States over the last decade, we now also have an extraordinary development in pension expenditure, which is reflected accordingly in heading 5. We are happy to go into this in detail in the negotiations. I am grateful for the objective admission. We look forward to Parliament's position, which will come in a few weeks' time. We will present you with an amendment in October, and I am grateful to you for your personal contribution, for taking the lead in the negotiations in the Council. This is a clear sign. The commitment gives us courage.

name: Daniele Viotti
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has been a busy day here in Parliament today. This morning the votes on Hungary, the vote to activate sanctions finally against Hungary, and not against the Hungarian people, but for their freedom, for freedom of the press, for just justice. Then the copyright vote, and I personally came out quite disappointed today. I do not think this will be the way to protect small publishers, to protect authors and so on, but perhaps we will have a different, less free Internet. And then now we get to the heart of the budget debate. I would like to thank the Minister for being here with us and for making an immediate commitment to accompany us and to discuss this budget with us together, but I would like to say a few very clear words to him. This debate, these two months that separate us from the final for the adoption of the budget, will be a derby. And it will be a derby exactly between those who think they want to give Europe a perspective and a future for Europe and those who only want to control the public accounts. It will be a derby between those who think they can give prosperity and priorities to our businesses, our universities, our municipalities, our citizens and those who will only have a look at the vegetable garden of the next elections in May 2019. And again between those who want to give real solutions to the issue of migration and those who want to howl at the bad Europe that is not able to provide solutions. Minister, I think – and I say this, if You will allow me, with a joke – that at this stage we are looking at the next budget with different lenses, with deforming lenses. You look at the next budget with the lens of the 2018 budget, and then you talk about the increases that have taken place, the increases that you have put in your reading, and I look at your reading of the 2019 budget instead with the lens of the European Commission's proposal, which is a proposal that is based on the accounts that come in and on the reality that the European Commission sees before it. So you want some data? The figures are that compared with the European Commission's budget proposal there are cuts of 794 million on research and development on line 1, there are three million cuts in youth unemployment, there are 340 million cuts in agriculture in your budget proposal. These are the deforming lenses, and we want to work on that. And then there is the great question of Africa and the countries from which migration originates. We want to deal with this in a very serious way. My government says, says its government, all the governments of Europe say that they must be helped at home, an expression that I do not like at all. If, however, this is the objective, but if we really want, I say, to eradicate and eradicate the real reasons for migration – poverty, security, instability of governments, wars, etc. – we need to invest. Instead, in your draft budget there is a cut of EUR 306 million on the fourth line of the European budget, that is, humanitarian aid, cooperation and peace instruments. I want to increase these figures. I want to increase these figures, because I think that migration and the security of migration are done by investing in these countries. Finally, I would like to say a few words, Minister, Commission. I would like to thank you once again and I think that the path and the dialogue will be constructive. But one thing must be explained well to the citizens: that what this House is asking for, what Parliament is asking for is not the moon. I come to the end, Madam President. This money, you have to tell the citizens, this money is there. This money is available and can be invested, just want it. I believe that we can make a journey together, the Council and Parliament, to find a solution to the issues that are there. With regard to the subject of Turkey, touched on by the Commissioner, I would simply like to say that there is only one possibility of compromise, to respect the pacts that have been reached in the past, and we will certainly find a solution, a solution that will satisfy our citizens and, above all, give a perspective. Thank you again, and we are absolutely available, as you know, for formal and informal meetings and anything else to find solutions.

name: Paul Rübig
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Federal Minister Löger, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work he has done on this report. Budget is always a negotiating issue. It is important to focus on setting common goals and preparing a budget that invests in Europe, where growth and jobs are generated. That is why it is important that we see that a great deal of performance is being done not only in the Commission budget, but also in the other institutions – we have nine other institutions, in addition to the Commission, which make up approximately EUR 4 billion. When I look at how different the rates of increase are here, I see that data protection – and we have just adopted the General Data Protection Regulation – is at the top, with a plus of 16%. That is why I also support the Council's cuts of around EUR 100 000. That is not very much, but it is a symbol of the fact that very large increases are also subject to a reduction. One of my concerns is the financing of the European Court of Justice. We have talked about Brexit, and on Brexit it is clear that disputes arising from Article 50 must be dealt with quickly and efficiently by the Court of Justice. That is why the 16 posts here are a prerequisite for whether the Withdrawal Treaty or hard Brexit can also be resolved by the court and not by other institutions. This year, we have finally made the 5% reduction in staff, and Parliament has also cut its posts by 5%. This is, of course, already noticeable in the House. But the difference between the European budget and the national one is also very large: the European level ultimately has less than 1% of GDP available, the nation states 30 to 50%. We are now negotiating behind the comma, so I hope that we can reach an agreement here soon and quickly and efficiently.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: Chairman of the Committee on Budgets - Madam President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, with the cuts made by the Council on the draft budget 2019, the technocratic, bureaucratic phase, which is being worked on by representatives of national ministries, budget or finance ministries, without clear political instruction, ends. Thus ends a ritual exercise of plank. What I see is that, year after year, the overall cut is growing: 1.2 billion in 2018, 1.55 billion in 2019. By amplifying - we have heard your message, Minister - the margins available, the Council gives the impression that it is seeking to protect itself, showing a kind of timidity, turning the European Union budget into a budgetary back-up wheel, as it does for the financing of the reception of Syrian refugees in Turkey. The phase of bureaucratic arbitrariness must give way to that of political vision and engagement. On the eve of the European elections, we must send a clear and voluntary message to European citizens. Let us respond to their impatience by confirming a Europe that speaks to them, a Europe that prepares for their future, a Europe that protects them. To agree to increase the margins for unforeseen events would be to forego action and show our inability to decide. This last budget of the legislature must carry an understandable message, a promising message. Preparing for the future means making research a priority and empowering our researchers and laboratories. For example, in an area as crucial as digital, can we resign ourselves to the need for global giants to be American or Chinese and not European? Preparing for the future also means investing in education and vocational training, and offering young people the opportunity to meet European diversity through Erasmus scholarships. I have heard your comment, Minister, there is progress. But you should know that despite this progress, Erasmus is causing frustration, as almost one in two eligible applications is rejected each year. Protecting Europeans means taking stock of migration challenges and having greater resources to control our external borders and implement a new partnership with African countries, whose population will double by 2050, as President Juncker reminded this morning in this Chamber, is to establish constructive relations with the countries of the neighbourhood, the Balkans and the Middle East. Protecting Europeans means giving substance to structured cooperation in defence and security, in the fight against globalised terrorism. In two weeks, informed by our rapporteur-general Daniele Viotti and Paul Rubig, the Committee on Budgets will vote on its own version of the 2019 budget. Then comes the time for the plenary, here in Strasbourg, at the end of October, and we will start conciliation. In advance, I thank the Austrian Presidency, Mr Minister, for your presence and your commitment, which I have no doubt. I thank you and Commissioner Oettinger, who had to leave us, for your understanding and for the help you will give us. In conclusion, I would like to express my strong hope that the 2019 budget will not simply be an extension of previous budgets that mark a new plank in commitment appropriations and in payment appropriations. The time has come to identify the common European goods, that is, the prerogatives of sovereignty that States can no longer exercise on their own because of the challenges that globalisation poses to them, whether it is climate, defence, migration, space, terrorism, digital and artificial intelligence. May we convince our Heads of State and Government that the appropriations, which have become ineffective when they are committed at the national level, must now be transferred to the European Union budget in order to be spent more usefully. This would be demonstrated as to what European added value can be. In other words, the European Union budget would increase without increasing public spending in Europe. Europe is in crisis, Europe is in danger. We were elected to restore it and restore confidence to all Europeans. Our budget invites us, ladies and gentlemen, to live up to our words.

name: Hartwig Löger
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, High Commission, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The contributions have shown that we will have a constructive and critical discussion in the coming weeks. However, I am also happy to take up the image of the general rapporteur, Mr Viotti, who, as an Austrian in particular, has called on me, as an Austrian, to enter a derby, where I confess that Austria is unlikely to make it in football at the moment. But – and I am happy to accept the picture: my image and my hope is that, as it has been mentioned, we will be able to form a joint team in the coming weeks, a joint team from Parliament, the Commission and also from the Council's point of view, in order to prepare ourselves for the points that we have already defined and found together in terms of content. , to provide the right measures and to put the right budget funds behind them for 2019. Our adversaries are not here, our adversaries are on a global scale – others who are trying to weaken Europe, others who are trying to undermine and undermine this European future. Therefore, in all the necessary discussions that we are going to have, I should like to remember that, in the end, we must form a team together to deliver for Europe, for the citizens, what we need, namely as victors at global level, as a united Europe, to look to the future as a united Europe. I would like to make a few points. We have deliberately defined this proposal in a balanced form, and I make no secret of the fact that we, too, are certainly more dynamic here or there in the Council proposal, in a medium- and long-term perspective. But it is a responsibility that we have in common to be able to afford the programmes and the measures that we are taking. We must also live up to the responsibility of the taxpayers in Europe, and we in the Council take them very seriously, namely to ensure that we achieve this budget and budget in 2019 on the basis of reasonable resources. Finally, once again, I would like to make an appeal: we have the opportunity to discuss things together, and I am prepared to go into tough discussions and accept the conflicts. However, it is important that we finally recognise, including in the proposal that Parliament will prepare and adopt in the coming weeks on the basis of this discussion: we will go through the objective together. I am building on the constructive basis that has emerged in today's discussion and the common objectives that we will be able to demonstrate in time as a clear symbol for the citizens of Europe that we – Parliament, the Commission and the Council – are capable of achieving common objectives with the 2019 budget. We owe that to the Europeans. Especially before an election of the European Parliament, it is important to send the message and the signal to all countries that we are in a position to develop something together for Europe.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Regional development projects are being implemented at full speed, with Member States, including Hungary, sending to Brussels the invoices for an increasing number of investments already made. In 2019, a record amount of cohesion funding is expected to be dissient in Hungary, so it is of the utmost importance that sufficient resources are available to settle member states' accounts, so we want to increase regional development resources by 10% to a total of EUR 4.3 billion. An aspect defining the entire seven-year EU financial framework is to avoid a payment crisis at the end of previous programmes, when there are not enough resources left in the budget by the end of the cycle. This will also provide money for the next EU development programmes, which start after 2020. The Council would block funds related to the management of illegal migration (EUR 460 million commitment and payment of EUR 94.5 million) because Member States could not agree on related issues. This Council decision fully reflects Hungarian interests, so we will do everything in our strength in the European Parliament to defend this position. Do not spend EU funds on illegal immigration.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on Cornelia Ernst's report, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the protection of personal persons with regard to the handling of personal data by EU institutions, bodies and bodies and the free movement of such data, and repealing Regulation (EC) 45/2001 and Decision 1247/2002/CE (COM (2017)0008 - C8-0008/2017 - 2017/0002 (COD)) (A8-0313/2017).

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It can be said that since 2011 we have been creating something like a road traffic code for the digital society. The General Data Protection Regulation and Directive are the basis for the most comprehensive and modern data protection legislation in the world in order to effectively protect citizens' fundamental rights, their right to informational self-determination. And as is the case with road traffic, it must be clear who has priority, where one-way streets are, at what speed you can set off. And, of course, the rules must apply everywhere. Otherwise it will not be possible. Traffic has no limits. The aim of this regulation is now to implement the data protection package, if you like, in the European institutions and for the European Data Protection Supervisor. I can say with a clear conscience that we have really ensured that what applies to every EU citizen on data protection must, of course, also apply to the EU institutions – such as the Council, the European Parliament, the Commission – and not everyone can cook their own soup and that it simply should not be so easy to ask future assistants here in the European Parliament. How many cigarettes they smoke, whether they've been to the psychiatrist, what illnesses their parents had, and so on and so forth. But the European Public Prosecutor should also be subject to the same rules, Eurojust and, of course, Europol. I would remind you that the Europol regulation is the only one, the only law in which biometric data is still not counted as particularly sensitive data. And to Europol, I would also like to say quite conciliatoryly: no, Parliament never intended to undermine Europol's work – on the contrary, to create transparency, including in terms of data protection. I think we will be able to do that by 2022. However, the regulation also regulates stronger competences – and this was very important to us – for the European Data Protection Supervisor and data protection officer in general. And here we really agreed: more competences must be found here and, above all, resources must be significantly increased. We also wanted a strong data protection committee. In this context, the regulation also introduces a new model of coordinated supervision for database and information systems. Up to now, for centralised systems containing data from the Member States, there has been a separate supervisory body consisting of EDPS, national authorities, each with its own procedures, its own chairmanship, its own Tralala, I say now. We have actually put an end to this in order to have a single mechanism of control. And that's good. We are also pleased to have contributed a little to transparency and freedom of information. This is the system for access to EU documents. There, we have achieved an important clarification that citizens who want to receive certain information from the EU cannot simply be fed cheaply. And with that, we have implemented a bit of the court rulings in the Bavarian Lager and Dennekamp cases in this law. However, as is always the case in life, there is also a downside, and that is internal rules that we all cannot particularly suffer. However, these are half-sensible precisely where specific rules are needed to carry out tasks – OLAF, for example – or because the GDPR has given up room for manoeuvre and homework in some places for the Member States, as well as for the balance of freedom of expression and data protection, without, however, – and this was important to us – undermining, undermining, the existing law. That is why safety nets and the control of the EDPS were also necessary. Let me conclude by saying a personal word: thank you to the shadow rapporteurs, who were really my absolute support. We are a small group, and we really have to work on this. And also thank you to the staff. Otherwise we would not have been able to act in this way. We would also like to thank the Commission, which not only put a good draft on the table, but was helpful as a mediator, the Legal Service, the LIBE Secretariat. These are all professional props. I got to know that. Thank you very much! And I say to the Council: it still has a lot to do, namely ePrivacy. We are through, we are done with our homework and now we expect them to be done by the Council. Add to that.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Ernst, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, for the very constructive negotiations on the proposed regulation. The final text provides the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies with a strong and coherent data protection framework aligned with the General Data Protection Regulation, as well as, where relevant, the Data Protection Law Enforcement Directive. It will ensure that everyone is protected when EU institutions and agencies process their personal data, whether it is staff of the EU institutions, visitors to our buildings or recipients of EU funding. Let me briefly go through the main elements of the regulation. The final text introduces novel concepts in line with the General Data Protection Regulation such as data protection by design and by default, the need to notify a personal data breach to the European Data Protection Supervisor and to the data subject – the people affected by the breach – and the need for a data protection impact assessment prior to processing when this might result in a high risk for the rights and freedoms of people. The agreement modernises data subject rights, in particular by introducing the right to data portability, an explicit reference to the right to be forgotten, and the need to provide the data subject with more information. Article 25, providing for the possibility to use internal rules to restrict data subject rights, strikes the right balance. While respecting the requirements of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, it meets the operational needs of Union institutions and bodies. The legal text meets the quality of law requirement as formulated by both the Luxembourg and Strasbourg courts. The new rules will abolish unnecessary bureaucratic requirements such as, for instance, prior checks. Supervision has also been reinforced, in line with the General Data Protection Regulation. The European Data Protection Supervisor will now have the possibility to impose a pecuniary fine on a Union institution, body, office or agency, which is an unprecedented power in EU law. Finally, a word on the issue of scope, which has been the subject of many discussions. The Commission welcomes the balanced result, which has been reached after intense negotiations. The Commission has always called for a coherent data protection regime for all institutions, bodies, offices and agencies to avoid unnecessary fragmentation. At the same time, the specific nature of the work of law enforcement agencies needs to be recognised, and interoperability between these EU agencies and Member State authorities needs to be ensured. The inclusion of Eurojust under the scope of this regulation and the review clause for the Europol and European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) regulations are important achievements in this regard. The Commission, however, regrets the complete exclusion of missions referred to in Articles 42/1, 43 and 44 of the Treaty under the Common Security and Defence Policy from the scope of the regulation, as this creates a gap which will need to be filled with additional legislative instruments.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the new EU Directive on Data Protection in the area of Police and Judicial Cooperation is sometimes called the little sister of the General Data Protection Regulation. The rules for data protection in the EU institutions are probably not more than a distant cousin in the public eye. However, this does not do the regulation justice. The EU institutions have to make sure that our own data protection rules live up to the high standards that we expect companies and public authorities all over Europe and beyond to comply with. This is precisely what this regulation seeks to do. We as the S&D Group would very much have preferred to have one set of data protection rules for everybody, including the EU institutions. However, the Commission chose a different approach. The data protection rules for EU institutions that we will be voting on tomorrow is, therefore, the third step in our endeavour to secure EU citizens’ fundamental right to data protection. Despite the challenge of having different texts, overall, I think we managed to achieve pretty good results. The new rules are aligned with high data protection regulation standards and, for example, like in GDPR, this regulation guarantees certain rights to citizens, such as the right to know what kind of personal data an EU institution holds about you, as well as the right to ask for the correction or even deletion of those data.  As the S&D Group, we believe that this regulation, coupled with GDPR and the Police Directive, represents an ambitious step towards securing the fundamental rights of persons. In this context, we agree that an independent supervisory body should be set up to ensure the protection of fundamental right to data protection in the EU institutions too. I find it regrettable, however, that EU agencies are not fully covered by this new regulation. Europol, after long debates, continues to have its own set of rules. However, it is our understanding in the S&D Group that the future Europol reform will rectify this problem, thus helping to create legal certainty and uniform rules, including for the processing of operational data.  Together with and on behalf of our shadow, Miriam Dalli, we would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Cornelia Ernst. Together, we managed to agree a piece of ambitious and progressive legislation. Through tomorrow’s vote, this House will show what Parliament and the Council together can achieve in the area of fundamental rights protection in all sectors. In particular, I am happy to see that e-privacy rules are incorporated in this regulation. However, there is a missing piece: the e-privacy regulation for outside the EU institutions. E—privacy seeks to protect the confidentiality of communication as a whole. It was proposed by the Commission in January 2017 and Parliament adopted its position in October. But ever since then, the file has been stuck in the Council. Member States are unwilling to make a bold step towards protecting fundamental rights online, despite the fact that the current e—privacy rules do not even cover main players such as Facebook or WhatsApp, and this has to change. Member States have to move and the Austrian Presidency has to be more ambitious than just aiming for a progress report in December.  To sum up, with the regulation for data protection in EU institutions, we are taking another important step towards ensuring fundamental rights in the digital era, and this House stands ready – and the S&D Group stands ready – to add the missing piece to this protective framework. We want to start negotiations on the e-privacy regulation with the Council now.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Dear Chairman, the General Data Protection Regulation, although it imposed new obligations and restrictions on businesses, has given individuals important guarantees against lawlessness that unfortunately has been known to reign in this area. For this reason, I am particularly pleased that today we are discussing the adaptation of union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies to the same rules. Expanding the area of legal certainty is a goal that I wholeheartedly support at every opportunity and at the same time take the opportunity to thank Rapporteur Ernst for this report.  I would like to take particular attention to the fact that, in the application of this Regulation, it is essential to ensure that Union agencies processing operational data, in particular when it comes to investigating criminal offences and prosecuting perpetrators, are able to truly fulfil their mission in practice as well.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, let me first thank our rapporteur, Cornelia Ernst, for her excellent work. It was really a pleasure to work with you and I think the results speak for themselves. Regulation 45/2001 is part of the historic reform of the European Data Protection landscape, which aims to remove legal fragmentation by harmonising common rules in principles between the EU agencies that carry out law enforcement tasks. From the start, the objective of the European Parliament was to end the so-called stand-alone regimes such as Eurojust, Europol and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. The final interinstitutional agreement was in the end a victory for the European Parliament, because for the first time we have ensured that the stand-alone regimes cannot deviate from the principles of this regulation. The harmonised rules in the regulation will, furthermore, prevent data protection loopholes in the cooperation between the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. Finally, I call on the Commission to evaluate in the future whether to extend the scope of the regulation and to include all EU law enforcement agencies in order to increase the legal consistency of data transfers between EU bodies and agencies, increase mutual trust and data exchange between data agencies, as well as legal certainty for data subjects.

name: Romeo Franz
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The same rules that apply to companies and public authorities in the Member States should also apply to the EU institutions. It is therefore good that, under the General Data Protection Regulation, the regulation on data protection in the EU institutions and agencies is now also being modernised.  In terms of content, this dossier was largely indisputable because we were guided by the General Data Protection Regulation. However, we Greens are particularly pleased that there is also a specific chapter on data protection in European law enforcement authorities, which is based on the directive on data protection in the police sector for the Member States. That was our demand from the outset. Here, too, the following applies: uniform standards facilitate the exchange of data.  We would have liked this chapter to apply from the outset to Europol and the European Public Prosecutor's Office, not just Eurojust. We therefore call on the Commission to present the adjustment as soon as possible. I would like to express my thanks for the good cooperation, especially on behalf of Jan Philipp Albrecht, who negotiated this for our group.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this proposal for a regulation is of great interest. It transposes to the institutions of the European Union the application of the famous RGPD, the general regulation on the protection of personal data. However, this transposition is a good thing because the EU institutions must lead by example and agree to apply these rules of privacy to individuals on their own. For this is the purpose of this text: it is a question of forcing the Eu institutions to respect the essential protection of the personal data of individuals, just like the Member States. I regret, in this regard, that the Commission has tried to grant itself an exceptional regime and I congratulate the Ernst report for breaking its attempt to put itself, in a way, above European law.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, the needs of the modern era have forced several people to make their personal data known to different bodies. This reality imposes urgently the need to protect personal data not only by unauthorized disclosure, without the permission of the holder, but also in terms of their processing. The same principle applies to the institutions, bodies and institutions of the European Union because it is an inalienable right for every person to respect his private, family life, as well as his communication and residence. In this sense, the new rules on the protection of personal data and their processing by the institutions and bodies of the European Union are moving in the right direction. The only dissonance is the possibility still available to the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the European Police, Europol, to process personal data in order to prevent, detect and prosecute a crime. This must end because there is a risk that personal data will be used by some governments to pursue political opponents.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we can all see how the new GDPR rules have been shaken up in a number of media outlets, and since we both come from the Czech Republic, we know how much panic it has caused in the Czech Republic, because they have been used by Eurosceptics who have said that they will again restrict and bully people, even though these rules are intended to protect ordinary people. That is why this legislation needs to be explained consistently. Although the EU institutions in the field of personal data protection are among the very consistent ones, this legislation also needs to be worked on fairly consistently and needs to be explained, so I am glad that the EU is also adopting this legislation at the highest level. Of course, there must be exceptions for some agencies, such as Europol, Eurojust or EUIPO, which, by their very nature, have to perform slightly different tasks and have a different way of handling personal data. However, Personally, I think that the way in which this protection of individuals in relation to data processing is conceived, as proposed by the European Commission, is quite well implemented and the proposal, as presented by you, makes sense from my point of view.  Finally, let me add here that it is important, as we will communicate this externally, that the whole GDPR is often the subject of myths and its purpose is not bullying, but the protection of ordinary people, and I think that should be the main message of today's meeting here over this legislation.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The decision-making of the General Data Protection Regulation was an important success of European legislation. As an example, it guarantees a uniform framework for the whole of the Union, protects the privacy of users and safeguards fundamental rights. It goes without saying that these rules should also be made compulsory for the institutions of the Union. Data protection and the right to privacy are fundamental rights that must apply to all areas. It is high time that this was finally done.  The legislative report presented by Cornelia Ernst resolves all the relevant issues in this context. The current rules of 2001 will be adapted to the General Data Protection Regulation and the E-Privacy Directive. It is therefore important that this legislative project is swiftly finalised on the basis of Parliament's decision and not watered down.  I would also like to highlight the role of the European Data Protection Supervisor. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has made important improvements to the Commission's proposal, particularly as regards the scope of the institutions. Eurojust, Europol and the European Public Prosecutor – the central institutions for the common area of freedom, security and justice – are now also covered. Europol and Eurojust are now subject to the same rules as the police authorities in the Member States.  It is very regrettable that all this has taken far too long. In fact, this obvious, obvious project should and could have been implemented quickly and quickly. Once again, it was the short-sighted interests of individual Member States that made it impossible to implement them quickly.  I would particularly like to thank the rapporteur for not letting up and for sticking to this case.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Madam President, the same title of the report is partly contradictory. In practice, it is almost impossible to ensure the protection of personal data and at the same time the free movement of such data between Union bodies. Unfortunately, we have witnessed many cases in which, despite the various protection measures that have been taken from time to time, citizens' personal data ended up on the Internet, easily accessible to anyone. Our aim must be to find the right balance to ensure the anonymity and at the same time the safety of European citizens. I do not think there is any reason to exchange the data of citizens who do not concern the authorities or who do not have convictions against them. On the contrary, evidence of illegal immigrants, let alone terrorism suspects, I think it is imperative that they be communicated to all the security services of the Member States. Finally, I am strongly opposed to the movement of personal data of European citizens for any reason other than the prevention of criminal acts and criminal offences in general.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years we have been redefining the rights to privacy and protection of personal data in Europe. The most visible face of this change is the general data protection regulation. With its entry into force this year, we better protect European citizens, empower the Union for the challenges of the future and lead in the world the changes towards greater protection.  Cases such as Facebook and Cambridge Analytica make it clear that we were right, but that regulation is just one of the four major pillars of data protection in Europe, as has already been mentioned by several speakers. In addition, the so-called police data protection directive, the e-privacy directive and, finally, the regulation we are debating today.  It is clear that the Union and all its bodies have to set an example, which is why aligning the Union's rights and duties with the General Data Protection Regulation was imperative. That's what we do with this new instrument. Of course, in very specific cases, such as Europol, the data processed lack a specific regime, but let us not take the whole on the part. This new instrument will undoubtedly protect personal data held by european union entities, including this Parliament. The data protection reform in Europe will be completed and once again we will reaffirm European leadership in the world in defending these fundamental rights. I can only say to Mrs Ernst for the excellent work she has done.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, this European Parliament is never more Parliament than when it legislates and is certainly never politically more relevant than when it legislates on fundamental rights, because that is one of the assets of the Lisbon Treaty, which recognises the right to privacy in Article 16 there, as well as its fundamental character in Article 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. We took it very seriously from the previous legislature, when we launched the Data Protection Regulation, which is a huge step forward, and the Directive aimed at law enforcement, police and judiciary agencies, investigating crimes and debugging their responsibilities. But it does so also now when it updates Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 with a new one aimed at data processing in the European institutions. We celebrate. We can only regret that it is not a uniform treatment, that there is still a set of agencies that are not included (Eurojust or Europol). But we have emphasized the strength of the European Data Protection Supervisor to ensure very effective sanctions on breaches of this new right in force.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the regulation on protection against the processing of personal data is very important. We must place great emphasis on strengthening individual rights and of course citizens must not accept any processing of their own data. The fact that this will be extended to the Community institutions is, in fact, very serious. The exceptions given must also be such that they really support the public interest. I would like to say, however, that the application of the general data protection regulation now extends to political communication. Commissioner, I want your attention, because Members and MEPs must communicate with citizens; The way in which this regulation is interpreted on the merits has restricted the right to political communication, because political communication is not a commodity. Therefore, we must be careful how MEPs, politicians and citizens communicate and have very specific instructions from the European Parliament itself in the run-up to the European elections. This is a very important issue and we need to discuss it in detail.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, MEP Cornelia Ernst's report on the protection of individuals with regard to their data processing by the Institutions of the Union comes at a time when we are also discussing the need to improve the relevant framework for the Internet. At EU level we have already established rules on respect for personal data but, in practice, the issue remains unknown and potentially dangerous for many citizens. Protection against the processing of personal data is a fundamental human right enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, but much remains to be done to ensure the full application of these provisions. We must equip citizens with new possibilities, such as withdrawing consent to process their data at all times. The citizen must know who, where and for what purpose they are processing his data. The Ernst report is moving in this very direction and I therefore believe that we should vote in favour of it.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I fully endorse what many of you have said in this debate. With the data protection package in application since May, we now need to ensure that the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies are fully equipped with an equally modernised data protection legal regime. This is important for the protection of the fundamental rights of anyone whose personal data is processed by EU institutions and agencies. I therefore encourage you to endorse this agreement tomorrow. On Europol and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, there is a robust review clause which foresees that the Commission will, by 1 May 2022, review the founding legal acts of both agencies. Finally, the Commission calls on the European Data Protection Supervisor to ensure the monitoring and application of this regulation, as the enforcer of this regulation – its supervisory role, which has now been further strengthened – is of utmost importance for real practice.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you for the contributions of the political groups. I would like to make two very brief comments. The first is that Commissioner Jourova said that the area of foreign and security policy is missing here. That's right. Unfortunately, this could not be regulated by the regulation. In fact, you have to look back at the Treaties to see how this can be done the wisest – a big and open problem. The second is my request, including to the Commissioner, to put pressure on the Council as well. We would like ePrivacy to be negotiated and not just to talk about it and to say in the member states that there is anything that is not true. It is very, very important that ePrivacy actually comes into being here in the negotiations and still in this legislature. Everything else we find really bad. The Council really has not gone into a good place here. Our request is – and I am certainly speaking on the other groups in this case – to exert pressure. It doesn't go on like this. The Council must act.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 13 September 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. – The proposal calls on the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies to adopt a high level of a protection of personal data, which is required from the private companies. I believe that this regulation along with GDPR will contribute to securing the fundamental rights of private persons in the digital environment. Right to privacy has been a long term respected basic value, which should not be undermined by any means, in any context. Retention of data about ethnic origin, religion, political orientation, health data, sexual life and other shall be banned. It is understandable that institutions, such as Eurojust, Europol and the European Public Prosecutor, are excluded from the scope of the regulation due to the specific nature of their work. However, Europol and Eurojust are currently subject of the same set of rules such as police authorities in the individual Member States.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: - Mark Demesmaeker's report, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the European strategy for plastics in a circular economy (2018/2035(INI)) (A8-0262/2018), - the question with a request for an oral reply to the Council on options on the interface issues between chemical legislation, the products and waste deposited by Lukas Mandl, Christel Schaldemose, Mark Demesmaeker, Anneli Jäätteenmäki, Lynn Boylan, Davor Škrlec, Piernicola Pedicini, Joëlle Mélin, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety ((O-000063/20 18 - B8-0036/2018) (2018/2589(RSP), and - the question with a request for an oral reply to the Commission on options on the interface issues between chemical legislation , the products and waste deposited by Lukas Mandl, Christel Schaldemose, Mark Demesmaeker, Anneli Jäätteenmäki, Lynn Boylan, Davor Škrlec, Piernicola Pedicini, Joëlle Mélin, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000064/2018 - B8-0037/2018) (2018/2589(RSP)

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, a few days ago, a major clean-up of the ocean began in the United States. The images went around the world. The Ocean Cleanup wants to use plastic catchers to help clean up the plastic soup in the Pacific Ocean. I hope that the boyhood dream of the young Dutchman Boyan Slat will be a success. Cleaning up the rubbish of the past is noble, but of course we must first of all ensure that we prevent plastic waste from ending up in the sea. So we need to be more sensible with plastic. That is the focus of our debate here today.  Plastic is an important and valuable material, which is still hard to imagine from our society and economy. The problem is the way we produce and use plastic today. It's untenable. Plastic is developed to last forever, but all too often we only use it once. Sometimes it disappears into the environment after just a few seconds or minutes in the garbage bag, or worse. We are very careless with the material: we produce almost 26 million tonnes of plastic waste every year in the European Union, but only 30% of it collects for recycling.  All this has disastrous consequences for the environment, the climate and the economy. Our ecosystems suffer from pollution. Not least our seas and oceans, which turn into a plastic soup. We are missing opportunities for less CO2 emissions. We are literally draining the euros out of our economy. 95 percent of the value of the material is lost. Moreover, the recent Chinese ban on the import of plastic waste from the European Union is putting our noses in the face. For years, we have conveniently outsourced our plastic waste problem in Europe. We must therefore use the Chinese ban as an opportunity to invest in recycling capacity in the European Union and change our policy.  The momentum there, not only at the political level, is also growing among many citizens to take action. It is about turning this public concern into public responsibility, into joint responsibility. So my report is not a plea against plastic, but it is a plea for a circular economy in which we deal with plastic in a sustainable and responsible way, so that we can stop the harmful consequences and maintain the value in the chain.  To succeed, we need to use the strategy as leverage for circular production and consumption models. We have to deliver customization, as there are no passe-partout solutions. And we need to work together across the entire value chain.  Better and more plastic recycling is the beginning. A few months ago, we adopted new ambitious waste legislation here. A complete and rapid implementation of this is essential. But more is needed: for example, all plastic packaging must be cost-efficiently recyclable or reusable by 2030 at the latest. Through the packaging directive we want to work on a truly circular product design.  Companies can make a difference by linking their brand name and marketing to circular production and consumption models. The creation of a genuine internal market for recycled plastic is also fundamental. Today, the proportion of recycled plastic is estimated to be only 6%. To increase this, we need to strengthen confidence in the market through quality standards and verification. Minimum requirements for recycled content, a lower VAT rate and a circular purchasing policy can also further encourage the use of recycled plastic.  More and better recycling is necessary, but not enough in itself to become a real circular economy. I'm going to keep stressing that. Preventing plastic waste remains crucial. This can be done, among other things, through smart measures on disposable plastic. On this point, the Commission has now come up with a legislative proposal, and we in the Committee on the Environment are working on this together with mr Frédérique Ries and others. My report also calls for a well-thought-out use of bio-plastic. Based on clear standards and criteria, biodegradable plastic can play a supporting role, but it is not a beatifying solution for marine litter. Bio-based plastic can help reduce our dependence on third countries by partially differentiating the raw materials. But research and development are of great importance here to give innovation every opportunity. For oxo-plastic and microplastics in cosmetics, among others, we ask for a ban until 2020. Finally, we call for further research and innovation efforts, including in the next multi-annual financial framework. The EU must also join the global ly and, of course, set a good example in its own institutions. I would like to thank the fellow shadow rapporteurs for the very constructive cooperation. I hope that tomorrow we will say 'yes' by a large majority to a new circular plastic economy that offers opportunities for the environment, climate and economy.

name: Lukas Mandl
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner Katainen, Secretary of State Edtstadler, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I would like to inform you of the position in the motion for a resolution by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy on the implementation of the Circular Economy Package on options for regulating the interface between chemicals product and waste legislation. The aim of this initiative is to minimise the presence of substances of concern in recycled products and to strengthen the market for secondary raw materials. These are raw materials that are extracted from discarded material through recycling. On 16 January this year, the Commission adopted new measures to implement the Circular Economy Action Plan. The Commission communication analysed the four main problems identified at the interface between chemicals product and waste legislation and analysed the extent to which they hinder the development of a circular economy. The four problems mentioned, which I will address later, are, firstly, insufficient information on substances of concern in products and waste, the presence of substances of concern in recycled materials, uncertainties as to the criteria to be met, according to which materials are not considered waste, and fourthly, difficulties in applying the European Union's methods for classifying waste and impacting the recyclability of materials. It is important, in the interests of the circular economy, to fill this gap and to counteract this problem. A number of oral questions have therefore been put to the European Parliament and a motion for a resolution have been drawn up from the European Parliament.
