In general, the motion for a resolution refers to the following content: the Committee on the Environment welcomes the Communication from the European Commission and the accompanying Staff Working Document. However, rapid action is expected to be taken to address this interface problem. The primary objective of the European Commission should be to prevent hazardous chemicals from entering the material cycle and to achieve full coherence between the implementing rules in waste and chemicals legislation. For a true circular economy, the products must be developed in such a way that they last long, that they can be repaired and reused. And, of course, the products must also be developed with minimal use of substances of concern. The implementation of chemicals product and waste legislation can be a challenge especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. Particular attention should be paid to small and medium-sized enterprises. More details on the four issues raised, which have been analysed by the Commission, are, firstly, that substances of concern are those of concern and that substances of concern are those identified as substances of concern under REACH and substances that have been banned under the Stockholm Convention. All substances of concern should be tracked as soon as possible and information on these substances, including their composition and concentration, should be fully accessible to all stakeholders in the supply chain, to recycling companies and to the public. The second defined problem is the handling of the presence of substances of concern in recycled materials. This is primarily about the possibility of recycling materials containing substances of concern. This should only be considered if there are no materials without substances of concern that can be used as substitutes. More than 80% of the environmental impact of a product is to be determined during the design phase. The Ecodesign Directive and other product-specific legislation should be used to lay down requirements for the replacement of substances of concern. It is important to ensure a level playing field between eu-made and imported articles. Products manufactured in the EU must not be penalised by imported products. The third problem defined is the uncertainty about criteria according to which materials are not considered waste. Clear rules are needed to determine the conditions under which something is no longer covered by the waste legislation, and robust criteria for the end of waste status are also needed. These clear EU rules must be designed in such a way that they can also be implemented by small and medium-sized enterprises. On the part of the House, the European Commission and the Member States are invited to consider the criteria for the end of the waste status. The fourth problem defined is the difficulties in applying the European Union's methods for the classification of waste and the consequences of the recyclability of materials. Here, the House believes that the European Commission should revise the European waste list without delay. In conclusion, I would like to say that there is great tension in the committee with the answers from the Commission and the Council to the oral questions, so that they can then enter into a political debate conducted from the centre together.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the Council welcomed the package of communications presented by the Commission in January 2018 and actions undertaken to deliver on the 2015 Action Plan on the Circular Economy. This is reflected in a set of Council conclusions adopted by the Environment Council on 25 June 2018. The Council calls for a high-level political commitment to be maintained for an ambitious implementation of the whole Circular Economy Action Plan. In this context, its conclusions emphasise that the transition to a truly circular economy involves closing the loop of product life circles and turning them into real value chains through greater recycling. Furthermore, reuse is closely interconnected with creating non-toxic material cycles where substances of concerning products and waste are soundly managed and reduced to a minimum.  This is also underlined in the resolution by the European Parliament on this topic. A more consistent approach between chemical and waste rules is therefore required. It is necessary to establish clearly, together with all stakeholders, what is a substance of concern and how to deal with the presence of such substances in recycled materials. Information to the consumers and all actors in the value chain on the possible presence of substances of concern in materials is of greatest importance.  In this respect, the Council welcomes, as you do in your draft resolution, the recently agreed provisions of the revised Waste Framework Directive that complement existing REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals) obligations for suppliers to inform their customers when articles contain substances of very high concern. A relevant tracking system throughout the supply chain should also encompass all products imported into the Union that may contain substances of concern. Secondary raw materials need, in principle, to meet the same criteria as primary raw materials. However, the detoxification of waste containing legacy substances might, in certain cases, require a differentiated approach that also adequately controls the risks for human health and the environment.  In this respect, the Council encourages the Commission’s action to develop a methodology addressing the management of waste containing substances of concern. The Council encourages Member States to make use of all possibilities under the Ecodesign Directive or other product-specific legislation to promote the circularity of products and to support voluntary methods and approaches regarding the substitution of materials containing substances of concern as early as the design phase. The Council underlines that it is important for end-of-waste criteria to be implemented effectively and favours the establishment of guidelines that allow a clear distinction between waste and product status to avoid the need for operators to comply with two sets of rules. Efforts to harmonise these criteria should focus firstly on the most important waste streams.  Finally, the Council calls urgently on the Commission in particular for concrete actions to be taken to remove technical, financial and market barriers preventing recycling and the uptake of secondary raw materials. Effective measures are needed to avoid, remove, or reduce the presence of substances of concern as much and as soon as possible to ensure non-toxic material cycles.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I really want to thank the Parliament and especially the rapporteur, honourable Member Mark Demesmaeker, and all shadows for a very positive approach towards the plastics strategy. The strategy is fully in line with the thinking and approach we first put forward in the circular economic action plan. It addresses the whole value chain and creates synergies between economic and environmental goals. As you rightly recall in your report, the strategy aims at fostering a new plastics economy where reuse and recycling activities are truly integrated in the production chains, delivering great added value and prosperity in Europe, for example by improving the dialogue and cooperation across the value chain, addressing all its key players from plastics producers to end-users and recyclers. To this end, the wider plastics industry is currently working on voluntary commitments, and a pledging campaign is ongoing to support objectives of this strategy by increasing the uptake of recycled contents in new products. The goal is very simple: to ensure that by 2030 all plastic packaging is reusable or recyclable; that more than half of EU plastics waste is recycled – today it’s only 30%; and that demand for recycled plastics in Europe grows at least four-fold. Today, only 6% of the plastics used in products put on the EU market comes from recycling. To support innovation in this field and guide future funding decisions, the Commission will develop a strategic research innovation agenda for plastics. In the meantime, and by 2020, Horizon 2020 will have invested more than EUR 350 million in plastics innovation. Also, financial incentives are an important way to steer the policies towards a more sustainable future. As you highlighted in your report, in the proposal for the next long-term budget, the Commission foresees a Member State contribution based on the amount of non-recycled plastics packaging waste. Such a contribution putting for the very first time at the EU level the price of the negative externality of not recycling will help implement the Waste Package and the Plastics Strategy. The Plastics Strategy will also help deliver the EU’s energy union vision for low-carbon energy-efficient economy. In terms of CO2 savings, recycling only half of all plastic waste generated in the EU each year would be equivalent to taking off the roads more than 13 million cars. The strategy also announced a new legislative initiative to reduce litter from single-use plastics items and fishing gear. This initiative is already being negotiated by the European Parliament and the Council, as you know. Besides, the Plastics Strategy also features action to reduce pollution from microplastics, the legislative proposal on port reception facilities to tackle sea-based marine litter and the preparation of new labelling rules to ensure that consumers get clear information about biodegradable and compostable plastics. Action is ongoing on all these fronts. Regarding the second question – the oral question submitted by the Parliament in relation to the interface between chemical products and waste legislation – we very much appreciate the Parliament’s interest in this area. In 2015, the Commission made a commitment to assess the issues. This is exactly what we have done in the Communication which we published in January. We identified four main issues and we set out a list of planned actions. These actions will be delivered or well under way by the end of the mandate of the current Commission in 2019. What has been done so far? We published guidelines to promote a more coherent approach to waste classification. We launched a study to develop a specific decision-making methodology to support the decision on the recyclability of waste containing substances of concern. We are also preparing to launch two further studies. Firstly, the visibility study on the use of the information system to enable information on the presence of substances of concern in materials to be available to recyclers. Secondly, the study of Member States’ practices as regards implementation and verification of end-of-waste provisions. The Interface Communication is currently being considered by stakeholders, and an open consultation is running until the end of October. At the end of this process, the Commission will consider the most effective and inclusive way forward for addressing the identified challenges. However, while this is all ongoing work which is on track, I am happy to point out that there have already been some spin-off developments. We found that addressing chemicals of concern in food packaging is not sufficient, because there is a risk of incidental contamination with substances that were not originally present in plastic materials but may originate from use or mis-use of plastics. This situation could prevent effective recycling of food packaging, which is a significant market. Therefore, in the framework of the Regulation on Food Contact Materials, the Commission is currently working on the applications related to around 100 recycling processes to de-contaminate recycled PET to make that material suitable for food packaging. On batteries, we are going to monitor the coherence of different legislative instruments to ensure a smooth functioning of the internal market for batteries, waste batteries and materials coming from recycled batteries. Also, following the recent adoption of the amendments to the Waste Framework Directive, the Commission and the European Chemicals Agency are looking into establishing a database for the future collection of information on substances of very high concern in articles. Such a database would also help to promote non-toxic material recycling and improve the risk management of chemicals during repair and other forms of refuse- and waste-recovering process. With this summary, I trust that you will agree with me that a significant amount of work is already under way to address the interface between chemical products and waste legislation.

name: John Flack
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleague Mark Demesmaeker, and all MEPs involved in this excellent report, and I would like to thank the PECH Committee for the opportunity to work on our contribution to the strategy covering marine plastic litter. When reading the final report, I was delighted to see that the rapporteur and ENVI colleagues included all the good work done in PECH as well as the specific measures I suggested in my opinion. This is a step forward, but we must do more, and now that we are working on the legislative proposal from the Commission, I hope all this good work is taken into account. We think about plastic bottles, bags and straws floating around, but I also want to remind colleagues of the damage done by ghost gear: abandoned fishing nets trapping, strangling and drowning untold numbers of marine mammals and birds, as I highlighted by distributing Netty the dolphin to many, many Members here, and I hope he might have reached the Commission as well. My country, the United Kingdom, has done a lot in the war against plastics and micro plastics in particular, and since this is a problem that can only be tackled globally, I can only hope that national governments across Europe and European citizens continue to cooperate together.

name: Karl-Heinz Florenz
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Madam President-in-Office of the Council and Marc Demesmaeker, I would like to add my congratulations. It was a very fruitful collaboration.  Commissioner, you have taken a broad bow, and as someone who has been in this House for quite a long time, I would then propose the alternative: let us then show how much the Member States have implemented. I am not taking my country out of it. The whole series of the Presidency of the Council would be full, because an unimaginable number of things in Europe have not been implemented in the field of waste. And that is actually regrettable.  Mr Demesmaeker pointed out the figures: 140 million tonnes of plastic waste are floating in the oceans – the equivalent of half of Europe. I've been told that you can see the plastic paints - I think only five pieces in this world - from space. So there is reason enough to do something about it. And I believe that we must also be aware that seventy per cent of this waste is also in the depths of the waters and that it is not easy to get out of it.  We drink it, we taste it, and we inhale plastic. And that is an important reason, because we find it in honey, in meat, in all sorts of circumstances. That is one of the reasons why we need to get to the bottom of it. The consequences are that one day we will also notice this in terms of health. And I'm really not an anxious man, but I don't want to hide the fact that plastic is a great success for society, because we have it for the freshness of food etc., etc., blood bags are made with it – so all things that are important. And, Commissioner, you have rightly said this, and Mr Demesmaeker has also said that we must deal with it better, we must allow a process of awareness to be carried out in our minds and we really think about what we are doing with it.  We have increased our plastic quantities twentyfold since 1960. All of this is reason enough to actually increase the thirty per cent that we are recycling so far. We will all work on this together, and I am pleased that this report will not be a punishment for industry, but a motivation to drive innovation.

name: Christel Schaldemose
text: for the S&D Group. Mr President! The transition to a sustainable and circular economy is necessary. For the sake of the environment, to reduce the pressure on our planet's resources, and then for the sake of our health. That is why it is very good that we are now taking a major step, not least in the area of plastics. The plastics strategy put forward is ambitious in terms of reuse and recycling. However, this level of ambition for plastics must apply throughout the way we produce. In our circular economy, it must be possible for all our products to be upgradeable, they must be durable, they must be repairable, they must be recyclable and recyclable. We need to do this in all other areas, not just in the area of plastics. However, in order to ensure that this happens in a circular economy, it is also very important that we ensure that no hazardous chemicals enter our material cycle. That is the aim, as the Commission has said, that is what everyone in this House wants. But we are not on target yet! Until we are on target, it is very important that we make a huge effort. We need to step up efforts to substitution substances of very high concern, not least endocrine disruptors. We must provide a very comprehensive product information, not least on substances of concern, so that recycling and recycling take this into account. Moreover, we must also step up efforts to classify, register and trace and dispose of the waste that has dangerous substances in it. Because we must not compromise the safety of consumers on the way to a circular society. There is a long way to go before we are in the finish line before we have a well-functioning circular economy, and products already in the design phase take these things into account. In order to achieve this objective, it requires a great deal of effort from everyone: the Commission, the Member States, our agencies, our companies, etc., all of us must join! In our resolution in this House, we are putting pressure on the Member States to make the effort they have promised, otherwise we will not achieve our objectives. Fortunately, however, the ambitions are in place, and thank you for that!

name: James Nicholson
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, can I also add my congratulations to Mr Demesmaeker on an excellent piece of work. I think that it is a very opportune moment to be debating this today, at a time when citizens not only in my own constituency, but across Europe and indeed the world are more conscious of the impact which plastic use is having on our environment. There is a clear momentum in tackling these issues, and now is the time to act.  There is no denying that plastic is an essential material for our society and economy. However, we need to transform the way in which plastic and plastic products are managed. Currently less than 30% of all plastic waste is recycled. Indeed, plastic waste accounts for over 80% of marine litter, something which Mr Flack has referred to.  This has a devastating environmental impact, with up to 500 000 tonnes of plastic entering our seas and oceans each year. But I have to ask the question, and we should all be asking the question: somebody has to put that plastic there for others to take out, so there must be a serious educational problem somewhere along the line, since we are not getting the message across. The Commission may want to consider further action in pursuit of a circular plastic economy by introducing the recommended new provisions reducing hazardous substances in plastics. In that way we can increase plastic recycling without increasing the risk of emitting hazardous substances into the environment.  This is one cause of the problem. Everyone tells you that they support this, and they all express fine words, but, unfortunately, we all know that it is extremely expensive. We must be aware that China has closed its doors to Europe’s plastic, including other countries in the Far East. We have got to find other ways of dealing with the problem. It is our problem and we must deal with it. And we must take care that when we are producing plastic we do not put other substances into bottles or whatever which are not recyclable.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, thank you to the rapporteur and to my colleagues, we have prepared this report in a very good agreement. The concern about the plastic challenge is shared by the entire European Parliament, the whole world. The Finnish Safety and Chemicals Agency recently investigated products from low-cost online stores outside the EU. Almost all toys, jewellery and electrical appliances were in some way unfit. The toys contained life-threatening parts, electrical appliances caused electric shocks, jewellery did not contain promised precious metals and cosmetics did not contain lists of ingredients. Product design and consumption habits play a significant role in addressing the plastic challenge. There is a lot of low-quality and non-recythric plastic on the market, which therefore has no value whatsoever. In our waterways, in lakes, rivers and in the sea, plastic causes a great deal of damage, damage whose harmful effects on the ecosystem we do not even know. Mr President, I have said on various occasions that plastic is a good material: it is sustainable, safe, cheap and versatile at best. Our problems stem from the fact that the material cycle is not working. We need to think about the circulation of plastic as a whole from start to finish. According to the waste hierarchy, the priority must be to reduce the amount of waste, then reuse and recycling. Mr President, we need an open-minded attitude. Plastics can be replaced with a variety of products made from renewable materials. For example, there are already plastic-free coffee cups on the market. Research is being carried out and still needs to be done. Personally, of course, we need to observe what we could each do ourselves to reduce plastic waste.

name: Marco Affronte
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not be able to do so. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by emphasising – someone has already done so – that finally, after the ecologists have been trying for years to bring this issue to the attention of the general public, it has finally reached us. The mainstream of information talks a lot about it, the public now know that there is a very serious problem that we are trying to address, and that is important because we have so much pressure on the institutions and on those who have to make decisions. From this point of view, there is a fundamental concern for the environment and for the oceans, which are full of this plastic, but let us also remember that 31 % of plastic still goes to landfill and as much as 39 % goes to incinerators, and therefore there are also direct and indirect consequences for our health. We welcome, of course, the intervention of the European Commission, with the plastics strategy and also with the first two pieces of legislation that we are currently evaluating, because it is important, precisely, to intervene in a strong and legislative way.  We intervened on the file – even though it was already a good file in itself, given the fine work that has been done by the rapporteur – with points that we consider fundamental. First of all, the concept of prevention: first we must prevent and then solve the problem upstream, and then we must act on the one on which we cannot intervene upstream. We have called for a ban on oxo-degradable plastics and microplastics that are voluntarily included in cosmetics, we have focused on toxic materials that must be eliminated from the production circuit, and we have called for the internationalization of costs, that is, the manufacturer must take care of what happens to his products when they are placed on the market and then become precisely a waste that ends up in the seas. From this point of view, it is important to work with industry to make a faster change than politics and institutions can do.

name: Eleonora Forenza
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are santering about the use of plastics and the role that the Union must play in promoting a circular economy whose importance could not be overestimated. We are doing so on the basis of a positive text, which we will support, and by objectives that have been set out, which are very important. I am referring to the clampdown on the use of microplastics and disposable materials, and in particular to the objective that every plastic material produced should be recyclable by 2030. I come from a land, the South of Italy, which has all too often been transformed into the landfill site of industrial waste in the productive north of Italy and Europe. I also trained politically in the environmental struggles against landfill and incinerators. For many years now, the committees have been proposing a 'zero waste' model and a truly circular economy. In order to achieve this, the production of goods must be completely reoriented and the economy as a whole radically transformed, and the habits and behaviour of Europeans and Europeans must be followed. This is a goal that can only be achieved through a major initiative managed and financed by the public sector. This report is a huge step forward, but it must not make us forget the contradiction of a European Union that votes for positive solutions such as this, while continuing to implement neoliberal policies of competition and the pursuit of profit, which are in clear conflict with the objectives we are debating today.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, plastics is still a global emergency in a European Union that was finally supposed to give an answer, perhaps even belatedly. Even today, 25 million tonnes of plastic waste are being generated in the Eu ropean Union – as Commissioner Katainen has just mentioned – of which only a small 30 % is recycled. 31 % – and this has just been mentioned – of this plastic is still landfilled and as much as 39 % is even incinerated, even if we were not in the Middle Ages. And let's remember that some types of this plastic, unfortunately, have a particular aspect: it takes over 400 years to dissolve on land. Therefore, if anyone asks what this European Union is for, we can say today that there is finally a positive response, because we believe that the balance sheet of this report is positive. In the meantime, because it achieves the goal of reducing plastic waste through prevention, and secondly because packaging is also a good result, which by 2030 will have to be reusable and recyclable plastic. More could certainly have been done to increase the share of plastic recycling, which is still too low in the European Union, but we have still managed to ban the landfill of plastics by 2030, and that is a very good thing for us.  We also called for a ban on the incineration of plastic in cement plants and incinerators, because they generate emissions that are harmful to the environment and toxic to human health, but unfortunately our amendments on this point were not adopted. However, together with the other political forces, we have succeeded in banning the use of oxo-degradable plastic and also in banning the addition of microplastics in cosmetics, personal hygiene products, detergents and household cleaning products by 2020. Finally, let us remember that citizens must always be informed and made aware. The real revolution is made by them when they go shopping in supermarkets, which unfortunately are still full of plastic containers that in turn are packed in other plastic containers. I wonder why, even to this day, fruit is already sold peeled in plastic containers. I mean, we really don't even have time to peel fruit anymore. So, if we really want to get rid of plastic waste, we have to refuse to agree to buy plastic when we shop in our supermarkets.

name: Sylvie Goddyn
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, with ten tonnes of plastic produced per second in the world and more than nine billion tonnes accumulated since 1950, plastic has become the archetype of 21st century waste. Production has never stopped growing, so much so that plastic is overflowing from our garbage cans and is found everywhere: in our oceans, in our soils, in organisms and even on our plates. Today, everyone is aware of this: we are dealing with an unprecedented environmental and health crisis, where the problems have been hidden under the carpet. For example, only 9% of the plastics produced around the world have been recycled and we are still unable to properly collect all the waste for storage and reprocessing. Also, this new European strategy is welcome. Except that it leads to a false good solution, that of creating a new market to reuse used plastic. In fact, it will promote the production of a new generation of plastic that is more easily recyclable and reusable by companies. Now, we all see that after the nightmarish dream of globalization and exponential growth, the world is gradually regaining consciousness of its limitations, and perhaps even of its mistakes. Excessive plastic production is a mistake and if we do not separate ourselves from plastics wherever possible, we must agree on a drastic reduction in production. I make it clear that this report misses this vital objective. It will even promote a revival of this industry thanks to the misleading concept of the circular economy. Let's face it: recycling plastic is a problem, not least because it is not free of toxic chemicals and because of the cost of recycling. That is why I have tabled two amendments, which support a more coherent vision, with the aim of reducing plastic pollution. The aim is to encourage and tax-favour substitutes for plastics, such as wood, glass and cardboard. Finally, let us pay attention to recycling in third countries that do not meet our standards. Nevertheless, I will support this report. Indeed, against plastic pollution, it is better to have a strategy than no strategy at all.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, this week an ambitious plan to clean up the great Pacific garbage patch, or dump, got under way, and it is the Americans taking the lead. The technology involved is impressive: a giant scoop and return of the material to land. The biggest challenge they are having to address is to catch the plastic, and not the marine life. This technology though, addresses just one part of the problem, namely dealing with existing build-up. Part two of the problem is to stop waterborne plastic, principally deposited in rivers, entering into the marine area. Here again the USA, via Baltimore’s ‘Mr Trash Wheel’, has shown the way, removing two million pounds of trash from Baltimore’s inner harbour since 2014. I cite these two examples because the report appears to be indicating duplication by the European Union, which is totally inefficient and totally ineffective, when solutions exist out there. What I would ask the EU to do is to look at the 10 most polluting rivers in the world, none of which is on the European continent, and to consider incentivising or penalising countries there.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, the accumulation of plastic in the environment, particularly in the oceans, has become unbearable. That is why the European plastic strategy is essential. China's decision to ban imports of European plastic waste offers us an opportunity to create the conditions for a genuine domestic market for recycled materials. But the problem is recycling.  Barriers to better recycling are essentially technical and economic. I am thinking in particular of the cost gap between virgin plastics and recycled plastics.  It is important to support not only local authorities, but also businesses, to make the necessary investments, no doubt through concrete legislation. I have retained the desire to introduce a price on non-recyclable. I think that is particularly important.  So we have several actions to take: action on the design and composition of plastics: we talked about dangerous substances; action on collection and recycling, I have just mentioned, there is much to be done in the Member States; action on consumers, to learn about responsible and environmentally friendly actions; Action to classify materials; and above all action to ensure the quality of recycling, because it is clear that recycled plastic still suffers from a very bad reputation and that it is necessary to raise awareness of the more responsible use of plastics and to improve the quality of recycled plastics. This is a condition to make them more attractive to consumers. I think the world needs to reinvent itself and I imagine we can have a new secondary resource industry.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – President of Grazzi, insellem lill-Vi大i President tal-Kummissjoni, imma b'mod partikolari lil Mark Demesmaeker li, f'dan ir-rapport għamel bi大大a xogħol tajba ħafna għaliex huwa fatt li, jiena ngħid fid-dinja kollha, imma b'mod partikolari wkoll fl-Unjoni Ewropea, niġeneraw ħafna plastic, iżżżejjed ngħid ji. Imma, fl-istess ħin, mhux hawk plastic huwa ħażin għaliex gandħna plastic li huwa material versatili, li għandu aktar minn funzjoni waħda, pereżempju biex iżomm l-ikel f jew anki anki fl-użu tal-medi大ina jew insulazzjoni. Imma minkejja dan, irridu na大大ertaw ruħna li ma jkollniex plastic li jispi大大a fl-ibħra tagħna. Jiena ġejja mill-Baħar Mediterranju u naf kemm din tista' tkun problema. L-iskart tal-plastic fil-fatt f'pajjiżi li huma fil-Mediterran huwa fost l-akbar tħassib ta-大idini Ewropej u s-suġġetti li qegħd iin niddutu llum jgħin liħ-ħittadini jagħmlu l-aħjar għażla biex innaqqsu l-iskart u nnaqqsu l-impatt tiegħu. Issa jekk verament irridu nsolvu l-problema, irridu nnaqqsu l-kwantità ta' plastic liġġeneraw. U din hija l-opportunità tagħna biex verament ninvestu f'ekonomija ġdida u niżviluppaw swieq ġodda. U għalhekk li rridu niżviluppaw aktar l-innovazzjoni, u li nagħmlu prodotti minn material li jintuża aktar minn darba. Jiena nemmen li dan huwa l-bidu ta' ekonomija 大irkolari u aktar sostenibbli. Irridu ninvestu wkoll, iżda, f'aktar kuxjenza pubblika għaliex gandħna bżonn kampanji pubbli大i u rridu wkoll nippromwovu d-disinn u l-produzzjoni tal-plastic li huma konformi mal-użu aktar minn darba u l-ħtiġijiet ta' riiklaġġ. B'dan il-mod biss jista' jkollna ekonomija 大irkolari li tnaqqas it-tniġġis mill-plastic u l-impatt negattiv fuq l-ambjent u fuq is-saħħa tan-nies.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr When we in Finland at some point in the early 1950s moved from wooden toys to toys made of plastic, we thought we had taken a huge step forward. About 70 years later, we see that this time too it was not.  While we are now determined to limit in some way the production of plastics, we must also sort out where plastic is a useful product. Where the plastic is used and can not be replaced by other means. We therefore have before us a major investigation in which we have to be clear when plastic is directly dangerous and life-threatening, not only for us humans, but also for fish and animals. We need to find out where we can replace it, with products from the Finnish forest, for example, and where we cannot replace it and therefore have to ensure that it continues to be manufactured.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Dear Chairman, I will start with one statistic. This summer I conducted a survey among the citizens of the Republic of Croatia that lasted a month and listening to you here as we should, of course, put a lot of effort and money into raising citizens' minds so that we should change our habits, I can say that 96% of the citizens in that survey said that they are ready to replace the products they use today from disposable plastic for an alternative that will , of course, to be much better for the environment and for all these problems that we mentioned today.  So where exactly is the problem? The problem exists locally because most countries do not have good infrastructure that would provide citizens with exactly what we talked about today. So I can collect waste separately. That this waste can very quickly become a secondary raw material, as our Vice-President of the Commission said, to become a value for entrepreneurship. We do not have the support for our entrepreneurs and the economy to produce reusable products, which will be made of alternative materials. And we can ask ourselves, by our example, do we show citizens how it really needs to be changed? When was the last time you turned down a single-use plastic bag they offered you?  So these are issues that we need to talk about, that we need to change awareness about and in which we need to invest money in the future budget of the European Union.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, caithfidh mé a rá go bhfuil sé thar a bheith in for go dtabharfaidh an tigh seo aghaidh ar na dúshláin ollmhóra atá romhainn ó thaobh truailliú, agus go háirithe plaisteach. Agus cé go gcuirim fáilte roimh an tuarascáil agus gur céim chun tosaigh é, ní fiú faic é mura bhfuil sé curtha i bhfeidhm go láidir.  Sub léir go bhfuil dualgas orainn on bag freagracht and ghlacadh maidir le húsáid plaisteach, ach tá dualgas níos mó ar na comhlachtaí ilnáisiúnta – agus cinn eile nach iad – an rud ceart and dhéanamh agus cosc and chur on plaistigh and úsáid ina gcuid táirgí. Táim with moladh mar sin, go mbeadh pionós faoi leith curtha orthu siúd nach nglacann le reachtaíocht chun deireadh and chur le húsáid plaisteach aonarach.  Ní hamháin go gcaithfimid réiteach práinneach a fháil on an bhfadhb atá ann faoi láthair, ach caithfimid dul i ngleic leis an bplaisteach aonarach atá with líonadh ár bhfarraigí gach nóiméad de gach lá. Níos mó plaisteach inár bhfarraigí in 2050 ná éisc; tá sé deacair é sin a shamhlú. Agus mar sin, ní féidir ligean dó seo leanúint on aghaidh.  Mar sin, coinnímis leis an toil agus an dea-obair, ach níos tábhachtaí fós, caithfear an reachtaíocht seo a chur chun cinn agus deireadh and chur le plaisteach aonarach ach go háirithe.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I support efforts to reduce the amount of plastic being used because, for the foreseeable future, a lot of it will end up in the open environment, including the oceans, from which it cannot realistically be collected for recycling or anything else. It is well known that all plastics create fragments as they degrade but we know that fragments of ordinary plastic could accumulate for decades, and perhaps for as long as 100 years as micro-plastics, before they become biodegradable. New plastic goods therefore urgently need to be modified at manufacture so that if they do get into the open environment they will become biodegradable much more quickly than ordinary plastic. This modified type of plastic is known as oxo-degradable or oxo-biodegradable, and the technology is available here and now from an entrepreneurial firm in my own constituency in the UK. I was therefore astonished to see that Article 42 of the report calls for a ban on this technology without a vote, and I am angered that foreign MEPs should seek to extinguish British innovation. The Commission has at least gone through the motions of asking for a scientific study on this but, with the greatest respect to the rapporteur, Mr Demesmaeker, neither he nor his colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety are polymer scientists. They are therefore in no position to come to a conclusion in advance of a scientific report and they have not, in fact, included a single line of evidence in their report to justify such an important decision which they are asking Parliament to make. I will be voting against this report because only the British Government should have the power to prevent British innovation. If the report succeeds tomorrow it will confirm that the EU favours ideology over science yet again, and that factual evidence is a mere irrelevance. At the very least, voting on this topic should be delayed until a scientific report is to hand. In my own speciality, of UK agriculture, hundreds of hectares of land are covered in plastic as a frost protection. It can be heavily contaminated with soil when it is removed a few months later, making disposal a major problem. If it was oxo-degradable it could be removed to a building and allowed virtually to disappear. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, are there any other scientific arguments in favour of oxo-biodegradable plastics other than the fact that it’s produced in your constituency?

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – The argument is that it we should allow it to be evaluated scientifically and it should not be completely disregarded by a committee that is called the ‘Committee on the Environment’ in the European Parliament, the members of which are not scientists.

name: Danilo Oscar Lancini (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ten rivers account for 93 % of the planet's plastic pollution: eight in Asia, two in Africa, zero in Europe. We must tackle this problem by acting where we can achieve a significant effect, namely the collection of waste in Asian and African countries. Reducing and restricting single-use plastic products in Europe does not solve the problem. The numbers speak for themselves: the disposable dish represents only 0.02 % of the artifacts found on the beaches, and is therefore not significant at European level. Italy has a significant share of manufacturing industry engaged in the production of single-use plastic dishes, which will suffer considerable damage.  At the moment there is no alternative to single-use plastic dishes that guarantee the same performance and the same hygiene and food safety for consumers. Replacing them with paper is certainly to the pleasure of the producing countries of Northern Europe, the same countries that strongly promote this directive, but this does not benefit European citizens and the environment. Let us avoid being influenced by false media campaigns and fully apply existing waste legislation, not by resorting to shortcuts that have no decisive effect on solving the problem, but are measures that only have an impact on public opinion and not on the environment. Let us remember the example of biofuels...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: Mr President, thank you to the rapporteurs and colleagues for the very good cooperation. We're on the road. This weekend, the plastic cull of the Ocean Cleanup project chose the spacious sop of the Pacific Ocean. I am proud of initiator Boyan Slat, a Dutch student of 24 years. He started it and understood what policymakers actually haven't understood for years. We have to act. It is now time to prevent the plastic soup from increasing and gaining the upper hand. The soup has to be cleaned up slowly by projects like Ocean Cleanup or the fishermen in the North Sea, when they are fishing. We must also help them. Unfortunately, there are also quite a few disposable forks and the like that would be degradable under the influence of oxygen, but therefore do not prove biodegradable in the aquatic environment. We're being fooled. This is shabby plastic! We must therefore move towards fully reusable plastics and an internal market for secondary raw materials. Producers need to start designing reusable products. The production of plastic waste is unacceptable because microplastics pollute our environment and our seas.  These reusable plastics do require a clear policy framework. Substances of concern should not be allowed into the circular raw materials when reused, as others have said. Commissioner Katainen, it is time for a clear policy framework and better legislation. You have the EFSI resources. Let us use it for this too. We can get started with this. And of course we also need to work on the necessary promotion: mothers, children, students, everyone can do something about it. Finally, I would like to say a word to my English colleague who has just left. I would like to say: go out for a day with the English fishermen. Hopefully they can convince you, because it's almost too late.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Mr President, between the beginning and the end of my speech, an additional 45 tonnes of plastic will end up in the oceans. As you know, more than 13 million tonnes of waste are dumped into our seas every year. The European Commission's proposal is a drop in the bucket. It is not by banning cotton swab sticks, cutlery, plates, straws and drink mixer sticks and rods for balloons that we will solve the problem. No, the culprits are not our European citizens who throw their packets of crisps into recyclable bins, and we must stop the guilt of consumers dictated by the industry and the plastic packaging lobbies. Stop with this neo-liberal logic, which we know all too well in France and which consists in saying that pollution is the fault of the consumer, the financial crisis is the fault of households and unemployment is the fault of the unemployed. The European Union must take responsibility and tackle the real polluters of the planet: the giants of industry. Do you really believe that a company like Coca Cola cannot afford to change the business model to produce less plastic? We urgently need to initiate a Marshall Plan for the oceans, on the basis of the polluter-pay principle, to regulate the production, use, sale, import and recycling of plastic products in a strict and non-negotiable manner. Finally, I propose to open up the new European Solidarity Corps, which we created yesterday, to projects based on waste collection. Excuse me for exceeding 5 tons.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: Mr President, plastic, in the mid-1950s, was a revolution, an invention that changed everything: products, quantities, possibilities, practices and our behaviours as well. But today, this is the fact that we are falling under the waste and our oceans are dying from it. For half, it's these plates, these cotton swabs, these straws, these cups, these bottles... all these everyday objects that are used once, discarded and then take 500 years or even 1,000 years to decompose. So, as the European Parliament's rapporteur on this single-use plastics directive, I obviously support Marc Demesmaeker's ambition to promote the dynamics of moving to a circular plastics economy. That being said, recycling is, somewhere, encouraging production. And sometimes it's very complicated, especially when plastics contain problematic chemicals. Clearly, the sustainable solution is to reduce the production, the consumption of plastic. Every year, 500,000 tonnes of plastic waste are dumped into the seas of the European Union, which is no longer sustainable.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President! Thank you to Mark Demesmaeker for an excellent report. I could almost say that I fully agree with what is the challenge here, so I will not repeat it, but overall say: think when I did the plastic bag law at the time, when it was used by the Commission to say that it was 'small things'. It was something we should not be dealing with in the EUROPEAN Union. And now Frans Timmermans has admitted that he was wrong, and that was included in Jean-Claude Juncker's "State of the Union" speech - it's something to celebrate! We need plastic, that is true, as several people have said. But there can't be poison in it. It must be used as little as possible and it must be recyclable and recoverable where we need it. And let me say that this is a great opportunity for all of us now to go out and meet our constituents and be able to tell them that we are actually taking a concern seriously that has now become pan-European. You have to be on the far right or co-producer of Oxo so as not to take this seriously. We are, after all, sitting with Frédérique Ries and working on a ban on single-use plastic. This is a very important piece of legislation that is coming now. Here I would like to stress three things that are crucial: no poison in plastic – it is not just a marine environmental problem, it is also a problem for the rest of nature – and we must focus on prevention and prevention! Finally, let me say that I think the Commission is too unambitious with Oxo. We know that it just falls to pieces, we know that Symphony is trying to spread it in Africa, in Asia, and that is only to propagate microplastics! It's not doing anything good for our nature. And I do not understand that we cannot stop right now and say that this should be banned. There is scientific evidence for this.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the scientific community agrees that plastics consumption seriously endangers the environment, and you will surely have seen it in the summer. It could be that on the beaches we already have more plastics than tourists. But it's more—and now seriously—if we do nothing, according to the United Nations in 2050 there will be more plastics than fish at sea. Can you imagine that? I think it would be really terrible. It must be acknowledged that what the Commission is proposing on this issue is going in the right direction, but we are late and therefore we cannot be insufficient, as I am afraid we are being. What this is all about is radically changing the way we produce and therefore also consuming, putting drastic plastic reduction, reuse and recycling at the center, first of all. In other words, it is not just a question of creating – and I say 'alone'— new materials or advertising recycling campaigns only, but it is a question of telling markets, companies, that images like this of fruit wrapped in plastics, which you will recognize, no longer make sense or place. And for this, plastics producers and lobbies must be left out of future decision-making.

name: Mireille D’Ornano (EFDD).
text: Mr President, better management of plastics is an absolute emergency when we know that more than 150 million tonnes of plastics would be in the oceans. I am pleasantly surprised to see my colleagues today grasping this subject. For the record, in a resolution tabled in January 2017, I proposed that Parliament urgently call on the European Commission to support all serious projects aimed at developing boats to remove plastics from the oceans. Indeed, several very innovative projects have appeared for this purpose and are just waiting to be supported. Unfortunately, the main political groups did not see fit to act on my proposal. So yes, we can discuss the hours of the urgency to act, but what are we waiting for to take action? Time is running out before the oceans turn into a giant garbage can and the situation becomes unmanageable.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we have a plastic problem in Europe. We still use single—use plastic cups for our coffees, plastic straws in our drinks, single—use plastic water bottles and plastic cutlery in many of our cafes and takeaways. This leads to pollution across the continent, particularly in our coastal areas and marine environments, where it has a massive negative impact on our maritime and fisheries sectors, which has obvious implications for human health and indeed tourism.  It is vital that we take immediate action to tackle plastic waste and bring in strict measures at EU level to do so. It is unacceptable that in 2018, we still have such a level of plastic waste. For this reason, I welcome the Commission’s strategy on plastics. I particularly welcome the proposal for a single—use plastics directive, for which I am PPE rapporteur in the Committee on Fisheries (PECH). Of the litter found on our beaches in Europe, 84% is made up of plastic, with 50% being single—use plastic. We simply must be strong in acting on this and we cannot afford to water down the Commission proposals. Moreover, measures to reduce plastic waste work. In Ireland in 2002, for example, we introduced a levy on plastic bags. The move had an immediate effect on consumer behaviour and a decrease in plastic bag usage from an estimated 328 bags per capita to an estimated 14 bags per capita by 2014.  It is important to properly communicate the facts about plastics to European citizens. We must empower them to reduce their consumption of plastics and to understand the significant environmental damage that has been done. I am hosting a public meeting on this very issue this Friday in my constituency in County Waterford. The people of Waterford know only too well the damage that comes from plastic pollution: they see it every summer as they clean up what tourists leave behind on their beaches. I look forward to meeting them and reporting back to Parliament.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is not a question of demonising plastic, because this material can also be useful in many areas. However, we must endeavour to contain this flood of plastic products and, above all, to carry out reuse and recycling as consistently as it is somehow feasible.  The question is: how can we encourage companies to perform with less material consumption? How can we encourage them to include this avoidance aspect with standards? The Ecodesign Directive must also be extended to plastic products. How can we achieve that we can use tax rates to promote what we want and then also hinder certain types of plastic use? We also need larger publicity campaigns so that citizens know how these products are treated and disposed of. And I would also like to say one more thing: if we use replacement materials, then we must also look carefully at whether they are really better. There are also many things that may not be as good as it looks.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which For sixty years, plastic has made our lives easier in many areas, and it is an integral part of life, of everyday life. But it has very problematic consequences. It can be found wherever we do not want it: in the rivers, in the soil and also in the sea. And that is a big problem that we have at the moment.  Three-quarters of the world's marine litter is plastic, and 300 million tonnes of plastic products are produced on the global market each year. We can only recycle thirty per cent here in the EU, and only six per cent are recycled. That is far too little! We must therefore consider what we can do to improve this.  I am currently working on the Marine Waste Directive and i am looking at what can be done to really bring all the waste ashore. That is one thing. We recently had a big plastic exhibition about my marine group, in April, where you could look and see what science has figured out, what different plastics there are and what it can do to harm. And then it is the case that, as Jo Leinen has just said, there are indeed many opportunities to bet on new product lines, on alternative materials that we can use, or on start-ups that, for example, clean the ocean and remove the waste everywhere. So we have a lot of opportunities to improve there, and we should certainly do that.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Vice-President Katainen, Mr Demesmaeker, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. For politics, there are three main tasks on the plastic front. Firstly, we need to make the public aware of how far we have come to a point where plastic waste threatens to overwhelm us, so that plastic itself appears in our food. Secondly, we must make it clear to the public that things are different. Thirdly, we must set a reliable framework for this, which will enable citizens to actually move sensibly without so much plastic waste. To this end, the Commission has presented an ambitious strategy, which we all welcome. You have all put forward many arguments on this. It is important to make it clear to us how it is called: nothing is as powerful as an idea whose time has come. The time has come for the idea that the plastic waste must be removed – not to be thrown away, but not to arise in the first place. That is why I want to promote that as many of you as possible take part in The Global Clean-up Day on 15 September, in which we are committed to ensuring that plastic waste does not dominate our future.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, excessive waste and waste production is inseparable from existing production and consumption models. Questioning the excessive production of waste and waste, including disposable plastics, necessarily requires questioning these production and consumption models. It requires questioning, ultimately, a system, capitalism, which is founded on an irrational and unsustainable relationship between man and nature. Combating this irrationality does not dispense with measures that, although apparently small, can have a wide reach and a great impact. It just does not dispense is also the great measures. One and the other should, in its application, be guided by principles and concerns of social justice and not by the principle of the sacrosanct market that those who pay can pollute. A regulatory approach to a market approach should also be favoured in this area, promoting, alongside waste reduction, re-use and recycling, for example, at packaging level. That was the point of an opinion of the Committee on Industry of which he was rapporteur. Finally, scientific research and technological development also play an important role here in the search for more sustainable alternatives to current materials.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the plastic materials obtained through organic polymers were an immense discovery of the chemical engineering of the last century which brought the opportunity to design new products because of their malleability, hardness, low cost and, above all, their durability. But if the low cost determined mass production and disposable use, its durability determined the perpetuation of them in our seas and oceans. The truth is that, together, these characteristics have promoted the environmental disaster that we now recognise and which are so well exposed in this report. The fact is that, because of human irresponsibility in the use and disposal of plastic material, today we are experiencing the global drama of ocean pollution with an impact on biodiversity that adds to the already difficult consequences of climate change. I therefore congratulate the rapporteur on this dossier on the excellent work that will enable us to show that Europe is responsible for leading the world in this mission of not further aggravating an unsustainable situation. But that's not enough. And it is not enough because it is not only Europeans who are concerned about their fishing material, using alternatives to disposable plastics, recycling and thinking about ecodesign. This issue needs to be on the global agenda of climate diplomacy and more ambitious measures must be taken immediately in Europe's trade relations with third countries. What is not enough is also that we have the courage to outline an ambitious strategy and then postpone the concrete measures for its continuation. Ladies and gentlemen, what is needed is to change the behaviour of civil society and the business fabric must be a partner in this objective. We need, in this joint effort with the Commission and the Member States, that industries be part of the solution and that the modernisation of the production sector is made more ecologically conscious.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent It is time for the EU to take the lead even more clearly today and show that today's plastic consumption is not sustainable. Plastic littering is a problem worldwide, and europe needs to show much more clearly leadership. But it is also a question of the EU doing its own homework. Every year, up to 500 000 tonnes of plastic litter is found in the EU's maritime areas, and the Mediterranean is, in fact, the sea with the highest concentration of plastic litter worldwide. If nothing is done, by 2050 there will be more plastic than fish in the oceans. This is an insanity that needs to stop.  Now that we are taking action against the environmental effects of plastics, we must also ensure that hazardous chemicals are phased out and instead create a non-toxic cycle. Because, my friends, this applies not least to all the microplastics that end up in our seas. While we only see about 1% of the plastic mountains in the oceans, most of it is hidden beneath the surface, attracting chemicals that can become harmful to both human health and the environment. I would therefore like the Commission to present the action plan for a non-toxic environment promised under the 7th Environment Action Programme. I want to know when, and when will the promised strategy against endocrine disruptors actually come?

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, I think we need to say that, in area of the circular economy, we have made significant progress. I don’t want to be repetitive because a lot has been said here today in terms of what the situation is, the challenges, the objectives and how to meet them, and that is something that I can subscribe to. However, let me just add a different point of view. We have just adopted and brought into force the legislation on the circular economy, all the directives that we have thoroughly negotiated. I think that we need to have a look not just at the strategy but also at the plastics proposal. How does it fit with the system? Take, for example, the collection target for beverage bottles: I have no problem with being ambitious but does it fit entirely? I mean, are we not in fact diluting the targets we have? Eventually, is there something that we need to do to prevent discrimination between products, or an additional requirements for extending producers’ liability? Again, this is an important issue, but what about consumers? In terms of the whole chain, we can’t put the burden on producers for the misbehaviour of consumers. So a number of issues need to be looked into, including awareness, and I’m sure that if we manage to fit this piece properly into the system that we have established then we can deliver results.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, I am pleased that the European institutions have begun to work purposefully on the issue of plastic pollution. The plastic strategy under discussion today is an ambitious goal of making plastic recycling a profitable business, promoting a faster transition to a circular economy and innovation. In welcoming this initiative, I would nevertheless like to draw attention to a few moments. First of all, we need to talk about a clean circular economy. Although recycled, toxic plastics that circulate continuously will pose no less risk to the environment and human health. In preparing the opinion of the Committee on Rural Development for Agriculture on reducing the environmental impact of single-use plastic products, I proposed the use of the concept of a circular non-toxic economy. The repeated use of clean and non-toxic products, that's what needs to be the basis.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the main objective of the plastics strategy is to reduce plastic waste. The good news was that we still have a lot of work to do, but the bad news is that plastic waste is increasing enormously around the world all the time. The worrying information emerged that only 30% of plastic is still recycled, around 30% go to landfills and around 30% go to landfill. The main objective now is to make a complete effort to prevent the generation of plastic waste. It has a big impact on both the economy and the environment.  We already have a lot going on. The new Waste Directive obliges Member States to organise recycling and sorting of plastic. It's an important step. Similarly, the Commission has proposed that, in future, plastic should be fully recyclable and that certain single-use plastics should also be abandoned. One proposal included in the Commission's multiannual financial framework is the introduction of a certain type of plastic tax, which would further push member states into recycling plastics. We still have a lot of work to do. One of the most important things for the consumer is that we need clearer labelling of which plastics can be recycled and how they should be sorted. On the other hand, industry also needs uniform standards on how recycled plastics can be used. There is still a lot of work to be done in both of these. As well as the need to invest enough in research and product development in the sector, so that we can also find sustainable bio-based replacements for plastics that are environmentally friendly. This is the kind of work that is going on across Europe and it is important that we direct research resources towards this. Of course, this is also a big international issue. Plastic is coming into Europe from all over the world in the same way that plastic is exported from Europe to the rest of the world. It is important that we also strive to cooperate internationally and with standards here. I am very pleased that in the summer an agreement was signed with China to promote the circular economy jointly, because of course there is a common interest here for both of us.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the circular economy today represents a very important opportunity for regions and cities for the coming period. The overproduction of plastics is also an alarming aspect of the current linear economy. Cool plastics can be found on the street, in forests, water reservoirs, in national parks and in the seas. They're all around us like unnecessary garbage. It is therefore necessary to acknowledge the Commission's actions in alleming an additional €100 million under Horizon 2020 to support investments in tackling the circular economy. We should therefore also introduce multi-level incentives to reduce plastic production in the future cohesion policy. We must look at plastics as a production cycle, use up to their recycling or safe disposal. But I am fully committed to and support the replacement of plastics with new types of packaging material that has minimal impact on the environment, is biodegradable and ultimately whole-useless.

name: Elsi Katainen (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the world is indeed drowning in plastic and we need an ambitious plastics strategy. We must stop the passage of plastic into food, water, our system. However, a strategy alone is not enough, we need more ambitious legislation that obliges us to recycle and reuse plastic, because a leap into a plastic-free world is certainly not going to happen overnight. We also need to further develop alternative materials for plastic. For example, by managing forests sustainably, we can combat climate change and replace many plastic products with wood-based raw materials. There must also be room for all innovations and solutions that promote the recycling of plastic. We should be aware, for example, of the enormous potential of chemical recycling as one of the major solvers of the plastic challenge. In order to meet the challenge of sustainable use of plastic, we need to invest in cutting-level science, where horizon Europe, for example, plays a huge role.

name: Linnéa Engström (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent Today we are debating the threat of plastics. It takes twenty seconds to produce new plastic, twenty minutes to use it and more than 400 years for it to be broken down into the environment. If we talk about our oceans, it never breaks down, but is only finely distributed to microplastics, which end up in our bodies. We do not have time; we need to tackle this major environmental threat now. That is why I welcome the Commission's proposal to ban ten plastic disposables. Unfortunately, however, it is not enough; we need to be much more ambitious and take action against this plastic threat. We must raise our ambitions so that everyone assumes their responsibilities. Let us really work together now, all together, to reduce our plastic dependence. Business, civil society, we here in the European system and all the Member States – we have everything to gain from dissing the plastic.

name: Christophe Hansen (PPE).
text: Mr President, I thank Mr de Demesmaeker for this remarkable report and the work he has done. Ladies and gentlemen, 87% of our citizens are concerned about the damage caused by plastic. I am one of those 87% because I too want to leave a livable planet for future generations.  This morning, Jean-Claude Juncker affirmed his desire to enshrine the reduction of the use of plastics in European legislation. The proposal on single-use plastics, to which Mr Juncker was referring, still lacks ambition for my liking. That is why I have tabled an amendment which obliges Member States to reduce their national consumption of plastic by 50%. A little nod, perhaps also, to the Austrian Presidency here: the European Parliament will certainly be ready to conclude this dossier under your presidency. We can do even more: first, ensure the innovation needed for a post-2020 circular economy policy; second, to develop a dynamic innovation and research sector to design alternatives to plastics; third, act to speed up what I call the 'Plexit', the exit of plastic. Colleagues, we also need a quick agreement before the 2019 elections on the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF). Allow me, since I still have some time, to respond to some of the comments of my colleagues who are no longer here. Mr. Agnew told us about oxodegradable plastics, but in fact these plastics are also made from petroleum. An additive is added, but their impact on animal health, human health and the environment is the same as that of conventional plastics. Mr Lancini said there is no alternative to some of the products that are covered by the single-use plastics proposal. I must tell him that these alternatives already exist; they are a little more expensive, but demand will grow and prices will become affordable.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, other Members have mentioned the incredible numbers of plastic consumption. When I'm done talking, a million plastic bottles will have been bought around the world. I believe that, as we have been doing in recent months, our first objective must be to inform: awareness-raising campaigns, a cultural battle. We need bans, but we must first work to convince European citizens that it is possible to do otherwise, that it is possible to overcome a disposable lifestyle, what Pope Francis in his splendid encyclical called "the culture of waste". And our North, our compass, must always be the circular economy. We need coordinated action. That is why I have proposed, for example, on single-use plastics, that the manufacturer's extended liability should include quotas to be paid in proportion to the durability of the product, its recyclability.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Mr Demesmaeker on this report on European policy on plastics, because we are facing an opportunity which must not be wasted. Citizenship of the Union has a growing sensitivity to the environmental effects of this material, which favours the necessary change of habits in order to advance a necessary revolution.  A change that forces us, to begin with, to recycle much more than 30% of the disposable plastic we collect now for that purpose. This same environmental awareness is driving technological initiatives that will focus the design of plastic packaging on circularity rather than recycling. A movement that will drive innovation and create sustainable wealth and employment.  We also have advanced waste regulations, and we know that designing the one that will regulate the secondary raw materials market, implementing quality standards and stimulating changes with tax measures, is the next step. That is why I encourage European innovation programmes to add to this movement, with particular attention to initiatives and entrepreneurship in this sector of the circular economy.

name: Tilly Metz (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her 25.8 million tonnes of plastic waste are produced in the EU each year. Less than 30% of this is recycled. Between 150 000 and 500 000 tonnes of plastic end up in the sea every year with devastating effects on marine ecosystems. Animals such as fish, turtles and birds get caught or suffocate in plastic. Plastic waste also causes great damage to land, with catastrophic consequences for animals. People also suffer harm. Microplastics, which can be present, among other things, by cosmetic products, can enter the seas or even the food chain – with potential health consequences. And by not reusing plastic, we lose between 70 and 105 billion a year. Action must now be taken! The costs of the environment and health must be taken into account. Sales, consumption and waste need to be better regulated. Above all, we must and will act to protect the health and the environment of citizens.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to draw our attention to the second part of the joint debate, and that is precisely the question: How to solve serious problems on the border of legislation on chemicals, products and waste? In January this year, the Commission published a communication addressing options for addressing issues just on the border of legislation on these chemicals. The communication aims to promote a broad debate within the Union and to find a way to address the main problems identified.  We deal with four critical issues. Insufficient information on substances of concern present in products and waste. Secondly, the presence of substances of concern in recycled materials. Thirdly, uncertainty as to how safe it is to dispose of these materials and whether they can cease to be waste. Fourthly, difficulties in applying the methodology. The conclusions of the Commission communication are therefore the four problems mentioned. We should address these problems so that we do not have obstacles in the circular economy. The ambition must be to achieve full regulatory compliance.  I therefore have the following two questions to the Council. How does the Council approach these issues and the possible measures proposed by the Commission to address the four most important problems? More specifically, how does the Council want to contribute to further unifying the interpretation and application of the provisions on materials that have ceased to be waste by the Member States?

name: Tiemo Wölken (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the As President Juncker said earlier in his speech, the proposals from the plastics strategy must be implemented before the election. And I agree with him: we must be ambitious here, because the Commission's proposals deserve it.  The problem of plastic waste is a problem that affects many areas, such as marine pollution. Tomorrow, we in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The Sea will vote on the so-called port reception facilities. The aim is not to dump the waste of ships in the sea, but to hand it over to ports. In order to have an incentive for this, we need a system of flat-rate charges so that it costs ships nothing to hand over waste to ports. And here I look in particular at the members from the Committee on Transport and Tourism, who are voting on it after us and who may be guided by our report.  In addition, of course, there is a major problem with microplastics that end up in the environment, for example through car tyres or abrasion of washing machines. Sooner or later, if we do not reduce consumption, we will have to resort to filtering techniques, and I do not want consumers alone to bear the costs.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, more than eight million tonnes of plastic are poured into our seas and oceans every year. To get an idea, this has already spawned in the Pacific an island the size of Spain, Italy and France together. Most of these plastics were single-use, but their degradation, which can last up to 1,000 years, is flooding our seas with microplastics that then end up in our food or on our plates.  The plastics we use only once may cost little money, but what you don't see—and that's the problem—is the price people pay: our health and the environment. That is why the European Greens insist so much on prevention and that the price when producing plastics reflects their real direct and indirect costs. Ridiculous images that we've all seen, like these fruits individually packaged in plastic, have to finish now.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the meantime, as shadow rapporteur, let me thank the rapporteur, Mr Demesmaeker, and all my fellow Members for the work they have done together and for the excellent cooperation that has led to the adoption of a shared and well-centred text. Parliament's objective is to support the Commission towards a new sustainable plastics economy, combining economic development with the protection of the environment and human health. Today, there are still too many plastic products on the market that cannot be recycled or reused and that, at best, can only be disposed of in incinerators or landfills, while at worst they are dispersed in both the marine and terrestrial environment, with serious damage both to biodiversity standards and to economic activities such as fishing or tourism. Well, we don't have time anymore. Through the report that we will be voting on tomorrow, Parliament is calling for a concrete commitment to a change of pace for the Commission and all the stakeholders involved, and defines a series of concrete measures to ensure that plastic is designed, produced and consumed and that its end-of-life is managed according to the principles of the circular economy. The other point on which our position is very clear is that of the need for immediate and urgent action to combat the other major problem: marine pollution from plastic.
