I personally felt it was important to include among these measures that of the contribution that fishermen are making to cleaning up our seas through so-called passive fishing. I am proud that one of the pilot projects of this type, 'Clean Archipelago', took place in my region, Tuscany. On the basis of the important results obtained, too, we wanted to emphasise that similar projects should be promoted throughout the European Union and that the burden of managing the plastic waste recovered should never fall on fishermen. It will also be important for this measure to be incorporated into the new port infrastructure directive currently under negotiation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, plastic pollution is one of the most serious environmental emergencies of our time, and we need to act quickly and in a coordinated manner. Every year we generate around 26 million tonnes of plastic waste in Europe, less than 30 % of which are collected for recycling purposes. The main challenge of the Commission's plastics strategy is to produce and use plastic in a sustainable way, in order to reduce waste production. We must therefore act intelligently and create the need to close the circle of the circular economy. While, therefore, the quality of recycling must be improved, plastic waste must be curbed and investment and innovation directed towards circular solutions, it is essential to create a stable internal market for secondary raw materials, removing the obstacles that this market faces, starting with the relationship between the selling price of virgin raw materials and that of secondary raw materials.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Demesmaeker, on his suggestion; The examples cited for environmental destruction, in particular that the oceans have been filled with plastics, are well known. This is of particular interest to Greece, because we have clean seas and we want to keep our seas clean. But you realize that when in other states there is no such protection and there is reckless use of plastics, problems arise for Greece as well. We are therefore the ones who insist that measures must be taken and of course this can be done, above all, on the support of the circular economy, because only through the circular economy can there be recycling, there can be prevention and, of course, there can be protection procedures. Of course, tax incentives are also needed in order to tackle the whole problem we are discussing.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, congratulations to the rapporteur who knows very well the importance of the sea for many peoples, such as mine. Plastic trash in the sea is a big problem. 80% of the garbage at sea is plastic, microplastic, so abundant that it is already part of our ecosystem. Microplastic absorbs other pollutants such as pesticides and heavy materials that cause health problems. The maritime sector, an ecologist, is very concerned and wants to fish for fish and not plastic bags or bottles. That is why we need an ambitious policy that does not stand by a timid but radical and urgent policy, because the model is no longer good. The model of producing and consuming no longer serves. And the circular economy is an opportunity, before garbage is overrun by land and sea.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, what we are talking about is a real ecological disaster because almost half of the 10 billion tonnes of plastic produced have ended up in nature and at the bottom of the oceans. We must keep in mind that by 2050, with population growth, 28.7 billion tonnes of plastic will be generated, almost triple the total plastic produced so far. That is to say the magnitude of the challenge that is before us. We should be ashamed that we have made our oceans garbage. If we do nothing, we will no longer have to talk about a 'seventh plastic continent', but a 'plastic planet'. That is why we need ambitious measures, radical measures. I want to end with a word about cigarette butts. People don't know that when they smoke a cigarette, they smoke plastic. We must therefore ask the industrialists to change the composition of cigarette butts, because cigarette butts are real scourges for the environment.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, plastics are now an important parameter for the lives of citizens and the economy of a state. But because of their low level of collection and recycling, they pollute the environment and create health problems, especially when they enter the food chain; they also destroy marine ecosystems when they end up in seas and oceans. In order to tackle this problem, both the Member States and the European Union must adopt effective laws to control the movement and movement of disposable plastics and other plastic waste so that they do not end up in the seas. They should also raise their level of collection and recycling so that waste can become important factors in the development of a country's economy.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is a welcome to hear the unanimity of this House, from all colleagues from different political groups, when it comes to seeing how to address the need we have to address the elimination of plastic in the usual use of our lives. Plastic certainly has uses that are interesting and that have made life easier for us, but we have to be aware that this usefulness that has given us to society is now a big problem.  We have exceeded the use of plastics in too many applications. Action must therefore be taken and that is why I congratulate the Commission because the strategy, the directive we are already debating, is on the right track. Let us take advantage before the end of the legislature to take action on this reduction of plastics, in that education in habits and information to consumers and in innovation and in new opportunities for the economic sectors.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, therefore, the challenges of plastics before us are important, on the one hand, both for the economy, the economy and ecology, and above all for our health, because the consequences of consuming microplastics are really catastrophic.  And if mankind lived so many years and centuries without plastic, when plastic became then a challenge and a developmental concept of humanity, now, of course, it can also become our gravedigger. But as much plastic as we produce is, of course, the product of a consumer society. And I think it is time, in this whole package, that we also think about trying to influence companies to produce products that are not just disposables, and that the way we understand and handle plastics also leads to consumers, because after all, it all ends and starts in the minds.  So, on the one hand, we have the responsibility of Europe, on the other hand, the Member States, the local communities and, of course, every individual. Only together, of course, can we defeat this evil for the common good.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the discussion around the plastics problem and the impact on the environment is a global problem, but which the European Union has been leading. This fight is not against plastics. What we want to face is the way they are used and what happens after they are no longer useful. I have welcomed the Commission's proposals to address the issue and to which this Parliament has been contributing decisively. I have organised several debates on the subject, in particular the impact on the oceans and the ways around it. I conclude, like the rapporteurs, that this issue is only comprehensively resolved and the circular economy of plastics is an important part of the problem that has to be fostered. To prevent plastics from reaching the sea is to prevent them from reaching our table. In this way, improving the fate of the plastics used is one way to reduce this impact.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: – Madam President, protecting the environment is essential as a guarantee of the future. But in the meantime, plastics suffocate the sea. More than 80% of marine litter corresponds to plastics. The European Union generates no more and no less than 25 – almost 26 – millions of tonnes per year. This is a lot, a lot of waste on our part and very little recycling: less than 30%. This is a great challenge that does not allow for delay. It needs concrete legislative initiatives by the Commission, initiatives that stimulate the economy towards a transition of business to the circular economy, a sustainable economy. We need prevention measures, population education. We need to involve municipalities if we want this strategy to succeed. And we need a specific measure to start cleaning the plastic seas, which is already a reality.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you all very much for this excellent debate. I believe that the circular economy will be one of the mega-trends in the coming years in the world economy. The second mega-trend is based on artificial intelligence, and these two are the ones which will reshape our societies and economy in the coming years. That is why I’m so glad that, as today’s debate here in the European Parliament has shown, this is one of the issues – the circular economy and the plastic strategy as part of it – which unite us. I don’t remember any other policy areas in this House in which the debate would have been so consensual. We share the same concerns and the same challenges, and we are trying, more or less, to find a solution from the same part of the world. So I really want to thank the House for its contribution to the circular economy. Actually, I would like to congratulate the European Parliament, and I hope that you congratulate the Commission and the Council also, on the fact that during this election period we have created a new policy which is called ‘circular economy’ in Europe. That is the reason why Europe is leading circular economy development in the world. The US is far behind us. China is the second best.  Talking about China, I participated in a high-level economic dialogue last June in Beijing, an EU-China dialogue, and right after that we had the EU-China summit in Beijing at which we discussed deepening our cooperation, especially on circular economy. We actually signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with our Chinese counterpart on enhanced cooperation between the EU and China on circular economy. Plastics is one part of that. I was discussing with my counterpart the possibility that we might manage to create a joint or common quality standard for plastic packages in China and Europe. If we did that, it would create an enormous market for the recycling of plastic waste. So there are lots of opportunities. Today we are losing 95% of the value of plastic packages, and it simply doesn’t make any sense. Plastic waste has a value and today we are losing most of this value, simply because we have not developed good policies to recycle plastic. Only 6% of the plastic in our market is recycled plastic. So this means that there are huge opportunities, but we just need better policies which encourage raising the quality of plastics – and there, for instance, the quality standard for plastic packages is of the utmost importance. My final word is on the plastic levy, which is part of our Multiannual Financial Framework proposal. I do hope that we get it through. If it is not possible to get it through, I really hope that Member States could look at it as a national solution. Taxation or levies can create healthy incentives to the economy. If we start taxing something it will create incentives to change behaviour, and if we put a levy on unrecycled recyclable plastic it is a good incentive for changing our business models. So once more I want to thank you for your contribution. Let’s continue our good cooperation.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, from my little experience with debates in this House, I got the impression that it must have been one of the rare debates where all the Members of this House are of the same opinion, no matter for which reason or from which political party they belong to, and I also want to thank you for this very fruitful discussion. We are all of the same opinion: there is the absolute need to reduce the plastic in our lives to a minimum level and to better use this in general useful material. It was also mentioned that much can be done at a regional level, for example with awareness-raising campaigns. Well, yes, it seems so easy at first sight to reduce the plastic in your life, but if you have ever tried to buy fruit, vegetables or meat and milk products in a supermarket without buying loads of plastic, you would have found out that it is much harder to do this and to manage this than you at first think. Let me assure you that the Austrian Presidency attaches great importance to the circular economy and Treaty-related files such as the reduction of the impact of certain plastic products on the environment. But we still have to do more, and I agree with many Members who mentioned that. Thus, the Council looks forward to the results of the Commission’s public consultations addressing the interface between chemical product and waste legislation, which is still ongoing until 29 October. To conclude, let me underline that the Council is and will remain open for discussions and cooperation with you, honourable Members, and of course with the Commission and interested stakeholders, in order to define a path forward to a truly circular economy.

name: Puhemies. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 13 March 2008. The rapporteur was Mr Sa99-2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – The way plastics are produced, used and disposed of today has devastating environmental, climate and economic drawbacks and potential negative health impacts on both humans and animals. I very much welcome this report, which tackles successively the need to move from design for recycling to design for circularity, the creation of a genuine single market for recycled plastics, prevention of plastic waste generation, as well as innovation and global action. A stable internal market for secondary raw materials is indispensable for safeguarding the transition to a circular economy, therefore the obstacles this market confronts with have to be fully addressed, while laying the ground for a level playing field. Indeed, the EU Plastic Strategy constitutes a necessary step forward in the EU’s transition towards a circular economy and as well as a crucial tool towards attaining the Sustainable Development Goal to prevent and reduce marine litter. Preventing the generation of plastic waste upfront and boosting our plastics recycling performance are both essential. Moreover, I strongly share the opinion that the plastics strategy should also be used as a lever for encouraging new, smart and circular business, production and consumption models covering the entire value chain.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – 26 million tonnes of plastic waste are produced annually in Europe. Some 79,000 tonnes of this type of waste end up in the oceans over an area of 1.6 million square kilometres. Due to its spread over such a large area, 90% of seabirds swallow plastic particles. I believe that this report is very important and necessary, as the impact of plastic waste on flora, fauna and human health is obviously negative. The solutions used for the management of marine plastic waste must be integrated into the overall plastics strategy. I support the rapporteur and believe that smart solutions are needed, to stimulate, through fiscal policies, the collection, but also the recycling of waste. I also believe that, in order to achieve a notable level of results, the priorities should be prevention, then education and, last but not least, the sanctioning of those who do not comply with the relevant legal provisions.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – It has become customary for essential documents on recycling and material flows to emphasise the need for a transition from a linear economy to a circular one. Given the fact that the basic materials of different plastic products are different hydrocarbons, it is by no means easy, especially as regards packaging materials in retail trade, to ensure classification according to the chemical composition, which is an important prerequisite for recycling. Logically, the first priority is therefore to prevent the generation of plastic waste, the second priority is reuse and the third is recycling. To do this, of course, it is necessary to use the appropriate technology for collection and sorting. Today, only 30% of plastic waste is collected for recycling in the EU. 31% of plastics are landfilled and 39% are incinerated. As regulations to prevent plastic landfilling will apply across the EU by 2030, there is a need to increase the possibilities for re-use of packaging and recyclability. The Commission is invited to introduce a ban on microplastics in a number of products by 2020, while setting out requirements to reduce their release from a variety of materials. Horizon 2020 is to allote EUR 100 million for research into the sorting, recycling and use of plastic resources. I therefore warmly support the above mentioned activities mentioned in the report, as well as the inclusion of the 'Ocean Without Plastics' programme.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – EU environmental policy helps to protect nature and ensure the health of its inhabitants. Unfortunately, the statistics are devastating: more than 8 million tonnes of plastic end up in the seas and oceans each year, and continuing to maintain this trend will result in more plastic litter than fish in the oceans by 2050. The Great Pacific Garbage Patch weighs more than 43,000 cars and covers an area five times that of Poland. Garbage negatively affects marine flora and fauna, penetrating our digestive system, causing various ailments.  We need to start with educational activities and make citizens aware that by increasing the number of plastics we use every day, we are harming ourselves and the environment. I welcome the fact that a large part of society, as well as business and SMEs, is starting to put emphasis on rational waste management and the use of biodegradable or reusable plastics.  As an excellent example, I can give here the practices already used, where many of us, buying takeaway drinks and bringing, for example, our own reusable cup for coffee, and thus giving up plastic, gain a discount in the form of a discount on the purchase of a drink. I would very much like and wish all of us that such practices become our daily habit and become a permanent part of our consciousness, which will certainly contribute to improving the environment.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. "The amount of plastic waste has risen in a threatening way as plastic consumption has multiplied over the past decades. It is only recently that more attention has been paid to the environmental and sustainability aspect. Plastic is a useful and durable material with many uses. However, it is essential that it be used in a more sustainable way.  Plastic waste has devastating environmental impacts on marine ecosystems, for example, and not all its health effects on humans are even known yet. The amount of waste generated must be reduced. Recycling and collection must also be promoted, as currently only 30% of plastic waste in the EU is collected for recycling. The market for recycled plastics should also be encouraged, as currently recycled material accounts for only around 6% of new plastic products, according to Commission figures. The report calls for all packaging plastics to be reusable or recyclable by 2030. The goal is tough, but necessary. I also think it is important to invest in research and development of alternative and environmentally friendly materials and, for example, in new recycling technologies.  The EU cannot solve the problem alone. Most of the plastic waste from the seas comes from rivers in Asia and Africa, where recycling and collection infrastructure and public awareness of the problem are lacking. In view of the international nature of the problem, I think it is a good thing that the EU is a trendse in this issue.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report (A8-0257/2018) (A8-0257/2018) by Karin Kadenbach, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the European Joint Health Action Plan to Combat Antimicrobial Resistance (2017/2254(INI)).

name: Karin Kadenbach
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of this House, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to stress that I am pleased that we have had the opportunity today to discuss the report on the European action plan to combat antimicrobial resistance, or AMR, here within the framework of the concept of 'health'. Because it is nothing less than one of the greatest threats we are currently facing.  In his State of the Union address this morning, President Juncker pointed out that only a strong and united Europe can protect its citizens against threats from inside and outside – from terrorism to climate change, as he said. I would like to add and emphasise that this common Europe, this joint effort, is also needed to protect people from growing health threats – from AMR, for example.  I would also like to say briefly here that I regret that President Juncker, in his speech today, did not address the issue of health, which is so important for the people, but also for the business location. In contrast to his 2017 speech, where he was pleased to point out the importance of a high vaccination rate and the need for all people in the EU to have access to vaccination. Vaccinations – also an important issue in connection with AMR.  Why is this fight against AMR, antimicrobial resistance so important? Because almost 500 people in the European Union die every week from infections caused by multi-resistant germs, largely ignored by media coverage, but also largely unnoticed by the general public perception. That is as many as there are deaths from road accidents in the European Union every year. And there will be many more if we do not engage, consistently and seriously tackle it.  We are threatened with a return to a pre-antibiotic, prepenicillin era, where a urinary tract infection could be a death sentence, where surgeries, transplants, chemotherapy could pose a much higher risk to patients than they are today. Lack of knowledge about the mode of action of antibiotics, improper use, abuse, overuse – both in human medicine and in animal husbandry – lack of hygiene measures, improper disposal – they are among the main causes of AMR.  The European Parliament has dealt with this issue on several occasions in the past, and many steps have already been initiated. I hope that Commissioner Andriukaitis will use his speaking time here to go into it in detail. I would also like to take this opportunity to express my thanks to him for his commitment and commitment. However, I would also like to thank those responsible in the European agencies working in this area for their good and fruitful cooperation.  The aim of this report is to support and, above all, to promote the work of the Commission and the Member States. We have drawn up a number of general proposals here, but in particular a large number of concrete suggestions and demands. In order to prevent, in addition to all the human suffering caused by disease and premature death in 2050, the economic damage caused by antibiotic-resistant infections will reach the financial impact of the 2008 economic crisis. Promote awareness-raising, health literacy, better education and training for all health professionals, and the development and use of rapid diagnostic tests, new and alternative medicines and treatments, the importance of prevention and immunisation, new business models to stimulate industry, universal access and the availability of antibiotics should only be a few of the areas of action that we have addressed in our report. Detect.  At this point, I would like to express my sincere thanks to all those who have worked so constructively and intensively here – the shadow rapporteurs in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The European Union, but also the colleagues in the committees that have been consulted. I look forward to today's exchange with them and Hope that the report will also receive strong support in the vote tomorrow, so that, in addition to President Juncker's statement, we can also take part in the threat to health. Europeans can take effective, strong action. A Europe that protects puts the protection of the health of its citizens at the top of its agenda.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the report being debated today is of the highest importance for public health. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Kadenbach, for her personal commitment and determination in leading this work, as well as the committees that have been involved in the preparation. We often take antimicrobials for granted, relying on them and believing that they will always be there to protect us. If you will allow me a personal note from my professional past as a medical doctor and a cardiac surgeon, I would like to stress how painful sepsis and death can be in situations where antibiotics can no longer help. I am also particularly struck by the very high speed with which resistance to bacteria has recently progressed, since the first therapeutic use of antibiotics less than a century ago in 1941. Excessive and inappropriate use of antimicrobials in humans, animals and plants and poor infection-control practices have led to growing antimicrobial resistance (AMR). This resistance has progressively transformed into a serious threat to public health worldwide. Honourable Members, let me remind you, as Ms Kadenbach also did, that 25 000 people die annually in the EU alone as a result of infections caused by resistant bacteria. Some estimate that if current infection and resistance trends continue, there could be 10 million deaths per year worldwide by 2050. In simple terms, there is a risk of reverting to a world where some common infections are no longer treatable. The European Union was quick to recognise the importance of tackling antimicrobial resistance, as the 2001 ‘Community strategy against antimicrobial resistance’ shows. This policy was reinforced with the 2011 Commission action plan, and last year a new and comprehensive EU action plan on antimicrobial resistance was adopted, pursuing the ‘One Health’ approach recognising that human health, animal health and the environment are interconnected. You will remember that I came to present that plan to the various relevant committees of the House. This milestone clearly underlined the Commission’s commitment to step up our actions to tackle the huge challenge of antimicrobial resistance. The new action plan contains concrete measures with EU added value. It supports the EU and its Member States in delivering innovative, effective and sustainable responses to antimicrobial resistance. It also reinforces the research agenda and enables the EU to promote global action and play a leading role in the fight against AMR. A first progress report was published in April of this year and it will be updated regularly Let me mention a few examples. First, the Commission published EU guidelines on the prudent use of antimicrobials in human health in July 2017. Second, a joint action project on antimicrobial resistance and healthcare-associated infections started in September 2017. This brings Member States and other stakeholders together to support the development and implementation of effective health policies against antimicrobial resistance and to reduce healthcare-associated infections. A second Joint Interagency Antimicrobial Consumption and Resistance Analysis (JIACRA) Report was published in July 2017 by the European Medicine Agency, the European Food Safety Authority and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, and we can now see the common efforts of the three agencies. Each provides evidence-based data on the correlation between antimicrobial consumption and resistance in humans and food-producing animals, and this will enable Member States to tailor their antimicrobial resistance policies better to the local context. Next, the Commission is providing training sessions for veterinary and public health staff from national authorities involved in AMR control, under the so-called Better Training for Safer Food programme, and is carrying out joint Commission-European Centre for Disease Control visits to Member States on request in the context of the implementation of national ‘One Health’ action plans against AMR. Meetings of the One Health Network government experts from human health, animal health and the environmental sector, as well as EU scientific agencies, are organised regularly and I am very glad that your report will be presented at the network meeting next month. Lastly, as to global activities, we can assure you that we will pursue our efforts in various forums, notably the G7 and G20, and in collaboration with the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), the World Health Organisation, the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation and the OECD. Antimicrobial resistance is indeed a global threat which requires global action. That means too that we have a collective responsibility to ensure that EU Member States deliver on the commitment they made when they endorsed the 2015 global action plan on AMR. Furthermore, the negotiations on the new EU regulation on veterinary medicine and on medicated feed are now successfully concluded and I am glad that the House will vote on the outcome of these trilogue negotiations no later than next month. This is a major milestone in the fight against AMR. Indeed, the draft regulation includes a ban on the preventive use of antibiotics in groups of animals, as well as the possibility of reserving certain antimicrobials for humans only. In addition, the 2006 ban on antibiotics as feed additives is now broadened to cover the use of all antimicrobial veterinary products as growth promoters in animals. This will be an important further step in the responsible and prudent use of antibiotics in the EU. Madam President, honourable Members, the report we are debating today is of great importance. It contains many valuable suggestions on ways to go further in our common fight against AMR and I will carefully analyse all the proposals you have made. Antimicrobial resistance will only get worse in the future if we do not continue to act together: not only the Commission but also the European Parliament, the Member States and, of course, all the stakeholders involved in the use of antimicrobials must reinforce our efforts. We need to do so to avoid a return to the pre-antibiotic era, with simple wounds and infections causing significant harm and even death, and routine medical procedures being very risky. That would be a really bad scenario. I look forward to the adoption of this report and I thank the House for its continued commitment. (Applause)

name: Lieve Wierinck
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the ITRE Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank Mrs Kadenbach for her report and her hard work. I appreciate that in her report she also took into account ITRE's advice on antimicrobial resistance. As rapporteur of ITRE, I have tried to find sustainable solutions. For me, these sustainable solutions lie in the following elements.  It is of immense importance that research and innovation are sustained. The search for new antibiotics is crucial, but epidemiology and immunology also offer opportunities. This search will mainly be undertaken by the pharmaceutical companies and research institutes. That is why there can be not only one economic model, but that there must be different motives for developing new antibiotics. Here we speak in the report of the pull and push incentives.  In addition, it is also important that the patient receives a quick and correct diagnosis. Is he infected with a bacterium or a virus and what bacterium is it? The technology of this new rapid diagnosis should be available and accessible in all Member States. Antimicrobial resistance is not only a European problem, but a global problem. We in the European Union must put our shoulders to it. We must look for possible solutions. We must take our responsibility here by seeking out European and international cooperation and solving a global problem together.

name: Matt Carthy
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Madam President, the rise in antimicrobial resistance is globally now recognised as one of the greatest potential threats to human health. There has been only one new antibiotic discovery in the past 30 years, and in February of last year, as has already been said, the WHO reported that within a generation, unless there are new antibiotics, deaths from drug resistance infection could reach 10 million a year. The agricultural community has a big role to play in curbing the overuse of antibiotics, and there are already some important legislative initiatives coming down the track with regard to the advertisement, sale and prescription and use of antibiotics on farms. This evening, though, I want to repeat one of the calls that the Agriculture and Rural Development Committee has made in this report, which is that the Commission must ban all food imports from third countries where antibiotics may still be used as growth promoters. Worldwide, 80% of the total consumption of medically imported antibiotics is in the animal sector for growth promotion in healthy animals. The link between antibiotic consumption by animals and resistance in humans cannot be denied, and if we are going to be realistic about combating this global issue, then this should be one of the first places to start. I want to thank the rapporteur for her work and her cooperation with our committee on this issue.

name: Renate Sommer
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Antibiotic-resistant germs – an immense, ever-growing threat to health and life. So many sick, lifelong disabled, deaths caused by these germs. We urgently need new antibiotics. But they are not available, and the development is expensive and takes a long time – up to twenty years, if it succeeds at all. We urgently need alternatives to the antibiotic. But these alternatives do not exist, at least not yet. We must promote development. That is why we need to be much more accountable with what we have. Half of the antibiotics are used improperly by the patient, but are also misprescribed by the medical staff. People know too little about it. The majority think antibiotics simply help against everything, against colds, colds, viruses. But that is just wrong, and we need to re-anchor this in our society, so that people know this so that they understand why these resistances are spreading and that everyone can be affected – this does not always affect others – so that everyone can and must make their contribution to slowing down or even stopping this development. , if that is still possible. Old medicines, for example, do not belong in the toilet. Hygiene is an important aspect, and as banal as it sounds, it starts with hand washing – which, of course, is particularly true in the health sector. Medical staff also need to be better trained. Infection prevention is the key word here, especially important in dealing with old and sick people. All this and much more – much has already been mentioned – is stated in our report. I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs of the other groups for their very constructive cooperation. But at one point we need to improve tomorrow: I would ask you to join me in deleting recital 63, which requires food labelling in relation to the use of antibiotics in farm animals. This is unnecessary and would even be tantamount to insinuation to the detriment of conventional agriculture, because animal products can only be marketed without antibiotics anyway. That is why appropriate waiting times after the use of medicines in animal husbandry are mandatory.

name: Bolesław G. Piecha (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to thank the rapporteur for the very comprehensive report on the European Action Plan 'One Health' to combat AMR. As a politician, but also as a doctor, I believe that the 'One Health' principle must play an important role in member states' health policies, because bacteria, virus or micro-organism know no bounds. It is clear that human and animal health are – today it is known – closely interlinked. Wide-ranging action programmes should be adopted that raise awareness among European societies of the use and handling of antibiotics not only for the treatment of humans, but also for animals. Member States must act in close cooperation in this regard, using, of course, the substantive, expert actions of the European Commission and the Member States.  Prevention and good health-promoting behaviour should not only be limited to restrictive sales of antibiotics (for example, without a prescription or online), but must also be closely linked to a social information campaign. The widening of sensitivity and the broad information campaign should apply not only to antibiotics. We must not forget vaccines. This phenomenon of the 20th century, which eliminated many infectious diseases from our space, has been forgotten by European societies. It should be returned to it and protective vaccinations should also be promoted.

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, the use of antibiotics is still rising spectacularly. The OECD has shown that in just 30 years, the use of antibiotics in the world has increased by a staggering 67%. In human health, antibiotics are still prescribed far too easily. As many as 50% of the prescribed antibiotics have no effect. Furthermore, in some parts of the world, large quantities of antibiotics are still dumped in the environment through wastewater when manufacturing medicines. Outside the EU, antibiotics are still used in livestock farming as a growth promoter to produce cheap meat. This is frightening and it has to be different when you consider that this is causing rapid decline in the action of the antibiotic and that we are no longer able to treat simple and common diseases and infections. In addition, there has been no research on antibiotics since 1987 and no new classes of antibiotics have been developed. Action is needed and countries cannot do this alone, the European Union cannot do this alone, it must be tackled globally. I am very much in favour of a Paris agreement on antibiotic resistance. We have to crack down on abuse. We need to do much more research into alternatives such as vaccination and develop new antibiotics, and we need to focus much more on preventing diseases in humans and animals than we are curing. And that is possible, evidenced by several Member States in the European Union, where human health care is effectively used. Or in my country, where farmers have invested fully in new stables, better hygiene and better management protocols. In seven years, the use of antibiotics in livestock farming there has fallen by 60%!

name: Martin Häusling
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to thank Mrs Kadenbach for the report, including the Commissioner, for dealing with the issue so prominently. I would have liked the President of the Commission to be the subject today, because in fact AMR is a time bomb and it is getting worse and worse. That is why I am annoyed that we are not taking a more vigorous approach to the issue, because it is also a reason for AMR that we are using too much antibiotics abusively and unnecessarily in many areas. This starts in human medicine, that antibiotics are still prescribed against colds. This is completely unnecessary. But there is too much use of antibiotics also in the field of animal husbandry. Prophylactic, metaphylactic antibiotics are used because too many animals are kept in too narrow stables and because animal husbandry is not properly designed. We cannot afford that. The cheap meat will be very expensive for us at some point if we carry on like this. In fact, we must also point out that more antibiotics are used in animal fattening than in the human sector. That cannot remain the case. We must also ensure that reserve antibiotics are no longer used in the animal sector. And we must prevent, in the case of antibiotic resistance, there being, so to speak, the transmission of animals to humans. I believe that we agree that we need more training, we need more research, especially in the direction of alternatives. The use of antibiotics must be the last resort, not the first means we use. Otherwise, we will not make any progress at this point.

name: Stefan Eck
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Andriukaitis, you know, I come from Germany, and that is why I would like to start by mentioning a worrying figure from my country of origin on this subject. In 2017, six times more antibiotics were used in agricultural livestock farming than in human medicine. Thousands of people are already being killed each year in Germany by antibiotic resistance. Public health is ignored by the German Government when it comes to farmers' profits. But let us talk about Europe. Multi-resistant germs infect millions of patients in European hospitals every year and are estimated to be responsible for 90,000 preventable deaths. When a person loses his life in the EU due to antibiotic resistance, our misguided agricultural policy, in particular, bears a great deal of complicity. For too long we have turned a blind eye to the problem and allowed mass animal husbandry to become the money machine of the pharmaceutical industry. We must now put a stop to unscrupulous fattening plants, which even use prophylactic antibiotics, and to the pharmaceutical industry. I hope that you, Commissioner Andriukaitis, will now do nails with your heads and do not act in the same way as in my own-initiative report on rabbit farming. We are still in the clinch. And by the way, you know for yourself how many antibiotics are being used in this sector. Finally, I would like to thank Mrs Kadenbach warmly for this report, and I hope that it will be adopted by a large majority.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to start by entering into mrs Kadenbach's thanks for her work and also for taking up and incorporating what we had already done in the 2015 own-initiative report for which I was rapporteur. Since then, unfortunately, antimicrobial resistance in the world has increased and in some countries, in some Member States, it has even reached and exceeded 25 %. Now the rapporteur, with the intention of limiting them, has rightly included all the possible causes in the text, but I would not like this to divert attention from the cause which, on a global scale, is by far the cause of the increase in antibiotic resistance, namely the use of antibiotics in animal farms. That is why I fully agree with what Mr Eck has just said.  We have spent these years fighting to improve veterinary legislation, because we know that the use of antibiotics for livestock is considerably greater than the use made of antibiotics for humans, and that the majority of feed intended for farm animals contains antibiotics. There are intensive farms with hygienic conditions and respect for animals that are really in a shameful state, with animals living their entire lives on each other in very tight cages, in the midst of their own excrement and often in the midst of mice. And these are precisely animals that are intended for human consumption, that can live in these very high-density lagers only because they are filled with antibiotics, which then have an effect on the resistance that develops in humans. Therefore, from our point of view, the main road is to ensure that the livestock and aquaculture sectors prevent diseases through good hygiene and good farming practices, rather than using antibiotics as prophylaxis. In short, today we are not saying anything new, but we say it with the knowledge that times are pressing and that we must speed up the search for new, but above all pragmatic, solutions. That is why we must ensure: one, the strict application of the rules and controls on veterinary medicinal products; two, the use of antibiotics in intensive farming as prophylaxis must be banned; and three, encourage organic and extensive farming patterns.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this report on the European Action Plan to Combat Antimicrobial Resistance highlights the different aspects behind antibiotic resistance, and the major seriousness of the latter, which causes several thousand deaths every year in Europe. It addresses both human and animal antibiotic resistance. It discusses ways of making better use of antibiotics in human pathology and in livestock farms. We should add phytosanitary plants, which are often potentisers of antibiotics. However, it does not point the finger at all at the persistent excesses of the free movement of humans, especially during irregular immigration, without health checks or respect for hygiene rules. This, of course, concerns particularly multidrug-resistant forms of tuberculosis. Nor does it point the finger at the free movement of goods in the trade of meat-food products from countries that do not comply with European standards, and this in the context, however, of official treaties with Europe. Because livestock antibiotics are used to prevent epidemics in herds, but above all to accelerate the growth of animals. This ultimately leads to contamination of the entire food chain. So we have to outlaw it. We therefore strongly urge the European Union to be consistent with the reality of the facts, by encouraging good practice, but above all by controlling its borders and by revising its treaties.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: –  Madam President – good evening, Chamber, and thank you very much. I am going to start with two statistics: 56 000 newborn Indian babies die from drug—resistant infections every year. 70% to 90% of all travellers to India return with drug—resistant gut bacteria. It has got nothing to do with animal feed: this is down to big corporations which are polluting the environment. Now let me go on and just quote from a report produced in the prestigious scientific journal ‘Infection’, literally within the last few weeks. They found excessively high levels of antibiotic and anti-fungal resistance in and around the major drug production hub of Hyderabad in India – and what’s the link? Most of the big drug companies are situated there and a significant amount of their production is exported to European Union Member States. Now, it is the responsibility of the European Medicines Agency to look at supply chain aspects. Nothing is being done to look at bulk manufacturing environmental impact, so can I ask the rapporteur and also the Commissioner to please look at that aspect and ensure that it is included in the report.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am very pleased that we are talking again in this Chamber about antibiotic resistance. It is such a serious problem that, in fact, humanity, but also Europe, does not like the growing phenomenon that we simply do not have an effective antibiotic for some diseases that reliably solves the infection. The so-called methicillin-resistant strains of Staphylococus aureus are known, which when you simply go to be treated, operate on a normal abdominal hernia to the hospital, and otherwise you are quite a healthy person, you may get such a resistant strain in the hospital and you may lose your life in this way. This also happens in our Europe, which is so developed. I am very pleased that, since we have been talking about this serious matter, antibiotic resistance, the European Union is already acting and has taken action, and I am also pleased that the Commissioner for Health is paying close attention to this issue. Already €1 billion has been invested in science and research in research into new molecules and new promising chemicals that could help in this area. It is pointed out that many antibiotics can be bought without a prescription, or that general practitioners and pediatricians sometimes prescribe antibiotics for both parental pressure and viral disease, but the main culprit here are meat producers or producers who give preventive massive doses in cattle farms for nothing and create blanket resistance to antibiotics. This must stop, and I am pleased that we are united in this House and that we will also be able to intervene with the Commissioner.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Karin Kadenbach, because I believe that he brings us here today a good report, which is very useful for the needs of European society and society at large to address this reduction in antibiotics and this antimicrobial resistance. I would also like to congratulate Commissioner Andriukaitis on his role because I believe he is pushing for important legislation.  I would like to mention — because I have heard from some colleagues and I think it is out of without knowledge, without anything else — that in recent years we have made great progress in reducing antibiotics also in animal health, which is the one I know best. I'm going to talk about the one I know best. They are about to agree on the two three-way dialogues, the Veterinary Medicines Regulation and the Medicines Regulation, and there will be a breakthrough with these Regulations. In addition, we have also adopted an animal health regulation in this legislature. In recent years, therefore, there has been a large reduction in antibiotics in animal use because we have made restrictive rules that have been adapted in each and every country.  Today's livestock has nothing to do with the one ten years ago. If you don't know him, get unheded. I believe that, just as this needs to be done and we must continue to insist on it, something else must also be done — I know it less - on the subject of antibiotics and their use in humans. But since I know him less, I try not to talk about what I don't know and to talk about what I know, which, in the case of animal health, these years have been very productive.

name: Thomas Waitz (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Multi-resistant germs, i.e. germs that are resistant to some or all antibiotics – we have heard: 25 000 deaths every year. A special thanks to Mrs Kadenbach for explicitly in her report that one of the main causes of multi-resistant germs comes from mass animal husbandry, especially from pig farming. Reserve antibiotics, i.e. antibiotics reserved for human medicine only, are the order of the day.  It must be possible to authorise certain antibiotics only for human medicine and to ban them in animal fattening. At the same time, however, we must be aware that these germs are spread across the European Union through animal transports – live animal transports. I have seen trucks where the manure has been ripped out at the back of the journey, so these germs have spread across Europe. It is the order of the day to immediately stop transporting animals from affected regions in order to prevent the further spread of these life-threatening germs. I would ask the Commissioner to take immediate action here.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, agriculture has a part to play in the crucial fight against antimicrobial resistance. I am pleased to report that in the UK, all prophylactic use stopped in 2016 and the livestock industry is moving towards a preventative approach three-pronged by security, vaccination and improved welfare to help replace the use of antibiotics. A target maximum of 50 milligrams of antibiotic per kilo of live weight has been set as an industry challenge. Critically important antibiotics used in human medicine have been removed from use in livestock altogether. The breeders of the various species are now concentrating on promoting genes that demonstrate resilience to infections, but this work could be enhanced by modern breeding techniques, which – unfortunately – the Green lobby of this House has so far managed to prevent farmers from using. The same Green lobby, of course, has persuaded the Commission to spend fortunes in money trying to get the farmers to improve the world’s weather. That money would be so much better spent on infrastructure grants for bio-security, and they would yield a real return in the reduction of antibiotic use.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The report deals with a very serious issue, namely AMR, the multi-resistance in bacteria. Far too many deaths in Europe's hospitals are due to their accounts, and more and more therapies are unfortunately no longer taking place.  It is absolutely right and the aim is absolutely to support us in doing something about it and doing the right thing and what is necessary at this point, and that certainly includes the fact that we are calling for some corrections, particularly in the area of livestock farming. However, and I would like to remind you of this at this point, we should not overshoot the mark. We should not start with labelling requirements, production controls and a general attack on conventional agriculture – and this also shimmers very clearly in some speeches here, that this is precisely the general attack on conventional agriculture – that we should not throw the baby out with the bathwater and not exaggerate the right direction of action.  Billions of demands will not make pure organic farming in Europe a success either. What we need is prevention, but in particular more research and, of course, the networking of national authorities in this important matter.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the good cooperation, and I can say that it is a very good cooperation. We are facing a major problem, a problem that threatens our very existence. We don't think about it enough.  Antibiotic-resistant bacteria could become a threat until 2050, disrupting our entire modern society, such as the 2008 financial crisis. When will the European Commission and the OECD agree on the actual current death statistics of antibiotic resistance? Commissioner, you spoke of 25 000, but others are talking about 40 000. What are we talking about?  Actually, it's not about numbers. We've got to get to work on this. Parliament has rightly given kudos to the Dutch livestock sector, which has reduced the use of antibiotics by two thirds. But we also look at human health care: carelessly and often pointlessly selling critical last-line antibiotics for a flu! Sales without medical prescriptions also need to be addressed, as does the dumping of antibiotics on the market. Antibiotics are still cheaper in some Member States than a packet of chewing gum or other items. Therefore, too few new antibiotics are being developed.  Together with a strong vaccination policy in the Member States, Europe must support the development of innovative new antibiotics. In the meantime, we are still waiting for a strategy to tackle pharmaceutical pollution. Antibiotic-resistant bacteria in surface water pose an uncontrollable danger if we continue like this. In another debate on the Water Framework Directive, I am also talking about this. Europe must now act more forcefully! Resistant bacteria do not stick to borders in these times of migration, and we all have to deal with that.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Madam Chairman, every time you take an antibiotic unnecessarily or do not comply with the prescribed dose, you steal from your children and grandchildren the opportunity to be treated one day. A world without antibiotics means dying of pneumonia or the most common cut on your finger. As with vaccinations, people have forgotten what the achievement of human civilization is.  It's a serious situation and it's getting worse. The last new class of antibiotics was put on the market back in the 1980s. Since then, there are no new drugs, and bacteria have developed resistance to one existing one by one. Perhaps raising panic is what we need at the moment because the causes of the development of superbugs are irresponsible farmers, patients and doctors, but also a policy that faces the situation too slowly. Of course, the problem is also in the level of social awareness and ignorance about the action and use of antibiotics. In 1945, the inventor of penicillin, Fleming, warned that human ignorance and irresponsibility could jeopardize his revolutionary discovery.  I would like to thank the Rapporteur and all the colleagues who worked on this report who proposes a number of concrete measures and moves. I hope that the Commission and the Council will take them into consideration very seriously and come up with ways to implement them as soon as possible. Thank you.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the one health definition has expanded the concept of human health to other factors influencing it, such as animal health and the environment. Regardless of whether antibiotic control in the environment is very incipient, I would like to welcome the effort of this resolution by proposing important measures in the field of animal health.  The fact is that it has become indeferred to halt the unruly use of antibiotics introduced by the intensification of animal husbandbreeding practices. However, even though antibiotics are important in ensuring food security, we cannot allow the options to reduce production costs at the expense of the future of our health.  As far as human health is concerned, it seems that the best remedy is to prevent it. I am convinced that the strengthening in the use of vaccines provided for in the report is too timely and, therefore, I would like to recall the number of deaths that could have been prevented in Europe this year if it were not for the anti-scientific campaign that discredited vaccines as an essential public health tool.  Without concealing that health systems in the Member States face enormous funding challenges, we must continue to invest in rapid diagnostic technologies and research into new antibiotics, especially those that function as the last therapeutic lines to be used only in extreme cases.  But in order to have these antibiotics, we will have to test new forms of remuneration for producers who do not place the volume of drug sales. I end by saying that antimicrobial resistance is a public health problem that civil society must be sensitizing to and is a global problem, and without wanting to create apocalyptic scenarios, today's regulation can prevent a global pandemic with unimaginable impact and dimensions.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: – Madam President, congratulations to my colleague Kadenbach on this very important report, which sets out a clear holistic approach to one of the great health threats at present, a threat which, if not fought - as it rightly reflects in the report - can overcome the current threat posed by cancer. We therefore need a proactive and clear attitude on the part of the Commission to put this important report in place. Research into new antibiotics? Yes, but it's not the only thing; medical devices that improve accuracy in the diagnosis and treatment of these infections. But we especially need new research models that allow and ensure access to future new antibiotics and devices. I welcome the need for a public research network for the development of these devices and antibiotics; budgeted, objectively and concretely monitored national plans; rational use of antibiotics, with the follow-up by specialists involved and monitoring this appropriate use, rational, human and animal use. And I welcome the european experience of the Pirasoa project for the rational use of antibiotics, which has been so effective.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very grateful to my fellow rapporteur Karin Kadenbach for delve into one of the most difficult health problems we face in the European Union and to produce such a thorough and comprehensive report.  We've got more and more victims, and new antibiotics are out of sight. However, we have the potential to reduce the burden of antimicrobial resistance, and I am pleased that we are very clear in this report, in which, in paragraph 104, we explicitly draw attention to the use of probiotics, for which several scientific studies have shown or demonstrated that they are very successful and that infection in hospitals can be reduced by up to 90%.  Each percent means thousands of victims who wouldn't be there if they used the most effective means. And here it seems that the common market in the European Union is not working, because if not, we would be using more probiotics.  We will not reach a more Europe with more victims because of antibiotic resistance. And I would like the common market to be operational in this area as well.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, today 700,000 people worldwide die every year from antimicrobial-resistant infections. Eventually, by 2050, an additional 10 million people a year could die as a result of this antimicrobial resistance. There is therefore an urgent need for action. I welcome the excellent report by my colleague Karin Kadenbach, and in particular paragraphs 27, 104 and 105, in which she encourages the adoption of innovative measures to combat the spread of infectious diseases. As part of one of my trips, in my constituency in France, I had the opportunity to discover one of these innovative tools. These are Steriall antimicrobial parts, made from copper by the Lebronze alloys group. 100% natural and durable, copper has antimicrobial efficacy. By providing door handles, thrust plates and antimicrobial alloy accessories to schools, nurseries, hospitals and nursing homes, we can effectively combat the spread of bacteria and viruses in these environments.  These copper parts can, in my opinion, become a key tool of antimicrobial resistance. That is why, Commissioner, I invite you to attend a conference, at the European Parliament's information office in Paris, on the prevention tools to be developed against this antimicrobial resistance.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, antimicrobial resistance is a serious threat to human health and economic development. The excessive and improper use of antimicrobials in humans and animals has accelerated the natural evolutionary processes of resistance, to the point that today some infections have even been rendered un curable by existing antimicrobials. Projections indicate that antimicrobial resistance could cause up to 10 million deaths per year in 2050 if no action is taken. The One Health action plan should play a central role in combating antimicrobial resistance. Diseases must be tackled both in humans and animals, taking particular account of the food chain and the environment. In this, the role that the European Commission will play in coordinating and monitoring the national action plans implemented by the Member States will be crucial. The correct use of antibiotics must be ensured by investing more in research, development, training and information, providing constant updates for medical staff for careful use of antibiotics.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, antimicrobial resistance is one of today's major challenges and is a global threat. It is important to control diseases without jeopardising the effectiveness of prophylactic means.  Ultimately, it is important to preserve the very treatment capacity of diseases, both in animals and in men. I note that water and soil pollution by human and veterinary antibiotics is a growing problem for the environment itself, and particular attention should be paid to this. I would like to stress the importance of member states' commitment to implement national action plans and create appropriate incentives to achieve this objective. This effort cannot be dissociated from international cooperation and should be encouraged. It seems to me to be the only possible approach and is also fundamental in research and development.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, antimicrobial resistance is indeed a serious issue and leads to too many deaths, precisely because of the use of antibiotics in animals. But Commissioner Andriukaitis, I would like your attention a little, because in Greece today there is a serious issue with West Nile virus. There have been 28 deaths so far; we have 189 cases. There is a serious problem in 27 municipalities in Attica. I repeat: West Nile virus; The point is that one third of the total cases have been recorded in Macedonia. The questions I am asking you are, firstly, the Greek Government has been in contact with the Commission to address this serious problem of West Nile virus in Greece or not, and secondly, you, as the Commission, in cooperation with the Greek authorities, what measures do you intend to take? This situation cannot continue; Greece is the third most affected country; first Serbia, second Italy and third Greece. I would like an answer because this issue is currently of concern to the entire Greek population and the West Nile virus is not treated with antibiotics! Please, I'd like your opinion. It interests all Greek citizens what you say.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. –  Mr President, honourable Members, listening to you tonight makes me rejoice. I am glad to see such a wide unanimity of views and convergence in your interventions. I am looking at the plastic strategy which was discussed before and now I see antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a topic which unites all of us. Thank you for that. Your report constitutes a strong political signal for us to step up our fight against antimicrobial resistance. As I said earlier, we have reached a critical point and the status quo is not an option. Inaction would cause millions of deaths globally. Isolation is not an option either. No single action will, in isolation, provide an adequate solution in a world that is increasingly interconnected and characterised by an intensive exchange of people and commodities. You rightly mentioned when speaking about AMR that we should draw attention to all the instruments which we have in our hands, from agriculture to hygiene measures, bio security, vaccination, prevention of diseases, animal welfare, proper use of antibiotics, and so on. We have a lot of instruments available, an excellent animal welfare platform and the One Health network, which can contribute a lot. We have achieved a lot in those four years of dealing with antimicrobial resistance and I am proud that we now have new legislation on our hands, which I mentioned. I strongly believe that it is only by joining our forces, including across borders, that we can make a difference in and win the fight against AMR in the EU and globally. We will now carefully analyse all the proposals you have made following tomorrow’s vote on your report. Once again, I thank you for your support and continued commitment.  Just speaking about Greece, let’s communicate because I have no signals from the Greek Government. It would be good now to stay in touch and we are ready to discuss in a concrete way and we will see how we can support the Greek Government in addressing those issues. At the moment, we have no information, no response from the Greek Government, but I am ready to communicate with you and to see how we can address these issues together.

name: Karin Kadenbach
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Once again, I would like to thank the Commissioner and all the Members who have made it so clear here today that we are dealing with an issue that is really a threat to the health of Europeans, which, in this context, is also a threat to Europe as a business location. I am only sorry that the representative of the Austrian Presidency of the Council did not also hear this part of the debate today. It is not only in the plastics strategy that we stand united as a Parliament, but also on health issues. A Europe that protects must be a Europe that puts the health protection of its citizens at the top of the agenda.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 13 September 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – According to the World Health Organization, antibiotic resistance has reached alarming levels all over the world, and anyone can one day be affected by this phenomenon. If we do not intervene urgently to combat it, there is a risk of going back to a "pre-antibiotic/penicillin" era. Unfortunately, due to antibiotic resistance, lung infections can result in death more frequently, the risks of routine operations increase, and immune suppression treatments, such as chemotherapy, can become too dangerous for patients. Therefore, The Member States and the Commission need to cooperate better with health actors to ensure that antibiotics are prescribed only in serious cases and that pharmacies do not issue antibiotics without a prescription. We cannot also omit the fact that, in intensive animal husbandry, antibiotics are overused, which also causes antibiotic resistance among humans. In this respect, I believe that better cooperation with veterinarians and farmers is needed to address this problem. In conclusion, I would like to congratulate the Commission on the initiative to finance through Horizon 2020 a series of researches for the discovery of new antibiotics, but also on the One Health strategy.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Marlene Mizzi, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the creation of a single digital portal providing access to information, procedures, support and problem solving services and a revision of Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012 (COM(2017)0256 – C8-0141/2017 – 2017/0086(COD)) (A8-0054/2018).

name: Marlene Mizzi
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, free movement in the single market is one of the biggest achievements of the EU. It provides opportunities for millions of EU citizens and businesses: to travel, study, work, shop and live in other Member States. Unfortunately, many still encounter difficulties when moving, working or studying in another Member State because facing 28 different national systems can be very frustrating and daunting both for citizens and for businesses looking to expand to new markets. Therefore, as the rapporteur on this legislation, I needed to understand where the challenges lie in order to address the issues in the interests of our citizens. The paradox we discovered during our work was that the problem was not always a lack of legislation, information or existing procedures. On the contrary, in many cases it was the existence of legislation which complicated matters. It was therefore important to address issues such as lengthy or unclear administrative procedures, complex and confusing information – which is all over the place – and difficulties in getting access to various public services. To make matters worse, when information is available only in a single language, it is not necessarily understood by the majority of the users. So voting in favour of the new rules tomorrow will help Parliament to reach an important milestone in significantly improving the lives of citizens and businesses, and will showcase the tangible benefits that the European Union can bring to its citizens. The new rules will establish a user-friendly, interactive European Single Digital Gateway which, based on people’s needs, will guide them to the most appropriate services and will provide access to all the necessary information and administrative procedures needed to move freely in the European Union. In simple words, we will create a European search engine which will connect all public services in Member States and will assist with information and procedures that currently are often scattered, incomplete and certainly not transparent. The gateway will provide information on matters such as travelling, working and retiring, residing and having access to education and healthcare, family residence, and citizens and consumer rights in the EU. Furthermore, it is not only information that is important, but also the quality of information, and that is why we are introducing quality standards in Member States to ensure high-quality, accurate and up-to-date information, which will also be accessible to end-users with disabilities. The gateway will also provide full, online, fair, non-discriminatory access to a list of 21 key administrative procedures such as requesting birth certificates, applying for study grants, requesting social security benefits, enrolling at universities, requesting diplomas, declaring income tax, and so on and so forth.  Another important milestone achieved with this legislation is the ‘once only’ principle, which for the first time ever will be introduced at European level. This means that citizens will no longer have to submit the same documents over and over again, but instead will submit them only once, and they can then be reused, while fully respecting the protection of personal data. And what is very important is that, whatever information people need, they will be able to obtain it in more than a single language. This effectively means no more wasting precious time and money; no more red tape and complex procedures; no more papers and hours of waiting in long queues in public places. Therefore, I urge all of you to support this regulation – a new important step towards providing a responsive, inclusive, borderless, user-friendly, digital public service to citizens and businesses at national and European level. Last, but not least, I would like to express my gratitude to the shadow rapporteurs, to the Commission and to the Bulgarian Presidency for their open and collaborative work on this report. We worked under extreme pressure and to a strict timetable but, when there is a will, a way will always be found to improve lives and to deliver tangible benefits to our citizens.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Honourable Members, thank you very much for this discussion on a single digital gateway. First, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs  Mizzi, the shadow rapporteurs and the Chair of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee for the really excellent cooperation, which enabled us to improve our initial proposals and reach a quick agreement on this file last May. Let me begin by saying why this proposal on the single digital gateway is so important. As we all know, the single market is a cornerstone of the European Union, but we observe that when crossing borders, many European citizens and companies still experience a jungle of confusing rules, complex procedures and endless paperwork. A survey has shown that more than 80% of businesses see administrative complexity as the number one problem for them in the single market, and this is exactly the problem we want to address with this regulation establishing a single digital gateway.  Let me go through the three points that I think are the most important. First, we want to inform people better – because most people and businesses are really keen to respect the law, but imagine yourself settling in another country, even for a very short time, and think about how difficult it is to find out which rules you have to comply with, let alone in another language. Two in every three small enterprises say that finding out about applicable rules is a huge challenge for them for exporting. As for bigger businesses – this is also very interesting data – bigger businesses dedicate up to 20% of human resources to keeping track of rules applicable to them. Even those twelve million people in Europe who reside in another Member State – if they even find information, they are not certain that they can really rely on it. The regulation will make sure that citizens and small businesses can easily find all the information they need on single market rules and it will be done at both EU and national level via the Your Europe web portal. They will be guided directly to official national websites that provide the precise clarification that they need. The information must be easy to find, easy to understand, up to date and translated into English. Thanks to the gateway quality label, they will know that they can trust this information. But speaking about quality, let me mention one very important thing that you have drawn attention to: the specific needs of persons with disabilities. In this context, I really welcome the introduction of requirements similar to those we have at national level for the Commission websites which will be part of the gateway. Second, the regulation will ensure that in five years, the most important procedures can be handled entirely online in all EU Member States. You are very ambitious on this because this will apply not just to the 13 procedures that we initially proposed but to the more than 20 that were proposed by you. The regulation will also ban any discrimination against cross-border citizens or companies who want to make use of national procedures that are already online. They will no longer be blocked because their phone numbers, postcodes or eID are rejected.  The regulation also makes a start with the implementation of the so-called ‘once only’ principle for cross-border data exchange.
