You rightly insisted that the regulation should ensure full data protection for the European citizens and, again, I want to reassure you that all the necessary data protection safeguards are in place in this regulation. The third point: the Commission and the national authorities have already set up numerous assistance services that citizens and companies can contact when facing problems, but still more than 9 out of 10 consumers and businesses – a huge majority – are unaware of their existence. Thanks to this regulation, anyone looking for assistance will be guided towards the service that is most suited to help.  Let me conclude by saying that users are at the centre of our interest. Users should not be asked to adapt to public authorities, but the other way round. This is what this regulation will ensure. With this regulation, the EU will deliver on some of the commitments from our Digital Single Market communication and from the Tallinn declaration. It will be a big step towards making the single market work better. Thank you very much for your valuable help and I am looking forward to this discussion.

name: Othmar Karas
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Who among us hasnot already been asked the question: What are you actually doing for me? And with the central digital gateway, we are making life easier for every EU citizen. I am pleased about that. Whether I am looking for information on the possibility of working in an EU country, whether I am going to recognise my professional qualifications from another Member State, seeking information on setting up a business or hiring employees, all EU countries are now making this information available to all EU citizens with the central digital gateway. But not only that. We are going further and digitising a number of government procedures that are now available to all EU citizens through the single digital gateway. From applying for a birth certificate, the registration slip, applying for study grants to registering a business activity, registering an employee with the health and pension insurance or in the income and corporate tax return – all administrative procedures for this and much more will be a thing of the past and can be carried out digitally for all citizens. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs in particular, as well as the Bulgarian Presidency, for their excellent cooperation. It was a great pleasure to be able to participate in this project, and I hope that many citizens will benefit from this project in their daily lives and feel that only the common European Union could make it possible to make these facilitations across borders.

name: Nicola Danti
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the creation of a Single European Digital Market has been one of the political priorities of this parliamentary term. In this context, one of the main challenges is to make the benefits of new technologies directly perceptible to citizens by simplifying their daily lives. The digital one-stop shop is a first concrete example. It is, in fact, a significant step towards the digitisation of public administrations and towards the simplification of procedures for citizens and businesses. The fundamental change introduced in the new regulation concerns the obligation for European public administrations to digitise a number of administrative procedures so that they can be completed online. Requesting a birth certificate or recognition of a diploma obtained abroad, or communicating the possession of a vehicle, notifying the opening or closing of a business or the activity they carry out in another country will be easier for citizens and businesses. In addition to promoting the digitisation of many services, this regulation establishes the one-time principle of 'once only' in the Union. The European authorities will thus be able to exchange data and documents already provided by the user, so as to minimise the administrative burden. The S&D Group has fought to ensure that the application of this principle complies fully with the General Data Protection Regulation, with full respect for privacy. The Digital One-Stop Shop Regulation is therefore an important step forward in digitising and simplifying the relationship between public administration and citizens and businesses, increasing transparency and promoting mobility within the European Union.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for It is nice to speak to you and to your Fellow Members in your mother tongue. It is worth stressing that an important part of this report is that the new EU regulation does not change the substance of national rules. Our political group, as conservatives, welcomes the recognition of the principle of subsidiarity and the fact that a common way of sharing information is important and that different national approaches continue to coexist. And that is probably the essence of the European Union, in a nut nut, on this issue.  I regret that it was impossible to include even more support for businesses in order to be able to work digitally with national actors, but I hope that future changes can further reduce the bureaucracy that is harming business. I am pleased that we can act across political divides on this issue – this is important. In today's society, where internet access is becoming more common and digital applications and tools enable more and more online tasks to be carried out, it is actually important that our countries go with the times. I am pleased that my government is doing this. The idea is that people waste less time in office and can work more and make more money. There is a step in the right direction – that is how I would sum up this regulation.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the creation of a single digital portal administered by the Commission would enable users to obtain all the information, help and services they need to operate effectively across borders. Member States should ensure that all administrative services defined by the text are fully available online, without discrimination, in at least one foreign language, and provide links and information to the Commission. This digital one-stop shop seems like a good idea. But who is this text for? In theory, to all. In fact, it is aimed at the proportion of EU nationals wishing to exploit the sacrosanct principle of freedom of movement. The studies are formal and the figures are unfortunately cruel: it appears that the proportion of nationals affected by the application of this regulation does not even exceed 5% of the total population of the European Union. Efforts are honourable to make life easier for these poor people, but it would still be more urgent to take care of the remaining 95%, who are waiting and demanding something else from their politicians. The challenges we face are immense, the stakes are serious and our action does not live up to the expectations of our fellow citizens, who are subjected to these fanciful regulations, more than they benefit from them. Texts of this nature seem perfectly incidental to our constituents and may, by the complexity of their implementation, be increasingly ineffective.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I believe that this portal will become an important element, reinforcing the identification of millions of citizens with our Europe. So, thank you very much, Marlene Mizzi and Othmar Karas, and congratulations for achieving compromise with the Council on this difficult file. It is a very concrete step forward and a very necessary one, because, according to different studies, we already have forty different EU information and problem—solving services, but 91.6% of EU citizens and businesses are unaware of any European—level online services. You say, Madam Commissioner, that 80% of businesses see administrative complexity as the number one problem in the single market, and that their costs go up to EUR 55 billion per year. But even worse than those billions is the frustration and anger when a tourist, an artist – and we love them, we proved this today – a company proprietor or a worker, a student, a patient or a doctor cannot find that necessary information, such as a form to fill out when he or she encounters problems when delivering documents online. This portal will help to solve those problems. I find it especially important today, when some politicians call Europe an imaginary community, the imaginowana wspólnota, which serves only those bureaucrats. You know what I am talking about. Instead, Member States must play an active part, not only in harmonising laws in the European Union, but also in informing citizens and sharing information, for example by building together this digital gateway so that all citizens of Europe can profit fully from the possibilities that our Europe gives them and that the single market offers.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am going to get straight to the point. It was a highly anticipated thing - highly anticipated by citizens, highly expected by businesses, especially small ones. We often discuss in the intergroup for SMEs what problems small firms have, what problems they have in cross-border work. This portal is aimed at improving the functioning of the single market, and this is an objective of the Commission. Digitalisation is another objective of the Commission. The portal solves this problem and we must say that we have long wanted that one-time principle to exist. It would make a lot of savings to the citizen, and to businesses, but of course these savings eventually go to the budgets of the states, they go to the budget of the European Union. We must also say that this administrative work is facilitated through the portal because, as was said in the report and as the rapporteur presented here, there will be an English translation. Of course, the states have a lot and a lot of responsibility, and the Commission also checks, updates the information, is accurate information so as not to confuse, so as not to confuse, because the aim is not that. The goal is to help. There is another problem, and I am glad, Commissioner, that you mentioned it - it must be non-discriminatory, it must also address people with disabilities and it must be non-discriminatory for other citizens as well. There are a lot of petitions and I think each of us is getting these petitions about the fact that a citizen can't handle it when they go to another state. He also said that our colleague, Mr Karas, that in the end our work seems abstract and we need to do something that goes to the citizen. Well, this regulation will surely come and be well received by citizens and, in the end, everyone wins. Interconnecting citizens and companies, businesses with local authorities, central authorities and not only in the state in which they are resident, but also in other states.

name: Ева Майдел (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we live in the internet, we are working to bring Europe to the forefront of digital technologies, we want our citizens to seize the opportunities that the internal market provides.  We have free movement of people, capital, services, goods, and at the same time for years our Union does not have a single information point where businesses and citizens can get information about the huge development potential that 28 Member States and 500 million consumers offer. This is unacceptable, these have been lost profits for years. Ninety-two per cent of consumers and businesses do not know the online services provided at European level and do not know who to turn to in the event of a problem. Europe wins when it delivers concrete results and solutions for its citizens, and that is why it is important that we adopt this regulation.  With the opening of the portal, Europe will save nearly one million hours from the time of its citizens – a time when they can realize their ideas, start a business and make it a reality or share their time with loved ones.  If access to high-quality and easily accessible information is made available online, European businesses could save between €11 billion and €55 billion a year. A single digital portal is not just a database or guide. This is a place that will change the face of our internal market – overcome barriers, give equal access to students, entrepreneurs, workers to the information they need when travelling, when they are studying or traineeship abroad, when they retire, move, register a car in another country. Europe wins when it treats all its citizens equally. That is why the portal will be available in all European languages for every citizen free of charge. I would like to thank the colleagues who worked on the file, as well as the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council, for their instrumental support to make the single digital portal a reality for European citizens.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are taking an essential step towards achieving one of the objectives of the European digital single market. The single digital gateway aims to create a single entry point, precisely at Union level, by integrating existing European and national portals, websites, networks, services and systems. This is crucial to help citizens and businesses take full advantage of the benefits of new digital tools and e-goverment strategies.  Parliament has repeatedly called for citizens and businesses to respond to the needs of citizens and businesses in their cross-border activities in the European internal market, and this proposal, on which I congratulate Mrs Mizzi, means that for the first time Member States will be obliged to make key administrative procedures available online, and that equally important information at national level is available in another official language of the European Union. It is a success that we can claim to be truly European, given the resistance of the Member States, and I only hope that we will ensure that the possible exceptions granted to the Member States do not then become a pretext for not complying with the obligations imposed.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Mr President! I very much welcome the agreement on a single digital portal, the 'digital single gateway'. It is important that we create the best possible conditions for our citizens, and not least for our small and medium-sized enterprises, which are so crucial to growth in Europe. Administrative facilitation plays a really big role here, and the single digital portal is a very good step. However, there are two things I would like to point out here today that are absolutely crucial to the success of the project. Firstly, Member States must and must play a part in the practical implementation of the portal, we know that implementation is incredibly important. It is with the portal, as it is with the EU in general, that it can only see as much as the Member States want to support. Member States must ensure digital solutions and provide access to their national procedures and arrangements, otherwise the portal cannot be the success it should. Secondly, I really hope that the Commission will ensure that the practical implementation of the portal is strongly anchored in DG GROW. DG GROW already operates successful portals for citizens and small businesses. It is important that we draw on the years of positive experiences with successful EU tools, such as "Your Europe" when the new portal is now established.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Internet and digital technologies are transforming the way people and businesses live, work, study, work and travel. Benefits for all Europeans can be achieved through open, efficient, inclusive and e-government-oriented public administration that provides borderless, personalised and easy-to-use end public digital services. The regulation we are debating aims to simplify contact between citizens and businesses, with problem-solving assistance services through the establishment of a digital one-stop shop to access information on the rules and requirements to be met under EU or national law. However, the European Commission and the Member States must work together in synergy to facilitate the effective and gradual implementation of the project and to facilitate the implementation of fully online procedures, which are also fully accessible to cross-border users in the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Mizzi, for her report and I think that the debate highlights the european Parliament's efforts to serve citizens; to be at the service of civil society; to be able to contribute to information and information because that is the key element. Through this single platform it is certain that citizens and businesses will have the right information, whether it is scholarships for our young people, whether it is looking for work in other regions, or taxation in force in certain states, because this is a key criterion for various companies to enhance their extroversion. But degree recognition will also be able to be served through this access to the single platform that I think we all support with our interventions.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Honourable Members, I want to thank you very much for your interventions, for your positive remarks and, of course, especially and primarily for your work on this proposal. With this proposal, we have a real opportunity to make the single market work a little bit better, both for our citizens and for our companies. Both of those groups should be able to enjoy the opportunities that the single market offers them.  Also thanks to this new instrument, small businesses – let me underline this – will save costs, more easily innovate and more easily expand across Europe. Let me also mention one important thing: with your help we can bring to reality another important promise of the digital single market strategy – that we want to ensure that public administrations modernise and respond better to the needs of the users. I, therefore, hope that you will endorse the regulation tomorrow. I hope and expect that in two years we will be able to launch the gateway with the proud name of ‘Your Europe’. Thank you very much for your help and for your work.

name: Marlene Mizzi
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for their contributions to this debate, and particularly my shadows. Thanks is due also to my political advisers, my assistants, the Commission and the Bulgarian Presidency. I am proud of the cooperation between all European institutions to make this important legislation a reality, but in truth I am proud mostly of the results we have achieved where in many instances we have achieved far more than we thought we would. Our ambitious stand really paid off. In the troubled and challenging times in which we live, with so many different crises facing the European Union on different fronts, I believe that it is our duty to communicate to our citizens the positive elements that the EU brings us. As we have seen in today’s debate, the regulation is a perfect example of how the EU can work and how it can change our lives for the better. The Single Digital Gateway will tangibly help citizens and businesses. It will pool together national and European information procedures and problem-solving services into a single entry point of the Your Europe portal, through which citizens can easily find and access what they need. The gateway will be user—friendly and multi-lingual, and will help start-ups and SMEs looking to start operating in other Member States. Such a service is of paramount importance when starting a business, accessing finances, taxation rules, accessing pensions rights and social benefits, as well as other information which citizens may require for their cross-border activities.  So it is on days like this that we should be particularly satisfied with our work as MEPs, seeing how our work will positively and tangibly impact European citizens: something that we really need to communicate. So thank you everyone, and I look forward to tomorrow’s vote.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 13 September 2018.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by István Ujhelyi, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, entitled 'Europe on the Move – An Action Programme on the Future of Mobility in the EU' (2017/2257(INI)) (A8-0241/2018).

name: István Ujhelyi
text: Artist. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear colleagues, I am very proud to have been and can be rapporteur for this report in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, and that I can now account for the work that we have done in plenary and before tomorrow's vote.  "Europe on the move, the future of EU mobility", is the title of the report. Have you ever thought about what European transport will look like in 10 years' time? At a time when children who go to school with their parents today will be 20 or 22 years old and travelling independently? How are they going to move from one village to another, from the village to the city, out of a city, home, from one big city to another, or between Budapest and Strasbourg?  A lot will change around us, but if we are not prepared for this, we in the European Union institutions will surely not be able to keep up with technology, the revolution that is taking place before our eyes in everyday life. That is why it is crucial that we talk more and more about this issue. The mobility sector and transport play a key role in the EU economy, not only for our society but also for the economy, which accounts for around 4% of EU GDP and more than 5% of EU employment. With the development of automated vehicles, digitalisation and the need to create cleaner transport, the sector is undergoing profound changes that will have an impact on our society in all respects. It is estimated that passenger transport will increase by around 42% between 2010 and 2050 and a 60% increase in freight transport over the same period.  In the report, I sought to answer the question of what changes the transport sector is undergoing, how our relationship to mobility is changing and what mobility means in the 21st century. Parallel processes are taking place. Sustainability, environmental protection, the creation of safe transport, the transformation of the energy sector and continuous infrastructure development have been brought to the fore.  The labour market is also changing and changing structurally and other competences will be needed. And this process will take place in 5-10 years. Our primary task is to formulate a comprehensive mobility strategy that includes the effects of digitalisation, environmental issues and, of course, to respond to the needs of the population. Mobility becomes a complex service, digital interconnection with each other creates new collaborations and forms of business. Think of sharing-based models.  Approximately EUR 740 billion is needed to build the entire trans-European transport network by 2030. In addition to EU funds, we need market participants and, of course, the Member States. Digitalisation is one of the most important factors, affecting all areas of the transport sector, will have an impact on users of mobility services, on service providers, and will also have an impact on European industry and workers.  It is our legislative responsibility to ensure that profound changes do not create tension in society and that the Competitiveness of the European Union is maintained. The transformation will be rapid and significant. We must also focus on research and development, and it is essential that the European Union maintains its technological leadership in an otherwise highly competitive world market.  The community and sharing economy is transforming the transport industry worldwide. As the value of transactions in the collaborative economy within the European transport industry was estimated at EUR 5.1 billion in 2015, an increase of 77% on the previous year, economic results based on non-cash sharing far outweilar this scenario. This also highlights the importance of the report. I don't know how many minutes I have, I've been told it works, but if my time is shorter than that, I can finish it quickly, because the people in this room... (The Member thanks the President in English for his reply.) I would like to thank the colleagues who have helped me with the work of the various factions. We discussed this within the TRAN committee, so I don't need to go into the details right now. I believe that the proposal will enjoy great support in tomorrow's vote, and I would like to thank in particular my own office and, in particular, my expert colleague Attila Benedek, who has worked hard to make this a joint, large European Parliament project, together with the Commission and the Member States.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the transport sector is changing fast. If we act now, we can seize the opportunity of this change and make European mobility sustainable, safe, smart and more accessible; European industry more competitive; and European jobs more secure. If we act now, we can lead in setting new global standards. These concepts are well reflected in the draft resolution prepared by Mr Ujhelyi, which supports more action – including at EU level – in this field. Allow me to specifically address three important topics raised in the report.   First, sustainability, transport is a major contributor to EU greenhouse gas emissions, as well as air pollution. We are committed to reducing and ultimately eliminating the negative externalities of our mobility. We can achieve this goal through stricter emissions standards, better consumer information, multimodality, smarter road charging, urban mobility planning, research and innovation, and by smarter use of public procurement to accelerate the transition towards zero— and low-emission vehicles. I would like to thank you for your support for this objective. We have several pending legislative proposals aimed at contributing to achieving exactly this. I therefore count on your active support to examine them as much as possible before the end of your mandate.  That brings me to the second point: Vision Zero. Until recently, Vision Zero – no road fatalities on European roads by 2050 – might have been perceived by some as an ambitious but distant vision. Today we can be much more confident. The fresh approach we are taking in road safety, with the so—called Safe System approach, and our move towards a connected and autonomous mobility are making Vision Zero a reality. With the third Mobility Package, we are proposing a strategy to make the EU an engaging global leader in autonomous mobility systems. We propose a clear, forward—looking and ambitious European agenda that provides a common vision, identifies clear supporting actions for developing and deploying key technology services and infrastructure, and that provides a clear action plan. Our strategy is based on three pillars. First, a legal framework that creates a single market for autonomous mobility, covering road safety, cybersecurity, access to data and data protection. Second, financial support to establish a new partnership with a consolidated sector—wide approach towards research and deployment throughout the EU, including for the coordination of pilot projects. Third, an in-depth assessment of the socioeconomic and ethical aspects of autonomous mobility, making deployment suitable to absorption capacity as well as the maturity of autonomous relations. We also propose to make a number of new vehicle safety technologies mandatory as part of the revision of the general safety regulation, for example, intelligence speed assistance, autonomous emergency braking and detection of pedestrians and cyclists. This will make sure that all road users will be able to benefit from the latest developments in technologies.  That brings me to the third topic: one platform for connected and autonomous mobility. Citizens’ mobility demands are growing, and their attitude to mobility is indeed changing. They want to shift seamlessly between different transport modes and enjoy easy access to travel information. Meanwhile, vehicles are becoming increasingly clean, connected and automated, and ultimately driverless and zero—emissions. This opens the possibility for vehicles to become an integral part of multimodal mobility, providing first and last—mile service and inclusive solutions for the elderly, disabled, and young people. Before we get there, we are engaging with stakeholders to address some very important enabling topics such as security, data protection, fair and equal access to data, liability and ethical implications, integration of automated vehicles into existing traffic, public acceptance, global standard settings, and many more.  This is why we proposed to bundle all efforts and create a single platform, the Connected and Automated Mobility (CAM), where all stakeholders come together to push our ambitious agenda further. Under the next MFF, this platform should evolve towards a fully—fledged partnership for connected and autonomous mobility, combining public and private efforts to escalate the development and deployment of innovative mobility solutions.

name: Damiano Zoffoli
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is a movement, Europe is moving towards a new model of development: a low-carbon economy. There's a long way to go. The transport sector is currently 94 % dependent on oil and is responsible for more than 25 % of greenhouse gas emissions. In addition, passenger and freight activities in Europe will increase by 60 % and 40 % respectively in 2050. The central point of the communication, which I agree with, is compliance with the Paris Agreement on Climate Change and the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. But how can these ambitious objectives be achieved? This is the answer: by promoting low- or zero-emission mobility, intermodality, shared mobility, the development of automated vehicles through interconnections of transport infrastructure networks, digital energy networks, digital technologies that will make it possible to implement the fundamental principle of 'polluter pays', for example with a electronic clearing system based on the environmental performance of vehicles.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Bulc, Mr rapporteur, thank you for your open attitude to dialogue. This has made it possible for us to recognize ourselves with our suggestions and concerns in this report. Thus, a balanced and reasonable text has been possible in our view. I think the treaty is very interesting and affects us all, but it is almost futureology. But it is not wrong to make forecasts of what is to come, apart from the concretions of the mobility package, which was an obligation we had in this own-initiative report. The digital mobility revolution and new smart technologies are a phenomenon, which is to produce an unstoppable and irreversible situation; affect the modernity, forms and modes of transport of the future, in which, according to the modern thesis of comodality, they have to act in symbiosis, so we will have to be very attentive to them.  Our main concerns are the safety, legality of these modes of transport, legal responsibility and training of workers in the sector, among other points. It is important to create bridges so that the coexistence between the old and the new modes of transport develops easily and in a progressive way in order to anticipate the advances to which the sector will be subjected. The sharing economy, ladies and gentlemen, which is a great label where so many things fit, that it has come to stay, cannot, in my opinion, be a jungle. It cannot be left to come from what happens, but it is necessary to rule it, it is necessary that the system has rules of the game in which innovation is not prevented, but that the acquired rights are respected.  These are the two keys on which we must base the future of European mobility, because it seems to me that it is the field of equity, of justice in the specific case.  We must try to make the sharing economy not one more label, Commissioner. Political decisions are not being taken, regulations are not prior, start-ups are subject to successive judgments in the various Member States incoherently. This is not the way, it seems to me that it is not the area on which it is up to us to work as politicians, but it is an inexcusable obligation to tackle them. I sincerely hope that this report will serve as a precedent for the future of European mobility to be another, to be positive for the whole of Europe. That's my judgment and desire.

name: Brando Benifei
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the future of mobility must be based on a number of key non-negotiable principles: accessibility for all citizens, transition to a sustainable system, scientific research in the sector of the highest quality, and, in my opinion, as a matter of priority, the highest safety standards for transport and infrastructure. I believe that absurd tragedies such as the collapse of the Morandi motorway bridge in my region, Liguria, really oblige us to think seriously. It is necessary to ensure that adequate resources, both European and national, are put in place for cutting-edge projects, that they are a key part of a strategy on mobility in step with technological development and the challenges of globalisation and climate change. It is also necessary that the impact of the transition in transport is really accompanied by an investment in the skills of workers in the sector. This transformation of the sector and of the production and consumption of mobility must be an opportunity, not a threat or a detriment. I think it's very much up to us.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for It is difficult to consider the motion for this resolution in isolation from the legislative proposals of the European Commission, which the Committee on Transport and this Parliament have been dealing with over the last few months. The ECR Group fully supports many of the demands of this report, including the need to digitise the transport sector and the need to increase investment in modern and secure infrastructure. These are obvious issues.  However, we have doubts as to whether some of the proposed solutions will not adversely affect the position of consumers and the operating conditions of small and medium-sized enterprises. Nor can we make investment in modern modes of transport dependent solely on climate objectives. We also disagree with the use of the extremely controversial concept of 'social dumping'. There is no such thing as social dumping, there is no definition of social dumping, but it is a concept that has been "fluttering" after this House for several years. In tomorrow's vote, therefore, we will abstain and not burn your proposal.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, First of all, I would like to thank the Commission and the rapporteur for their work on the future of mobility. Europe is on the move but faces very big challenges. And one of those challenges is road safety. How are we going to make Europe's roads safer for all road users? Every year, 25 000 people die on European roads as a way of passing through road accidents. I repeat: twenty-five thousand! Road safety in Europe must and must be improved! The mobility of people and goods continues to increase, which is good for our economy and the prosperity of Europeans, but that also leads to fuller roads and traffic congestion. Personally, I am even more concerned that all this is at the expense of the environment and the climate. Our mobility can only be future-proof if it is also sustainable. The challenge we face cannot be solved by individual Member States on their own. We need a common European approach, one that focuses on innovation with smart forms of mobility. The development of self-driving vehicles, for example. And this can contribute to fewer traffic accidents, better traffic flow and low CO2 emissions. But intelligent transport systems also help us move more sustainably, safely and efficiently.  I therefore very much welcome European initiatives, including the European ITS Congress. This congress will be held in 2019 in the Netherlands in my own region of Brabant, in the cities of Eindhoven and Helmond. I would literally like to say: be my guest! Because we shape the future of mobility together.

name: Jakop Dalunde
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Transport currently accounts for a quarter of Europe's greenhouse gas emissions, and now it is time for us to digitise the transport sector, so that we can both reduce emissions and ensure that we put in place the polluter-pays principle. For example, we need to introduce electronic tolls based on the climate impact of vehicles. We also welcome the development of new innovations for smart mobility, but more needs to be done, and that is why we call on the Commission and the Member States to promote more ambitious plans to make smart mobility sustainable, both in our cities and in rural areas. At the same time, Europe must become safer. We will protect the most vulnerable in traffic and ensure that we have better connectivity between vehicles, infrastructure and the network itself to ensure an unhindered and safe flow of traffic.  Finally, I would like to underline the role of innovation in a clean and sustainable future. We need to ensure that raw materials and battery cells are manufactured and recycled in a way that is sustainable, transparent and fair. An ambitious green transport policy is needed to reduce emissions quickly and efficiently. We need to do this now because the climate cannot wait.

name: Tania González Peñas
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, transport accounts for one third of Europe's final energy consumption, according to the European Environment Agency. So talking about an agenda for the future of mobility in Europe is, or should be, without a doubt, talking about sustainable and intelligent mobility, less polluting, safer, more accessible and also more affordable. Boosting sustainable mobility is spent on road transport to reduce CO2 emissions, a clear commitment to electric vehicles, clean batteries and the use of renewable energy, where efforts are beginning to be made. And yet, let us not deceive ourselves, it clearly goes through a commitment to public transport, to reduce the use of individual road transport, where demand continues to increase. Making a real effort to boost public transport — unfortunately, we have seen how the fourth rail package, which is liberalisation and somehow an attack on the train, which is the most sustainable and safest means of transport we have , has been approved in this parliamentary term , because I think it should be something that we must review and which should be a priority. To talk about sustainable mobility is also to take into account the social impact of transport at different territorial levels, the need to vertebrate rural territory, to engineer new forms of collective transport. And we are not talking about the false sharing economy, we are talking about forms of public transport, so that transport serves to nurture the territorial area and not to depopulate it. And, of course, urban areas are the places where CO2 emissions are most concentrated and it is necessary and urgent to bet on greener, more sustainable, more humane mobility, boosting the bicycle, driving the pedestrian in the center of cities and projecting cities in a way that encourages the use of public transport to connect with other territories. It is certainly something that should not only be for the year 2050, but is urgent and must be already.

name: Daniela Aiuto
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the issue of the future of mobility in Europe is closely linked to our vision of cities, urban centres, and how we intend to link them together, but also how we imagine the future of logistics in Europe, the exchange of internal goods and the supply of external ones. More and more European citizens are living in urban areas, which are increasingly congested and which have often been designed at distant times, without, of course, taking into account modern mobility needs. These needs have changed profoundly today and will change still further. We must, however, be courageous and allow the citizens of Europe to take back their cities, to make them more livable, more fluid and more easily accessible. This means making important choices in favour of public transport, its implementation, but also choices to improve the quality of air that is breathed in urban areas, through the facilitation of sustainable mobility, zero polluting emissions, and implementing the use of the collective means to the detriment of the private one. Only in this way will we be able to put in place initiatives worthy of redesigning a liveable future for European citizens.  With regard to the mobility of goods, we in the Committee on Transport have drawn up a text for which I was rapporteur, and which I hope will soon be negotiated with the Council, for example to relaunch combined freight transport, that is to say to transfer as many goods as possible from road to iron. But the future of mobility also means greater security in infrastructure, with a sharp increase in economic resources to monitor the state of European networks, especially in structurally sensitive points such as viaducts, tunnels and sections particularly at risk. We need to have more financial resources, perhaps having to be accompanied by budgetary constraints, especially for states such as Italy, for example, with geographical characteristics that require bold infrastructures such as bridges and tunnels, to carry out frequent maintenance on existing infrastructures, to implement, for example, their resilience to seismic events, or in any case to prolong the life of operation and ensure that citizens can take advantage of them in complete safety. The future of mobility in Europe, ladies and gentlemen, also passes through Genoa, from a city affected by a disaster that has become a symbol to which we must all look in order to understand how important it is to have safe and quality infrastructures, with priority thinking of existing ones, before we even sing large works that mobilise millions of euros.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mrs Bulc, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mrs Bulc, for the work she has all been very much on her part. Do you want future mobility to be safe, sustainable and just? Then we must also make them innovative, digital and competitive. How can we achieve this: through smart drivers, vehicles and infrastructure?  One step towards increasing road safety is the mandatory installation of safety-relevant driver assistance systems. They can compensate for human misconduct, which is responsible for about 92 percent of accidents. A further step is the creation of an infrastructure that includes charging stations for sustainable fuels throughout the country. In addition, this infrastructure must enable communication with the vehicles, especially in a transition phase on the way to the next stage of automation.  In all regulations, we should adopt a technology-neutral approach that covers the entire footprint of the vehicles. Every mode of transport must work on its efficiency, because there is no technology that can solve all the problems. And future mobility must allow smooth door-to-door transport, even across borders. To this end, EU citizens should be able to book travel by train, bus and plane on multimodal platforms and, at best, travel with a single ticket.  Neither the cleanest and low-emission vehicles nor diesel driving bans can solve the main problem in cities – congestion. For this, we need, among other things, an attractive and reliable public transport system, which also allows a safe and pleasant arrival for the last part of a trip. All this will take us many times further than simple diesel driving bans.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this dossier takes into account the major changes that are taking place and those that will take place in the next few years in the transport sector.  We are at an epochal turning point, digitalization and connected vehicles will forever change the habits of citizens and also the way of doing business. In considering this, however, we must remember that the real revolution will only be such if all areas are taken into account , and I am referring to rural, mountainous, all remote and ultra-remote areas, the inclusion of which is essential for their accessibility and also for promoting tourism. Furthermore, we cannot talk about transport of the future unless they guarantee the zero casualty target by 2030. Last but not least, they should contribute to the reduction of air pollution and therefore of CO2 emissions.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Mr President, clean, competitive and connected mobility, that is what we are doing. Mobility causes a quarter of all emissions in the European Union and remains the main cause of air pollution problems in our cities. Particulate matter, NOx – the health of our citizens is suffering and it is primarily for them that we need to work towards cleaner mobility.  In addition, we will have to offer more ambition to achieve our climate targets. To do this, policy makers need to frame and facilitate modal shift, new technologies and principles such as mobility as a service. Finally, can I also stress that we still need a strong European competitive automotive sector? When I hear that the market share of our European sector has fallen sharply over the last ten years, I am concerned. Car manufacturers can only secure their position if they are encouraged to innovate. The car was invented in Europe! Let us ensure that we continue to play a pioneering role in the future.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to support the meaning of this mobility report and call for the integration of local authorities from the outset into the necessary process of public-private collaboration, which must drive innovation and maintain European technological leadership in the global transport market and in particular the integration of its different modes.  Cities are the means in which the most complex mobility problems need to be solved. The positive impact that better mobility will have on them, with more humane and sustainable development, is already one of the key factors in good governance and sustainable development.  In launching strategic actions to address major challenges, cities are key to welcoming and driving practical experiences based on research and development. They are effective levers of change in people's habits; enable you to quickly rehearse, evaluate and share results. Therefore, experiences such as those to be launched in the capital of the Basque Country, which will turn the city of Vitoria-Gasteiz into a mobility laboratory, are the way forward. A path I hope will find support and encouragement in the European Union.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The field of transport and all related industries are now undergoing a key phase of development. New trends, autonomous vehicles, drones, intelligent transport systems are emerging before our eyes. We are also witnessing a rapidly growing space sector. All the trends I have mentioned must be reflected in the relevant legal framework that we have prepared, because we can wake up to a reality that we simply will not understand or will not be prepared for.  It is particularly important to adapt education, education and an adequate skills system to the needs of a changing market. This will ensure that employees are able to find themselves in a new situation and there will be no excessive competence gap. I think this is very important and that is what we need to pay particular attention to.  It is also very important to ensure safety, especially when new technologies enable the production of driverless vehicles. Europe absolutely needs a Zero Victims on the Road programme and safe transport. We must not forget that in twenty years' time both air and road traffic will double. We must also not forget about sustainable transport, which will allow for better standards and lower CO2 emissions. I hope that, with today's proposal, we will be able to achieve or move closer to the objectives, which is why this proposal deserves support, and the rapporteur congratulates him.

name: Петър Курумбашев (S&D).
text: – Mr President, let me congratulate the rapporteur on his efforts in this crucial area and on his timely report. It is very important to talk about innovation, autonomous means of transport and reducing carbon dioxide emissions, ending illegal recruitment practices and ensuring appropriate working conditions.  On the other hand, I would like to pay special attention, especially to Commissioner Bulc, that it is not possible to introduce controversial practices with both mobility packages. In Mobility Package 1, we prohibit the liberalisation of lorry transport, and in mobility package 2 we continue with bus liberalisation. In mobility package 1 we want to ban cabotage because we think it is bad for trucks, and in mobility package 2 we think we need to solve cabotage over 100 kilometers. In Mobility Package 1, we want to apply the Posted Workers Directive to lorry transport, and in mobility package 2 we want to not apply this directive. I get the impression of a very diverse and diverse approach by the Commission, with which it hardly wants to be remembered.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. Chairman, the transformation of the mobility sector driven by the digitisation of the economy clearly requires an adjustment of the Union's legislative framework and policy in this area. The new expertise and working methods implied by this transformation require Member States to adapt their education systems to future, new labour market requirements, in particular in the automotive industry.  The innovation and research sector needs to be fully supported in both financial and regulatory terms, and special support in this sector must be enjoyed by SMEs, which are engines of economic development in all healthy market economies. Thank you very much.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for this comprehensive report, which describes the challenges facing transport for the future. Personally, perhaps I would now focus on three major issues, the most important and urgent of which is, of course, the reduction of transport emissions. That is where we are facing really big challenges, because we know that emissions in transport have only increased. The forecast is that transport will increase considerably, so we now need really significant major cuts in transport emissions. In this context, we have legislation on this very reading, which also seeks to steer car manufacturers in the direction of producing lower-emission cars. Here it is important to take into account a wide range of technologies. The fastest way, as we know, is to add renewable fuel to car tanks, because the car fleet is regenerating extremely slowly. At the same time, however, it is clear that the electrification of transport and other alternative fuels must also be promoted. Another big trend is digitalisation and its promotion. On the other hand, digitalisation will also help us to reduce emissions by being able to design the entire transport system more efficiently. Thirdly, I would like to highlight the European Union's investment in both innovation and infrastructure. We are in the process of dealing with the budgetary framework for the coming period and it is important that we invest enough money in transport infrastructure, transport digitalisation, alternative energy and innovation and research, because we also need more information in order to remain at the forefront of the world in the field of clean transport in Europe.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the development of automated vehicles, digitalisation and the need to make transport less polluting, the mobility sector is changing radically. Transport safety remains the fundamental objective, and since human error is the main cause of accidents, automated transport will be able to make a significant contribution to the objective of zero deaths on Europe's roads. However, I believe that the transitional period will not be easy, since it will involve not only the integration of automated transport into the current context, including the creation of connectivity and the necessary infrastructure, but also the achievement of safe coexistence with traditional means of transport. The transport sector is currently the main cause of air pollution in urban areas and is responsible for more than 25 % of greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union. The transformation of the transport sector must therefore be increasingly oriented towards the development of solutions capable of ensuring environmental sustainability standards.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am glad that we are also addressing this problem, as it is estimated that passenger traffic will increase by around 40% by 60% in passenger and freight over the next 40 years. High number of accident victims on European roads: e.g. 25,000 people killed per year. It is important to talk about emissions resulting from transport, urban air pollution, which is the source of more than 25% of greenhouse gas emissions. I am not listing any more impacts, I would also mention the positives. Transport accounts for 4% of GDP and more than 5% of total employment in the EU.  We should follow the principle that who is the user and polluter pays. We should promote sustainable urban and rural mobility plans. We should support the introduction of a multimodal transport system for passengers, improving mobility and quality of service for citizens. It is also important to raise citizens' awareness of the environmental impacts of each mode of transport. The development of low-carbon transport services should be our priority. We should also provide sufficient information for citizens to find an alternative to road transport, especially the autonomous one. One of the other measures is also, for example, bike sharing in cities and municipalities.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that none of us can deny it - transport influences everything. It influences the economy, yields, productivity, influences the environment, obviously influences people's lives anywhere, in any country. Still in the European Union, unfortunately, we find citizens upset, companies upset, we have traffic jams, we have congestion in the urban environment. This report is very well welcome and has, of course, departed from the Commission communication 'Europe on the Move'. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all the colleagues who will support this report. I hope it will be voted on tomorrow, because, yes, in the field of transport we have to have a vision. We cannot change the infrastructure, be it by road, rail or any other means of transport, as we change furniture. That is why, Commissioner, you have a very complicated problem. Let us finally complete the mobility package and see how we make a long-term agenda and vision, because we need to adapt. We have a digitalised Europe and we also need to adapt transport to these new technologies and catch up with modern, computer-aided cars. We have to go from road transport to rail transport. There are a lot of things, you know them very well. The important thing is to integrate them and solve them.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the debate is indeed particularly interesting about how we can have sustainable transport, how there will be no pollution in the environment, how we will have automatic mobility systems. This is all very, very interesting. I am thinking of the inhabitants of the Aegean islands, Mrs Bulc, who, especially in winter, cannot move from one island to another or come from the Aegean islands to Athens. The big problem is today. These people want there to be a metaphorical equivalent, they want to be able to move. According to the regulations, the transport equivalent cannot be financed by the European Union itself and is made with state funds which are not sufficient. I think you should look at this issue, how there will be financial support for the transport equivalent so that businesses and citizens of the Aegean islands who have really been isolated can also be relieved.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this open and interesting debate. I have taken note of your comments. I also want to use this opportunity to thank Mr Ujhelyi one more time for the report. It highlights accurately that to achieve the best possible mobility in the future we need a holistic approach. Before I share my final thoughts with you, let me elaborate on two issues. First, on the impact on jobs: in order to support workers in the transport industry in adjusting to digitalisation and the transition to low-emission mobility, the Commission, in partnership with Member States and stakeholders such as employers, workers’ representatives and education and training providers, is addressing skill gaps and mismatches. Key initiatives include the EU Skills Agenda and the ‘Blueprint for sectorial cooperation on skills’ and we are really looking forward to the results of these measures. Secondly, on financing: as you know, the Commission has proposed an ambitious budget envelope for research and development for the next Multiannual Financial Framework period 2021-2027. New mobility solutions should be among the main beneficiaries of the Horizon Europe programme, with almost EUR 15 billion for mobility and energy activities. This will allow us to accelerate technological innovation. Of course, our Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) will also continue to support the deployment of new, modern infrastructure equipped with intelligent transport systems, and for the use of alternative sources of energy. We have proposed a budget of EUR 30.6 billion for CEF between 2021 and 2027, which, for the first time, will also include investment in road safety. I hope that, as we have proposed, this will be among the main criteria for project prioritisation. Technology is evolving faster and faster, and promises to find solutions. I do not doubt that there is always a technical solution to a problem, but I would like to stress one more time that technology is the means and not the final objective. I believe we should always put the users first – right next to the collective social benefits. Connected and autonomous mobility will flourish only if it is socially acceptable. Let’s not forget that our societies can only absorb a certain amount of new things. This is why it is so important that our strategy on connected and autonomous mobility covers not only technological and legal but also social and ethical questions. When we implement the necessary flanking measures to prepare for changes in jobs requirements and skills, and when we give meaningful answers to difficult ethical questions, then we can fully reap the benefits of the mobility of the future. Triple ‘Vision Zero’, no road fatalities, no pollution and no congestion: this is the commitment that can be achieved with such a holistic approach. But until then, we have a lot of work ahead and I am sure we will have many more discussions on this topic. I hope they will be as invigorating as today’s debate, and I count on your continued support. Together I am sure we can make a real and urgently needed difference.

name: István Ujhelyi
text: Artist. "Mr. President, I would like to thank you for your support Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to I thank you for the debate and let me take this opportunity to thank the Commissioner and the colleagues who wrote the original communication in the Commission, the original proposal, and those who also thanked them for the work. They did a good job not only until everything was ready for the Commission's communication, but also afterwards, because my colleagues were in very active contact, and I think there was exemplary cooperation between the Commission and Parliament's staff. And let me also thank the reporting colleagues, they have helped me a lot from the various factions. I will highlight three things now, at the end of the debate. One, perhaps most importantly, could affect any of us: there are 25 000 or more fatalities on Europe's transport roads every year. Our fundamental task and goal is to minimise this. It's part of our job together.  Secondly, the fact that we have entered the digital age, the world of digital development, also follows that we must ensure that every Single European citizen has the same transport access and the same transport option, born in the eastern, western, northern or southern parts of Europe, and in a big city or a small settlement. That's very important, too.  Thirdly, that workers in the transport sector, including those in our transport industry, i.e. our factories, must also receive very serious attention from us at European and nation-state level, as we are seeing very rapid technical progress in China and everywhere else. I'm pretty sure we're going to have to compete with them.  Let me say this last sentence: as a Hungarian, I considered this proposal particularly important, since this industry accounts for nearly 170 000 people in Hungary and 10% of GDP, a quarter of its exports. There's still work to be done. Thank you very much for the opportunity and thank you for working together!

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 13 September 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Decarbonisation of transport and the use of new technologies provide opportunities for the future of mobility. The Europe on the Move initiative enables European industries to become world leaders in innovation, digitisation and decarbonisation. We hope that this initiative will help the strategy to renew industrial policy in the European Union. Clean mobility is essential for our future, but it is also important to come to the aid of the companies that provide this mobility. I believe that the transition to fundamental modernisation of mobility in the European Union will have several challenges, but it must be socially correct, transport companies must not be burdened by administrative obligations and peripheral States should not be punished on the grounds of cross-border operations. I support the idea of drawing a clear direction, which supports investment in transport, but which also takes into account the possibilities of each Member State, and I hope that, in the future, we can also focus on issues such as shell companies exploiting both legislative loopholes and their own employees.
